HEADLINE: Vatican Says Gore Is Misrepresenting Population Talks

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Six days before the United Nations population conference in Cairo, the Vatican made an unusual, personal attack today on Vice President Al Gore, accusing him of misrepresenting the gathering's intentions on abortion.
The accusations were a setback for the Clinton Administration's effort to lower the level of discord with the Vatican over the conference. They also signaled the Vatican's continued readiness to confront the United States over central moral issues. 
 Since preparations for the conference began in April, Pope John Paul II and his aides have taken the lead in condemning it as likely to legitimize abortion as a means of birth control, in direct contradiction of Roman Catholic doctrine on the sanctity of life from the moment of conception.
Today's broadside by Joaquin Navarro-Valls, the Pope's chief spokesman, was the first time that the Vatican had formally accused the United States of being the principal sponsor of pro-abortion policies and also the first time it had publicly attacked a high American official by name.
"Mr. Al Gore, Vice President of the U.S.A. and member of the American delegation, recently stated that 'the United States has not sought, does not seek and will not seek to establish an international right to abortion,' " Mr. Navarro-Valls said at a news conference today. "The draft population document, which has the United States as its principal sponsor, contradicts, in reality, Mr. Gore's statement."
Mr. Gore made the remark quoted by the Vatican at the National Press Club in Washington this week. When asked for a response, Lorraine Voles, the spokeswoman for Mr. Gore, said tonight, "As we deal with the Vatican on a host of issues, there is much more on which we agree than we disagree."
But she added, "In this particular area, there are some differences."
To substantiate his assertion, Mr. Navarro-Valls quoted from passages in the conference document referring, for instance, to "the right to have access to methods of fertility regulation which are safe, efficacious, accessible and acceptable." He said the World Health Organization had defined "fertility regulation" as including abortion.
 
Vatican Guidelines
 A Vatican working document containing guidelines for the Vatican's delegation at the conference also alludes to other excerpts from the document saying "pregnancy termination" should be included in the "reproductive health care" services available to women.
The document itself, in a chapter covering "reproductive rights and reproductive health," speaks of "the right of men and women to be informed and to have access to safe, effective, affordable and acceptable methods of fertility regulation of their choice" -- a notion that the Vatican says is tantamount to abortion on demand. The phrase "reproductive rights" is often used in the United States as a synonym for abortion rights.
At his news conference, Mr. Navarro-Valls repeatedly singled out the Clinton Administration as the sponsor of much of the document's most contentious language, as if seeking to polarize the debate between "this administration," as he called the American Government, and people of different views in the United States and elsewhere.
By stressing the unusual usage -- "this administration" -- Mr. Navarro-Valls seemed to be suggesting that the Clinton Administration was not representative of mainstream governmental American thought and that its policies might therefore turn out to be transitory and lacking in credibility. Certainly, the Vatican was far more comfortable with the anti-abortion policies of the Reagan Administration than with Mr. Clinton's insistence that abortion be safe, legal and rare.
While the spokesman for Mr. Gore argued today that his comments represented American policy, the Vatican is seeking to suggest that the Clinton Administration is saying one thing publicly while advancing different views in the conference document.
 
A Wider Audience
 By attacking Vice President Gore and seeking to highlight inconsistencies in the American position, Mr. Navarro-Valls also seemed to be reaching to a wider audience in the Islamic world and the third world, seeking to win allies for the Vatican's cause by damaging the United States' credibility among those long used to questioning American intentions.
He said the Vatican would seek consensus at the conference, but would not shy from a straight vote among delegations, arguing that a ballot showing dissent from any final declaration would strip the conference's conclusions of "moral authority."
The Vatican has also raised objections to parts of the document on unsafe abortion that state "all governments, intergovernmental organizations and relevant nongovernmental organizations are urged to deal openly and forthrightly with unsafe abortion as a major health concern."
The internal Vatican working document argues: "It is often said that the Cairo conference speaks of abortion only to express concern for the many women who die as a result of 'unsafe abortion,' whether legal or illegal. But the text then asks governments to review their laws on abortion and to provide medical care to women who decide to terminate their pregnancies."
 
A Change in Focus
 The Vatican attack further raised the political temperature in advance of a gathering that has drawn what Italian commentators call the Pope's most determined campaign since his battle against Communism in his native Poland.
At issue mainly is language in the conference draft proposals that has drawn attention away from the gathering's stated aim -- to agree on ways to deal with a global crisis in population growth -- and focused it instead on what, for the Vatican, is the vital question of whether the proposals enshrine abortion and sex outside of marriage as human rights.
Specifically, Mr. Navarro-Valls said today, terms in the document like "reproductive health" and "reproductive rights" introduce the idea of "in effect, abortion on demand" as a proposed international right to be established by the gathering.
In what seemed a thinly veiled allusion to what the Vatican considers excessive influence on the drafting of the proposals by American feminists, Mr. Navarro-Valls said the Cairo gathering risked becoming "a session called to sanction a current life style in minority circles of certain opulent societies" and to impose those values on "the emerging, less developed cultures of our society."
The Vatican's determined position against the document reflects the huge differences in fundamental perceptions of what the conference is all about. For feminists, the gathering represents a potential turning point in elevating the economic and political status of the world's women as a way of encouraging them to curb the size of their families. The feminists also support the idea of making information on birth control available to all, including women who are not married.
For the Roman Catholic hierarchy, though, the gathering is seen as a moment that could enshrine in international agreements amoral notions relating to abortion, adolescent sexuality and the central role that the church believes should be played by the family.
"It is not a casual fact that an institution so natural, fundamental and universal as marriage is practically absent in the document text," Mr. Navarro-Valls said.
 
Backing From Islam
 While the Vatican has denied striking a formal alliance with Islamic countries, it has won significant backing from Islamic scholars who, like some Roman Catholic figures, argue that the effect of the document is to promote adolescent promiscuity, abortion and homosexuality.
Saudi Arabia, the Sudan and Lebanon have announced they will not attend the 170-nation conference in Cairo, where Egyptian Islamic fundamentalists threatened last week to attack participants in what they term the "conference of licentiousness." The Turkish Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, worried by strengthening Islamic sentiment in her own country, has also said she will not attend.
Beyond the arguments over abortion, the Vatican is also fundamentally opposed to the idea that population growth in itself is necessarily a hindrance to development.
According to the United Nations Population Fund, the world's population is set to increase from its current 5.6 billion to 8.5. billion in the year 2025. The Cairo conference is supposed to approve measures to stabilize the world's population at 7.27 billion by the year 2050.
"Population policies are only a part of development policy," Mr. Navarro-Valls said. "In fact they include a whole range of areas: nutrition, medicine, agriculture, education, demographics, economics and politics, together with more profound moral and spiritual dimensions. True development will not be respected if only demographic data is considered as the obstacle to development."
Such arguments reflect the Vatican's deep-rooted opposition to all forms of artificial contraception.

HEADLINE: When Children Kill Children: Boy, 11, Is Wanted in Chicago

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Someone stepped out of the shadows between two storefront churches on the city's far South Side the other night and started shooting wildly at a knot of teen-agers playing football.
When the gunfire stopped, a 14-year-old girl lay dead, killed by a bullet apparently meant for someone else. At first, the shooting appeared to be another senseless, though increasingly common, story of an innocent slaughtered in the street. 
 But the slaying of Shavon Dean has become more than that. It has shaken this city and made many here fear for the future, not because of the victim's tender years but because of the even younger age of her suspected killer, an 11-year-old boy.
The suspect, who police say belongs to a gang, stands 4-foot-8, sports a tattoo that says "I love mommy" and has an arrest record that could belong to a middle-age thug.
And ever since the shooting last Sunday night, the boy has eluded the police and their growing child-hunt.
"This is a tragedy for everybody on both sides," Shavon's aunt, Ida Falls, said today. "That boy is 11 years old. He don't know no better. The gangs tell him what to do and he does it. He's just a child, a child that killed a child."
The boy, who has not been identified by the police because of his age, lived around the corner from Shavon and is known in the neighborhood for causing trouble. He is also a suspect in the shooting and wounding of a teen-age boy earlier on Sunday in another skirmish in what seems like a never-ending gang war here.
But gunplay and funerals are not confined to big cities and their street gangs. In the apple-growing community of Wenatchee, Wash., about 160 miles east of Seattle, two 12-year-old boys were recently accused of killing a 50-year-old migrant farm worker.
The boys, the police say, shot the man 18 times with two stolen pistols after he told them to stop making noise and, they boys said, threw a rock at them.
In each case, the common thread is the ability of children to get their hands on guns.
Shavon Dean lived in a working-class neighborhood of single-story homes with neat lawns. But so much gunfire had rattled the area in the days leading up to her slaying, residents say, that most parents were telling their children to stay on their tree-shaded street -- where it was supposed to be safe. One of the churches on 108th Street had even erected a curbside basketball hoop so that teen-agers on the block would not have to go to school to play and risk being caught in a crossfire.
"When I was coming up," said Kenneth Reed, 22, "I had role models, somebody to look up to. It ain't that way any more. Now, you look up to the person with the biggest gun."
The 11-year-old boy wanted in Shavon's death has the kind of scarred personal background often associated with later violence.
"This is a tragic, tragic case" the Cook County Public Guardian, Patrick T. Murphy, who represents children and the elderly in the courts, said today. "This is a kid who has had nothing going for him his entire life."
The boy grew up amid gangs, drugs and rising unemployment. Mr. Murphy said the boy's mother was 15 when she first gave birth; she was 18 when he was born. Martha Allen, a spokeswoman for the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services, said that when the boy's mother was 21 he and four of his siblings were taken from her because of neglect and, in the cold code of bureaucracy, "risk of harm.".
The boy and his siblings were placed in the custody of their grandmother, who is now 46. She told The Chicago Sun-Times: "They are lying that he is supposed to have done some shooting. He's a nice kid, until he gets with the wrong group."
 
'A Time Bomb'
 According to child welfare documents, when the boy was 3 and taken from his mother to be put into his grandmother's care, he had several cigarette burn marks on his neck, shoulder and buttocks and other signs of physical abuse. "This kid was a time bomb waiting to explode," Mr. Murphy said. "He was turned into a sociopath by his family."
In the last eight years, officials say, the boy and an older brother have often run away from their grandmother's home, and late last year the boy was made a ward of the state.
He was placed in a group home on the city's North Side, but ran away in March and stayed on the run for several weeks, when he was picked up in a stolen car and held in a juvenile detention center. He was released in July, but was later arrested on an armed-robbery charge, and two days after that on a burglary charge. At the time of the shootings last Sunday, the authorities were planning to send him to a juvenile center out of the state.
His troubles with the law began at least two years before. In early 1992, he was arrested on a shoplifting charge. That same year, the police arrested him on charges of criminal damage to property and robbery. In 1993, he was arrested on a charge of attempted armed robbery.
At a news conference to discuss the city's crime-fighting programs, the police superintendent, Matt Rodriguez, said that while no motive had been found for the shooting that took Shavon Dean's life, older members of street gangs often recruited children to sell drugs and carry out shootings; this helps older gang members avoid arrest and the harsher sentences that adults receive.
"The 11-year-old is dangerous," Superintendent Rodriguez said, "but he is still an 11-year-old."
Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago said the state's juvenile justice system should be changed to "keep kids away from abusive and negligent parents and off the streets."
"This young kid," the Mayor said of the 11-year-old, "has fallen through the cracks."
The 11-year-old knew Shavon, said her aunt, Mrs. Falls, who stood near a street shrine of flowers and handwritten messages of grief and love to Shavon. Mrs. Falls said she took the boy and 12 other children to a local police station about three weeks ago to watch a film on crime. She said that she had liked the boy, who seemed quiet, but that the police had asked her not to bring him back because he had picked fights with some of the other children.
All morning today, neighbors and strangers stopped at the impromptu memorial to Shavon, mourning her but some also finding tragedy in the life of the boy accused of killing her.
"You can't just point the finger at the boy," said Johnnie Williams, 18. "You got to point the finger at the grown-ups who put the gun in his hands. Everybody knew Shavon and everybody knew the boy. We feel bad for both of them. Two lives been cut short here."
Shavon was to have started high school next week. She wanted to work in and maybe someday own a beauty shop. She was remembered as a friendly girl with a smile that could chase a tear.
On Sunday night, shortly before 9 o'clock, Shavon, a cousin and several other youngsters were walking the 50 yards from her aunt's house to Shavon's house when the shooter stepped out of the darkened lot between the First General Assembly Church of the First Born and the True Church of God Holiness in Christ.
As the bullets from the semiautomatic pistol, "too many, too fast to count" in the words of a witness, ripped the air, Shavon's cousin, Felicia Falls, 18, shouted to run. She and the others got safely inside Shavon's house, but Felicia soon realized that "somebody was missing."
"I looked out and saw Shavon lying curled up on the sidewalk," Felicia said. "I knew she was dead. I broke out hollering so God could hear me and stop this craziness."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Shavon Dean, 14, who was killed Sunday night on a Chicago street.; Ida Falls, left, whose 14-year-old niece, Shavon Dean, was shot to death on Sunday night in Chicago in attack apparently intended for someone else, comforted the victim's mother yesterday at the site of the shooting. (Paul Merideth for The New York Times) (pg. B10)

HEADLINE: For Cubans Trying to Leave Legally, 'Lamentations'

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Just beyond the green-glass offices of the American mission here, a few hundred yards from the seas dotted with the rafts of fleeing Cubans, scores of people gather each morning on a small patch of gravel and cement known as the Park of Lamentations.
Sitting in the shade of almond trees, they have become a steady reminder of how difficult it is for Cubans to travel to the United States by legal means. They are all waiting to see about visas, and under the current procedures, they may keep on waiting for months or even years. 
 "I don't want to throw myself into the sea, but what else can you do?" said Jose Miguel Gomez, a young man in the park who said he had been left behind as one of his siblings after another had left the country in rafts. "You can sit here a long time and nothing happens."
If successful, the negotiations that Cuban and American officials plan to begin on Thursday in New York may not help the raft refugees but could deliver some of "the Lamenting Ones." United States officials say they will offer to quicken the flow of legal immigrants in return for renewed efforts by the Cuban Government to stop those who, as it is said here, "throw themselves into the sea."
 
More Emigration Seen
 Yet after days in which thousands of Cubans have braved sharks and storms in the hope of a better future -- many of them knowing that their best fate might be rescue by the United States Coast Guard and internment at the American naval base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba -- many diplomats and other analysts have grown skeptical that such a deal would relieve the growing pressure for emigration.
"If there is a migration deal that satisfies 20,000, there will be 200,000 who want to go," a diplomat said. Speaking of Cuba's President, Fidel Castro, he added, "He will not be able to stop people from leaving now without using force and drawing blood, and I don't think he is going to do that."
Analysts perceive varying degrees of intensity in the desperation that is driving the refugees from the island. But they generally agree that the economic suffering and political discontent that have caused the exodus will not decline significantly over the next several years, barring an unexpected reversal of Government policies.
Legal and illegal immigration are also very different escape valves.
Most of the people taking to sea without visas are young men in their 20's and 30's, starkly pessimistic about their futures and often without family in the United States.
 
Seen as 'Almost Undesirable'
 Describing them as largely less employed and less educated than other members of their generation, a Cuban official called them "almost undesirable" -- an allusion to the several thousand criminals and psychiatric patients sent to the United States among more than 125,000 Cubans in the Mariel boatlift in 1980.
Among some 19,700 Cubans awaiting action on immigrant visa requests, the average age is closer to 50, United States immigration officials say. Relatively few of them represent potential raft escapees or important threats to the governing Communist Party. And when they pass through the system, American officials suggest, there may not be that many more qualified applicants behind them.
Only three weeks ago, in an interview on Cuban television, Mr. Castro dismissed talks on immigration as a pointless exercise that "would be a pastime taking up months, years in order to accomplish absolutely nothing."
"It is not a question of getting 1,000 or 10,000 or so extra visas and establishing communication between Coast Guards," he said. "None of these things get to the bottom of the problem."
But since the Clinton Administration abruptly ended the longstanding policy of accepting illegal Cuban immigrants, the Havana Government has seemed to focus more on the claim that the United States has reneged on a 1984 agreement that set an annual ceiling of 20,000 legal Cuban immigrants.
 
Misinterpretation Seen
 American officials respond that Cuba misinterpreted the accord.
Rather than a commitment or quota for any specific number of immigrant visas, they say, the figure -- which has since been raised to 27,845 -- was merely an upper limit that put Cubans on equal footing with other preferred countries.
The answer to why the United States Interests Section has granted only 2,059 immigrant visas over the last 10 months and even fewer in some recent years depends on who is asked.
Around of Park of Lamentations, which American diplomats prefer to call Liberty Park, there seems to be little question that the United States immigration authorities are making things tougher than necessary, perhaps to make them tougher for the Cuban Government.
"Maybe 300 people go in there every day," Gloria Ventana, a retired clerical worker, said, gesturing toward the United States mission. "The most they will ever give out are two or three visas!"
The diplomats say part of the problem is simply that with only seven consular officers, the mission is overwhelmed by a flow of paper that included more than 72,000 applications for non-immigrant visas in the fiscal year that ended in the fall of 1993.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Weary of their long wait, Cubans seeking American visas sat yesterday in the Park of Lamentations near the United States mission in Havana. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Companies
Time Warner is negotiating to buy the NBC network and some of its cable services for about $2.5 billion in stock and cash. In another potential network deal, Walt Disney has apparently contacted CBS about buying that company. [Page A1.]
John W. Kluge will merge four companies to form a company that will focus on Eastern Europe. [D1.] 
 Kroll Associates is trying to reinvent itself after years of being known as Wall Street's private eye. [D1.]
Time Inc.'s new editor in chief is said to be Norman Pearlstine, former executive editor of The Wall Street Journal. [D1.]
The proposed Lockheed-Martin Marietta merger could open the door for more deals involving military suppliers. [D2.]
Philip Morris's board voted to increase its dividend 19.6 percent and to authorize a $6 billion stock buyback program. [D3.]
Shares of the Big Three auto makers tumbled after reports of insider selling by Chrysler executives. [D3.]
Texas Instruments' stock fell sharply after a ruling by a Japanese court on its computer chip patent. [D3.]
Swiss Bank will acquire Brinson Partners, a Chicago investment management firm, in a $750 million stock deal. [D3.]
Macy and Federated gave projections for a merged department store company in a bankruptcy court filing. [D4.]
Conoco began pumping oil north of the Arctic Circle. [D4.]
A Times Square billboard that featured Joe Camel for five years will now promote healthy eating habits. [B3.]
Rutgers University gave Coca-Cola exclusive rights to sell its products on the school's three campuses in a $10 million deal. [B9.]
 
The Economy
Increases in prices were reported by corporate purchasing managers in both Chicago and New York. The price component of the index of leading indicators also showed a sharp rise. [D1.]
Federal regulators plan to require some banks to hold more capital to cover possible losses on derivatives. [D1.]
 
International
The United States signed a tax accord with Canada. [D6.]
 
Today's Columns
The amazing rise of shares of SFM shows how one good earnings report can set off a buying fever among speculators, many of whom buy first and ask questions later. And it shows how a thinly traded stock can go from obscurity to market prominence while little information is available. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
Changes in health care are still possible, despite the stalemate in Washington. Possibilities that would pass economic and political laugh tests include expanding Medicaid, limiting malpractice liability and permitting insurance companies to link premiums only to broad categories like age. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Burger King will try once again. The chain, which has had 18 advertising themes and 7 ad agencies in 20 years, introduced a campaign emphasizing value, called "Get your burger's worth." Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D17.]

Markets
Stocks slipped despite a strong surge in shares of Philip Morris, a component of the Dow industrials. The Dow fell 3.88 points. [D6.]
Treasury prices were little changed after economic reports added fresh evidence of a slowing economy. [D13.]
 Copper prices surged on signs of rising demand. Oil prices rose. [D16.] The dollar posted modest gains. [D16.]

HEADLINE: A Midlife Crisis at Kroll Associates

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
For years, Kroll Associates was Wall Street's private eye, specializing in digging up dirt in heated takeover battles. When merger mania cooled, Kroll kept its grip on the top rung by snaring such high-profile assignments as a request by the Kuwaiti Government to search for Saddam Hussein's hidden riches and revamping security at the World Trade Center after the 1993 terrorist bombing.
Along the way, Kroll redefined itself and its industry by offering crisis management advice to corporations, negotiating kidnapping cases in Brazil and uncovering computer criminals in Tokyo. 
 Now, faced with tough new competition from lawyers, accounting firms and other investigative agencies, the New York-based business and its cigar-chomping founder, Jules B. Kroll, are trying to reinvent themselves again. This time, he wants to be a full-line global provider of planning and analysis on every aspect of security and risk management the way that McKinsey & Company, the top-drawer global consulting operation, and Goldman, Sachs & Company, the financial services firm, offer strategic planning and investment banking services to the business world.
By the end of this decade Mr. Kroll wants to more than quadruple his firm's revenues. But achieving that lofty goal will not be easy, and changing the company's focus does not come without risks. In recent months, Kroll has trimmed its worldwide staff to 230 from 240, stirring rumors that it was in financial trouble. Mr. Kroll said the mix of people was changing to reflect the new business emphasis.
But the new makeover has left Mr. Kroll, who makes a very good living off other people's troubles, with a crisis of his own. Veteran employees have left or been eased out. Some long-term clients complain that Kroll has forgotten its roots as an investigative firm, and others grouse about the firm's high fees. Competitors, well versed in the art of corporate gamesmanship, stand ready to exploit any rumor of weakness in the leader of the pack.
Mr. Kroll blames unnamed competitors for spreading false rumors about the company's financial condition recently, touching off a round of crisis management at Kroll itself. Concerned about the consequences of the turmoil in a business that depends so heavily on reputation, Mr. Kroll made himself and top executives available for interviews, discussed the company's finances, and provided a window on the inner workings of the secretive, privately held company that operates in the gray area between gumshoe and government.
Combined with interviews with former Kroll employees, competitors and clients, the result is both a portrait of Kroll Associates and a snapshot of a booming industry that increasingly affects the way business and government operate.
Most work still comes from corporations. But more governments are turning to private firms for some tasks like monitoring court-ordered efforts to clean up corrupt industries, like Kroll's work to keep the Gambino crime family out of the trucking business in New York City's garment industry, and the attempt to break the mob's hold on Long Island's carting industry by Kroll's Michael Cherkasky, a former senior aide to the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.
Experts like Robert D. McCrie at John Jay College of Criminal Justice see opportunities for government to save money and get better results by hiring private investigative firms like Kroll. However, Mr. McCrie cautioned that dangers exist because these surrogates are less accountable than government employees.
Mr. Kroll wants to jettison the image of private eyes snooping through trash bins and bugging offices. He talks about building relationships with corporations to advise them on security and risk management.
The audacious plans of Mr. Kroll and his comparison of the company to such gold-plated firms as McKinsey and Goldman, Sachs even drew some good-natured skepticism from Robert J. McGuire, the former New York police commissioner who is Kroll's president.
"No matter what we do, people want to put a fedora and a trench coat on us," Mr. Kroll complained.
After all, Kroll is not an investment bank or a consulting firm. And there is no escaping the seamy side of investigative work.
Mr. Kroll acknowledged that the company had occasionally obtained telephone and bank records of investigative targets, violating company rules and probably the law. Two South African intelligence agents held by the Swiss police for bugging an office in Geneva in 1991 were sometime-employees of Kroll, but Mr. Kroll said they were not on Kroll business when they were arrested.
 
'Biggest Black Eye'
 The company's "biggest black eye," he said, came four years ago when investigators misrepresented themselves while interviewing former employees of a chemical company. A Delaware judge was so angry that he issued sanctions against two lawyers who had hired Kroll, but the action was later reversed.
Mr. McGuire instituted ethical guidelines when he became president in 1989, but he acknowledged that mistakes still occurred.
"The main issue is, 'Are you institutionally committed, without winks and nods, to complying with the law?' And we are," Mr. McGuire insisted. "Our reputation is all that enables us to function."
Since its founding in 1972 by Mr. Kroll, a former prosecutor, the firm has functioned exceptionally well for the most part. As Kroll became the leading investigative firm for takeovers in the 1980's, revenues grew fortyfold.
Growth has slowed dramatically, but still appears healthy, and Mr. Kroll said the company had remained profitable with a pretax profit margin of about 12 percent. Revenues were $40 million in 1990 and are on a pace to exceed $60 million this year, according to Kroll's figures.
The business mix has changed, too. In the 1980's, three or four big cases could generate half of the firm's annual revenue, and the company shunned small cases.
 
A $20,000 Fee
 Today the firm handles hundreds of smaller matters, with an average fee of $20,000, Mr. Kroll said. Company figures show the number of new clients has grown 78 percent since 1990 to 755 this year and the annual caseload is approaching 2,500, compared with 1,000 or fewer before.
Still, there are some mega-cases. The Kuwaitis paid Kroll as much as $100,000 a week for months in 1991 and 1992 to search for the hidden assets of Saddam Hussein. Over the last two years, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has paid Kroll $2.5 million to overhaul security at the World Trade Center and evaluate procedures at the agency's bridges, tunnels and airports.
Such expertise does not come cheap. Clients pay an average of $1,500 a day for the services of a Kroll agent. And the company's employees are well paid by industry standards. Senior managers earn $100,000 to $300,000 a year and top executives make as much as $500,000 a year.
Whether the company is worth its high fees depends on who is talking. "They saved us a lot of money," said Thomas E. Workman Jr., general counsel of Amgen Inc., the biotechnology company.
After receiving an internal memo warning that one of its scientists was stealing the formula for epogen, an Amgen product used in kidney failure, the company hired Kroll investigators last spring. They identified the suspect and, accompanied by F.B.I. agents, confronted him in the laboratory early one Sunday morning, Mr. Workman said.
 
Building Fortunes
 Mr. Kroll has become a wealthy man, with a limousine and an estate on Long Island Sound. In 1989, the company borrowed $20 million in 10-year notes from a teachers' pension fund, wiping out its bank debt and enabling Mr. Kroll, who then owned 100 percent of the firm, to pocket in excess of $7 million.
Last year, American International Group Inc., a leading insurance organization whose product lines including kidnapping coverage, bought 23 percent of Kroll for $15 million. Mr. Kroll and Maurice R. Greenberg, the chairman and chief executive of A.I.G., said there were no plans for the insurance giant to take a bigger share of Kroll. But both men see the partnership as a launching pad for new products that combine A.I.G. insurance expertise with Kroll's investigative and risk-analysis skills, such as providing coverage and security advice to a company entering a politically unstable part of the world.
Another area where Kroll expects growth is in its crisis-management business. "We're expanding the geographical and functional frontiers of the company," said Brian M. Jenkins, a former director of the RAND Corporation's program on political violence and terrorism and now head of crisis management at Kroll.
Crisis management, ranging from developing procedures to reduce security risks to analysis of political and economic stability in foreign countries, now provides about 20 percent of Kroll revenue, but it must grow sharply if the firm is to meet the $250 million mark by the year 2000.
Some clients complain that Kroll's zeal for new business has come at the expense of longtime customers. One morning this week, Mr. McGuire had to remind Mr. Jenkins that they had promised a business proposal a month ago to the chairman of a major European company.
"Sorry," Mr. Jenkins replied. "I'll add it to my list of 800 things to do."
 
Industry Getting Crowded
 As Kroll has refocused, it has left the door open for the many competitors who have sprung up in its wake.
The competition has also changed in recent years. As corporate snooping has become more accepted in the business world, a handful of law firms and accounting firms have gotten into the business.
"There's an increasing willingness on the part of corporations to acknowledge fraud and other problems and deal with them," said Michael D. Carey, a former British fraud investigator who is director of KPMG Peat Marwick's seven-member forensic and investigative services.
However, Kroll is still the one to beat. Last year, Kroll was chosen over three other companies to advise the Port Authority on a redesign of its security procedures.
"We have such confidence in them that I have followed every one of their recommendations," said Stanley Brezenoff, the Port Authority executive director.

HEADLINE: Cuba Reported to Encourage Convicts to Join the Refugees

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Fearing a repetition of an unwelcome aspect of the 1980 Mariel boatlift, Clinton Administration officials said today they had evidence that the Cuban Government had released several dozen prisoners and encouraged them to join the flood of Cuban refugees.
State Department officials said they would seek an explanation from Cuban diplomats in talks Thursday in New York about what they described as "indications" that the Cuban Government had granted two- or three-day furloughs to the prisoners and urged them to set out to sea. 
 "There are enough clear indications that prisoners are being given passes for a few days and are being told that they'll have to go back to jail if they come back," one official said.
Senator Bob Graham, a Florida Democrat, said that during his visit today to the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station, where more than 13,000 Cubans are being held, he had learned that there was "evidence that criminals have been unloaded on the United States." A State Department official said Senator Graham's estimate of 100 suspected prisoners was a reasonable number.
 
Prisoners Segregated at Base
 Senator Graham said the former prisoners had been segregated from the other Cuban refugees at Guantanamo and were being kept in a concrete blockhouse that had been used to store ammunition during World War II. He said those Cubans should be put on a United States Navy ship and sent into Havana Harbor, "with or without Castro's consent."
Administration officials adopted a cautious approach, saying they were trying to find out whether the newly arrived prisoners were hard-core criminals or political prisoners, and whether they were released recently or some time ago. According to these offcials, the Administration has not yet decided whether to seek to repatriate the refugees believed to be former convicts.
Administration officials said they had also received credible reports that Cuban authorities were providing some prisoners with the materials needed to build rafts.
For over a decade, successive administrations have unsuccessfully pressed President Fidel Castro to take back more than 1,500 former Cuban prisoners that American officials say the Cuban leader sent into the United States as part of the Mariel boatlift. An estimated 125,000 Cubans came to the United States during the boatlift. American officials also protested that Mr. Castro had sent mental patients and people with serious diseases.
 
U.S. Prepares for Talks
 As concerns grew about reports of prisoners joining the refugees, the Administration team handling the Cuba crisis put the finishing touches today on its bargaining position, based on their assessment that Mr. Castro may be willing to halt the exodus of refugees because it has in many ways backfired on him.
The offer, which will be presented to Cuban negotiators in New York on Thursday, is intended to persuade Cuba to stop the flood of boat people in return for the Administration's pledge to vastly increase the number of Cubans who are granted entry rights to the United States each year.
In the Administration's view, the mass migration has hurt Mr. Castro's image and he is feeling pressure from the Administration's measures to tightening the economic embargo on Cuba.
In an interview, Michael Skol, the State Department official who will head Washington's negotiating team, said, "We are working on the assumption that Cuba understands that it is in its interests as well as ours to curtail unsafe, illegal immigration."
 
Cubans See Pressure on U.S.
 But Cuban diplomats insisted in interviews today that it was not Mr. Castro who was feeling pressed to end the crisis.
"The real pressure is on the United States," said Rafael Dausa, spokesman for the Cuban Interests Section, which is in the Swiss Embassy in Washington. "The United States is having a real problem handling all the illegal people coming here."
The pressure grew today as the United States Coast Guard reported that 2,134 Cubans were picked up at sea by midnight, compared with 1,582 who were rescued Tuesday.
A senior Pentagon official said today that the military plans to begin flying some Cuban refugees from Guantanamo Bay to safe havens in Panama during the next week. Similarly, the official said, the Administration plans to fly some Haitian refugees from Guantanamo Bay to Suriname during the next few days. These moves represent the first time that Washington used third-country safe havens for refugees who tried to come to the United States, State Department officials said.
The plan is to send a planeload of refugees, or about 300 people, each day. Venezuela announced today that it would grant entry rights to 10,000 Cubans who have relatives there.
Foreign Minister Miguel Angel Burelli Rivas said in Caracas that his country was ready to grant entry to two family members of each of the 5,000 Cubans living in Venezuela.
And Costa Rica announced today that it would take for up to 24 months an unspecified number of Cubans who have relatives there.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Federated-Macy Filings Offer Preview of Union

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
Federated Department Stores Inc. and R. H. Macy & Company jointly filed statements in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York late yesterday that provided a broad blueprint for the structure of what would be the nation's largest department store company. The filings project conservative earnings growth, dramatic cost savings and significant debt reduction, as well as ambitious plans for store renovation and expansion.
The filings offered some detailed sales projections for the next five years, as well as information about what Macy creditors would receive and the settlement of about $4.7 billion in estimated claims against Macy. 
 Federated also announced that it had received commitments from Citibank and Chemical Bank for $1.1 billion of the necessary $2.8 billion in financing that would be used to pay for the Macy purchase and to refinance existing Federated debt. The source of the the rest of the financing remains unclear.
 
More Data to Come
 But the documents did not disclose the most eagerly awaited information about the new company: the number of stores to be closed or sold, and how many jobs would be eliminated. That information will be filed in one or more amended disclosure statements during September, Carol Sanger, a spokeswoman for Federated, said.
Yesterday's filings project increases in earnings of 3.6 percent a year for the next three years in stores open more than a year. The statements predict cost savings of $71 million in 1995 from the merger, increasing to $122 million a year thereafter before inflation, or $500 million by the end of the 1998 fiscal year.
"We think the earnings may be 5 or 6 percent, so the projection is very conservative, which is appropriate," said Isaac Lagnado, principal director of Tactical Retail Solutions, a market research and retail consulting company in New York. "The cost savings are very impressive, a monumental achievement that vindicates the wisdom of creating a department-store operation that is national in scope."
The statement also projects earnings before income, taxes and depreciation as 12.8 percent of sales by 1998 for the combined companies, up from 9.9 percent in the 1995 fiscal year. Net income would increase 73 percent, to $422 million in 1996 from $243.6 million in the 1995 fiscal year.
Total debt for Federated, as the combined company would be known, would decline from $5.1 billion in 1994 to $3.5 billion in 1998.
 
Plans for Expansion
 In addition, the statements hint at plans for future expansion and renovation: The company intends to spend 21 percent of its $2.8 billion capital budget from 1995 to 1998 to open between five and eight new stores a year, and 11 percent of the capital budget would be spent on technological improvements like computer systems. But existing stores would hardly be neglected, as 68 percent of the capital budget would be earmarked for upgrading and maintaining existing stores.
According to the filings, Roger N. Farah, who became president and chief operating officer of Macy in July, would receive $14 million should he leave the combined company, and would be free to work for a competitor. Mr. Farah had been caught in the middle of battle between Federated, his former employers, and Macy.
The merger, which is expected to be completed in December, would get Macy out of bankruptcy court protection. Before then, the plan requires the formal approval of Macy's creditors, although they have informally given their support, and of Judge Burton R. Lifland, who is presiding over the Macy case.
The companies have asked the court for a Sept. 29 hearing on approval of the statement. After that, the creditors will be asked to vote in mid-November. Federated's shareholders will also have to approve the merger plan.
 
Dismissals at Macy
 Macy has already dismissed about a third of the 300 administrative employees at its corporate headquarters on Herald Square in Manhattan, according to Ms. Sanger of Federated. The combined company will spend about $32 million on severance packages and performance bonuses, according to executives close to the company.
Although the Federal Trade Commission effectively approved the merger, the plan awaits approval from the New York Attorney General, G. Oliver Koppell.
"I suspect that some of the delay in filing details in the disclosure was caused by Mr. Koppell, who has created some waltzing around and negotiation," said Arnold Aronson, a former chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue who is a partner of Levy, Kerson, Aronson, a retail-industry industry consulting firm.
Mr. Koppell has threatened to bring suit against the two retailers unless they sell 12 Macy's stores in the New York area. Macy competes with three units of Federated in the region: Abraham & Straus, Bloomingdale's and Stern's.
Mr. Koppell said through a spokesman that he had no comment on yesterday's filings.

HEADLINE: Legislators In U.S. Differ Over Haiti

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
A day after the Clinton Administration issued its strongest threat to date of a military invasion of Haiti, two leading members of Congress expressed sharply divided views on using force to restore democracy there.
"I think we're right at the point of invasion," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. "I don't think you can send two high-ranking officials to the Caribbean making the kinds of comments that they made yesterday without following through." 
 Mr. Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat, was speaking of a visit on Tuesday by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch to Jamaica to confer with representatives of 13 Caribbean nations. The countries agreed to contribute a token force of 266 troops to support an American-led invasion to restore Haiti's exiled and ousted President, the Rev. Jean Bertrand Aristide.
 
Disagreement in Congress
 Mr. Hamilton, who made the remarks on the CBS News program "This Morning," said he believed Congress and the public would support an invasion. But Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who serves on the Foreign Affairs Committee, strongly disagreed in comments on the NBC News program "The Today Show." .
"The American people are not convinced that we have vital interests in invading Haiti, despite immigration, which we believe might continue even if Mr. Aristide was restored," he said. "And we've really not had a policy of forcing democracy on a country, however despicable that regime might be."
In a news conference at the State Department, Mr. Talbott and Mr. Deutch repeated a message to Haiti's military rulers that they must leave or will soon be forced from power.
But a contradiction still undercuts the Administration's threats. Senior American officials say the Haitian generals must go soon, or face an invasion. But they also say they want to exhaust all other options, including a trade embargo and other economic sanctions imposed against Haiti since Father Aristide's ouster in 1991.
 
Time for Sanctions
 If the United States is serious about giving sanctions a chance it could be several weeks or months before President Clinton orders an invasion. An 88-member, multinational observer force that is supposed to help the Dominican Republic seal its border to prevent smuggling into Haiti has yet to begin its mission and will not be operating fully until mid-September.
Training for the 266 troops from Jamaica, Trinidad and Tobago, Barbados and Belize will begin over the next two weeks at a United States Navy base in Roosevelt Roads, Puerto Rico, but will take two to three more weeks to complete, a senior Pentagon official said today.
About 30 United States Army special operations trainers stationed in the Caribbean who have special language skills will instruct the troops in crowd control, first aid, roadblocks, communications, peacetime rules of engagement, and the use of weapons.
The Caribbean troops are to form part of a 10,000-member, American led-force that would go into Haiti whether the generals leave on their own or are ousted.
 
U.S. Aid for Force
 The Caribbean troops would perform police work in the days after an invasion, military officials say. They will bring their own small arms, but the United States will provide vehicles, uniforms, helmets and water trailers, a Pentagon official said.
Lawmakers acknowledged today that an invasion is not likely soon but said that the Administration remains on that track.
"I would not say that it's imminent in the sense of the next few hours or days, but I do think it's getting very close," Mr. Hamilton said. "It's a matter of days, weeks away, before some kind of decisive action has to take place."
 
Ultimatum Is Suggested
 Randall Robinson, the leader of the lobbying group TransAfrica, said today that Mr. Clinton should immediately give Haiti's military leaders 48-hours notice to leave or be ousted. It was a 27-day hunger strike by Mr. Robinson that galvanized the public and the Congressional Black Caucus to press Mr. Clinton for a more aggressive policy this year.
Representative Kweisi Mfume, a Maryland Democrat who heads the Congressional Black Caucus, said "It's no longer a question of whether or not it's inevitable. It's a larger question of whether or not we find ourselves with reasons as to why we should not invade."
But Senator John S. McCain, an Arizona Republican on the Armed Services Committee, said he worries about what would happen after an invasion. "It is the post-invasion circumstances that I fear will bog down U.S. forces in a low-level, open-ended, ill-defined conflict which will require servicemen and women to serve as a virtual palace guard for President Aristide once he is returned to power," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Order Higher Bank Reserves

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Taking the first big steps to discourage banks from speculating in derivatives, Federal regulators said today that they were planning to require some banks to hold more capital to cover possible losses on such investments.
The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, part of the Treasury Department, announced that it would issue the proposed new rules on minimum capital standards Friday. And the Federal Reserve System, which also regulates many banks, quietly proposed a virtually identical set of regulations last week for a public comment period that will also end on Oct. 21. 
 Federal bank regulators usually put into effect the rules they propose, but sometimes make modifications based on the comments they receive.
 
A Volatile Product
 Derivatives are volatile financial securities or contracts based on assets like Treasury bonds, foreign currencies, or stock indexes. Their value can swing dramatically with small changes in the markets they are linked to. They are controversial because mutual funds and limited partnerships have suffered billions of dollars in losses from investments in derivatives this year.
The nation's biggest banks have reported relatively modest losses from derivatives up to now, although regulators say that a small community bank, which they refuse to identify, lost a quarter of its capital because of unwise investments in derivatives. But banks have received the most attention from regulators and from Congress because under Federal deposit insurance, the Government must reimburse depositors for losses if a bank failed.
The proposed new rules for minimum capital standards would penalize banks for trading in the most speculative derivatives by forcing them to tie up more of their net worth in safe investments like Treasury bonds instead of using it to make loans on which they can often make more profit. But banks that conducted most of their derivatives deals with only a few institutions would be allowed to hold less capital.
Susan M. Phillips, the Federal Reserve governor with the greatest expertise in derivatives, said in an interview that the proposed rules get "us closer to having the firms' capital more closely reflect the actual risk composition of their assets and liabilities."
But Ms. Phillips, a former head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, added that she and other regulators did not view derivatives as especially dangerous. "I don't think there is any greater risk to their derivatives activity than there is to the rest of their activities," she said of the banks.
 
Curbs on Commodities Deals
 The new rules would make it more costly for banks to trade any derivative that fluctuates in value based on stock market indexes or the prices of precious metals, oil or other commodities.
The rules would also make it more expensive for banks to trade long-term derivatives, which fluctuate in value with the level of interest rates or currency exchange rates over the course of five or more years.
But the new rules would allow a bank to set aside less capital than before if it and another financial institution engaged in a number of derivative deals with partly offsetting effects. For example, this could occur if the bank agreed to buy French francs from the other institution at one price and sell francs to the same institution at a different price.
Under the new rules, the bank would be allowed to allocate capital based on the combined credit risk of all these deals, instead of on each transaction. So conducting 10 derivatives deals with another bank could be cheaper than one deal with each of 10 banks.
 
View From Banking Industry
 James D. McLaughlin, the director of Federal agency relations at the American Bankers Association in Washington, said that few banks were active in the derivatives market and that the overall effect of the new regulations on them would not be great. "We're not opposed to it," he said.
The derivatives market has supported the new rules. Many deals are carried out between a few institutions and will qualify for the lower capital requirements, while relatively few deals involve the most speculative derivatives that will be subject to higher requirements, according to derivatives dealers.
But Douglas E. Harris, a senior deputy comptroller of the currency, said it was unclear whether the overall effect of the new regulations would be to increase or decrease the capital that banks must hold in reserve against possible losses. Banks try to hold as little capital as possible, while still meeting Federal standards, because they earn less interest on this money than on their loans.
A few proposals have also circulated in Congress to introduce broader controls on derivatives, and not just for banks. But no action is likely this year because Congress will be in session for only a few weeks between the August recess and adjournment for the November election campaign.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Little Change in Prices Of Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were nearly unchanged as two Commerce Department reports issued yesterday gave more fresh evidence that the economy is losing momentum. The Fed has raised short-term rates five times this year in an attempt to keep the economy from growing too fast and stymy inflation..
The index of leading indicators, which is intended to forecast the direction of growth over the next six months, stalled in July, while factory orders posted the sharpest drop in nearly two and a half years. 
 But with the the Labor Department report on August unemployment due tomorrow, investors remaind cautious and the Treasury market did not rally on the weak economic data.
Matthew F. Alexy, a government trading strategist for CS First Boston, suggested that another reason for the caution in the market was its continued obsession with inflation. Three reports yesterday showed that while growth is slowing prices seem to be still inching higher.
Corporate purchasing managers in both the Chicago and New York areas reported higher readings for August in their indexes of prices paid, while a Commerce Department tally showed a sharp jump for July in the price of materials particularly sensitive to the pace of business activity.
"The question now is how much higher can prices of products go if overall economic activity is waning?, Mr. Alexy said. "This is the issue the bond market faces now and it will be of some concern for a while." This is a worry the Fed also faces, he said.
"The situation in the market is that the economy is not overheating, but as always the market remains on an inflation watch," Mr. Alexy added. "I think if we were to get inflation numbers favorable to the market, we could make a significant move to lower rates."
The 30-year-bond rose 4/32 , to a price of 10020/32 , for a yield of 7.45 percent, down from 7.46 percent on Tuesday and the lowest since Aug. 17, a day after the Fed raised short-term rates for the fifth time this year. The yields on intermediate maturities moved slightly higher, while the rates on shorter-term bills were mixed.
A firmer dollar, which was higher against both the German mark and the Japanese yen, also helped to give Treasury securities a lift.
The no change in the index of leading indicators last month followed a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent in June. New orders for factory goods fell 2.3 percent in July, the first decline since February. "Today's factory orders revealed that the second-quarter surge in the pace of inventory accumulation continued through July, which bodes well for the third-quarter G.D.P. figure," said James Hale, fixed-income analyst with MMS International. Factory orders posted a nine-tenths of 1 percent increase in July, which he said appeared to imply a gain of roughly seven-tenths of 1 percent in overall business inventoriers for the month.
In the municipal market, where the demand for bonds issued offset worries about inflation and higher rates, the New York State Thruway Authority sold $196.09 million of local highway and bridge service contract bonds through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.
The issue was initially priced to yield a maximum 6.324 percent for an issue due in 2014, while another long maturity due 2013 was priced to yield 6.09 percent. For shorter-maturity serial bonds, yields ranged from 4 percent in 1995 to 5.30 percent in 2000, 5.55 percent in 2005 and 5.95 percent in 2010.
Some maturities that are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corporation, while noninsured issues are rated Baa-1 and BBB, respectively.

HEADLINE: Naohiro Amaya, 68; Helped Industry in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Naohiro Amaya, a major architect of the industrial policy that has contributed to Japan's dramatic economic growth, died here on Tuesday, one day before his 69th birthday.
The cause was lung cancer, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said. 
 Mr. Amaya worked at the ministry, usually known as MITI, from 1948 until 1981, rising to Deputy Minister for International Affairs, the highest post available to a career civil servant. Starting in 1987 he served as executive director and then chairman and chief executive of the Dentsu Institute for Human Studies, a research organization affiliated with Japan's largest advertising agency.
At MITI, Mr. Amaya was instrumental in drawing up plans by which the Government aided the development of Japanese industry. These measures included protection from imports and financial support to favored industries.
 
Criticized by U.S. Industry
 Economists have long argued whether such an industrial policy helped or hurt Japan and whether it should be adopted by the United States and other countries. Many American Government and industry officials have criticized the Japanese policies as unfair.
Mr. Amaya was frank in acknowledging that Japan was not a free trader and outspoken in defending MITI's industrial policy to the world. He argued that Japan would not have been able to rise from its impoverished condition after World War II had it relied solely on free-market forces. "We can't take that happy-go-lucky attitude," he said in 1985.
But in more recent years Mr. Amaya, arguing that times had changed, became a critic of too much government control of industry and of the bureaucracy of which he was a part. "What Japan needs now is a 'negative industrial policy,' " he said in 1993.
Mr. Amaya was particularly noted for his role in drawing up MITI's vision for the 1970's, which moved Japan into electronics and other "knowledge intensive" businesses from the heavy industry favored in the 1960's.
 
Negotiations in Washington
 As deputy minister from 1979 to 1981, Mr. Amaya led negotiations with Washington that resulted in Japan's voluntarily restricting exports of automobiles to the United States from 1981 until last March. Mr. Amaya urged the voluntary restraints as a way of heading off passage of a bill by Congress that would have imposed even harsher limits.
"For his efforts in the negotation, he was described by some auto magnates in Tokyo as a 'running dog' of the Americans," Clyde V. Prestowitz Jr., a former United States trade negotiator, wrote about Mr. Amaya in his book "Trading Places." But, Mr. Prestowitz added, "in fact, he deserved a medal for an oustanding act of industrial statesmanship."
Mr. Amaya studied politics at Tokyo University, graduating in 1948 and immediately joining the trade ministry. He was an author of many books and articles, mainly in Japanese, and was a frequent commentator on Japan's domestic and foreign policies.
He is survived by his wife, Kimiko; two sons, Taro and Jiro, and a daughter, Yukiko Amaya Yates.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Insider Selling Trims Auto Stocks

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Share prices of the Big Three auto makers tumbled yesterday, as reports of insider selling at the Chrysler Corporation apparently rekindled fears that the peak in auto sales and profits might have passed.
Chrysler's stock was the first to get pounded, but investors later broadened their selling to shares of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation as well. 
 At the end of the day, Chrysler stock was off by $1.50 a share, to $48. Ford shares lost $1.375, to $29.25. And General Motors declined by $1.75, to $50.25 a share.
A number of auto analysts said the market reaction was extreme and had nothing to do with the industry's underlying fundamentals, which they said remained positive.
The report of insider selling first appeared on Tuesday in The Wall Street Journal. Citing data compiled by CDA/Investnet, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., company that tracks and analyzes trading activity of corporate insiders, the article said that late last month 13 Chrysler vice presidents sold a combined 146,710 shares at prices ranging from $47 to $49 a share.
 
Earlier Insider Selling
 Earlier this year, Chrysler insiders also unloaded a big chunk of stock -- more than 100,000 shares. But at that point the stock was trading at around $60 a share, close to its 52-week high of $63.50.
"We expect to see insiders sell when the stock is going up, and we have seen selling when the stock was rising," Bob Gabele, president of CDA/Instinet, said yesterday.
"But when we see selling on a pull-back in the stock price, it indicates the insiders may not be waiting for the stock to come back. In fact, at times when stock prices are consolidating, you might expect to see insiders buying."
With sales off unsustainably high levels recorded earlier in the year and interest rates moving up, the report added to the concern of investors, who have been skittish about auto stocks for some months.
Rita McKay, a Chrysler spokeswoman, defended the insider sales as prudent portfolio management. Even with the sales, Chrysler stock is still a big part of managers' portfolios, she added.
"All officers are required to hold the equivalent of their annual salary in stock," she said, "and all officers do have an equal amount in stock."
 
Analysts Like Stocks
 Maryann N. Keller, who follows auto stocks for Furman Selz, said, "If I thought we were near the end of the cycle, I would have taken the stocks off our recommended list."
And the market has made adjustments to the stock prices," she added, "which are down about 15 percent from their highs, to levels that I think makes them all buys."
Jack V. Kirnan, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said: "Insider selling in the auto industry has never been a perfect predictor of future stock performance, and it in no way implies that Chrysler's management is anything but confident in their future. Rather, Chrysler's management is just cashing in on the rewards that have come since the company has come back from bankruptcy."
In Mr. Kirnan's view, sales have slowed from their earlier breakneck pace because showrooms are fairly empty. Demand, he contends, is still strong. And even though interest rates have been rising, compared with the relatively recent past they still remain low.
"Inventory levels are the leanest they have been in 10 years," he said. "There is no product to sell.
"There is no way the cycle is over. If it is, then the broader economy has some problems."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Modest Gains Ahead of Employment Data

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar ended firmer against most other leading currencies yesterday, helped by expectations that tomorrow's report on United States employment will show the economy is growing at a steady pace.
Prospects that Germany's central bankers will lower interest rates at a meeting on monetary policy today also helped the dollar gain, traders said. Lower German rates could bolster the dollar by making mark-denominated deposits less attractive. 
 "People are looking for signs of steady growth this Friday," said Lynn Tierney, a trader at Shawmut Bank of Boston. "Too-strong growth would shock the bond market."
Recent strength in the stock and bond markets has helped the dollar hold onto gains it made last Friday, when the Government said the United States economy grew at annual rate of 3.8 percent in the second quarter, up slightly from a previous estimate of 3.7 percent.
At that pace, many traders said, the economy can grow without spurring a rise in the inflation rate any time soon. Bonds rallied after that report, driving the dollar higher. Now traders are looking for more signs of steady, noninflationary growth.
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5816 marks, up from 1.5760 marks on Tuesday. The dollar rose to 100.18 Japanese yen, from 99.57 yen on Tuesday.
Traders said they were wary of selling the dollar before today's meeting of the Bundesbank. Some traders are still hoping for a rate cut, despite an increase in lending rates by France's big banks on Tuesday.
 
Have Rates Bottomed Out?
 The increase fueled speculation that European rates had bottomed, after falling for almost two years.
"People are clinging to the idea that the Bundesbank could cut rates," said Steve Flanagan, a trader at Paine Webber Inc.
Such speculation persists because this week's meeting is considered to be one of the central bank's last chances to cut rates before parliamentary elections in Germany in October, Mr. Flanagan said. After this week, a rate cut might seem politically motivated, because many members of the Parliament have called on the Bundesbank to cut rates to spur economic growth. The central bank is loath to appear subject to political control.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Major health care change may be dead, but something may pass.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
MAJOR health care reform, everyone now concedes, is dead for the year -- conceivably for the decade. But nobody is volunteering, as Hamlet put it, to lug the guts into the neighbor room. Indeed, it is dawning on initially exultant Republicans as well as disappointed Democrats that the politics of stalemate could be a lose-lose situation.
The image of Bill Clinton as the ineffectual big spender may reinforce hostility among those who already dislike the President. But it could be more than offset by the stain on the Presidential hopefuls Bob Dole, known in some quarters as the dark angel of gridlock, and Phil Gramm, who is working on his Marie Antoinette impersonation. 
 That's why Barry P. Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution and veteran of the Washington policy wars, predicts that Congress will still scramble to come up with something to prove it has been wrestling with reform -- and that the President will be almost obliged to sign anything written on a prescription pad.
Something, but what thing? Contrary to intuition, said Joseph Newhouse, an economist at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, "little reforms aren't necessarily easier than big ones." Mr. Newhouse notes, for example, that health insurance subsidies for low-income families ineligible for Medicare -- even modest subsidies -- could lead to "a raid on the Treasury" as employers drop what they are offering.
Still, it is possible to assemble a list of possibilities that pass economic and political laugh tests:
MEDICAID EXPANSION. The Feds, with more than a little financial help from the states, already provide passable medical care for the very poor who are eligible for welfare. And a primary goal of every major reform effort has been to expand Government-aided coverage to the near-poor who don't make the cutoff.
The catch, as Congress spent the last few months learning from its Budget Office, is that financial incentives to buy insurance -- as opposed to mandates to employers or individuals to buy insurance -- would cost the taxpayers a bundle. A more frugal way to extend coverage would be to focus on a few additional groups, rather than the millions of Americans who don't receive insurance from employers and can't afford their own policies on family incomes under, say, $20,000.
One target group that has the sympathy of the public would be children living under the poverty line. Another, Mr. Bosworth suggests, would be families currently eligible for the Earned Income Tax Credit -- America's little-understood negative income tax for the working poor. To keep down costs, this group might be asked to cover part of the cost of medical services, as most privately insured and Medicare patients do today.
Any of this would cost money. But one part of the Democrats' health care tax package -- the levy on tobacco -- could probably be resurrected without losing many votes in Congress. The revenues from anything less than a gargantuan sin tax would be inadequate to carry substantial numbers of enrollees for long. However, once the new constituency has a toehold in the budget, the politics of finding still more revenue would probably change.
MALPRACTICE REFORM. Most of the heavy-duty health care reform plans made a bow toward limiting malpractice liability. In political terms, this represented a sop to hospitals and physicians who would be under pressure on other fronts to cut costs, and who would therefore be willing to run interference against trial lawyers who want no part of malpractice reform.
Mr. Newhouse, however, notes that changes well short of, say, abolishing awards for pain and suffering could make a difference. One possibility would be "enterprise liability" in which hospitals would insure anyone providing care on the premises. That would limit legal fees by consolidating legal defense activities. And it would give health enterprises more systematic incentives to weed out dangerous practices -- and practitioners.
Enterprise liability is being tried voluntarily in a handful of hospitals, Mr. Newhouse reports. But one could imagine regulation toward this end, or perhaps other malpractice changes that do not tread heavily on the perquisites of America's plaintiff bar.
COMMUNITY RATING. One of the core ideas of health care reform is to spread the costs among people with vastly different prospects of ending up in the intensive care unit. But Mr. Bosworth points out that you can't just order insurers to cover everyone at the same dollar premium.
Apart from the obvious problems of preventing insurers from finding every possible excuse from serving a high-risk clientele, there is also the issue of what economists call moral hazard. "You can't allow people to decide when they want insurance," Mr. Bosworth said; that gives them the option of waiting until they are very likely to become sick.
There is, however, a halfway house. Insurers might be permitted to link premiums only to broad categories like age. And Mr. Bosworth would require insurers to take on smaller employee groups at prices comparable to larger groups -- and to take them without checking the health of individuals and excluding those in high-risk categories.
