HEADLINE: Shalala Praises Bipartisan Health Plan as Worth Serious Attention

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
With Congress in recess, the search for a compromise health care bill is focusing on a proposal devised by a bipartisan group of 20 senators, and a senior Administration official said today that the proposal deserved serious attention.
The official, Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said she was reasonably pleased with the plan after hearing extensive discussion of it at a conference of health policy experts in Jackson Hole, Wyo., over the weekend. 
 In addition, Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, chairman of the National Governors' Association, said in an interview, "Governors are very enthusiastic about this proposal and will probably support it when they see all the details."
But a coalition of 35 business groups, including the United States Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers, issued a statement saying the bipartisan proposal would do more harm than good, would increase health costs for many employers, would create strong incentives for companies to stop paying for their workers' insurance and would encourage an explosion of costly lawsuits.
 
Moderates Take the Stage
 The proposal, devised by a group that calls itself the "mainstream coalition," does not promise universal health insurance coverage, as President Clinton initially demanded. It would not require employers to buy insurance for their employees, but would require them to offer a choice of three or more health plans. Under the proposal, the Federal Government would regulate the practices of private health insurance companies, which are now regulated by the states, and it would provide subsidies to low-income people to help them buy insurance.
The group that drafted the mainstream proposal was led by Senators John H. Chafee, Republican of Rhode Island, and John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. While Congress is away, aides to the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell, are meeting with aides to Mr. Chafee and Mr. Breaux, seeking areas of agreement.
Senator Dave Durenberger, a Minnesota Republican who is a member of the coalition, said today: "The mainstream proposal is the main vehicle for staff discussions about incremental health care reform during the Congressional recess. It's the only game in town."
Mr. Durenberger explained the mainstream proposal to Dr. Shalala and others who attended the meeting of the Jackson Hole Group, a conclave of health policy experts, business executives, insurers, doctors, hospital officers and economists. The Jackson Hole Group has been meeting periodically since 1972, and President Clinton adopted some of its ideas in developing his health plan last year.
 
'It Could Be a Real Phoenix'
 In an interview today, Mr. Durenberger said: "Clinton-style health care reform had to die in order for sound health reform to rise up and get passed. The only viable health plan still on the table, the bipartisan mainstream proposal, isn't half-hearted or half-baked. It could be a real phoenix."
Dr. Shalala agreed. In an interview today, she said: "This is a serious proposal that needs to be looked at very carefully. It reflects a lot of knowledge and a lot of thought. I don't fully understand the financing. It is not the approach we originally favored, but it has the same goals and some of the same themes."
In the House of Representatives, where partisan lines are more sharply drawn, an eerie silence prevailed today. "It's unreal how quiet it is," said a health policy specialist on the House side of the Capitol, who was playing solitaire on his computer terminal. "We're on hold till the powers that be decide what they want to do next."
House Democratic leaders unveiled their health care plan on July 29, and detailed legislative language has been available since Aug. 10. But Democrats have been reluctant to take the bill to the House floor because unofficial vote counts suggest it would not pass in its current form, and many House members want to see if the Senate can agree on anything.
 
50-50 Chance of Passage
 Dr. Paul M. Ellwood, president of the Jackson Hole Group, said today: "We have better than a 50-50 chance of getting passage of health reform legislation based on the mainstream proposal this year. The Administration has constructed a solid rationale for accepting it, namely, this doesn't do any harm, and it's a first step toward longer-range objectives.
"The discussion, as usual at Jackson Hole, was mainly based on the question, 'Will it work?' I don't think we spent three minutes on politics. Our members thought it would work from top to bottom. These are very significant reforms. They're modest only by comparison with what President Clinton proposed."
But Julie L. Gackenbach, a lobbyist for the Chamber of Commerce, said businesses disliked the part of the proposal requiring companies to offer at least three health plans to employees. In addition, she said, "The mainstream proposal takes away the employer's flexibility to design a health plan that meets the employees' needs," because it would require companies to offer benefit packages prescribed by the Government.
Ms. Gackenbach said companies with 100 or fewer employees disliked the mainstream proposal because it would prevent them from serving as their own insurers. This ban would disrupt the health insurance arrangements of many small companies that are now self-insured, she said.
The chamber and other business groups also object to the Chafee-Breaux proposal because it would limit the ability of employers to take tax deductions for employee health benefits. The maximum deduction would be 10 percent above the average cost of health plans in the local market.
Mr. Chafee and Mr. Breaux say this limit would encourage employers and employees to choose lower-cost health plans. But employers denounce it as a new tax.
The bipartisan proposal would also restrict medical malpractice litigation, which doctors say contributes to rising health costs. The proposal says patients injured as a result of a doctor's negligence could not recover more than $250,000 for pain and suffering. It would also limit punitive damages and fees for plaintiffs' lawyers.
The Association of Trial Lawyers of America, one of the more influential lobbies on Capitol Hill, is fighting these proposals. Linda A. Lipsen, a lobbyist for the association, said: "The proposals frustrate people's rights to seek remedies when they've been injured. Medical negligence is rare, but when it occurs, consumers should be able to get full damages."
On the other hand, Frederick H. Graefe, a Washington lawyer who represents hospital insurance companies, praised the malpractice proposals, saying they would "reduce medical costs by reducing defensive medicine," the tests that doctors do to protect themselves against lawsuits.
Another section of the Chafee-Breaux proposal would give consumers new rights to challenge the denial of health insurance benefits. The Labor Secretary could impose a civil penalty of $750,000 on a health plan that repeatedly denied claims "without any reasonable basis."
In several decisions over the last decade, the Supreme Court has severely restricted the rights of consumers to recover damages when their claims were improperly denied or delayed by insurers.

HEADLINE: Reports Imply Somewhat Faster Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
The barrage of late-summer statistics pointing to slackened economic growth now exhibits a pattern that could imply somewhat faster inflation as well, according to various Government and private-sector reports published today.
While not yet setting off alarms, the price pressures seem to support the persistent credit-tightening by the Federal Reserve this year in its effort to prevent inflation from accelerating. 
 Today, corporate purchasing managers in both the Chicago and New York areas reported higher readings for August in their indexes of prices paid, while a Commerce Department tally showed a sharp jump for July in the price of materials particularly sensitive to the pace of business activity.
Indeed, excluding the price component, The department's index of leading indicators, which is designed to predict the course of the economy at large, has not risen at all since March. Higher prices for so-called sensitive materials, though not necessarily welcomed, are regarded as a harbinger of a stronger economy.
"We believe that inflation likely will surprise on the upside," Salomon Brothers told clients today, contending that the Federal Reserve would likely raise interest rates again at its November policy meeting.
In still another report today, the Commerce Department said new orders for factory goods fell 2.3 percent in July, the first decline since February. Nearly all the drop reflected durable goods, which were estimated last week to have skidded 4.2 percent and now show a 4.3 percent drop. Orders for nondurables, goods lasting less than three years, eased one-tenth of 1 percent.
Although reports of purchasing managers are seen by some analysts as unreliable inflation gauges -- as poor predictors of the present, much less the future -- the Chicago group raised eyebrows in citing "tremendous strength" in prices paid as this index jumped to 79.3 from 71.9 in July. Production also rose sharply, to 75.2 from 69.9, while new orders showed a small decline.
The New York chapter of the National Association of Purchasing Management said, meanwhile, that its price index climbed three points, to 60 percent, in August to match the highest reading since the survey began in mid-1993. A sharply higher proportion of members -- 58 percent, up from 50 percent -- reported slower deliveries from suppliers.
Still, analysts were not yet inclined to argue with the Clinton Administration in asserting that the economy remained in a healthy deceleration to a pace approximating its long-term potential.
Everett M. Ehrlich, the Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, called today's figures "consistent with a no-surprises growth path" with scant evidence of revived inflation.
The department's forecasting index, which was unchanged in July after negligible gains in May and June, showed 6 of 11 components pressing downward while only two components besides sensitive materials prices made positive contributions. The other two, the money supply and order backlogs of factory durables, changed so little that their effect rounded to zero.
The negatives were lower orders for manufactured consumer goods, sagging consumer expectations, faster deliveries to companies from their suppliers, a shorter workweek, a decline in contracts and orders for plant and equipment and lower stock prices.
The positive elements were the huge jump in the price of sensitive materials, a small rise in building permits and a small decline in first-time claims for unemployment insurance.
 
Other Indexes Mixed
 Two companion indexes were narrowly mixed. Coincident indicators, which generally change direction at the same time as the economy at large, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July while lagging indicators edged down one-tenth of 1 percent.
"We're looking for fairly modest growth in the second half" of about 2 1/2 percent, said Michael W. Keran, chief economist for the Prudential Insurance Company. He added that while job growth would be stronger than most analysts foresee, inflation worries were unfounded.
"They're not very good indicators of future inflation," Mr. Keran said of the price figures reported by purchasing managers.

HEADLINE: In Hartford, an Insider, and Proud of It

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Aug. 31

 BODY:
In a state that has recently been fertile ground for insurgent candidates attacking the political system, John B. Larson's campaign for governor is preaching a novel message: Government works.
In conversations with voters, Mr. Larson, the Democratic president pro tem of the State Senate, rattles off his legislative accomplishments to counter complaints that government is a quagmire. His commercials focus on his efforts to pass laws to immunize children, provide family medical leaves and ban assault weapons. 
 And while Mr. Larson acknowledges that unemployment, high taxes, crime and faltering schools are plaguing Connecticut, his stump speeches emphasize that it will take a skilled insider to deal with those problems.
"These days, a lot of candidates do a good job of scaring people, portraying government as a hydra-headed beast," he said in an interview. "But we're just regular people trying to do the best we can. I'm proud of what I've done, and I'll stand by it."
It is a position that contrasts sharply with some of the most successful campaigns of the last four years. In 1990, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was elected governor on a third-party ticket, promising to turn the political world upside down. Two years later, Jerry Brown, the former California governor, won the state's Democratic presidential primary with a much more radical version of the same message.
 
A Tough Primary
 This year, Mr. Larson faces a tough Sept. 13 primary against State Comptroller William E. Curry, a self-styled outsider who hopes to tap voter dissatisfaction with the leadership of the state government. The two men come from different wings of the Democratic Party, with Mr. Larson winning the party organization's endorsement, and Mr. Curry being a favorite of progressives and grassroots citizens groups.
The winner of the primary will join a three-way race, including the winner of the Republican primary between former United States Representative John Rowland and Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer and the nominee of Mr. Weicker's A Connecticut Party, Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark.
Mr. Larson announced his plans to run for governor more than a year ago, and since then he has been cultivating an image as an effective legislator in touch with working families. He has spent more than $500,000 on commercials with the tagline, "Listening, leading, getting things done."
The commercials cut back and forth between shots of Mr. Larson working as a legislator -- swinging the gavel and writing at his desk -- and Mr. Larson out talking to people. One biographical spot ends with the lines: "We know he'll fight for us because he's one of us. We know he'll get things done, because he already has."
In his stump speeches and meetings with voters, Mr. Larson offers a long list of the bills he has passed.
He regularly cites the family and medical leave bill, the first in the nation to allow parents to take a leave of absence from work to deal with medical emergencies. He often refers to his efforts to protect special benefits for the elderly to buy medicine, his success in promoting Head Start programs and his work in establishing family resource centers in Connecticut schools to offer day care and other social services to parents.
 
Sturdy Democratic Themes
 Michael Meotti, a State Senator who supports Mr. Curry, said: "John's message is a very traditional Democratic message -- a great deal of concern about social services and state services that give you the boost up the ladder, the helping hand in government. There clearly is a link between John and the themes that most Democratic candidates have used for much of the post-World War II generation."
In campaign appearances, Mr. Larson, 46, often begins by describing his background as a "product of public housing, public schools and public service." One of eight children, the son of a firefighter at Pratt & Whitney Aircraft, he grew up in a Federal housing project in East Hartford and was a star quarterback in high school.
He has never left that blue-collar town, and in campaigning, he appears to relish spending time with workers like those he grew up around. On Saturday, he perked up noticeably when he arrived at a carpenters' union picnic in West Haven.
"I could stay with those guys all day," he remarked later, after reminiscing about high school sports with several men.
 
A Package of Incentives
 "This campaign is about jobs," he told the carpenters, and he drew loud cheers when he promised that, under him the state would not be hiring out-of-state companies.
Mr. Larson has proposed a package of incentives to spur economic growth and talks about turning Connecticut into a cradle for high-technology industry. In one speech, he said that bringing the "information superhighway" into the public schools would be the equivalent of the New Deal's W.P.A. program, and that completing major highway projects would give the economy a boost.
The jobs package includes tax incentives for small businesses and a 25 percent cut in the income tax for middle-class families, using $287 million in savings from pared-down computer operations, revised agreement with government contractors, more efficient management and monies no longer needed to repay the state's debts.
 
A Dissenting View
 But Richard T. Mulready, co-chairman of the General Assembly's finance committee and a Democrat who has not taken sides in the primary race, said the specifics of Mr. Larson's income-tax proposal "did not add up."
And Mr. Curry's criticism of Mr. Larson goes even deeper, into a questioning of his leadership ability.
In debates between the two, Mr. Curry pointed out that Mr. Larson presided over the State Senate in the late 1980's as Connecticut raised taxes and racked up the largest deficit in proportion to its budget of any state in the nation.
And he questioned the relevance of Mr. Larson's repetition of the bills he had passed. "Are any of these initiatives making a difference in people's lives?" Mr. Curry asked.
 
Opponents With Similarities
 But supporters of both men say their similarities are greater than their differences. Both talk about hiring more police officers, holding down taxes, improving child care services and schools and saving more state funds through better management.
A Quinnipiac College Poll of 602 registered voters earlier this month showed Mr. Larson ahead in the race with the support of 23 percent of registered Democrats to 9 percent for Mr. Curry. (The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percentage points.)
But the large number of undecided voters and the difficulty in predicting the turnout for a primary makes it hard to handicap the race.
Kevin Sullivan, a State Senator and Larson supporter, said the primary may test voters' attitude toward government.
"I think people may be tired of candidates who run against the system," he said. "John is clearly in a different school."

HEADLINE: Ben Chavis Wasn't The Problem

BYLINE: By Michael Eric Dyson; Michael Eric Dyson, professor of communication at the University of North Carolina, is author of the forthcoming "Making Malcolm: The Myth and Meaning of Malcolm X."

DATELINE: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

 BODY:
If the N.A.A.C.P. thinks it has solved its problems by dismissing Benjamin Chavis as executive director, it is avoiding a couple of tough lessons. First, it has lost touch with many African-Americans, especially the working-class and the permanently poor. Second, it has strayed way too far from its radical roots.
The N.A.A.C.P., like most civil rights groups, made racism its focus in combating the forces of inequality that strangled opportunities for blacks at the beginning of this century. Its specialty of attack was painstakingly shaped in our nation's courtrooms. Its piece de resistance -- the legal brief -- was fashioned by scholars and advocates like Charles Houston and Thurgood Marshall, who raised the defense of black interests to high, dramatic art. The results were sometimes revolutionary. 
 One was the monumental decision in Brown v. Board of Education -- the nation celebrated its 40th anniversary this year -- which attacked the destructive myth of separate but equal schools. With such cases, the N.A.A.C.P.'s place in history is guaranteed.
But times have worsened for the people the organization so nobly defended. Racism undeniably continues to haunt and hurt black lives. Its lethal trace can be discerned despite subtle changes in the DNA of racial bigotry. But a specter hardly anticipated in the heyday of the civil rights movement has tragically materialized.
Sharp class divisions, which were masked and partially absorbed by the illusory uniformity imposed on black life under segregation, have ripped black communities apart. The gulf between have-gots and have-nots has only widened with the strategies the N.A.A.C.P. used to bring blacks into the economic mainstream. An unintended consequence of its success has been the trumpeting of differences among our nation's blacks even as it sought the social ground for common experiences between the races.
Until Mr. Chavis was hired, this fact seemed lost on the N.A.A.C.P. Increasingly consumed with its corporate financing, the organization lost track of its less fortunate kin. The rank and file may have been working class, but its public face flashed the smile of smug bourgeois achievement.
Meanwhile, the poor, and particularly black youth, came under attack in political arguments that blamed their failures on their "pathological" culture, as seen in teen pregnancy, welfare dependency and violence.
Like most black institutions limited by an exhausted liberal vocabulary, the N.A.A.C.P. had little energy or inclination to defend people whose experience was alien to its core constituency. For many poor and young blacks, it has become a relic, an ethnosaur.
Mr. Chavis's elevation promised a new day in the N.A.A.C.P., with someone who would swell membership rolls with the young and disaffected. But as he reached out to gang members, rappers and controversial leaders like Louis Farrakhan, he curried disfavor with the organization's elite and mainstream black leaders. His critics arsaid he was aborting the group's traditional goals of mainstream acceptance and interracial cooperation.
But such logic reveals a huge non sequitur. Dialogue is not capitulation; conversation is not conversion. When black leaders speak to one another, even argue with one another, that doesn't mean they can't do the same with white allies. The idea that Mr. Chavis should not have met with or talked to certain kinds of blacks is a poisonous surrender; after all, during the civil rights movement, black leaders often met with white figures who were explicitly, violently racist.

Even more troubling is the notion that to get along with the nonblack side of its constituency (read wealthy white and corporate donors), the association must steer clear of the vital issues that mold the lives of most black people. If this idea perisists, N.A.A.C.P. will stand for national association for the advancement of corporate privilege, comfortable positions and complacent policies.
Such a fate can be avoided if black people who can afford it will give to political and social organizations. It would then be less likely that groups like the N.A.A.C.P. would be straitjacketed, silenced or bought off by interests inimical to black communities. Such patronage would bolster the prophetic and independent posture these organizations might adopt, especially if they are critical of big businesses and market machinations.
Though many African-Americans are displeased with what happened to Mr. Chavis, how many of us have given recently to the N.A.A.C.P., the National Urban League, the Rainbow Coalition, the Progressive National Baptist Convention and similar groups?
Mr. Chavis may be guilty of poor administration and personal missteps, but he cannot be faulted for trying to change the organization's direction. Its guardians have it only half right when they claim that the N.A.A.C.P. has drifted from its base. They overlook the radical democracy and political progressivism of founding figures like W. E. B. Du Bois. This pioneering historian and cultural critic expressed with eloquence a complex vision of justice and equality.
The N.A.A.C.P. must recapture its radical dimensions precisely because the problems of black Americans -- unemployment and urban violence, neoliberal rebuffs of racial progress and neoconservative assaults on young blacks, economic collapse and revived racism -- are most assuredly not moderate. To insist that the N.A.A.C.P. needs to be its old moderate self once again contradicts its glorious, and radical, legacy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Awe-Struck U.S. Executives Survey the China Market

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 1

 BODY:
John E. Bryson, chairman of the Southern California Edison Company, looked at the power-industry requirements of this country and was staggered by the scale of building that must occur in order to sustain China's extraordinary economic expansion.
"This is the largest power market in the world," says Mr. Bryson, one of 24 American chief executives who accompanied Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown to China over the last week. Mr. Bryson visited China for the first time, though his company's Mission Energy unit is negotiating power-plant deals in three southern Chinese provinces. 
 The American executives who traveled here on an aged Air Force Boeing 707 with Secretary Brown lent their names and corporate prestige to his barnstorming tour for "commercial diplomacy." With the visit ending, Mr. Brown spoke in Hong Kong today of building a new commercial relationship between China and the United States.
The businessmen arrived in China on Saturday with a variety of questions about how to fit their business strategies to the fastest-growing emerging market in the world. They left understanding that the answers to almost any question about succeeding in China are time and money.
During a whirlwind of meetings in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou, the American executives found China's leadership enigmatic, and the notion of political risk never far from their thoughts now that Deng Xiaoping, the country's paramount leader, has passed his 90th birthday.
The businessmen said they were comfortable with President Clinton's new human rights policy, which is based on the idea that sustained development of China's economy will lead to greater political freedom.
"Commerce breeds industry, and as you increase the quality of life of a people, freedom follows," said Edwin Lupberger, a close friend of Mr. Clinton from Arkansas and chairman of the Entergy Corporation, a large electrical utility in the Southern United States.
Herded together as a United States delegation, some of the visiting corporate chiefs seemed lost without their limousines, executive jets and coattails of staff. When their plane broke down on Tuesday, many of them sat in the bar at the China World Hotel and actually wasted time.
In hot and dusty Beijing, there wasn't a power lunch to be had. But these executives know a market when they see one.
Robert S. O'Neil, chief executive of the engineering firm De Leuw, Cather & Company, which helped build the Washington, D.C., subway system, has looked out across China's backward urban landscape and counted 19 subway systems and 82 airports that are moving into design, construction or reconstruction phases in the next few years.
"We know there is a market here for us," Mr. O'Neil said. His firm has been working on Shanghai's subway project since 1987.
 
Highly Competitive Market
 Little of this has been easy. Last winter, his negotiators were close to winning a huge contract to provide engineering services for the subway system in Guangzhou, when Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany "came over here with his concessionary loans and took the contract away from us," Mr. O'Neil said.
His firm, a subsidiary of the Parsons Corporation, has now formed a consortium with other American companies like Motorola and General Railway Signal to compete better by tailoring their integrated products and systems to what China's rail projects are not able to develop domestically, like modern train control systems, communications and operating systems.
Mr. Bryson of Southern California Edison was awe-struck by the statistic that China plans to add 12,000 megawatts of installed power plant capacity each year to keep up with the country's fast-growing demand for electrical power.
"You know in our whole system," Mr. Bryson said of the Southern California region, "we operate 18,000 megawatts of generating capacity." It has taken his company several decades to develop its grid, which is only half again as large as China's annual growth in power.
Other figures bear out Mr. Bryson's enthusiasm. Just to turn the lights on in the thousands of factories rising out of the ground each year in this country, the Ministry of Power must build the equivalent of 15 to 20 large American power stations every 12 months.
Richard J. Swift, chairman of the Foster Wheeler Corporation, has been selling boilers and related equipment to the Chinese since 1984. He figures that the state-owned power industry will be able to manufacture the equipment for about three-quarters of the plants that need to be built each year.
"So you're looking at 2,000 to 3,000 megawatts of outside source power plants per year," Mr. Swift said. Though his company has been just an equipment seller in the past, he said he is now considering teaming up with Mr. Lupberger's Entergy Corporation and Mr. Bryson's Mission Energy to take equity positions in some of China's power-plant projects.
 
Deals Concluded on Trip
 Mr. Lupberger signed one of the many memorandums of understanding here to go forward on a big power deal, though he may be facing a year or more of negotiations over rates of return.
Entergy has agreed to buy into the aging Datong No. 2 power station in Shanxi province west of Beijing and double its capacity from 1,200 megawatts to 2,400 megawatts.
With a Hong Kong partner sharing the risk, Entergy would have a 22 percent stake in the project, putting up $70 million in equity and bringing along nearly $400 million of United States Export-Import Bank financing.
"Our business is not just capital, but technology and expertise," Mr. Lupberger said, "so we bring something to the party other than money."
But the businessmen acknowledged the long road ahead. There is a continuing dispute within the Chinese Government on what kind of profit foreign companies should be allowed to make selling electricity in a country that still considers itself socialist.
"If there is one thing we have learned," Mr. Lupberger said, "it's that the Chinese don't move fast on anything."

Companies
 Why is NBC -- and possibly CBS -- close to being sold to a Hollywood studio? There is one basic answer: for both buyers and sellers, the time is right, and may never be more so. The broadcast business has made a strong financial comeback, and the two studios have powerful incentives to protect their lucrative positions as suppliers of network programming. News Analysis. HEADLINE: Miami Beach Journal;
The Gold Coast Fights for Its Image

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 30

 BODY:
Men who walk the tide line on the white sand, nude-bathing beach here say they have come to look for Cuban refugees washing up on American shores.
Why they gaze inland instead of out to sea is a question that compromises the sincerity of their mission. 
 The nearest Cuban refugees, some 700 of them, are locked up in a detention center nearly 20 miles away, on the edge of the Everglades. But most residents of Greater Miami, population two million, expect it is only a matter of time before they are released and absorbed locally, soon to be followed by tens of thousands more held by the American authorities at Guantanamo Bay and from Cuba proper.
South Florida is still coping with the aftermath of Hurricane Andrew, which struck the peninsula below Miami two years ago this month, and with an epidemic of highly publicized shootings of tourists within the past year. The latest influx of refugees is just one more trial for a metropolitan area that not too long ago promoted itself worldwide as the Gold Coast.
The story of Gerald and Pam McLaughlin testifies to the tarnishing of Miami's image. The couple, artists from the town of Cejax, outside Toronto, said today that they had to overcome their travel agent's objections when they told her they wanted to spend two weeks in South Florida.
"Florida gets a really bad press in Canada," said Mr. McLaughlin, 35, a tall man with gray eyes and a drooping walrus mustache. "All you hear about are tourists being shot."
The McLaughlins were having lunch at Mad Max, a cafe in one of the Art Deco hotels on the southern end of Miami Beach that opens to spill people out on the sidewalk beneath umbrella-topped tables.
Then, in words that could send shudders of pain through local boosters, Mr. McLaughlin said: "Our agent advised against flying into Miami. Much too dangerous, she said. Why didn't we consider flying to Havana for our holiday? Much safer there."
A blood-red parrot with green-tipped wings used as a prop for a sidewalk photographer nearby let out a squawk that could be heard uptown at the Chamber of Commerce.
As it turned out, the couple spent their two-week vacation avoiding the Miami area, stopping in Miami Beach only for lunch before catching a plane home this evening.
But Miami and Miami Beach, like punch-drunk fighters, gamely keep fighting back.
"Those of us who are part of the past, and hopefully part of the future, take these setbacks in stride," said Mayor Seymour Gelber of Miami Beach. "The natural attractions of climate, ocean and beach that brought people here for the better part of a century will continue doing so."
The Mayor says Miami Beach is a gentler place than it was a decade ago. That was when mostly penniless Cuban refugees from the 1980 Mariel boat lift were settled here by public agencies, producing what he said was "an influx of crime and drugs in the South Beach area." South Beach is about a 12-block area at the south end of Miami Beach.
But those same refugees, the Mayor pointed out, are now "part of the success story" of this city of 93,000 people. Most have moved into the work force and contribute to the economic and social vibrancy of Greater Miami, the Mayor said. Crime has dropped in Miami Beach in recent years, and millions of dollars are being spent to rejuvenate the convention and tourism industry, he said.
Lincoln Road, which in the Gold Coast's heyday in the 1950's offered gold-plated shopping at Saks Fifth Avenue and Bergdorf-Goodman, is replacing its reputation for a moribund retail industry with one as a home for the arts. Both the New World Symphony and the Miami Ballet Company use Lincoln Road as a home base. Fittingly, two old tourist hotels, the Plymouth and the Ansonia, are being rebuilt into apartments for the young musicians and dancers.
But starving artists, while good for the soul, did not compensate for the business lost when German tourism dropped 36 percent this year after nine foreign tourists, including one German visitor in Miami, were attacked and killed while vacationing in Florida over the past two years.
Two new hotels, one with 800 rooms and the other with 250, will rise next to the Miami Beach Convention Center, the Mayor said, the first hotels to be built on Miami Beach in 30 years.
And some famous home-grown Floridians have selected South Beach for their restaurants. Burt Reynolds plans to open a new eatery this week not far from the one owned by Gloria Estefan. More important, said Brad Anderson, the 33-year old manager of the Mad Max cafe, who came here three years ago chasing an elusive singing career, more and more young people are being drawn to the area, which previously drew only Social Security pensioners and was dubbed "God's Waiting Room."
Still, all that is happening here is only modest reinvestment, compared with the activity across Biscayne Bay on the mainland.
In non-Hispanic Miami, the name of H. Wayne Huizenga is treated with the same deprecation on some radio talk shows as that dished out to Fidel Castro on the many Spanish-language stations here. Most of the resentment is aimed at the speed with which Mr. Huizenga (pronounced high-ZEEN-geh) has used his $700 million-plus wealth, mainly derived from his ownership and investment in Waste Management Inc. and Blockbuster Video, to snap up three of South Florida's four professional sports franchises -- the Miami Dolphins (football); the Florida Marlins (baseball), and the Florida Panthers (hockey) -- that represent the last icons of diminishing pride in the region.
But it is the tycoon's plan to build a $1 billion sports and entertainment complex on 2,500 acres of wetlands on the fringe of the Everglades that is generating the most acrimony. It may turn out to be the most costly private project in Miami history since receding waters lifted the peninsula from the ocean depths.
Mr. Huizenga sees his project, inevitably dubbed "Wayne's World, as a real competitor to Disney World, the Orlando-area attraction that has been detouring visitors away from South Florida for nearly a quarter of a century and turned the Gold Coast into the Old Coast.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite the influx of Cuban refugees, life goes on in Miami Beach. Patrons ate lunch on Wednesday at the News Cafe on Ocean Drive. (Susan Greenwood for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1745 words

HEADLINE: Tourism Enriches an Island Resort, But Hilton Head Blacks Feel Left Out

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., Aug. 31

 BODY:
One day when he was a small boy and this was an undeveloped dream world of salt marsh, beach front and pine forest where all the inhabitants were black, Gene Wiley saw something he had never seen before -- a white man.
"I mean no disrespect, but I couldn't figure it out -- a nose like Bob Hope, hair that the wind blew all over his face like it didn't have no strength in it," recalls Mr. Wiley, who is 68. "We felt sorry for the guy; we felt like he was the victim of a plague or something. Then one day my father took me to Savannah and the whole damn town was white, and I knew this plague had taken the whole town and pretty soon it would be on Hilton Head Island, too." 
 As Mr. Wiley sees it, his boyhood forebodings have all come true. His island has become overwhelmingly white, in the form of a celebrated resort largely controlled by giant corporations serving affluent vacationers and Northern retirees. As for the few native islanders who have not left Hilton Head, they have largely been pushed to the margins, some of them working in low-paying jobs in the hotels and restaurants that have overtaken the island.
This weekend, though, the presence of Hilton Head's black minority may be more readily recognized, if fleetingly. The reason is an event that will be one in a seemingly endless series of showdowns over the symbolism of the Old South; in this case, a demonstration against flying the Confederate battle flag over the state Capitol in Columbia.
Blacks, many coming in buses from the mainland and led by the state branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, will march on Saturday. They are threatening to call for an economic boycott of the state unless the flag comes down; Hilton Head was chosen for the demonstration because of its lucrative tourist industry. Whites, who will hold a countermarch the next day, say removing the flag would be an insult to their heritage.
Tourism officials here are exasperated. They say that Hilton Head has nothing to do with the flag dispute and that the marches and the proposed boycott will hurt not only the tourism industry here but also the blacks who work in it. And yet the demonstrations are more than a fight over historic symbols. The marches will also serve as a reminder that to a large extent, even on this generically upscale resort island, the discontent and tensions that the South has always known are alive and just beneath the surface, unresolved.
 
The Ever-Present Plantation
 Once, blacks picked the long-strand cotton and worked the fields here among the South Carolina Sea Islands. Now, they clean linens, scrape deviled crabs off dirty plates and trim azaleas on private, gated resorts with names like Shipyard Plantation, Port Royal Plantation, Wexford Plantation, Colleton River Plantation and Hilton Head Plantation.
"The concept of the plantation hasn't changed," said Billie Burn, a landowner and local historian on Daufuskie Island, just across Calibogue Sound. "It's just reversed places. It used to be you couldn't get off the plantations. Now you can't get on."
To be sure, many blacks have shared in the prosperity. Those on the plantations include wealthy blacks like the sports star Michael Jordan, who has a house here. The N.A.A.C.P. recently held a convention on Hilton Head. But for many blacks, development has meant only low-wage jobs and displacement.
"I used to be in the resort industry myself until I realized just how apartheid-like our system is here," said Bill Ferguson, Hilton Head's only black town council member, who owns a landscaping design business. "Those who have money and wealth have not paved the way or even allowed the local people to take part in economic development and become self-sufficient or self-sustaining."
 
Civil War Watershed
 Before the Civil War, the Sea Islands were home to some of the wealthiest plantations in the South. But that world ended seven months after the fall of Fort Sumter, when landowners fleeing Union gunboats left behind 10,000 slaves who began a precarious existence as freed men and women.
After the war, some blacks remained on plantations as hired help. But many, particularly on Hilton Head, bought land and lived and worked in self-contained communities, many of which spoke the lilting mixture of English and African dialects known as Gullah.
Reachable only by boat until the 1930's, the Sea Islands remained largely isolated until well into the 1950's, when the development began on Hilton Head. Since then the population of the islands has exploded. Hilton Head alone has a permanent population of about 28,000, about 2,300 of them native black islanders.
Unlike most of seaside resorts in the United States, the South Carolina coast has a sizable black population. According to the Penn Center, founded on St. Helena Island in 1862 as the nation's first school for former slaves and now an educational and advocacy group, blacks still make up 36 percent of the coastal population in the state. If heavily white Hilton Head is discounted, the figure is 43 percent.
But the proportions are rapidly changing. The white population on the South Carolina coast increased by 72 percent from 1980 to 1990. The black population grew by 1 percent. Overall, blacks earn about a third of what whites earn.
 
The Tourists Arrive
 Nostalgia aside, the Sea Islands have never been a utopia. Minus air conditioning and luxury condominiums, they were places where the heat, mosquitoes and rattlesnakes were as much a part of life as the warm sun and bountiful sea. For decades, young people have been leaving to look for work. Most of those who stayed lived in poverty.
Many people, black and white, say the tourist boom has finally provided the jobs that can allow many people to stay on the island.
"Unemployment in Beaufort County is at record lows," said Cliff Charnes, chairman of the Hilton Head Visitors and Convention Bureau and president of the Sea Pines Company, the pioneer developer on Hilton Head. "You might go three counties inland, and it may be a 12-to-15 percent unemployment. Here it might be 2 to 3 percent. In every way I can think of, the life style is healthier and economically more solid in the coastal communities than inland across the South."
Ronald Stewart works at one of the hotels as a maintenance supervisor by day and drives a cab at night. He finds the "plantation" terminology demeaning but said he felt lucky to be able to work and rear his children on Hilton Head. "I wouldn't live anywhere else," he said.
Still, few places have institutionalized inequality to the degree that Hilton Head has. Because most services are provided by the plantations themselves, there are two Hilton Heads, the luxury world inside the plantations and the world outside, where residents are still seeking municipal water, sewer service and paved roads. Because of growth restrictions, much of the land owned by blacks cannot be fully developed.
For many who work on Hilton Head but live elsewhere, the situation is worse. Often a job means a three-hour commute each way, resulting in a workday that is longer than when work was done in the fields.
Wilhelmina Green, 45 years old, has six children and one grandchild and a husband who gets medical disability payments. She leaves her home on St. Helena Island about 1 P.M. for her job as a kitchen worker on Hilton Head. She catches the bus that serves the plantations, riding for three hours on a bus full of other black cooks, dishwashers, maids and waitresses. She arrives about 4 P.M. and works in a restaurant on one of the plantations until midnight. With less traffic late at night, she gets home about 2 A.M. Her pay: $6.50 an hour, with benefits.
Some black residents who have sold their land have made out well. Many have not. As the islands have been developed, taxes have skyrocketed, forcing some blacks to sell off their land or see it auctioned off for back taxes.
Similarly, loses are incurred on many properties called heirs' properties, land held in the name of the estate of the original landowner, often going back to the 19th century. Under South Carolina law, if one heir chooses to sell his interest, the buyer can have the entire property sold at auction to get his portion. As a result, developers often seek out distant heirs, often finding them out of state. The developers offer modest amounts for the heir's share of the property and then force a partition sale for the rest, at which they can expect to be the top bidder.
"They don't want black people around," said Mr. Wiley, a former member of Hilton Head's planning commission. "They want you to live on the mainland in some housing project, put a badge on you with your picture on it, come on a bus to work and then get the hell off."
 
Daufuskie's Example
 Most island blacks, including James Mitchell, a financial consultant and head of Hilton Head's N.A.A.C.P. group, say that development overall has been good for the island but that not enough has been done to allow blacks to participate fully. In that sense, Mr. Mitchell said, the flag protest reflects the same struggle for respect that African-Americans routinely face.
For a worst-case example, Hilton Head's blacks need only look across the water to Daufuskie. The island was once largely black, but its native population has been in decline since 1959, when pollution from the Savannah River ruined the shellfish beds that were the basis of its economy. Now, the old road to the beach has been closed and a new one rerouted around a golf course. The old African-American cemeteries are hidden on the edges of golf course fairways, and only about 60 old-time residents live outside the plantations that are the island's future.
One day this summer, Yvonne Wilson, whose roots on the island date from the time of slavery, drove her pickup on the unpaved roads from the dense, green glades of the old Daufuskie to the manicured fairways of the new one, giving a history tour as she went. She passed the remains of slave quarters, the 127-year-old United Baptist Church, the brick ruins that once served improbably as the local jail, and the Silver Dew winery.
"I want to make sure my kids can be a part of this as well," she said. "My biggest fear is that before long, we'll all be gone, and other than a marker here or a graveyard there, there will be nothing left to say that at one time black people were ever here."

HEADLINE: North Korea Invites Carter To Mediate

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Kim Jong Il, the reclusive Communist leader who is expected to succeed his father as absolute ruler of North Korea, has sent a letter to former President Jimmy Carter inviting him to Pyongyang to mediate the dispute with the United States over the North's nuclear ambitions, American officials said today.
The reports on the invitation are part of a slow broadening of contacts with North Korea, as the United States leads efforts to halt Pyongyang's suspected nuclear weapons program and North Korea seeks to end its isolation with economic assistance and broader diplomatic recognition. As part of that process, the Clinton Administration announced today that, as expected, it would begin technical discussions with North Korea on Sept. 10 to fill out some of the details of an agreement reached between the two countries last month in Geneva. 
 Clinton Administration officials said that one group will meet in Pyongyang to discuss how the two countries will establish liaison offices in each others' capitals, a step toward diplomatic recognition. Another group will meet in Berlin to discuss details of North Korea's request that the United States supply a modern, light water nuclear reactor to generate electricity and replace North Korea's existing nuclear facilities.
Though Mr. Carter has reportedly not yet accepted the invitation, his second in recent months, the letter gave some insight into the thinking of Mr. Kim, who dropped out of sight shortly after his father, Kim Il Sung, died in early July.
Mr. Kim reportedly indicated in the letter that he would continue to follow the flexible policy on the nuclear issue that his father adopted shortly before his death from a heart attack. But he expressed no interest in rescheduling what would have been a first meeting with the South Korean President, Kim Young Sam.
The invitation was reported here today in a major daily newspaper, the Joong Ang Daily News, and was confirmed by an American official in Washington, who said that the letter had been received several weeks ago and that Mr. Carter had yet to accept the invitation. Mr. Carter is reportedly in Liberia, where he is expected to help mediate a bloody dispute between feuding tribal groups.
But it was clear that the American Government -- which, thanks to an earlier effort by Mr. Carter, is already engaged in high-level negotiations with North Korea -- was unenthusiastic about the prospect of Mr. Carter's opening a new and uncertain channel to the Government in North Korea. The South Korean Government has been little short of hostile to the idea and to Mr. Carter personally.
 
A Negative View
 "This has to be looked at a little negatively," a South Korean official said. "At this stage, what can he do in Pyongyang? Clearly, North Korea has been trying to drive a wedge between the United States and South Korea."
In Edgartown, Mass., a senior aide to President Clinton said today that the White House understood that Mr. Carter had a standing invitation from North Korea to return there, but that the former President had no plans to travel there in the foreseeable future.
The White House also sought to play down the significance of the talks between the United States and North Korea that are to begin Sept. 10 in Pyongyang. Dee Dee Myers, a spokeswoman for Mr. Clinton, said in Edgartown that the discussions about the possible opening of an American liaison office in North Korea were intended simply "to allow us to be prepared" if the dispute over nuclear weapons is resolved.
"This is not any kind of diplomatic conversation," Ms. Myers said. "It is a technical conversation." She said the purpose of discussing logistical arrangements was that "if a decision was made to open a liaison office, we would have enough information to be able to move forward quickly."
Separate talks are also to begin in Berlin on Sept. 10, and will focus on providing North Korea with technology to build a safer nuclear reactor. The high-level talks between the two countries are to resume on Sept. 23 in Geneva, Ms. Myers said.
Relations with North Korea have been in a tense and critical phase for 18 months, ever since North Korea refused inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency access to nuclear sites. The refusal stoked fears that North Korea was producing plutonium for building nuclear bombs. The C.I.A. estimates that North Korea already has the materials to build two nuclear bombs.
 
Carter Visited in June
 The United States threatened to impose economic sanctions if North Korea kept its sites closed, and North Korea warned that such action would be taken as an act of war.
In June, Mr. Carter visited Pyongyang and met with Kim Il Sung. Mr. Carter's effort was played down in both South Korea and Washington because of worries that he was overly sympathetic to North Korea's view, but he seemed to have extracted several concessions from Mr. Kim that led to a new opening.
North Korea agreed to freeze its nuclear program and to allow inspectors to monitor where some spent reactor fuel rods were being stored. In return, the United States agreed to resume negotiations with the North Koreans without other conditions.

HEADLINE: Stocks Down For 2d Day; Dow Off 11.98

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
For the second consecutive day, the stock market pulled back from recent gains and closed down on leading indexes -- especially the Nasdaq composite index, which has a large number of high-technology stocks that were hurt by a troubled outlook for the computer business. Bond prices were steady, and the dollar fell.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 11.98 points, to 3,901.44, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 2.32 points, to 473.17. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index fell a steep 6.67 points, to 758.95. 
 In the last two days, the Dow has fallen nearly 16 points. But the market often rallies, however modestly, on the Friday before the long Labor Day weekend. Last year, for example, the Dow rose nearly 8 points, to 3,633.93.
 
Employment Data Due
 This morning, before the stock market opens at 9:30, traders will scrutinize the Labor Department's report on employment. Wall Street economists have had a poor record of predicting the volatile unemployment rate and other jobless data, so the market could be surprised by the figures.
A higher-than-expected figure implies a slowing economy and would be bullish for bonds and for some stocks, but a lower-than-expected figure implies possible inflationary pressures and would be bearish for both stocks and bonds because a too-strong economy could prompt further rate increases from the Federal Reserve. The consensus Wall Street estimate is for an August rate of 6.1 percent, unchanged from July.
Technology stocks were the newsmakers yesterday, with four of the top five industries in the Standard & Poor's 500 showing major price declines coming from high-technology areas. They were semiconductors, software, computer systems and local telephone companies, which are major purchasers of computer equipment.
The exception was the top price mover, electric utilities, whose shares were hurt, in part, when an analyst at CS First Boston lowered his assessments to "sell" on Consolidated Edison and Niagara Mohawk Power. The analyst noted that the New York Public Service Commission staff had recommended to regulators a rate cut for Niagara, which could affect Con Ed's pending rate case.
 
Decline for AST
 Of the technology stocks, AST Research, a large maker of personal computers, showed one of the sharpest falls, down 415/16 , to 131/16 , after AST warned that product delays and lower prices for computers would hurt results in the quarter ending on Sept. 30. AST, which was the most active stock yesterday at 14.9 million shares, made the announcement after the market closed on Wednesday. The AST announcement called into question whether industry sales would rise over the next few months.
The AST warning also cast a pall on a wide range of computer-related stocks, including Compaq, which fell 2 1/4, to 35; Microsoft, down 2, to 56 1/8; Intel, down 1 1/2, to 64 1/4, and Cisco Systems, down 5/16 , to 24 1/2.

LENGTH: 1430 words

HEADLINE: Lawyers' Repute Has Faded, but Desire to Be One Hasn't

BYLINE: CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Adam Bonin has read all the horror stories about lawyers -- how hard they work, how little respect they get, how thankless their profession has become. Yet from the first time he saw "L.A. Law," Mr. Bonin says, he knew he wanted to be a lawyer.
"That show made law look so cool," said Mr. Bonin, a 21-year-old Philadelphian recently accepted by the University of Chicago Law School. "I like being on the spot and being in the spotlight, and that means law or politics." 
 Becky Pennell, 23, of Richmond, Wash., who is at Stanford Law School, takes the cautionary tales about the profession more to heart. But Ms. Pennell said she planned to work with the homeless and did not think the public images of lawyers would apply to her.
"Yes, it's discouraging when people don't differentiate between ambulance chasers and legal aid attorneys," she said. "But in public interest law you are not working to get more billable hours or to make partner, but to have a positive impact on the world."
It is almost impossible to pick up a law journal without reading yet another story about how miserable the lot of lawyers has become. They work 80 hours a week or more, yet their chances of making partner are getting slimmer every day. Many feel like hypocrites, increasingly forced to defend, say, environmental polluters by day, even if they attend Sierra Club meetings by night. In place of the respect once accorded lawyers, they cannot attend a cocktail party without hearing yet another lawyer joke.
 
No Dearth of Law Students
 In such an environment, law schools should be facing a tough sell to undergraduates wary of spending three years and probably close to $90,000 to pursue a reviled profession.
And in fact, the flood of would-be lawyers has declined to about 85,000 this year from a peak of 94,000 in 1991, according to the Law School Admission Council.
But such drops can easily be pegged to the economy and the aging of the nation's population. And at the top schools, applications are stable or even rising.
"We're going to be in business for a while," said Nan McNamara, assistant dean for admissions at New York University School of Law, whose applications were up this year.
At Yale Law School, officials are bracing for too many students. While applications are holding steady, the yield -- the number of students a school accepts who actually enroll -- turned out to be 217, instead of the 175 students Yale had expected.
"Our yield rate has been going up each year," said Jean K. Webb, Yale Law School's director of admissions. "Is it the recession? Is it the continued belief that lawyers get high salaries? Is it a spillover from the medical profession, where morale is even worse? We've looked at all these possible reasons, and the truth is, we don't know what it is."
Gerald L. Wilson, a pre-law adviser at Duke University's Trinity College, where more than 20 percent of the graduating class goes on to law school, said of the applicants, "They all know the job market is bleak, the profession is changing, but each one thinks he or she will be the exception.".
Law school admissions deans say they are picking up the same attitude. "None of our applicants are saying, 'Gee, I didn't know there are unhappy lawyers out there,' " said Richard I. Badger, dean of students and head of the admissions committee at the University of Chicago Law School, where applications were up 8 percent this year. "They say they know what they want to do and these other unhappy people did not."
In interviews, admissions deans and law students said that many students assumed, with some justification, that backbreaking hours and backbiting environments are largely the hallmarks of big-city law firms handling huge corporate cases. These students are looking to careers in public interest law, as legal aid lawyers or environmental advocates, for example, or to careers with smaller firms in medium-sized cities.
At Stanford, for example, the proportion of students joining law firms immediately after graduation has decreased by about 9 percent over the last five years, while the proportion going to judicial clerkships has increased 7 percent and the proportion going into public interest law is up 3 percent.
"Students increasingly realize that what they are losing financially by going into public service, they are getting back in triplicate in job satisfaction," said Madeline Kochen, director of public interest law programs at Stanford.
Even students going into conventional law firms insist that they can find the ones that will not force them into moral dilemmas.
Kevin J. O'Connor, 27, who will graduate from Rutgers University School of Law at Newark next year, has already accepted a job with Porzio, Bromberg & Newman in Morristown, N.J. Mr. O'Connor says "everyone seems happy" at the the 40-member corporate law firm, which specializes in litigation and environmental law.
He added: "I don't think I will feel uncomfortable defending corporations in product liability suits. It is the plaintiffs' attorneys who usually bring the cases without merit."
Indeed, law students seem to have a penchant for differentiating between "them" (the lawyers who give the profession a bad name) and "us" (those who will restore the law to its former prestige).
Amy C. Hagen, 24, of Troy, Mich., worked as a paralegal in a New York firm before joining the Class of '97 at Chicago Law School. The 90-hour weeks she saw people working did not faze her, and the work excited her. "Even my father believes all lawyers are crooks, and that can be pretty discouraging," Ms. Hagen said. "But I learned that the lawyers solving corporate problems or negotiating mergers and acquisitions are not the same ambulance-chasing lawyers doing infomercials on television."
 
A Professional Accessory
 There was a time, admissions deans say, when paralegal experience was about the only experience that law students had. No more.
"We get nurses interested in malpractice law or bioethics, psychiatrists who want to be expert witnesses, engineers and military officers driven to intellectual property law by defense cutbacks, all kinds of people who fear their careers are stagnating," said Giles W. Kennedy, director of law admissions at the University of Georgia School of Law.
Mark Rozman, a 26-year-old electrical engineer from Haverhill, Mass., is a case in point. He knows that law jobs are getting harder to find. But he does not see much future in his current job with a military contractor.
"Sure the bad publicity about the job market and the erosion of prestige scares me, but I'm hoping patent law will be different," said Mr. Rozman, who is studying intellectual property law at Georgia. "And down here in the South, the pay may be lower, but so is the stress."
Actually, many older students now in law school say they do not intend to practice law at all. They see the extra degree as a way to make themselves more valuable in their current jobs, and thus shield themselves from employee cutbacks.
"Many of our students plan to go back to their jobs and do copyright research or offer patent advice, without ever even taking the bar," said Olga Hunczak, director of admissions at the Rutgers law school. "They are not worried about getting a job; they have a job. In fact, many of their companies paid their tuition."
 
'A Delaying Tactic'
 Others see it as a way to postpone making career decisions. "For many, law school is a delaying tactic, a holding pattern," said Mr. Wilson of Duke. "Even if they don't practice law, they feel a law degree is a marketable credential, where a Ph.D. in English is not."
Part of that holding-pattern mentality is driven by the fairly bleak job market for college graduates. And students who decide in their senior year that they need more education have a pretty narrow field of choice.
"They can't go to med school because they haven't taken physics and chemistry, and business schools almost always require a lot of work experience," said Faye Deal, director of admissions and financial aid at Stanford Law School. "In a sense, for these students a law degree is the most accessible choice."
It is also, other school officials point out, an intellectually stimulating environment. And they say that jokes notwithstanding, lawyers still command their share of respect. "Society has a love/hate relationship with the legal profession," Mr. Wilson of Duke noted. "We may hate lawyers in the aggregate, but as individuals they are still the ones we choose as our community leaders."

HEADLINE: 11 Stowaways Found on Ship In Container

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Sept. 1

 BODY:
Eleven stowaways endured four days locked in an oven-hot shipping container with little food or water and no bedding, apparently dreaming that their voyage from the Caribbean to the United States would bring good jobs. But it appears that all they will get for their agony is a quick trip home to the Dominican Republic.
The 11 were discovered this morning when a deckhand aboard the Carolina at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal heard them yelling and pounding on the sides of the container, which was stacked about 40 feet above the deck. Firefighters, ambulance technicians and seamen let the stowaways -- 10 men and a woman -- out of the container before dawn today. 
 None of the stowaways have requested political asylum, officials of the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today, which means that they will almost certainly be sent back immediately to the Dominican Republic.
"They were emaciated," said Paul Visoskas, head of an emergency rescue team from University Hospital here. "I don't know how they survived. God only knows what those people must have suffered, with the heat and the ship rolling on the ocean."
 
Three Days at Sea in Foul Box
 Capt. John J. Reinke of the Port Authority police said three of the 11 were semiconscious when rescue teams took them from the foul-smelling container shortly before 3:15 A.M. today.
"They were all very scared and all very weak," Captain Reinke said.
The 11, who ranged in age from 18 to 53, had endured three days at sea in the container and another at the dock in Elizabeth before help came. About three-fourths of the container was filled with boxes of clothing, leaving the 11 squeezed during their journey into a little cubicle measuring perhaps 8 by 10 feet, the captain said.
Daytime temperatures may have reached 130 degrees, said Dr. Arthur Calise, who treated four of the stowaways at Newark Beth Israel Medical Center here. What little food and water they took into the container at the port of Rio Haina in the Dominican Republic on Saturday night was gone by Monday, two days before the Carolina docked in Elizabeth, Nancy Pacheco, a nurse at the medical center, said.
 
Deportation Being Arranged
 Four of the 11 remained hospitalized tonight, including the oldest stowaway, Juan Feliz, 53, a diabetic. Officials at Newark Beth Israel Medical Center said he was suffering from severe dehydration and would require perhaps two more days of medical care. All the others suffered milder degrees of dehydration.
The seven who were treated and released during the day were questioned immediately by agents of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. By early this evening, none had requested political asylum in the United States, paving the way for the agency to order them returned to their homeland in short order.
During an afternoon news conference, William R. Tillman, deputy director of the immigration office here, said preparations were under way to return them on the Carolina when she sails from Elizabeth for the Dominican Republic at 10:30 P.M. Friday. But tonight, Mr. Tillman said that those released from hospitals might possibly be flown home.
The owner of the Carolina, Puerto Rican Marine Management Inc. of Edison, N.J., is responsible for paying for their return trip under immigration law. If it does not return them, the company is subject to a fine of $3,000 per stowaway.
Mr. Tillman said the return could be delayed if any of the stowaways asked for asylum while still in the United States. If such a request were made, he said, the agency would take formal custody of the stowaways from the ship's owner until a hearing had been held by an immigration judge. The stowaways' upkeep pending the hearing would be paid by the immigration agency.
Until a policy change this month, the I.N.S. had required the owner of a ship or plane that stowaways took to the United States to pay for their food and lodging before asylum hearings.
 
Eligibility Seems Unlikely
 Mr. Tillman said he doubted any of the 11 would seek asylum because they did not satisfy the criteria. He and other immigration officials said several of the stowaways said during interviews that they came to the United States in hopes of getting work.
Economic hardship is not grounds for asylum under the agency's rules. Those eligible for asylum must be fleeing political, religious, racial, or ethnic persecution in their homeland.
Mr. Tillman said investigators were still trying to learn how and why the 11 came to enter the cargo container in Rio Haina sometime on Saturday. The ship had arrived there from San Juan, Puerto Rico.
"Some of them indicated they had assistance in identifying the container and getting into it," he said.
One of three stowaways treated at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Elizabeth told medical personnel someone was paid at the Dominican port.
"He said they paid a lot of money to be brought here," said Susan Diamond, a hospital spokeswoman. "They wanted to work. They thought they would be fed and cared for and brought into the United States."
Mr. Tillman said officials believed dockworkers got the money. He expressed doubts that anyone aboard the Carolina was involved.
The stowaways told medical officials they carried one bottle of water and a few snacks into the container Saturday. They all shared the water, each drinking a capful every few hours before it was gone on Monday, Dr. Calise of Newark Beth Israel Medical Center said.
The little amount of food was eaten quickly, too. "They all looked as if they hadn't eaten even before the trip," said Ms. Pacheco, the nurse at Newark Beth Israel.
The Carolina docked in Elizabeth at 7:15 A.M. Wednesday and was not unloaded immediately. The container remained where it had throughout the three days at sea, the fifth highest in a stack of six on the ship's open deck.

HEADLINE: A Mixed August for Retailers

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The nation's leading retailers reported mixed results for August yesterday, as consumers continued to demonstrate a penchant for bargain-based shopping.
Still, analysts said last month's retail sales supported the notion that consumers, who are responsible for about two-thirds of the economy, are spending enough to maintain growth at a moderate pace. 
 "If you look at most merchandise lines in most stores, consumer spending has not held up badly," Sandra Shaber, a senior vice president at the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said. "What the job market is generating in terms of checks, the consumer is spending.
"The missing link at this point is cars," she added. "And the real thrust to consumer spending has to come from car sales."
 
Part of a Larger Data Picture
 The retailers' reports come as the economy's growth appears to be cooling off. A survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management showed manufacturing growth slowing in August, though there were signs of rising prices. [Page D5.]
Separately, the Government is to report today on the nation's employment in August, and economists are expecting the figures to show that the economy created fewer new jobs than the 259,000 added in July.
Economists, analysts and investors are reviewing these data for signals about the economy and the direction of the bond and stock markets. They hope to discern how much the economy may slow in the second half of the year from its second-quarter pace of 3.8 percent and whether the slowdown will take pressure off price increases. If it does, the Federal Reserve may avoid another rise in short-term interest rates, which many analysts expect in November.
 There were some indications of strength in the retailers' August sales. Jeffrey M. Feiner, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said the firm's composite index of sales at 22 leading retailing companies rose 4.9 percent in August, following a 3.9 percent increase in July.
"But the gains are not as big as they were earlier in the year," Mr. Feiner said.
August is often viewed as an indicator of how retailers will perform in the fall, their most important season, because of the back-to-school sales during the month.
But analysts said what happens in August is less useful a barometer than it was a few years ago.
"Back-to-school sales are hard to gauge these days because school starts at various times in various parts of the country," Mr. Feiner said. "September should provide a better read on fall clothing sales."
Of the big chains, analysts said they were particularly impressed with sales at Sears, Roebuck & Company and the J. C. Penney Company.
Sears said same-store sales rose 5.2 percent, and overall sales were up 5.1 percent. At Penney, same-store sales increased 10.9 percent, while total sales, including its drugstore and catalogue operations, rose 10.7 percent. And Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, said same-store sales rose 6.6 percent from a year ago, while total sales were up 22 percent.
Same-store sales, or sales from stores open at least a year, are considered the most accurate measure of a retailer's strength. They exclude the results of newer stores, where sales tend to be unusually high. Same-store sales also exclude results from stores closed in the past year.
"The fact that Sears and Penney did terrifically suggests that Americans are willing to go out and buy, but at stores that are very moderately priced," said Kurt Barnard, a retailing consultant in Berkeley Heights, N.J. and publisher of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report.
Federated Department Stores Inc. also posted robust results. The company reported a 5.9 percent increase in same-store sales, an an 11.6 percent gain in overall business. It said its results were helped by strong sales of items for the home like bedroom and bathroom furnishings.
Cost-conscious shopping was the theme at even the toniest stores.
Mr. Barnard said he was taken aback by an 11.3 percent increase in same-store sales Neiman Marcus reported for August until he noticed the high-priced chain was running clearance sales last month.
Consumers bought clothes last month, but they did not do their shopping at specialty apparel chains.
Wayne Hood, a retailing analyst at Prudential Securities, said same-store sales at the specialty retailers he tracks fell 1 percent in August, following a 1.1 percent drop in July.
Among specialty retailers, Limited Inc. said same-store sales were unchanged in August, while its overall business rose 7 percent. At Gap Inc., same-store sales fell 5 percent, while total sales rose 6 percent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS: The Snack-Food Frontier;
Chinese to Get a Taste Of Cheese-Less Cheetos

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
At last, Cheetos, the snack, has come to China, the country. The catch? They don't taste like Cheetos.
The maker of Cheetos, Pepsico, announced a $1 million joint venture yesterday to produce the little crispy-tasting cheese puffs in Guangdong province, where the per-capita income is among the highest in China. It marks the first time a major snack-food brand will be produced in China for Chinese tastes, Pepsico said. 
 But these Cheetos don't taste like cheese, which is hardly a mainstay of the Chinese diet. "We are offering two flavors, Savory American Cream and Zesty Japanese Steak," Jeffrey Goh, general manager of Pepsico Foods International, said in a telephone interview from the city of Guangzhou.
In focus groups for more than 1,000 people in Guangzhou, Shanghai and Beijing, the cheese-ish taste of American Cheetos did not, as they say, test well. Pepsico had to try more than 600 flavors, ranging from Roasted Cuttlefish to Sweet Carmel, before settling on Savory American Cream ("a buttered popcorn flavor," Mr. Goh said) and Zesty Japanese Steak ("a teriyaki-type taste").
But is a Cheeto a Cheeto if it doesn't taste like cheese? "It's still crispy, it has a Cheeto shape and it's fun to eat, so it's a Cheeto," Mr. Goh said.
Among those who tried the first run of Chinese Cheetos yesterday were the United States Secretary of Commerce, Ronald H. Brown, and a group of American executives visiting Guangzhou as part of a trade mission to China. Mr. Brown's reaction was not reported by the foreign news media assembled to cover the tour.
The estimated market for Western snack foods in Guangdong province is $40 million to $70 million, Mr. Goh said. The province, with 70 million consumers, represents a market that is one-third the size of the United States population. If the snack foods are a success, the line will expand to Hong Kong and the rest of China.
"With the Chinese economy gaining momentum and work hours increasing, between-meal snacking is rising as rapidly as disposable income," Mr. Goh said.
The introduction of Cheetos will be backed by television and print advertising and promotions based on Chester Cheetah, the brand's feline brand symbol, riding a Harley-Davidson motorcycle. The packages will carry the Cheeto logo in English along with the Chinese characters "qi duo" (pronounced CHEE dwaugh).
"Luckily," Mr. Goh said, "the translation is 'new surprise,' instead of some phrase that might offend people."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pepsico plans to make Cheetos in China. But the snacks won't taste like cheese, which is not a mainstay in the Chinese diet.
