HEADLINE: Inflation Still Discerned In a Cooler Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The economy cooled in August but not enough to put the freeze on inflation, a widely followed survey of industrial companies showed yesterday.
The National Association of Purchasing Management's report for August showed activity at the nation's factories expanded at a much weaker pace than any time in the last eight months, suggesting that the economy is slowing down. 
 But the survey, considered a leading economic forecasting tool, disclosed that the number of companies reporting higher prices for raw materials rose to the highest level in six years, suggesting that inflation pressures still menace the economy because those price increases could be passed on to consumers.
Economists said the data did not necessarily mean that a surge in prices was imminent. Rather, they said, the survey reflects the inflationary effects of strong economic growth in the first half of the year.
"We probably won't see a real slowdown in prices until a few months down the road," said Bernie Markstein, chief economist at Meridian Bancorp, a large regional banking company in Reading, Pa.
The purchasing managers' report coincided with the release of other economic data that presented a mixed picture. Weekly unemployment insurance claims hit a six-week high. Leading retailers said sales were mixed in August. And construction spending rose moderately in July.
 
Focus of Financial Markets
 The financial markets will be focusing today on the Government's report on employment in August for further signs of inflationary pressures.
The purchasing managers' manufacturing index, based on responses from purchasing managers at 300 large industrial companies, fell 56.2 percent in August from 57.8 percent in July.
An index reading above 50 percent indicates an expansion, while a reading below 50 percent indicates a decline.
Factory production grew at a lower level than in July and new orders were down at more companies than the month before, the survey showed.
But the purchasing managers' price index, closely watched by the financial markets, jumped to 74.5 percent, from 73.1 percent in July, its highest level since August 1988.
"This increase in material prices is one of the strongest concerns of purchasers," said Ralph G. Kauffman, chairman of the purchasing managers' business survey committee and manager of procurement at the Oryx Energy Company.
Among the other economic reports yesterday, the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing first-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose by 9,000 last week, to 332,000, but the increase largely reflected an end to many summer vacation jobs.
The figure was slightly smaller than economists expected. They did not expect the dismissal of seasonal workers to affect the August unemployment figures.
Meanwhile, spending on construction projects rose moderately in July despite a drop in residential building because of heavy government spending.
 
Rise in Construction Spending
 The Commerce Department said construction spending was up six-tenths of 1 percent in July, the fifth straight gain, after advancing three-tenths of 1 percent in June.
Spending on residential, nonresidential and government projects totaled $510.5 billion at a seasonally adjusted annual rate, up from a revised $507.5 billion in June.
The gain in construction spending was a little more than analysts forecast, but they noted the advance was concentrated in the public sector. Private construction spending was weaker than anticipated.
"At this point, it looks like residential construction outlays will decline in the third quarter while nonresidential construction will be up slightly," said economists for Merrill Lynch & Company in a statement.
The residential spending decline included a four-tenths of 1 percent drop in outlays for single-family houses. Apartment outlays fell eight-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Slightly Weaker; Jobs Report Today Awaited

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened slightly yesterday in thin, technically driven trading as most currency dealers avoided taking new positions ahead of today's report on United States employment.
The dollar followed the bond market, which dipped after a national manufacturing survey indicated sharp and potentially inflationary increases in raw material prices last month. The dollar recouped most of the early drop as bond prices recovered. 
 Bond prices, which are highly sensitive to signs of inflation, fell after the National Association of Purchasing Management said its price index rose to a six-year high in August. In recent months, currency dealers have increasingly watched the prices of dollar-denominated assets in order to gauge demand for the dollar.
 
A Movement in Tandem
 "Capital markets now seem more important than trade flows," said David Durst, a vice president at Bear, Stearns & Company. "The question is whether funds are going to be deployed in dollar, yen or mark assets. That's why the bond and the dollar have been rallying and falling in tandem."
In late New York trading yesterday, the dollar fell to 99.71 Japanese yen from 100.18 yen on Wednesday. The dollar fell to 1.5750 German marks, from 1.5816 marks on Wednesday.
The decision yesterday by the Bundesbank to leave interest rates unchanged appeared to have little impact, although some market participants said the lack of action by the German central bank had helped support the mark.
In any case, few dealers were willing to make major bets on the dollar in advance of today's employment data for August.
The British pound advanced broadly yesterday on speculation that the Bank of England would raise interest rates and on hope that the Irish Republican Army cease-fire would yield a permanent settlement in Northern Ireland.
Jim Blackwelder, a vice president at NatWest Financial Markets Group, said, "If the I.R.A. situation bears fruit, it could make the U.K. investment environment look a lot more favorable." .
In New York trading, the British pound advanced to $1.5455, from $1.5340 on Wednesday.
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.3225 Swiss francs, down from 1.3325 francs on Wednesday; at 5.3905 French francs, down from 5.4135 francs, and at 1,583 Italian lire, down from 1,589 lire.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Rollbacks An Issue For Union In Talks

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Negotiators for the National Hockey League and its Players Association met for four hours yesterday at the league headquarters in Manhattan and bargained over terms of a new collective bargaining agreement.
No settlement was announced but when the meeting ended, Bob Goodenow, the executive director of the union, expressed displeasure over rollbacks of benefits imposed by Commissioner Gary Bettman. 
 "It's a blatant economic attack on the players, and I don't think it's good for the relationship," Goodenow said. "But he's made his decision. Anything he would do to make it more difficult is not in our mutual best objectives. He's got his reasons. Ask Gary Bettman."
Bettman said he was surprised that Goodenow complained about the rollbacks.
"They never raised the issue," Bettman said, referring to the bargaining session that had just ended.
Bettman said that both sides have set tentative dates for further negotiations next week.
Asked to characterize yesterday's session, Bettman replied: "The fact that we are continuing to meet is positive. We're committed to try to make a deal. The fact that we've gotten into bargaining for the first time in five months is a positive."
Referring again to the benefit cutbacks, Bettman said: "My goal is not to punish the players. My goal is to make a deal."
Referring to the baseball strike now in its fourth week, Bettman said "I don't want to be in that situation."
As of yesterday, Bettman unilaterally slashed player benefits, including insurance and pension contributions, and he eliminated per-diem expense money for training camp.
The 26 teams are returning to camp next week in preparation for the regular season, which begins Oct. 1. An expected lockout of the players was averted Wednesday when the league announced that the training camps would open as scheduled. The union has been working without a collective bargaining agreement since last Sept. 15.
Among the major issues is a salary structure that is based on team revenues. Bettman has not used the term salary cap, which he helped develop as an executive with the National Basketball Association in the 1980's. But hockey players have said they are wary of any salary structure based on revenue because they fear it will amount to salary restrictions similar to those in the National Football League which have caused roster disruptions this summer.
Although top league officials and union officials attended yesterday's session, no players were at the table. This is an indication that talks are at an early stage and that tradeoffs and decisions are not about to happen soon.
It is possible that the benefit cutbacks imposed by Bettman could be rescinded and restored to the players on a retroactive basis if an agreement is reached before the season.

HEADLINE: Summer's Last Hurrah: The Final Fling Before the Fall;
Recircling the Globe

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
Here are 10 ways to celebrate the Labor Day weekend in the New York metropolitan region. (An introduction appears on page C1.)
If you're a Unisphere, the world is a lonely place. You're one of a kind. Your youth is gone. And to tell the truth, you were never very popular in the first place. When the World's Fair packed up and left Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, it left you behind to stew in a pool of stagnant water, like a soda can from the Pepsi Pavilion. 
 The Unisphere is 30. The immense stainless steel globe, the symbol of the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, is not the most handsome work of public art in New York City. Nor is Flushing Meadows-Corona Park the city's greatest outdoor space. The landscape has so little variety of scale that walking through the park can bring on the kind of panic you may have experienced in a nightmare: you trudge and trudge and go nowhere.
In theory, the Unisphere represents "peace through understanding," but its real theme is size. That's a World's Fair archetype: the biggest wedge of cheese, the world's most powerful light bulb. Twelve stories high, weighing 900,000 pounds, the world's biggest globe was designed and executed by United States Steel, and it commemorates a moment when steel led the American industrial economy, that economy was the strongest in the world and the nation stood on the verge of conquering the universe. From the rim of the reflecting pool, the globe presents an image of the earth as it would look from a distance of 6,000 miles.
Today, the Unisphere looks poignantly isolated within a time warp of faded optimism. Though the park is heavily used, the area around the globe is often gripped by a strange, ominous silence. This object was made to be surrounded by bustling crowds, snapping flags, gushing fountains, colored lights and nightly displays of fireworks overhead, not to mention the strange menagerie of 150 pavilions that once stood here in jumbled profusion. Nothing can compensate for the loss of context around this metallic centerpiece.
But since last May, thanks to a $3 million renovation sponsored by the office of the Queens Borough President, the Unisphere has gleamed with something like its former high spirits. The reflecting pool has been patched up, with new fountain jets that shoot the water to a height of 22 feet. New lighting illuminates the fountains at night. Rose gardens now bloom where the New England and New Jersey pavilions once stood.
The best way to get there is, of course, by Ford Mustang. The original model was unveiled at the fair in April 1964. And pack some Belgian waffles. Not the world's biggest dessert, perhaps, but surely one of the heaviest, this sandwich of pastry, strawberries and whipped cream was the culinary craze of the 1964-65 World's Fair, and can still be found on the menus of many coffee shops in town. HERBERT MUSCHAMP

GRAPHIC: Photo: A survivor of the 60's: The Unisphere in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. (Adam Fernandez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Real Truth of Poverty

 BODY:
Demonizing welfare mothers has become political sport, with politicians everywhere blaming them for moral decline, budget deficits and even poverty itself. A report this week by New York's Citizens Budget Commission challenges this stereotype in useful and enlightening ways. It shows that women on welfare make up a far smaller percentage of the poor than popular wisdom would have it. It also confirms what previous studies have shown: Medicaid, not welfare, is the prime source of runaway spending on poverty.
Welfare mothers are routinely portrayed as slackers who make up the bulk of the poor and soak up more money every year. The fact is that only one in four poor households in New York City is headed by a single parent; welfare payments, when adjusted for inflation, have actually declined by 30 percent since 1972. 
 The poor in New York are also more ethnically diverse than commonly supposed. Among the elderly, for example, nearly half of all households in poverty are headed by whites. Like earlier studies, the commission's report suggests that the failure of welfare payments to keep pace with inflation contributes to homelessness.
For years, Gov. Mario Cuomo has proposed that New York State assume the share paid by local governments for Medicaid, the program of medical insurance for the poor. That is because New York is one of the few states that makes local governments pick up part of the tab for Medicaid. The Governor's plan foundered partly because he would take back local sales or income taxes in exchange for picking up Medicaid, a prospect that worried many suburban legislators.
Medicaid siphons off money that might be devoted to education, training, infrastructure. Because it has a large poverty population, New York levies onerous state and city taxes that become a major factor in persuading businesses to locate elsewhere. This, over time, erodes the tax base.
New York City will spend about $2.5 billion on Medicaid in 1995. It ought to pay nothing. The nation's poor should be a national responsibility, with Washington paying the entire tab. Short of that, the state should pay Medicaid bills for all its poor citizens.
The commission's report provides a fresh rationale for a state takeover of Medicaid. Medicaid, it says, is the "largest and most rapidly growing expenditure for the poor." Again, welfare mothers and their children account for far less spending than one might think. The elderly and disabled make up less than a quarter of New York's Medicaid population but account for nearly 60 percent of total Medicaid costs.
New York City taxpayers have been hit hard by the need to pay for programs that cater to a large poverty population. But welfare mothers are not breaking the city's back. The costs of providing housing, education and police protection to an economically disadvantaged population are huge -- as are the runaway costs of health care for the elderly and disabled.

HEADLINE: Long Baseball Timeout Gives Edge to Players

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When employers such as baseball owners are confronted by a union such as the players' union, resolution of their disputes is not subject to the market forces of supply and demand, but to their ability to tolerate a long shutdown. Here the players have an overwhelming advantage because the cost to them is the loss of after-tax income, subject anyway to the highest tax rates. 
 The owners not only lose income, but also their high overhead costs continue whether they are open for business or not. Millionaire ballplayers can survive even if they never play another game in their lives.
I see at least three ways to approach this high-stakes economic game between intractable disputants, and give the taxpayers a break too.
(1) The owners continue the season with minor-league players, as they did when umpires went on strike.
(2) The Government breaks the baseball monopoly by permitting more major-league franchises, thus tending to put a lid on player salaries.
(3) The Internal Revenue Service disallows the tax-exempt status of municipal bonds used to finance the building of sports facilities; after which professional sports are totally privatized, that is, cities will not be permitted to help build or to finance the building of sports facilities.
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman wisely declined to let New Jersey help finance a new stadium in Camden for the 76ers basketball team. If the owners can afford million-dollar salaries, they can pay for building their own facilities.
 
LOUIS MANZELLE
Highlands, N.J., Aug. 30, 1994
The writer is an adjunct professor of economics at Monmouth College.

HEADLINE: A Slaying Shows Ulster Peace Is Still Elusive

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 2

 BODY:
It was a killing like hundreds of others over the last 25 years in Northern Ireland: a group of gunmen approached a man repairing a car on a Belfast Street, shot him dead and fled. The victim was Roman Catholic; the killers were members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters, a Protestant paramilitary group.
But for politicians and church leaders here, the bluntly sectarian killing Thursday night -- the first blood spilled since the Irish Republican Army declared its unilateral cease-fire nearly 24 hours earlier -- was less a shock than a cold-blooded reminder of how distant any real or lasting peace is in the divided province. 
 Still, in a vote of confidence and an expression of hope that peace will hold, President Clinton promised today to increase United States aid greatly both to Ireland and to Northern Ireland. [Page 3.]
Gerry Adams, the head of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the I.R.A., vowed today that the I.R.A. would not be provoked into breaking its commitment to its cease-fire. But the leaders of the province's militant Protestant paramilitaries have said nothing about their own long-term intentions to either abide by the truce or step up the violence against Catholic and republican targets.
"There is, among these men, a lot of apprehension and uncertainty, and I don't believe they know themselves yet what they will do," said the Rev. Roy Magee, a Presbyterian pastor who keeps lines of communication open to the secretive Protestant paramilitary groups that have grown in both size and menace in recent years. "My hope is it will be positive and they will abide with the truce."
The one thing that is certain, he said, is that whenever the Loyalist community feels its back is against the wall, the rosters of the outlawed militant organizations swell. The Ulster Freedom Fighters, which took responsibility for the killing of the Catholic, John O'Hanlon, on Thursday night, has a hard-core membership of about 500 to 600, police estimates show, and the rival Ulster Volunteer Force about 350 to 500.
From the tumbledown neighborhoods of the Protestant ghetto in Shankill, where the unemployed young men idling on street corners provide rich fodder for the Loyalist gun squads, to the rolling green countryside of rural Londonderry and Antrim, where the monied Loyalist gentry presides, Northern Ireland's majority Protestants are feeling very much on the defensive these days.
While only the smallest and most militant minority of the Protestant population favors a resort to violence, there is at nearly every level a palpable suspicion and fear, a growing conviction that the I.R.A. cease-fire is the latest step in some much larger, undefined conspiracy directed at loosening Ulster's ties to London.
In this view, it is Ulster against what they call the pan-Irish republican movement, from the I.R.A and the Irish-American lobby to the Dublin politicians, each of them abetted by a weak and duplicitous British Government that wouldn't mind shedding the enormous cost -- about $5.1 billion this year alone, twice what it was in 1989 -- of keeping the troubled province afloat.
"I am a British subject, not an Irish one," said Jean Arbuthot, a 48-year-old woman taking her grandson for a walk in Shankill today. "I say we have been betrayed by London. Why else would the I.R.A. have called a cease-fire?"
 
Signs of Double-Dealing
 Even while the British Government insists there will be no constitutional change in Northern Ireland without the consent of the majority of people living there, the militant Protestants see new signs of double-dealing, like London's grudging acknowledgement last year, after repeated and persistent denials, that it had engaged in secret talks with the I.R.A.
On Thursday, their ire was raised again by reports that four republican prisoners convicted on terrorist offenses had been suddenly moved from jails in England to Northern Ireland, to be closer to home. The British said no deal was made; the Loyalists don't believe it.
Demographics, too, will work against the Protestants in the long term. While they now make up about 57 percent of the 1.6 million people who live in the six counties of Ulster, studies here suggest Catholics may have a voting majority before the middle of the next century, as a result of higher birth rates.
If Protestant politics in Ulster sometimes suggest a kind of siege mentality, Ulster's own history begins with a celebration of a siege: the defiant stand in Derry of a band of Protestant settlers, loyal to the new King William and Queen Mary of England, who held out successfully for 108 days against Catholic forces of the deposed King James II.
 
'Have to Stand for Something'
 Even now, says Gregory Campbell, a Unionist politician in Londonderry, the party is too often perceived as being on the defensive and reactionary, a champion of the Northern Ireland status quo. "We've got to go on the offensive," he said. "Be more innovative, progressive, effective, dynamic. We've got to push our British ties the way the republicans push their Irishness. We have to rally support from Scotch-Irish in America. We have to stand for something instead of just reacting to something."
But Paul Bew, a professor of Irish politics at Queen's University in Belfast, says he always wonders to himself, when he hears such talk, "why the heart sinks and the mind knows that the mission is unlikely to succeed." Unionism, he says, has been stripped over the years of its public respectability and credibility.
While Unionists took the largest share of the vote in the 1993 local elections, winning 46 percent of the vote to 34 percent by republicans, their ranks are deeply divided, split by a long and enduring feud between the fiery fundamentalist preacher, the Rev. Ian Paisley, and the more mainstream James Molyneaux.
At the same time, said Pastor Magee, many young Protestants regard both men as hopelessly out of touch with their own increasingly desperate situation, reflected in jobless rates of 50 percent in Shankill and other inner-city Protestant neighborhoods.
 
No Jobs for Protestants
 "Twenty-five years ago, it was the Catholics who complained they didn't have jobs and decent living," said George Young, 44, who lives in Shankill. "Now it's the Protestants who can't find work either, and the politicians don't seem to care."
One British journalist who had covered the outbreak of what the Irish call "the troubles" wrote this week that the fear and loathing he detected in Protestant neighborhoods reminded him of what it felt like in the Catholic Bogside.
"It was like throwing a switch and waking up in 1969 again," said Richard Kay of the Daily Mail. "After 25 years fighting and fearing the I.R.A., will Ulster's police now face the menace of Protestant gunmen?"
But Pastor Magee says the very specter of gun battles between Protestant paramilitaries and members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, whose officers themselves are overwhelmingly Protestant, is one reason he believes the Protestant gunmen will show restraint. "For years, the Loyalist paramilitaries have said they were avenging the deaths of policeman and soldiers killed by the I.R.A.," he said. "To do battle with them now would be a recipe for disaster, and give Gerry Adams the profile of a peace general."
Police officials in Belfast offer another reason why the Protestants might eschew a campaign of violence: if the I.R.A. keeps to its cease-fire, there are 12,000 police officers and 18,000 soldiers who will have more time to keep an eye on Protestant gunmen.

LENGTH: 1162 words

HEADLINE: A Republican Candidate Shrugs Off Spoiler Tag

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Pauline Kezer slipped back and forth between roles as she worked the crowd in Bushnell Park, where state office workers flock at lunchtime. One moment she was a Republican candidate for governor, seeking votes in the party's Sept. 13 primary. The next, she was Connecticut's Secretary of the State, encouraging people to register to vote, explaining how to do it, and sending an aide to bring registration forms from her office.
Mrs. Kezer, who was elected Secretary of the State in 1990, has also embraced a divided role in the race for her party's nomination. To the public, she offers herself as a good-government candidate, promising to "return political power to the people." Within her party, however, she is attacking the record of the leadership's candidate, John Rowland, a former Congressman who nearly won the 1990 race and who has held large leads in polls this year. For that, she has been derided as the party's Tonya Harding -- a woman willing to hurt -- for the sake of her own ambitions -- the party's best chance to elect a governor in more than 20 years. 
 Mrs. Kezer, who says her involvement in politics grew out of an interest in helping battered women in the 1970's, makes no apologies for taking on Mr. Rowland. She says he is simply too conservative to win in a moderate state like Connecticut, where only two Republicans have won statewide elections since 1970 -- herself and former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a liberal who left the party in 1990 to make his successful run for governor as an independent.
She also contends that Mr. Rowland is a weakened candidate, because the only qualification he has added to his record since 1990 is that of lobbyist, paid hundreds of thousands of dollars by the state's military contractors as they laid off thousands of employees.
 
Personal Attacks
 She has also attacked his participation in the House bank, which was closed in 1992 after a scandal over its practice of covering overdrafts until members made their checks good. Mr. Rowland's 108 overdrafts during his three terms were more than twice those of any other House member from Connecticut.
"Our strategy," Mrs. Kezer said, "is simply to say this person has a record he is going to have to live with, and two parts of it are very unsettling."
Party leaders have angrily denounced Mrs. Kezer for a radio ad that says Mr. Rowland "peddled his influence" and bounced checks, saying it broke her pledge to stay away from personal attacks.
The state chairman, John Mastropietro, called Mrs. Kezer "a poster child" for how not to conduct a primary. "Nasty and distorted advertising campaigns are beneath the intelligence of voters," he said.
 
A Counterattack
 Mr. Rowland at first responded by saying that the House bank's practices were a regrettable mistake, but that no harm ultimately was done; he defended his work as a consultant for corporations, saying he was helping them avoid more layoffs.
But in a recent letter to local and state Republican leaders, he deplored what he called the "negative, distorted radio ads."
"It is extremely unfortunate that Pauline has chosen to sink to this depth in her desperate attempt to advance her personal agenda," he wrote. "The truth is, she's helping the Democrats and A Connecticut Party by playing the spoiler."
The primary winner will face two opponents in November, Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark of A Connecticut Party, the party Governor Weicker founded, and either State Senator John Larson or State Comptroller Bill Curry, who are running in the Democratic primary.
Those campaigns all say that Mrs. Kezer has raised potentially damaging issues, especially Mr. Rowland's transition from Congressman to highly paid consultant.
"So many people have become distant from their government simply because they feel it's been taken over by lobbyists, special interest groups and PACs," said Mr. Curry's spokesman, Roy Ochiogrosso. "So when someone comes out of that environment to run for office, he bears a heavy burden of proof to say he's now going to represent your interests."
Mrs. Kezer says she is cast as a spoiler because there is nothing to attack in her record of eight years as a state representative from Plainville and four years as Secretary of the State. All she is doing, she says, is comparing her record of service to Mr. Rowland's. And how can she be the spoiler, she asks, when she is the one Republican who won in 1990?
"I kept saying to party leaders, 'How do you know John can go the distance?' " she said. "And they said, 'He's the only one who can raise the money.' I said, 'He raised $3 million last time and he still lost.' "
 
A Risk
 But in attacking Mr. Rowland after barely qualifying for the primary, she has risked appearing combative and shrill. With little money for advertising, she has striven to extend the controversy over her ad, broadcast only a few times by a handful of radio stations, by calling news conferences to protest the counterattacks on her.
As a challenger forced to conduct a low-budget campaign, however, she spends her days shaking the hands of strangers and arriving early at town committee meetings and sitting through the officers' reports to show she is not there just to make her speech.
"My mother always told me, it's not polite to eat and run," she said.
At age 52, she often campaigns with her family, including grandchildren who wear T-shirts that say "I Like My Grandma" on the front and "You Will Too" on the back. She pledges to restore Connecticut's economic competitiveness by cutting the state budget 10 percent in her first two years and by cutting the personal income tax by 10 percent each year for four years. Mr. Rowland says he has a plan to eliminate the tax. Her proposals for economic development also call for cutting business taxes and focusing the state's investment resources on specific industries.
 
Voters Promised a Role
 In a state where huge deficits and the imposition of the income tax in 1991 have fueled widespread unhappiness with government, Mrs. Kezer is also promising voters a larger voice by allowing referendums on new laws, putting term limits on elected officials and placing more restrictions on lobbyists and political action committees.
As Secretary of the State, she says, she reduced her budget 25 percent without layoffs while improving the office's efficiency.
In Bushnell Park, across the street from her office, Mrs. Kezer met state employees who are angry that legislators rejected pay raises they had won in arbitration this year. She told them the state budget could be cut further. Chief executives, she said, have a responsibility to plan for contingencies like arbitration awards. Real savings, she said, must come from reorganizing state government to make it more efficient, and that must involve the employees themselves.
"If I'm lucky enough to be governor," she said, "you'll have a voice in the decisions that have to be made."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Cuba Make Progress on Refugees

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 2

 BODY:
United States and Cuban negotiators made progress today in talks focusing on a proposal by the Clinton Administration to vastly increase the number of Cubans who would be granted entry through legal means if Havana agreed to halt the chaotic flow of boat people, American officials said.
 Meeting for eight hours on the second day of talks, the Administration gave the Cubans a formal written offer that would commit the United States to admit at least 20,000 Cubans a year through legal immigration, far more than the 2,700 who received visas over the past 12 months, the officials said.
 
 The Administration's hope was that this offer, which meets a longstanding demand of Fidel Castro, would induce him to halt the latest surge of Cubans, which began last month.
 One Administration official said the two sides appeared close to agreement, with the Cubans carefully analyzing the American offer. But another official warned that so many details still needed to be worked out that an accord could easily fall through.
 "We're not there yet," said one Administration official.
 Tonight American and Cuban officials announced that the talks would be adjourned until Sunday so the two sides could take stock and consult with their respective capitals.
 The number of Cubans picked up by the United States Coast Guard dropped today from Thursday, but it remained high. The Coast Guard reported that 1,271 Cubans had been picked up in the Straits of Florida by 10 P.M. today, compared with 1,921 on all of Thursday.
 One official said the flow slowed because a backlog of Cubans waiting to flee after last weekend's storm had dissipated.
 David Johnson, a spokesman for the United States delegation, told journalists huddled outside the Cuban mission to the United Nations, where the meeting was held, that the session today was "a thorough, in-depth discussion of possible solutions."
 From the public comments of the two sides, it appeared that the Cubans' insistence that the talks address not just immigration issues, but also ways to ease Washington's economic sanctions against Cuba, could become a sticking point.
 
Disputes Over Focus
 On Thursday, Ricardo Alarcon, Cuba's chief negotiator, suggested on the ABC News program Nightline that the two sides might reach a partial solution "that will help each side get out of this situation."
 The White House has pledged to limit its discussions with the Cubans to immigration matters. Another factor reducing the Administration's bargaining flexibility is Mr. Clinton's promise to Cuban-American groups that he would step up sanctions against Havana.
 Mr. Clinton took such actions -- stepping up anti-Castro broadcasts and banning almost all remittances to Cuba -- after the powerful Cuban American National Foundation complained that his decision to end the 28-year-old American practice of allowing entry for all Cuban refugees punished the Cuban people without punishing Mr. Castro.
 
Reaching the 20,000 Mark
 United States officials said they formally proposed today three ways to admit more than 20,000 Cubans a year -- visas, refugee programs and the Attorney General's discretionary power to admit people for humanitarian or emergency purposes.
 To reach the 20,000 mark, American officials said they would probably grant quick admission to the 19,700 Cubans on a list of more than 3 million people worldwide waiting for visas. Then, they say they would relax the traditionally strict standards for political refugee status so that more Cubans could qualify.
 Another likely step will be for the Attorney General to admit a sizable group of Cubans who do not, under the complex web of immigration preferences, qualify for visas, including cousins, aunts, uncles and grandparents of Cuban-Americans. Current immigration law allows in only members of immediate families: spouses, children, parents and siblings.
 Administration officials said today that the Cubans had assured them in the talks that no dangerous criminals were being released and encouraged to flee by boat.
 
Prisoners Released in Cuba
 State Department officials have said in recent days that they had indications that the Cuban Government had released an estimated 100 prisoners and urged them to set to sea. On Thursday, Mr. Alarcon said on television that some criminals may have taken to rafts during brief prison furloughs, but said it was "preposterous" to suggest that Havana was encouraging criminals to leave.
 Throughout the day, several dozen demonstrators shouted anti-Castro slogans and carried anti-Communist placards across the street from the Cuban mission at 38th Street and Lexington Avenue in Manhattan.
 This morning scuffles broke out between some anti-Castro demonstrators and a few protesters who were part of a group of more than 100 people demanding an end to the embargo against Cuba.

HEADLINE: Ulster Truce Could Bring A 'Dividend'

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Interrupting his vacation to meet with Ireland's Deputy Prime Minister, President Clinton signaled today that he intends to reward the turn toward peace in Northern Ireland with a substantial increase in United States aid.
 Neither Mr. Clinton nor the Irish envoy, Dick Spring, made any public mention of a specific figure for aid, which would be aimed at promoting economic development both north and south of the border. But Mr. Clinton said he believed that the parties who called a halt to violence on Wednesday deserved a "peace dividend," and Mr. Spring said he felt "very satisfied" that the Administration would increase its assistance.
 
 The United States contributes $20 million a year to the International Fund for Ireland for projects on both sides of the border, and Administration officials have said they are considering expanding that figure to $100 million. While key lawmakers have said that it is not likely that new aid would be approved this year, aides to Mr. Clinton said he would seek in coming months to expand trade and investment in the region.
 
A Break From Vacation
 Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokeswoman, nevertheless sought to damp expectations that any new aid might be immediate or vast. Ms. Myers said the President had reminded Mr. Spring that his options would be limited by constraints on the Federal budget.
 Mr. Clinton spoke briefly with Irish reporters after the meeting, and his remarks about the possible aid increase were his first of any substance since he began his vacation here a week ago. But the President declined to take questions.
 Mr. Clinton has steered clear of the American press. In a brief discussion before the meeting with Mr. Spring, one journalist tried to turn a conversation about crossword puzzles into one about growing tensions over Haiti, but Mr. Clinton backed away, gazed at the sky, shook his head and said, "Not today."
 The President was plainly eager to share the glow from Wednesday's announcement of a cease-fire by the Irish Republican Army, and he won particular praise from the Irish envoy for his decision last spring to allow Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, to make a two-day visit to the United States. Sinn Fein is the political wing of the I.R.A.
 
Adams Visit Recalled
 The British Government and the State Department had both recommended against that move. But Mr. Spring said today that it was instrumental in exposing the Sinn Fein leader to Irish-American sentiments and "played a significant role in showing Mr. Adams the path to follow."
 At a news conference in a school gymnasium here, Mr. Spring said that Mr. Clinton "has a very strong personal commitment to helping in any way possible to end the conflict in Northern Ireland." The Irish official, who is also Minister of Foreign Affairs, said that sentiment had "come through very strongly" in this morning's 45-minute meeting, which took place in the main residence on the 25-acre compound where the President is staying -- an unpainted, wood house next to a horse paddock.
Minutes after the meeting adjourned, Mr. Clinton resumed a more familiar vacation schedule, jogging through a state forest along a paved bicycle trail, then joining his family for an afternoon trip on a boat owned by Robert Day, a friend of Mr. Clinton's political ally and close friend, the Washington lawyer Vernon Jordan. The trip took them to Naushon Island, south of Cape Cod, to visit Senator John Kerry, the Massachusetts Democrat, who has a family residence there.
 On Thursday night Mr. Clinton shared a microphone with the singer Carly Simon to bid happy birthday to Ms. Myers, who turned 33 years old, then took up a tenor saxophone to jam with the singer and a Jamaican band, Jamaica Me Crazy, for half a dozen songs, including a raucous version of the Motown hit "Respect."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Job growth slackened as the nation's unemployment rate stood unchanged in August, at 6.1 percent. The report confirmed a slowdown in the economy. Only 179,000 new jobs were added to the payroll -- the smallest rise since January. At the same time, the growth in factory and other jobs was sufficient to blunt concern that the economy was slowing too much. [Page 1.] 
 The job market improved in New York, with the state's unemployment rate falling to 6.9 percent from 7.1 percent in July. The unemployment rates in New York City and New Jersey also declined. [47.]
 
Companies
First Financial Management made a bid valued at $1.07 billion for Western Union Financial Services, the world's largest money-transfer business, topping a bid by Forstmann Little. [35.]
Virtual mayhem has been a winner for Id Software, a company whose oldest owner is 30. The company produces software games like Doom and Castle Wolfenstein that pulsate with full-color 3-D comic-book-style animated graphics of violent battle. [35.]
Chrysler opened a new plant that will produce the Chrysler Cirrus and Dodge Stratus compact cars that the auto maker hopes will make inroads against competitors like the Toyota Camry, the Honda Accord and the Nissan Altima. [37.]
Colgate-Palmolive is planning a $100 million revamping that would eliminate up to 3,000 jobs, a news service reported. [37.]
Metropolitan Life reassigned a top executive. [37.]
 
International
Is it still a Swiss Army knife if it is made in China? The American distributor for Victorinox, which makes 80 percent of the Swiss Army knives sold abroad, has sued in New York to stop Chinese knock-offs. The case is being closely watched in Ibach, Switzerland, population 3,500, the home of Victorinox. [35.]
Brazil is experiencing a franchising boom as United States companies -- particularly fast-food chains -- take advantage of its new free-market policies and economic stability. [35.]
 
Markets
Bond traders managed to find hints of inflationary pressure despite a soft employment report for August. Treasury prices slumped in a shortened trading session after an early surge. [35.]
 Stocks were mixed in thin trading ahead of the holiday weekend. Although the employment report initially lifted stocks, a slowing economy is sure to affect the outlook for fourth-quarter corporate profits. The Dow fell 15.86 points. [36.]
The dollar followed the bond market downward, weakening against the German mark and Japanese yen. [46.]
Cocoa prices tumbled on news of rain in the Ivory Coast, the world's leading producer of cocoa. Natural gas prices fell. [46.]
Your Money The costs of college certainly include housing, and the purchase of an apartment for a daughter or son in college is an idea whose time may have come -- again. The concept gained popularity in the mid-1980's, when parents thought they could profit from a rising real estate market as well as offset college costs. But few parents who buy today have such expectations. If they are interested, it is often because owning may be cheaper than renting. [33.]
 Individual retirement accounts are protected from creditors in New York and a growing number of other states. [33]
The way stockbrokers are compensated will be examined by a high-profile Securities and Exchange Commission committee. [33.]
Mortgage lenders are more forgiving of applicants with a history of late payments, delinquencies -- even bankruptcies. [34.]

HEADLINE: Anglers Ignore Hudson Warnings;
Most Either Don't Know of Cancer Concern or Don't Care

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YONKERS, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Tommy Jackson has heard all the warnings against eating the striped bass, white perch and eel that he pulls from the PCB-polluted waters of the Hudson River.
And yet, seven days a week, he sits on a graffiti-scrawled cement block on this city's waterfront, fishing for his dinner. Unemployed for five years, Mr. Jackson, a thin and weathered man of 52, said he had little patience for state guidelines recommending that he eat no more than one meal a month of most of the fish he catches. 
 "I think it's a big fairy tale," he said of the advisories, which are based on studies that have linked PCB's (polychlorinated biphenyls) to cancer in animals and to nervous-system disorders in humans. "I'm trying to survive off this river."
No one knows how many anglers may be risking their health by regularly tapping the lower Hudson River as a means of subsistence. But Mr. Jackson says he knows about 50 people in Yonkers alone who do so, many of them using the fish to feed their families. And a survey released last year by the environmental group Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, which interviewed 336 fishermen at 20 popular spots between Staten Island and Troy, found that more than 35 percent ate more fish than the state recommended. A vast majority of the families, the survey said, were poor.
"If the people are consuming the fish on a daily or somewhat weekly basis, there is a long-term risk," said Larry Skinner, an official who monitors fishing for the Department of Environmental Conservation. "There is an increased risk of cancer. There is also an increased risk to the unborn and to young children."
Some anglers, like Mr. Jackson, have read the recommendations but choose to ignore them. But most, the Clearwater group contends, do not know about the advisories because state health and environmental officials have not done enough to reach those most in need of information, particularly immigrants who speak little English.
"There's a lot of people that have no clue, who believe that if a fish looks healthy it is healthy," said Hannah Kalkstein, a Clearwater volunteer who helped prepare the survey. "The reality is that PCB contamination does not show."
The primary source of the PCB's is believed to be the General Electric plants in Hudson Falls and nearby Fort Edward that used the chemicals from the 1940's until the 1970's as a fire retardant in capacitors. Ever since 1975, when the chemicals were first discovered in the Hudson, the state has banned the commercial sale of the river's most prolific fish, the striped bass, and issued strict advisories on eating bass and other fish.
The state sends annual news releases to media organizations detailing the guidelines, and includes them in the packet that anglers receive when they buy fishing licenses. But according to state law, no license is required to fish the Hudson. State officials say that they have to do a better job of getting the word out, but that they lack the money to do so.
In July, the Department of Environmental Conservation created a position for a "citizen participation specialist," to develop a program to educate anglers on the dangers of eating too much fish from polluted waters, Mr. Skinner said. Using $163,000 from the Environmental Protection Agency, the department will also hire up to four seasonal employees next spring to discuss the issue with anglers at popular points on the Hudson and on Lakes Erie and Ontario.
While the department began to distribute advisory pamphlets to tackle shops and public parks in July, the literature is only available in English. Mr. Skinner said that officials were planning to add a Spanish translation and were considering versions in Vietnamese and Chinese, based, in part, on the finding by Clearwater that these groups were among the least-informed on the issue.
Because of elevated levels of PCB's found in Hudson River fish over the years, the state recommends that people eat no fish -- other than American shad -- that have been caught between the Rip Van Winkle Bridge in Catskill and the Troy Dam, the stretch with the highest PCB concentration.
For all areas south of Catskill -- including New York Harbor and the Harlem and East Rivers -- the recommendations are these: people should eat no more than one meal a week of shad, Atlantic sturgeon, blueback herring, blue crab, bluegill, pumpkinseed and yellow perch, and no more than one meal a month of all other fish.
The guidelines also recommend that women in their childbearing years and children under 15 eat no fish caught in the Hudson. But Carolyn Aryee, a 30-year-old mother of two who usually uses food stamps to buy food, said she had heard no such warning. Fishing for white perch off the Yonkers city pier with her father, Johnnie LeGrand, and her sons, ages 4 and 9, Ms. Aryee said she planned to feed her family that night by frying their catch in onions and seasoning salt.
"I'm still alive," she said, the family's four rods leaning against a metal fence, the lines baited with earthworms and cast into the water. "They must be good. They taste good when I eat 'em."
"It's a free meal," she added. "I don't have to buy anything."
A few moments later, Rudolph Driver, 65, a retired carpenter, was chatting with several friends as they fished off the city pier a few yards from Ms. Aryee. But his rod was nowhere in sight. Asked why he had come empty-handed, Mr. Driver cited the state recommendations and a fervent desire not to get sick.
"I'm an old man," he said. "And I got a bad heart."

HEADLINE: Citing Safety, U.S. Bans Airlines of 9 Nations

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
The Federal Aviation Administration has barred airlines from nine nations from flying to the United States because of poor safety procedures.
The unusual action, announced today, is a response to safety questions from consumer groups. Officials say they hope the economic fallout of the ban will encourage the airlines to follow safety guidelines. 
 The aviation agency surveyed safety procedures in 30 of the 93 countries that have commercial flights to the United States. The agency sought to determine if the aviation authorities in each country were meeting the safety requirements of the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations agency. Its rules are less strict than those of the Federal Aviation Administration.
The aviation agency did not reveal details about the safety deficiencies that had prompted it to ban the nine airlines.
The banned airlines are from Belize, the Dominican Republic, Gambia, Ghana, Honduras, Nicaragua, Paraguay, Uruguay and Zaire. Four other countries were allowed to continue flying into the United States, but under increased supervison by the aviation agency. They are Bolivia, El Salvador, Guatemala and the Netherlands Antilles.
 
Survey of Other Countries
 A survey of the 63 remaining countries is under way and is expected to be completed in late 1996.
In the past, airlines have been barred from flying to the United States only for political reasons, like the embargo against Cuba. The Federal Department of Transportation and the aviation administration have been focusing more on safety since 1990, when 73 people were killed when a Colombian jetliner ran out of fuel and crashed on Long Island while waiting for clearance to land at Kennedy International Airport. The review began in 1991.
Representative Robert A. Borski, a Pennsylvania Democrat who heads the House subcommittee on Investigations and Oversight, praised the aviation agency's action.
"More than half of all international passengers are United States citizens," Mr. Borski said. "We're the marketplace for the world. All we want is the proper oversight."
Arnold Barnett, a professor of operations research and statistics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said his research showed that the chances that an air traveler would be killed were 25 times higher on a foreign flight than on a domestic one.
 
Likely Effects of Ban
 Countries with economies that depend on tourism, like Belize and the Dominican Republic, are likely to suffer most from the ban.
David S. Stempler, the executive director of the International Airline Passengers Association, a consumer group that had been urging the aviation agency to release the survey, said of the banned countries, "If they want to do business in the United States, the ticket for admission is these procedures."
The survey looked at compliance with all air safety guidelines, but particularly focused on pilot training, aircraft maintenance and air carrier certification.
The three African nations whose flights have been banned have said they will not try to comply with the safety requirements. Telephone calls to the remaining six nations' air carriers and embassies were not returned.

HEADLINE: Unemployment Declined in New York Region in August

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Unemployment dropped in the New York metropolitan region in August, the Government reported yesterday, enabling the region to catch up slightly with the rest of the nation.
The jobless rates in New York and New Jersey fell last month, while unemployment held steady nationwide. Northeastern states have generally lagged behind the rest of the country in recovering from the recession. 
 The Labor Department said the unemployment rate for New York State declined to 6.9 percent, from 7.1 percent in July. For New York City, the rate fell to 8.5 percent, from 8.8 percent.
New Jersey's unemployment rate dropped to its lowest level of the year: 6 percent from 6.4 percent in July.
The national jobless rate was stable in August at 6.1 percent.
Connecticut is not among the 11 states for which the department provides separate figures when it releases the national jobs data each month.
While the August jobless rate in New York City declined, there appears to be little sign of consistent improvement, said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
New York City's jobless rate reached double-digit levels earlier in the year, and has stayed in a narrow range of 8.4 to 8.8 percent since May, he said.
In New York City, 278,000 people were unemployed in August, while almost three million people held jobs. A total of 598,000 New York State residents were jobless last month, with slightly more than eight million holding jobs.
New Jersey's situation looks brighter. The state's jobless rate has been declining all year, and the August number was the first monthly figure below the national level since November 1993.
Mr. Ehrenhalt attributed New Jersey's gains to growth in trade and in the service and construction industries, as well as to a slowdown in factory job losses.
There were 246,000 unemployed New Jersey residents in August, with 3.85 million people holding jobs. Mr. Ehrenhalt said August was the third consecutive month of strengthening employment in New Jersey.
Joseph Seneca, professor of economics at Rutgers University, said, "This is a consistent improvement and indicates the recovery is for real."

HEADLINE: DROP IN NEW JOBS SIGNALS A SLOWING FOR THE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Employment figures released today provided the clearest evidence to date that the economy has slowed from last year's unsustainable pace, but that it retains enough strength to avoid braking too severely.
Job growth slackened in August as the unemployment rate, 6.1 percent, stood at essentially the same level for a fourth straight month, the Labor Department reported today. The rate had fallen markedly early this year. 
 The data, which provide the first broad view of economic performance for the month, seemed to reduce further the chance that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates again at its policy meeting in September.
At the same time, the growth in factory and other jobs was sufficient to blunt concern that the economy might sink to an unsatisfactorily low pace of expansion, because of tighter Government spending, higher taxes and higher interest rates.
Merrill Lynch called the employment figures "constructive" on the whole. The report showed a smaller-than-expected rise of 179,000 payroll jobs last month, the lowest increase since January. That rise was far below the average of 293,000 so far this year and below the 259,000 jobs created in July.
The Clinton Administration, meanwhile, took the occasion to boast that 3.1 million jobs had been created since Labor Day of 1993.
"The U.S. economy continues to enjoy healthy growth in incomes and employment," Laura D'Andrea Tyson, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said. Moreover, she added, "there is no sign of an intensification of inflationary pressures in today's report."
The report initially cheered the bond market, but traders looking for any hints of inflation soon found other reasons to sell. [Page 35.]
Private analysts noted that average hourly earnings rose a skimpy 2 cents last month, cutting the annual rate of increase in the latest three months to just 1.5 percent. This suggested lackluster consumer spending as the holiday shopping season approaches.
"With wages falling below inflation, consumers are not going to have the discretionary buying power to give the economy much support," said Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist at HSBC Holdings Inc. in New York. The Consumer Price Index rose at a 3.3 percent compounded annual rate for the three months that ended in July.
What seems to be happening, economists and business people say, is that companies facing sharp increases in the cost of various commodities -- but unable to raise their own prices -- are stoutly holding the line on wages, their biggest expense.
As has become common this year, partly because of new methods involving the Government's survey of households, commentators and securities traders found elements of the labor-market report hard to interpret, or, in the case of inflation, at odds with other readings.
 
Columbia Inflation Index Up
 For example, a Columbia University index intended to predict inflation jumped today to 111.4 in August from 109.5 in July, with all four available components contributing to the rise.
"It is evident," the university's Center for International Business Cycle Research concluded, "that the leading indicators of inflation are still locked in cyclical upswings and continue to point to a cyclical upturn in U.S. inflation this year."
When this result was published, the bond market gave up its early gains.
The 179,000 new payroll jobs included a 32,000 increase in factory jobs. The factory sector showed more vigor than many expected, even allowing for the reopening of automobile plants that were closed for retooling in July. The factory workweek and factory overtime, both already at near-record levels, edged up by 6 minutes and 12 minutes, respectively, also reflecting activity in the auto industry.
On the other hand, construction jobs eased 6,000 in August after 13 straight months of growth that swelled payrolls by more than 300,000, the department noted. Analysts pointed to this as a reflection of the toll that rising interest rates have taken on housing in recent months, although some jobs were also lost to exceptional rain in the South.
 
The World Cup Effect
 Employment in the retail trade was essentially unchanged after two months of robust growth. Some of the 29,000-job decline at bars and restaurants was attributed to the end of the World Cup soccer tournament.
The temporary-help sector added an unusually small 15,000 jobs, less than half the average of the preceding 12 months. But health services added 38,000 as employment rebounded at hospitals.
The so-called bias adjustment, a figure representing the estimated number of jobs at fledgling companies that the statistical mechanism does not yet capture, is 158,000 this quarter, or 88 percent of the August gain.
The department's index of aggregate hours for production workers edged down two-tenths of a point, to 129.1, while 57 percent of industries reported adding workers, compared with 58.8 percent in July, the survey of payrolls also showed. Also, the average workweek in the private sector fell by 12 minutes.
Although unchanged nationally, at 6.1 percent, the unemployment rate edged down in the Northeast, to 6.4 percent; in the South, to 5.8 percent, and in the Midwest, to 5.1 percent. The rate in the West edged up, however, to 7.5 percent. None of these moves was more than two-tenths of a point.
 
Skepticism Over Big Gain
 Among the 11 largest states, the jobless rate eased marginally in eight and rose marginally in North Carolina and Michigan. The Massachusetts rate remained at 5.9 percent.
The jobless rate in California, whose economy has been sluggish, fell to 8.9 percent in August from 9 percent in July. New York now shows a jobless rate of 6.9 percent, down from 7.1 percent, and New Jersey slipped to 6 percent from 6.4 percent.
According to the department's survey of households, the basis for calculating the unemployment rate, the labor force soared by 732,000. And 714,000 of those people -- a stunning number -- found jobs. But economists, who have long favored the payroll survey and have been particularly skeptical about the reliability of the household survey since it was overhauled early this year, tended to dismiss these increases as probably little more than partial catching-up from earlier lags.
One fact that suggests that seasonal adjustment distortions are involved is that the labor force fell by 422,000 and employment fell by 10,000 last month when no adjustment for recurring seasonal patterns is made.
The household tally also showed 489,000 workers too discouraged to look for jobs, 7,079,000 workers with two or more jobs (including 260,000 with primary and secondary jobs both full-time), and 4,284,000 people working part time who would have preferred full-time work. There was a 253,000 decline in the number of people idle for less than five weeks.

HEADLINE: U.S. Bonds Sag on Hint Of Inflation

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities slumped yesterday in a shortened trading session after a quick, early surge, as traders managed to find hints of inflationary pressures even though August's employment report was soft.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond ended the day down 16/32 of a percentage point, at 1004/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.49 percent, from 7.45 percent on Thursday -- back to where it was a week ago. 
 Yesterday's reversal reflects how sensitive the bond market has become to the slightest suggestion of inflation.
 
 
Opening Surge
 Bond prices surged when trading opened after the Labor Department reported that job growth slackened in August. The report appeared to confirm other signs that the economy was slowing, thus easing the potential for inflation.
Only 179,000 new jobs were created last month, a figure well below expectations and below July's 259,000 jobs. The unemployment rate was unchanged at 6.1 percent.
The report also suggested that wage pressure remained moderate and that the Federal Reserve would be inclined to leave monetary policy steady for now.
Normally, the report should have encouraged bullish investors to commit more cash to the bond market.
But inflation-obsessed traders quickly discovered reasons to sell, and the bond market gave back all of its gains within about an hour.
Some traders noted that the employment report showed hourly wages rising 2 cents in the month, even though the growth rate was less than in previous months.
The biggest factor in the selling, traders said, was a report by Columbia University's Center for International Business Cycle Research, which showed higher inflation in August.
Traders consider the Columbia index to be forward-looking and note that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, pays attention to it.
The center said its inflation index rose to 111.4 in August, its highest figure in five years, up from 109.1 the previous month.
 
 
Producer Prices
 "The problem, of course, is next week, with new inflation numbers that may not be so friendly to the bond market," said Stephen Slifer, chief financial market economist for the fixed-income division of Lehman Brothers. The Government reports on producer prices for August on Friday.
"We're expecting the Producer Price Index over all will rise 0.4 percent, while the core rises 0.3 percent," Mr. Slifer said.
The bond market was also weighed down yesterday by the dollar, which fell against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies. A falling dollar has capped many bond rallies this year, a bond trader said.
For investors from overseas, a weaker dollar reduces the value of dollar-denominated assets like Treasury securities.
 
 
10-Year Note Falls
 Other Treasury issues were pulled down by the bond market's retreat. The 10-year Treasury note fell 6/32 of a point, while its yield rose to 7.19 percent from 7.16 percent.
The discount rate on three-month bill rose one basis point, to 4.54 percent, while the rate on the six-month bill gained four basis points, to 4.82 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Many traders left early yesterday after the Public Securities Association recommended that the market close at 2 P.M. in observance of the Labor Day weekend.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Loses Early Gains After a Bond Rally Fizzles

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most other leading currencies yesterday, giving up early gains after a rally in the Treasury market evaporated.
Bonds jumped in early trading, pulling the dollar higher, after the Labor Department said the economy added 179,000 jobs in August. The smaller-than-expected increase spurred speculation that inflation in the United States was not poised to accelerate. 
 The bond rally turned into a loss because the report failed to convince investors that wages and prices were not rising more quickly as the economy grows. Inflation erodes the value of fixed-income investments like bonds.
"The bond rally faded, and the dollar faded with it," said Peter Gloyne, manager of institutional foreign-exchange trading at the First National Bank of Chicago. "The outlook for the dollar appears a little bearish again."
Recent strength in American stock and bond markets helped the dollar recover from lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark. Currency traders watch bond prices for clues about foreign demand for American assets, and the dollars needed to buy them.
"The dollar won't rally unless there is demand for U.S. stocks and bonds," said Earl Johnson, foreign-exchange adviser at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.5537 marks, down from 1.5750 marks on Thursday, its biggest one-day slide in three weeks. It rose as high as 1.5833 marks as bonds surged in the wake of the jobs report. The dollar fell to 99.20 yen, from 99.71 yen on Thursday.
Traders said the dollar's fall was exaggerated by investors who sold the currency before the Labor Day weekend.
"People weren't confident enough to hold dollars while they were away for three days," said Karl Halligan, vice president for strategic trading at CIC New York.
The dollar fell further after Germany's Transportation Minister, Matthias Wissmann, said the economy grew 2.3 percent in the second quarter, compared with the quarter a year earlier.
With signs that German growth is picking up speed, the Bundesbank will have little reason to lower interest rates anytime soon, a move that would make mark-denominated deposits less attractive.
In other currency trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 5.3235 French francs, down from 5.3895 francs on Thursday, and at 1.3055 Swiss francs, down from 1.3226 Swiss francs. The British pound rose to $1.5485 from $1.5461.

HEADLINE: With Brazil's New Prosperity Come Arby's and Pizza Hut

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 27

 BODY:
On Avenida Paulista, a canyon of corporate headquarters in South America's largest city, office workers looking for lunch can choose among four McDonald's, a Pizza Hut, an Arby's and a KFC.
In the next couple of weeks, Fred DeLuca, who directs an empire of 9,400 Subway restaurants from Milford, Conn., is to open Brazil's first Subway on this street. 
 With franchising nearing saturation in the United States, Latin America's largest economy is experiencing a franchising boom as American companies take advantage of Brazil's new free-market policies and economic stability.
"Brazil is where Mexico was two years ago," said Guilherme Affonso Ferreira, who opened the Arby's last year. "Volume is going to be the name of the game. Whoever arrives at the year 2000 without 300 or 400 fast-food restaurants in Brazil is going to be out of the game."
With fast-food chains leading the way, franchising is spreading. Based on a survey of its 640 members, the Brazilian Franchise Association estimates that the number of outlets will expand by 44 percent this year, to 25,600 nationally.
Evidence of the boom could be seen on the crowded floor of the association's annual fair late last month. Compared with last year, the number of exhibitors increased 50 percent, to 179, and paid attendance doubled to 27,000, largely prospective franchisees. By contrast, virtually the same number of people attended a show in Washington in April, with almost three times as many franchisers.
"I've never seen so many people at a franchising fair -- the big one in Washington was nothing like this," said Mark Baccash, a New Yorker who directs international expansion for Office I Superstore, a chain of office-supply stores.
For decades, legal restrictions and economic instability fenced off Brazil from foreign franchisers. But two years ago, the Government eased rules on the international remittance of royalties and speeded the process for the registration of foreign franchising contracts.
"There are no rules and regulations that impede us now in Brazil," said William B. Cherkasky, president of the International Franchise Association, a Washington-based trade group. Mr. Cherkasky, who has visited Brazil four times over the last decade, added, "Brazil has become a lot friendlier in the last two years."
In broader terms, Brazil may be returning to the high growth and low inflation that made it a "miracle economy" in the early 1970's. Last year's 5 percent growth rate is expected to be duplicated this year. A new economic plan has reduced monthly inflation from 50 percent in June to 5 percent in August.
Business confidence has soared, and all public opinion polls now indicate that in October's presidential elections, voters will choose Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a former Finance Minister from Sao Paulo, the country's financial center. In a recent survey of business executives, 97 percent favored Mr. Cardoso's election.
Brazil -- with 154 million people, about half the population of South America -- is where United States franchisers say they want to first plant their flag before branching out in the region. There are about 65 United States franchisers in this country.
"If you succeed in Mexico and Brazil, it opens up all of Latin America," said Aaron Cano, international marketing manager for the Ziebart International Corporation. "We have 12 franchises in Brazil. We have decided to have 60 more locations here in the next two or three years."
 
Growth Is Predicted
 Other American service franchisers predicted similar growth.
Avis plans to quadruple its car fleet to 6,500 by the end of next year. Jani King, a commercial cleaning company, plans to expand its Brazil franchise to 600 from 54 by the end of 1997.
Postnet, a Las Vegas-based office service company, recently opened its first outlet here. By the end of 1998, the company plans to have 200 outlets in Brazil. Tuffy hopes to open its first auto service center here in January, part of a plan to expand to a dozen by the end of 1995.
Over all, the biggest growth is expected to be in fast food. With about 75 percent of Brazil's people living in cities and with increasing numbers of women in the work force, Brazil seems ready for fast food.
Some 1,265 new fast-food outlets are to open this year, an increase of 56 percent. Virtually every major American fast-food franchiser is in this country.
"Over the next seven years, we plan to open 200 stores," said Mario Silva, operations director here for Subway. To cater to local tastes, Subway has included espresso coffee and ice cream on its menus.
Even so, a local newspaper, Folha, had difficulty describing some new sandwiches. The paper reported that they were "cold sandwiches, 30 centimeters long, known in the United States as 'submarinos.' "
Brazilian franchising experts warn that Americans interested in this market should do research here and be flexible.
"If a company wants to come down here and sell bagels, they should see if there is a market first," said Bernard Jeger, president of the Brazilian Franchise Association and the founder of a frozen-yogurt chain, Nicecream. "You have American franchisers who think they can sign a $500,000 contract without even investing $5,000 in coming down here to get to learn the market," said Mr. Jeger, an immigrant from Belgium.
Another hurdle is finding a local partner who will aggressively expand a Brazilian franchise.
Rogerio M. Marques, the Brazil franchiser for Radio Shack, agreed, adding, "You have to find someone who shares the same values and culture -- forget the financial part."
 
Expanding by Franchising
 A United States-educated Brazilian, Mr. Marques will open Brazil's fifth Radio Shack, in October in Brasilia, the capital. The 73-year-old company owns its stores in the United States, but decided to speed expansion here through franchising. By the end of 1998, Radio Shack wants to have 58 franchise outlets in this country.
With new franchisers from the United States complaining about the limited amount of English here, longtime American franchisers say training is a major hurdle.
"It takes time to train people to a new business, a new system," said Gregory J. Ryan, president of Restco, a company that franchises 75 McDonald's restaurants in the southern half of the country. Intending to open 20 restaurants a year through the end of the decade, Mr. Ryan plans a Hamburger University in 1995, the regional training centers for McDonald's employees.
To convey quality, fast service and low prices, many of Brazil's 565 home-grown franchisers have adopted English-language company names.
"There are Brazilian franchisers who put American flags in their logos to win credibility," said Paulo Cesar Mauro, a franchising broker.
Mr. Baccash, who has been visiting this country for almost 20 years, said: "I feel a tremendous opening to American products. Anything American is a plus."

HEADLINE: MORTGAGES;
Lenders More Forgiving Of Poor Credit Records

BYLINE: By Nick Ravo 

 BODY:
PEOPLE with smudged credit records are finding it easier to buy a home these days as hard-pressed lenders seeking customers become more forgiving of applicants with a history of late payments, delinquencies and even bankruptcies.
 Mortgages are usually graded "A" through "D" for risk. An "A" mortgage conforms to the standards set by the major mortgage buyers in the secondary market, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
Until recently, applicants with these types of nonconforming loans usually had only one recourse: "hard-money" lenders, mortgage bankers or finance companies that require huge down payments and charged credit-card rates with several points. (A point is a fee equal to 1 percent of the loan.) These loans were also generally available only for second mortgages and refinancings. 
 Now, though, lending terms for "B" and "C" loans are becoming much less onerous, and, more important, they are being offered on first mortgages, too. ("D" loans still carry astronomically high rates and require large equity levels and are generally used only for second mortgages.)
"It used to be that if Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae wouldn't buy their loans, applicants would be rejected and left to the sharks," said William Steed, president of Home Mortgage Center, a mortgage banker in Alexandria, Va., that began offering nonconforming mortgages six months ago. "But with the downturn in the economy, it left an awful lot of people out there who were behind in their payments, and it wasn't entirely their fault. They were laid off, downsized, maybe had a medical problem."
Today, they are back on their feet "and they are the same backbone of the economy that they always were," he said.
What constitutes a "B," "C" or "D" loan varies widely among lenders, as do the rates and minimum down payments. A typical "B" loan applicant is often someone who has missed a few payments but has had a stable credit record for the last 12 months, as well as a steady stream of income. A "C" rating can range from several missed payments to a bankruptcy that's two to four years old, though some applicants with bankruptcies may qualify for a "B" loan.
"The 'B,' 'C,' 'D' market is very fragmented, and there are many people in it," said John Romeo, vice president of Prudential Home Mortgage in St. Louis, one of the nation's largest mortgage bankers. "The important thing is that you have cleaned up your act," he said.
Terms for "B" and "C' loans range from an adjustable rate starting at about 7 percent with an annual cap of 2 percent, a lifetime cap of 6 percent and 3 points to fixed-rates of 11 or 12 percent and 3.5 points. A minimum 20 percent down payment is needed to avoid private mortgage insurance. As much as 35 to 40 percent may be required for some loans, however.
"In two to four years, if they have kept a clean credit record, they refinance into an "A" loan," Mr. Romeo said.
Part of the growth in "B" and "C" mortgages comes from investors are looking for higher yields in the secondary market and are willing to take the additional risk of nonconforming loans.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "THE GOING RATES" shows common mortgage terms for first mortgages. (Source: Home Mortgage Center; Abor National Mortgage)
