HEADLINE: Opening New Fronts At Battery Park City

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
ONLY a decade ago, the word "City" in Battery Park City seemed misplaced; not because the project's scale and ambition were insufficient but because this new 92-acre neighborhood on the Hudson River had little of the drama and combustion that characterize truly urban life.
While its plazas are crossed today by streams of ferry-borne commuters and its playgrounds are filled with squealing children, the development still has an insular quality that attracts those seeking a respite from Manhattan and bothers those who wish it were more public. Whether Battery Park City will ever be fully integrated into the fabric of New York remains to be seen. 
 However, it is beginning to earn the "City" in its own title. There are new trophies and simmering headaches. Plans are in a state of constant evolution. And almost everywhere, from the southern tip to the northern edge, construction is happening or impending.
South Park, embroiled in controversy a few years ago, is being built. To the north, New York's Holocaust memorial -- known formally as the Living Memorial to the Holocaust-Museum of Jewish Heritage -- is to begin rising next month, following numerous course changes since 1986.
The South Cove has just reopened after a landscape renovation. The North Cove is getting a new park, now under construction, which will link the southern part of Battery Park City to the Hudson River Park.
Overlooking the North Cove is the site of the new headquarters of the New York Mercantile Exchange, which will include two large trading floors; one for Nymex and one for Comex, the Commodity Exchange. This plan was announced a month ago and the ground lease is now under negotiation.
At the north end of Battery Park City, four sites are being offered for residential construction, with a potential total of almost 1 million square feet of space. Proposals from developers are due Sept. 16.
Nearby, the Battery Park City Authority is planning its own development, combining a public school for about 700 students (kindergarten through the eighth grade) and a tower with some 200 two- and three-bedroom apartments, 30 percent of them subsidized for middle-income families.
"The idea is to encourage families to move to Battery Park City and live here for a very long time," said David Emil, president and chief executive of the authority. "If we can do that, it will be one of the most successful things we do."
So this is one vision of the future Battery Park City: a family place of parks, schools and large apartments; a business place whose role is underscored by the new exchange; a cultural place with its own museum and expanding collection of public art, like the waterfront pylons by Martin Puryear that are to arrive next spring.
That is not to suggest an idyllic present, however. For instance, owners at the 107-unit Hudson View West condominium have been in a state of open rebellion against the authority since June 1993, withholding their ground rent payments and their payments in lieu of real estate taxes.
The president of the board of managers, Arthur J. Sikula, said an average one-bedroom apartment at Hudson View West had dropped in value over seven years to $100,000 from $200,000. Meanwhile, he said, monthly maintenance costs had risen to $1,200 from $650. That has left about half the owners in arrears. "What's going to happen," he said, "is that in the coming months the building is just going to go under."
(Because the issue is in the courts, the authority will not comment.)
Until the fate of Olympia & York is settled, a question mark will also hang over the World Financial Center, which it operates.
At present, Olympia & York "is doing a spectacular job of maintaining the project and we're very happy with the relationship," Mr. Emil said. "Olympia & York has been current on every rent payment and obligation to us. They have never been a day late. They have told us that they regard this as their most valuable asset."
LAST year, in a financial prospectus, the authority cautioned prospective bond buyers that if the United States subsidiary of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. followed its Canadian parent into bankruptcy, "a cessation of payment obligations" was possible that might "continue for a significant period of time."
But Mr. Emil said last month that the authority is confident that it would be able to collect rent from Olympia & York's subtenants at the World Financial Center in the event of bankruptcy.
And Harry W. Albright Jr., the chairman of the authority, said that the refinancing eight months ago of more than $850 million of the authority's debt "included significant reserves for any potential problems with our major tenants, including Olympia & York."
Technically, all developers and owners at Battery Park City are tenants or subtenants of the Battery Park City Authority. Tenants are charged rent ($9.2 million last year for the World Financial Center; $8.8 million for all of the residential projects) and payments in lieu of real estate taxes ($59.3 million for the World Financial Center; $11.9 million for the residential projects). Olympia & York is the tenant at One, Two and Four World Financial Center; American Express is the tenant at Three World Financial Center.
Mr. Albright said the debt refinancing would result in savings of $13 million a year and called it the most significant recent event at Battery Park City. "That debt restructuring guarantees the future financial integrity and safety of Battery Park City for a long, long time to come," he said.
The authority is undertaking a major development of its own: a $60 million public school and apartment tower at the north end of Battery Park City, across Chambers Street from Stuyvesant High School.
The school, with about 100,000 square feet of space, would occupy four or five floors at the base of the building and the 250,000-square-foot apartment building would rise above it. Construction is to begin next spring. The architects are Pasanella & Klein Stolzman & Berg and Costas Kondylis.
"We want a design oriented toward family use," Mr. Emil said. "Children under 18 don't need a marble-lined bathroom or a bedroom the size of their parents'."
By forgoing a development profit, the authority calculates that it will be able to subsidize up to 30 percent of the apartments, making them available to families with incomes between $40,000 and $60,000. A two-bedroom unit might rent for $1,000 a month.
The district manager of Community Board 1 in lower Manhattan, Paul Goldstein, said the board had long favored the idea of an elementary school and family-sized apartments at Battery Park City and was pleased to see the authority moving in that direction.
Also in the north neighborhood, the authority has issued a request for proposals from developers for four residential sites. The largest potential development, on the same block as Stuyvesant, would be a tower up to 350 feet high, with 320,000 square feet of space (roughly 35 stories and 300 units).
Two sites are on River Terrace, overlooking Hudson River Park. These could accommodate buildings of 200,000 and 240,000 square feet. The other, on North End Avenue, could be developed with 220,000 square feet.
Buildings are to follow new design guidelines devised by Ralph Lerner, Alexander Gorlin and Machado & Silvetti Associates. Mr. Emil said one goal was to create a link between Battery Park City and TriBeCa.
For example, North End Avenue was originally intended to invoke something of Park Avenue. But Musa Train Klebnikov, director of project development, said the consultants suggested developing North End Avenue as more of an extension of the blocks to the east, with lively street-level uses and the distinctive long canopies, or marquees, that overhang many TriBeCa sidewalks.
Mr. Emil said the authority also asked its design consultants what could be learned from the south residential neighborhood. "It appears in the current market at Battery Park City," Mr. Emil said, "that you need something greater than 200,000 square feet to get economies of scale."
Another set of guidelines is being developed for two key sites by Polshek & Partners, Robert A. M. Stern and Menz & Cook.
One of the sites, immediately north of the World Financial Center, could accommodate an office building with some 2.5 million square feet of space. The other site, between the World Financial Center and the Hudson River, is where the $225 million New York Mercantile Exchange is to rise.
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a month ago that the Mercantile Exchange, newly merged with the Commodity Exchange, would move to Battery Park City. Mr. Emil said a letter of intent had been signed. "We expect to have a lease before the end of the year," he said.
THE deal has ended a decade-long search for new space by the Mercantile Exchange, now at Four World Trade Center. Daniel Rappaport, chairman of the exchange, said that "an extraordinary amount" of thought had been given to moving to Jersey City.
To prevent that, New York State and New York City offered a $125 million contribution toward construction of the new building, plus $23 million in real estate tax abatements, $9.8 million in rent abatements, $6.3 million in mortgage-recording tax abatements, $4.6 million in sales tax abatements and $15 million in savings through the use of electricity from the New York State Power Authority.
The building is to have about 500,000 square feet of space, Mr. Emil said, with two 25,000-square-foot trading floors. It would overlook the North Cove park, which is now under construction, to designs by Mitchell/ Giurgola and Child Associates.
From Olympia & York's standpoint, "any development -- so long as it's in keeping with the standards and objectives of the World Financial Center -- would be a plus," said Tom P. Falus, executive vice president.
Mr. Falus said the office towers were close to 100 percent occupied. The largest recent deal involved the subletting last year of some 320,000 square feet of Merrill Lynch space to Deloitte & Touche. The World Financial Center will lose a major office tenant next summer when Daiwa Securities moves to Financial Square, at Old Slip and South Street.
"That's the only departure we've ever had," Mr. Falus said. "The reason, quite frankly, is that we didn't have the space to accommodate them." He said deals had already been made for about half of Daiwa's 100,000 square feet of space. "As a general rule," he said, "the World Financial Center is still the first choice of any financial-services tenant in lower Manhattan. The problem is that it's not available."
Retail space at the World Financial Center is quite a different story. Up to 250,000 square feet of space is designated for retail use but only about 180,000 square feet of that is "viable," Mr. Falus said. The rest is poorly situated, often downright remote. Of the "viable" space, 85 to 90 percent is rented.
"Ann Taylor has just about doubled its space," Mr. Falus said, "and food operations are generally doing very well, but some of the smaller specialty operators are having a difficult time."
Difficulties are also plaguing the Hudson View West condominium at 300 Albany Street. Mr. Sikula, the board president, traced the problem to a ground lease that he said was disproportionately high, contrasted with nearby buildings. That, in turn, affected payments in lieu of real estate taxes, which are based on assessments of apartments in surrounding buildings where the rent is not as high and where values are stable or rising.
Mr. Sikula said the rent strike and an unsuccessful lawsuit were efforts to get the authority to undertake a reevaluation of assessment and payment policies. Instead, he said, the authority has gone to court seeking to compel the owners to pay.
Speaking generally about the south residential neighborhood, and excepting Hudson View West specifically, Maria S. Crouch, president of the Battery Park City Owners Association, said: "The market has started to come back, albeit slowly. We've seen an increase in sales throughout the community and an increase in value and prices."
Ms. Crouch, who also heads the Battery Park City committee of Community Board 1, said the development had matured and was "really becoming a neighborhood."
Among other things, she cited the Holocaust memorial and museum, a two-story, 20,000-square-foot building designed by Kevin Roche John Dinkeloo Associates. Ground is to be broken on that project Oct. 16.
EIGHT years ago, the New York City Holocaust Memorial Commission entered into a lease with the Battery Park City Authority for a 64,000-square-foot parcel at the southern end of the development. At the time, the idea was to finance the memorial in part by the sale of development rights.
That plan collapsed with the real estate market. The commission scaled back the project and returned some 42,000 square feet of the site. "I believe they gave up something of great value," Mr. Emil said. "So do they."
In return, the authority committed itself to paying half the construction costs, matching private contributions dollar for dollar, up to $10 million. This is, in effect, an advance against future revenues expected from the site that the commission gave back. When the site is developed, the authority will pay another $7.5 million to the commission.
Near the memorial is South Park, 3.5 acres of rolling and formal lawns, flower beds, tree-lined allees and one-story brick pavilions, joined by a little bridge, with a cafe and viewing deck. The architects are Machado & Silvetti Associates, the landscape architects are Hanna/Olin and the garden designer is Lynden B. Miller.
Mr. Emil said a cafe operator would be selected through a request for proposals. The park is to open in the summer of 1996.
Overlooking South Park is a site earmarked for a luxury hotel, with up to 700 rooms. A request for proposals was issued in 1990 but Mr. Emil said it was never possible to achieve a successful lease negotiation. There are no current plans.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Reducing Water Usage

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS 

 BODY:
THE right to an abundance of domestic water at little cost is something Americans have traditionally taken for granted, like free speech. And they revel in the opportunity.
Several studies have shown that per capita water usage in the United States is higher than almost anywhere else in the world, with New York City, incidentally, near the top of the list. 
 It's a legacy, historians say, of the work of reformers at the turn of the century who promoted heavy water use to improve personal hygiene and control epidemics. Pressure from those reformers and the economical manner in which water could be brought into multifamily buildings also discouraged the installation of individual water meters. The costs were therefore never clearly recognized.
The resulting legacy of carefree usage is now coming back to haunt boards of condominiums and co-ops. For without personal accountability (and that may be impossible, since individual water meters are prohibitively expensive to install because many water lines come into each unit), it's going to be tough to persuade people to modify lifelong habits.
It's serious, since water costs are going up the way fuel oil costs did in the 1970's. For instance, the water bill at the 161-unit Elmwood Park Condominiums II in Staten Island rose from $16,000 in 1986 to $52,000 in 1994, without any substantial increase in consumption.
Ultimately, these increases could affect real estate values. Buildings that continually raise carrying charges to keep up with rising water bills may become less appealing compared with, say, a neighboring complex with a usage control program.
But it's not going to be easy. Consider the Toilet Rebate Program introduced earlier this year by the New York City Department of Environmental Protection. Designed to encourage owners and boards to install low-flush toilets, it offers a rebate of $150 each for every 5-gallon-per-flush toilet replaced by a 1.6-gallon model. (For details call the Toilet Rebate Program at (212) 685-5575.)
But it may be money down the drain because there's no great rush to sign up.
"None of my buildings want to bother," said Martin Filler, president of Island Condo Management, which manages some 30 buildings on Staten Island. "They don't want the mess."
Others scoff, insisting these toilets don't really work. Thus ongoing educational programs will be needed to change attitudes. And these many have to be combined with regular monitoring of building-wide usage so that any sudden spurt in demand never goes undetected for long.
In this manner, leaks -- as formidable an enemy as wanton consumption -- can be quickly detected and repaired. The introduction of new technology alone will not do the job, experts have found. Some people have quietly even removed their low-flow shower heads.
Despite these obstacles, there are some interesting success stories. Philip Howard Apartments, a 600-unit co-op on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn, gained the cooperation of its shareholders for the new toilet installation program by having the contractor install one of the new models in the co-op's offices (free of charge) and letting residents test it themselves. Units of matching bathroom colors were also offered.
Board members or residents might also be persuaded to visit the laboratory and showrooms of a plumbing concern that does these installations. In New York City, for instance, there's the exhibit at Water Savers Inc. at 451 West 46th Street.
To constantly remind residents of the water consumed by even a minor drip, Doug Kleine, executive vice president of the Soil and Water Conservation Society, headquartered in Ankeny, Iowa, recommended setting up a display in the lobby that shows how much water is lost when, say, even 5 drips a minute are left untended. It's done by showing how quickly those drips fill a large container. A calculator could then interpret those losses in dollars on a building-wide basis for an entire year, perhaps on a colored chart.
"You have to continually remind people and find ways to eliminate obstacles to behavior change," Mr. Kleine said. "You can't just tell them once."
Mr. Kleine has studied the conduct of condominium residents for more than a decade as the former director of research for the Community Associations Institute. He suggested that if the condominium or co-op consisted of several buildings, then a similar chart or contest might regularly report on one building's usage over another's, assuming each building had its own water meter. Peer pressure, he noted, might then do the rest.
At the four-building, 1,500-unit Watergate at Landmark condominium in Alexandria, Va., thousands of gallons are being saved through an innovative maintenance program that might be duplicated in almost any setting. The board hired a national consultation and contracting company, Metropolitan Water Saving Inc., of Bethesda, Md., to check each apartment for leaks and repair those leaks as detected.
To avoid heavy upfront costs, an agreement was worked out whereby the company would be paid on a cost-saving basis. Its fee would equal 75 percent of the saving on water bills compared with costs a year earlier for the first three months after completion and 50 percent for the next 33 months.
Should usage suddenly spurt during the term of the three-year contract, the company would be responsible for detecting the leak and making the repair, with its incentive based on restoring the cost savings to a point where it continued to collect a monthly fee.
The goal is also to assure ongoing monitoring of consumption. The company agreed to make that check on a twice-weekly basis. The condominium now plans to reactivate the repair program every six or seven years so it becomes a regular part of operations.
David Wilborn, president of Metropolitan, said the deal made financial sense based on its own research, which indicated that a toilet -- the heaviest domestic water user of all -- normally increased consumption to 185 to 200 gallons a day after five to seven years as a result of minor leaks. More normal usage is
125 gallons a day. Ninety percent of the toilets in the first phase of Watergate project were found to have either small or major leaks.
After completing repairs on only two of the Watergate buildings, its water saving for May and June alone totaled $11,956, reports Ron Kirby, president of Community Management Corporation of Fairfax, Va., the managing agent.
Access to all apartments was assured, he noted, because the condominium's lawyers explained to residents that saving money on water usage was a board responsibility since water charges were part of monthly maintenance. Thus the board had a fiduciary responsibility to keep those costs down. And even small, undetected leaks could raise everyone's costs even if the fixtures themselves belonged to the unit owners.
A newly published, easy-to-read, 112-page book on the topic, "How much is enough? Controlling Water Demand in Apartment Buildings," by Peter H Judd, offers excellent ideas, too.
Dr. Judd was formerly the chief of conservation in the New York City Bureau of Water Registry and a conservation planner with Northeast Utilities in Connecticut. For a copy of the $31 book call the American Water Works Association at 1-800-926-7337 and refer to catalogue number 20291GK.

HEADLINE: Welcome Business, Unwelcome Change

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
WHEN you ask people in Mystic what they want their community to look like 20 years from now, their answers go something like this: "More toward Nantucket than Coney Island." Or, "I don't want it to become the Southeastern Connecticut Gift Shop." While these descriptions may be imprecise, they show a concern for preserving the charm as Mystic grows as a tourist attraction.
Southeastern Connecticut, and Mystic with it, is certainly in a tourism boom. This is the region that includes Ledyard, where Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino is situated; Montville, where the Mohegan Indians plan to open a gambling casino; Norwich, which recently became home to a minor league baseball team, and New London, which is being promoted for development as a vacation destination. And so, Mystic Marinelife Aquarium and Mystic Seaport Museum plan to expand. If the demand for tourist information is an accurate indicator, vacationers are reacting to southeastern Connecticut's attractions. Connecticut's Mystic & More, a travel promotion bureau, has had requests for 88,733 information packets this year, up 24 percent from the 1993 total, according to the bureau's chairwoman, Rita Schmidt. 
 When Stonington's First Selectman, David S. Burdge, started spending summers in Mystic 40 years ago, there were only three motels and a few restaurants in the area. Today, there are 4,000 rooms in hotels, motels or bed and breakfast establishments and dozens of eating places. The quiet, seaside community of Mr. Burdge's youth has been transformed as families and groups of school children flock to the aquarium and seaport. The downtown business district is a hubbub of window shoppers and traffic. Crowds of people in T-shirts, shorts and sneakers amble along the narrow sidewalks, ice cream cones in hand, pointing out shops and historic homes to each other.
 
Another Atlantic City?
 As they watch all this activity, residents say they are torn between a desire to preserve the beautiful shoreline and small-town atmosphere that inspired them to settle in Mystic and excitement about the new business opportunities in tourism. Some people say they fear the problems associated with casino gambling may spread to Mystic. Others argue that zoning regulations and the legal limits on gambling protect Mystic from becoming another Atlantic City or Coney Island.
Niel Spillane, who moved to Mystic 33 years ago, said he fought hard to preserve the residential character of his neighborhood near downtown Mystic. As the influx of vacationers started in the early 1970's, he said, complaints about tourist traffic became staples of cocktail party chatter. But controversy really boiled up recently around a proposal by the Mashantucket Pequots, owners of the Foxwoods casino, to build a two-story private club in downtown Mystic that would include a store, public restrooms, a meeting room, bar and outdoor deck. The tribe plans to transport Foxwoods patrons from Ledyard to Mystic by bus and run boat trips from the club's dock on the Mystic River. More than 800 residents signed petitions opposing the project. The Stonington Planning and Zoning Commission, which held four public hearings on the Mashantuckets' application, must make a decision by Oct. 7. Some people involved in the debate raised the broader question about what type of place they want Mystic to be in the years ahead and how they can make their vision a reality.
"Who's looking out for the needs and future of this region?" asked Susan Duncan, who moved to Mystic with her family three years ago. "I'm not sure anybody is. I've talked to a lot of people over the last three years, and there's not as much vision as I would like to see."
Mrs. Duncan and her husband, David, organized Mystic Residents for Compatible Development, a group of about 40 families who oppose the Mashantuckets' plan. Members say the proposed club would add more traffic and noise to already congested downtown streets, and its connection with Foxwoods would create an environment for crime. The group is not against all development, said David Duncan, who added, "Change is not bad as long as it's well planned and thought out."
 
Building a Resort
 But a lawyer for the Mashantuckets, Jackson T. King, said gambling in Mystic is out of the question. "It's a hundred percent illegal and not what the tribe wants to do," Mr. King said. "The tribe is engaged in building a full-scale resort, so when people come in, they have things to do in the whole region. The tribe has for a couple of years now been encouraging guests at the casino to visit Mystic Seaport. Many residents and merchants tell us they're happy with the proposal and that it's something they would welcome."
But William Yates, who has lived in Mystic for 27 years, said he wonders how much development is enough. "The more people you add, the more attraction there is to add services," he said. "It's a snowball."
Anything they do at the Foxwoods casino, he said "adds to the potential for people to come down here and for more hotels, motels and amusements."
Solving land-use problems is complicated in Mystic, since the community is divided by the Mystic River into sections that lie in the towns of Groton and Stonington. A dense commercial district surrounded by stable, historic residential neighborhoods lies to the west on the Groton side of the river, and large tourist and retail attractions, including the seaport, aquarium and the Olde Mistick Village shopping center, are on the east bank in Stonington. The two downtowns are connected by a drawbridge, which is raised every hour, putting another bump in the traffic flow.
The Groton side of Mystic is in a historic district, which allows regulation of changes to buildings, parking lots and the appearance of streets. Stonington, however, voted down the idea of a Mystic historic district.
 
Traffic and Parking
 Although Groton and Stonington have undertaken several planning efforts and studies over the years, both jointly and separately, traffic and parking problems persist. And there is no formal way for the towns to work together on land use decisions, Groton's Mayor, Dolores E. Hauber, said in a report she gave last May at the Mayor's Institute on City Design.
Yet, decisions made over the years by one town have affected the other. Ms. Hauber mentioned as an example the opposition of Groton residents to a plan to place the word "Mystic" on the Exit 89 sign on Interstate 95, which would have directed tourist traffic through one of Groton's residential areas. The state's Department of Transportation is expected to present several alternatives at a meeting this month, Mr. Burdge said.
Another example of a decision that had an impact on both towns, Ms. Hauber said, was Stonington's approval of contemporary condominiums directly across the river from the stately Greek Revival homes in Groton.
The towns are beginning to value collaboration more, however, as shown in the purchase of property on the Stonington side of the river for a waterfront park. And Groton's town manager, Ronald P. LeBlanc, noted that officials and business owners from both towns are meeting to find solutions to transportation and parking problems. Stonington's director of planning, Blanche Higgins, said, "I think the towns are working more closely now than they have in a long time."
Although Foxwoods has brought badly needed jobs to southeastern Connecticut, the casino, which has its own hotels, restaurants and shops, does not appear so far to have had a direct effect on business in Mystic. Sales this summer have been about the same as last year, depending on the type of business, a member of the Mystic Chamber of Commerce, Donna Williston, said. Mrs. Williston, who owns a frame shop and gallery, is chairwoman of the chamber's Downtown Committee. "Some say business is flat, no better than last year. Others say it's better. I can't say I've seen a trend or a high percentage of increase in traffic," she said.
"People are taking their disposable income and going to Foxwoods," said Ms. Schmidt of Connecticut's Mystic & More group. Mystic, then, must build an identity that stands on its own and attracts tourists year after year for reasons other than gambling, Ms. Schmidt said. Orderly development may mean drawing a steady stream of vacationers throughout the year instead of encouraging jam-packed streets in July and August.
The only valid question concerning the Mashantuckets' private club, Ms. Hauber said, is whether or not the building complies with zoning laws. Mr. King said the building would allow only about 30 parking spaces. A number of boats, the largest carrying about 60 people, would operate several trips daily from the dock.
Even though Groton and Stonington are communicating more than ever, the towns respect each other's autonomy. "We can't tell Stonington what to do," Ms. Hauber said, referring to the Mashantuckets' plan. "Tourism is here to stay. How do we work with it?" she asked. "What effect will Foxwoods have on all this? I'm glad the Mashantuckets are doing it. And it's on the reservation. We'll watch to see how it goes. We're not in Ledyard."
As the region moves from an economy dependent on military contracting, the changes in the way of doing business seem frightening, Ms. Hauber said. "We always had tourism, but more people are coming in, different people," she explained. "There's been a shift in our economic growth, and when you see all that, you tend to worry if it will work out. I have faith in the tribe."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Traffic clogs West Main Street, on the Groton side of town. Across a drawbridge, it's Stonington. (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 8; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1436 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Art World;
Galleries, Off Critical List, Opening or Expanding

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
WHEN Gary Snyder opened Snyder Fine Arts in SoHo four years ago, the gallery stuck out like a sore thumb. It specialized in American art from the 20's through the 50's, a much better fit with the uptown art scene than with the avant garde art in SoHo. But SoHo space was $16 a square foot and rents on 57th Street were triple that.
Not anymore. Next month Mr. Snyder will move into 2,000 square feet at 20 West 57th Street, a building just off Fifth Avenue that has several galleries carrying traditional art. And he is paying less than $30 a foot. 
 "We did O.K. in SoHo, but a gallery like ours fits better uptown," he said. "And rents have come down so tremendously that we can finally afford to be there."
Mr. Snyder is not alone. Brokers report that in the last six months dozens of galleries have been opening or expanding, particularly in the historically art-rich 57th Street corridor between Park Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, and in the town houses off Madison Avenue in the 70's.
"In the last six months we've made 10 or 15 gallery deals," said E. William Judson, the president of Judson Realty, a brokerage firm that many galleries use. "There's so much activity that space on upper Madison Avenue is actually getting tight."
Other brokers make similar reports. "I did no gallery transactions at all in the last couple of years," said Robert L. Freedman, a vice chairman of Williams Real Estate. "Now I'm handling two expansions."
It is quite a change from the way this decade started out. Indeed, if misery truly likes company, then real estate people probably spent a lot of time hobnobbing with art dealers over the last few years. The real estate market was ailing, but the art market was virtually dead. Many galleries closed their doors as their owners either left the art world or handled their dwindling business from their homes. Many of those that hung in did so only by negotiating slashed rents with their landlords.
Now, thanks to the recovering economy, the seemingly moribund art world is showing a pulse. "The art market in America is really picking up, and all this moving around is just one sign of it," said Gilbert S. Edelson, a vice president of the Manhattan-based Art Dealers Association of America.
Indeed, the art market is looking so promising that many first-timers are opening dealerships. Ian G. Kennedy and Simon Dickinson, both long-time executives at Christies Fine Art Auctioneers, recently opened Simon Dickinson Inc., a gallery specializing in old masters. Mr. Dickinson is handling the London end of the business; Mr. Kennedy has leased space at 14 East 73d Street.
Similarly, last fall James Reinish resigned from the venerable art dealership Hirschl & Adler to join Martha Parrish, another Hirschl & Adler veteran, in a new gallery. For a time they operated out of Ms. Parrish's 600-square-foot office at 790 Madison Avenue, near 67th Street. In July, they moved into 1,400 square feet at 25 East 73d Street.
"We wouldn't have moved if the art market hadn't been doing well," Mr. Reinish said.
For buildings that specialize in art gallery tenants, the change comes not a moment too soon. With more than a third of its space devoted to galleries, the Fuller Building -- 595 Madison, at 57th Street -- is the art industry's uptown fulcrum. The building started the year more than a quarter vacant. Today it has plenty of office space available, but its gallery space is disappearing fast.
"We can pretty much rent any galleries that become available now, and that certainly wasn't true two years ago," said Thomas T. Garden, a vice president of LaSalle Partners and the building's leasing agent.
NEARBY buildings are trying to capitalize on the art market's rebound. A couple of years ago the Crown Building, 730 Fifth Avenue at 57th Street, lost a tenant that had occupied 100,000 square feet at the base. The space has high ceilings and a long, deep layout. To most office tenants, that means a dearth of windows and corner offices; to galleries, it means lots of wall-display space and controllable lighting.
The building's owners courted gallery tenants, at first to no avail. But in the last year Israel Sack, the antiques dealer, has taken 11,000 square feet and the Kennedy Galleries have leased about 8,600, both gargantuan deals by art gallery standards. Kenneth Krasnow, a broker at Cushman & Wakefield who handles leasing for the building, says he is negotiating several more gallery leases.
"Until recently, you couldn't get a gallery owner to listen to what you have to say," Mr. Krasnow said. "Now many are so confident of their future that they are rushing to move while rents are still reasonable."
That mentality is not confined to 57th Street. For several years, Bonni Benrubi ran her photography dealership out of an office on East 74th Street and had hankered to open a public space. This year she finally did it.
"My market has gotten very strong, but the rents are still affordable," said Ms. Benrubi, who recently leased 1,800 square feet of gallery space at 52 East 76th Street.
In a sense, art galleries are a landlord's delight. Most are happy with low floor space that corporations often spurn, or space in town houses that are too noncorporate for most commercial tenants. They rarely expect rich landlord contributions to improving their space, even though some of them install expensive millwork, ceiling effects and the like. Since the galleries thrive on unpartitioned rooms, landlords can generally rerent the space to another gallery if the first one leaves, without making many changes.
And even with the lower concessions, art galleries will often pay higher rents than commercial tenants. Mr. Judson says that gallery space on 57th Street is going for $25 to $35 a square foot. That's lower than the $40 to $50 such space commanded five years ago, but half again as much as SoHo gallery space is commanding. And it is a nice sum for landlords awash in small spaces, and more than most office tenants would pay.
In industry-concentrated buildings like the Fuller Building, rents are even richer. Mr. Garden says he is asking from the mid-$30's to $40 a square foot for gallery space, and tenant representatives say he is achieving those rent levels.
"Galleries pay a premium to be clustered together," said Mr. Freedman of Williams.
UNLIKE, say, supermarkets, which want to distance themselves from competition, galleries have a symbiotic relationship with their rivals. Potential customers are far more likely to plan a buying trip if they can visit several galleries selling similar genres without wasting too much time traveling. In fact, some dealers are teaming up, not only to share the rental expense of a gallery, but also to give would-be buyers a chance at one-stop shopping.
Adam Boxer had been operating a by-appointment-only business selling avant garde photography out of his Brooklyn home. He wasn't going broke, but he certainly wasn't getting throngs of visitors. The Brooklyn location was part of the problem; dealing from home was the other part.
"Somehow, people feel they are intruding when they are in your home, so they feel obligated to buy something," Mr. Boxer said. "Because they hate that sense of obligation, many just don't come at all."
So this year Mr. Boxer joined with three other art dealers. One had closed her gallery a year ago because of the economy, another wanted to try her hand at art, the third has another gallery on 18th Street. Together, they formed the Ubu Gallery, which will officially open later this month at 16 East 78th Street.
"Many of our European clients stay at the Mark Hotel a block away, and many of our New York clients live on the upper East Side," Mr. Boxer said. "We want people to feel comfortable dropping by, maybe to sit in our garden, maybe just to browse."
The supply of well-located and well-appoiinted gallery spaces is dwindling fast. Brokers and art dealers alike report that, aside from space in large 57th Street office buildings, good uptown gallery space is getting harder to find.
Mr. Kennedy discovered that when he went hunting for space this year. One of the first places he saw was the fourth floor of 14 East 73d Street. The space had nice views and a spiral staircase that can accommodate large canvases. But Mr. Kennedy wanted to hold out for higher ceilings.
"Everyone said this was a buyer's market, that it would be easy to find exactly what we wanted," he said. "Well, we looked and looked, and there really isn't a lot of space available for our needs." He took the 73rd Street space.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

GALAPAGOS NATURE
Fifty of Katie Lee's illustrations of the flora and fauna of the Galapagos Islands, soon to be published in "A Visit to Galapagos" (Abrams, New York) go on display at the Silo in New Milford today through Oct. 2.
They are remarkable studies in gouache and pen and ink, depicting every last whisker, feather and scale in clinical detail, yet elegant, artful and emotionally compelling. Not only do they hold the attention of the viewer far longer than most paintings do, but they also evoke a welter of thoughts about the world's wildlife, which is what Ms. Lee had in mind. Conveying respect for all of the planet's creatures and plants is her mission. 
 The exhibition also contains paintings of butterflies, flowers and other subjects that she found on trips to Brazil, Venezuela and the Amazon. Her work has been shown in England and Australia, as well as the United States, and has been commissioned for educational television programs and by institutions such as the Smithsonian. A public reception for the artist is to be held next Sunday from 1 to 3 P.M. The Silo, at 44 Upland Road, is open every day from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. free of charge. Call 355-0300 for more information.
 
ILLNESS AND DRAMA
 Something a little different is in store for theatergoers who attend the Second Step Players' production of "Postcards From the Ledge: A Relevant and Irreverent Look at Mental Illness." Performances will be given at 7 P.M. on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center in Waterford. Second Step Players, based in Norwich, is composed of artists and production personnel who have received diagnoses of mental illnesses.
A certain nuttiness is not unusual in the theater under any circumstances, and this troupe extrapolates on that premise with cheerful abandon. The show is loud, funny, oddball and touching in its exploration of what it means to be crazy in America. In one segment the future of managed health care is raked over the cuckoo's nest at the Mental Health Depot, Your Psychological Superstore. There is group therapy for bikers, and a fashion scoop on what the sartorially correct manic-depressive will wear next season.
Tickets are $14 at the door, $12 in advance, and for people who are under treatment for mental disorders, $10. The theater is at 305 Great Neck Road and the number for reservations or more information is 443-1238.
 
MORE BOGOSIAN
 Eric Bogosian -- the actor, writer, social critic, satirist and humorist who brought us "Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll" -- has a new one-man show called "Pounding Nails in the Floor With My Forehead." It will arrive at the Yale University Theater, 222 York Street in New Haven, on Saturday for two performances, at 7 and 9:30 P.M.
The piece, directed by Mr. Bogosian's wife, Jo Bonney, won an Obie this year for excellence in writing. Mr. Bogosian has been riding a wave of success that began with "Drinking in America" and "Talk Radio," which was made into a film by Oliver Stone. "Sex, Drugs, Rock & Roll" was also adapted for the screen, and directed by John McNaughton.
"Suburbia," Mr. Bogosian's most recent play, opened at Lincoln Center last spring to enthusiastic reviews. "The Essential Bogosian," a collection of his work, was recently published by the Theater Communications Group.
"Pounding Nails" is a series of portrayals of men searching for "the baby within," timid men recovering from the women's movement, men fearing deadly disease, and men who obsess about anything and everything. But as Bogosian fans know, the portrayals, while slashing and burning contemporary society, are as hilarious as they are accurate.
Tickets are $21, students $11. Call 432-1234 for reservations or more information.
 
TALKING ANTIQUES
 As a lecture title, "You're Richer Than You Think" certainly gets one's attention. Henry Callan, a well-known appraiser of antiques, will deliver a talk by that name at 9 A.M. on Saturday during the 19th annual Putnam Cottage Antiques Show in Greenwich.
Mr. Callan has collected antiques since he was 12 years old, and over the years he has also collected master's degrees in history, theology and library science. He has taught school, lived in France and sailed around the world.
Culled from all this experience is a keen eye for the worth of things and which ones appreciate over time as opposed to those that do not. Inflation, he believes, has increased the worth of many people's possessions more than they realize, and he will give advice on how to appraise what you have, how to protect it, when and how to sell, and how to invest more wisely.
The lecture and antiques show are to be held at the Old Greenwich Civic Center on Harding Road from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturday and 11 to 5 on Sunday. Nearly 60 dealers will display 18th- and 19th-century furnishings, paintings, prints, china, crystal, silver, jewelry and other items.
A china and glass restoration clinic will be available for consultation and repairs, and Mr. Callan will give verbal appraisals during both days for $5 an item. Admission to the show is $5; admission to the show, lecture and light breakfast on Saturday is $10. Call 637-9708 for more information.
 
ROAD RALLIES
 Two road rallies are scheduled this month by the Fairfield County Sports Car Club, sanctioned by the New England Region Sports Car Club. The first, starting at 9:30 A.M. Saturday, will be a 135-mile run over paved and unpaved roads in northwestern Connecticut and southwestern Massachusetts.
Drivers may register and have their cars inspected for $25 from 7 to 9 P.M. Friday and from 8 to 9 A.M. Saturday at the Fairfield Inn, Hartford Airport, 2 Loten Drive in Windsor Locks, where the rally will start and finish. A rally seminar for new teams will be held at 8 P.M. on Friday.
The second rally, on Sept. 24, will be held in Rhode Island, starting at the shore in Misquamicut. To register or obtain more information call 489-6503.
 
FLORAL COMPETITION
 "A Floral Palette," a Garden Club of America flower show presented by the New London Garden Club and the Lyman Allyn Art Museum, will open at the museum on Friday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and continue on Saturday from 11 to 5. Competing floral arrangements will be placed in the museum's various galleries, complementing the paintings, sculpture or decorative arts on display.
A horticulture section will feature rooted plants, house plants, cut specimens, herbs and vegetables. An educational exhibit will depict the biodiversity of the Burnham Brook Preserve in Haddam. In addition, a slide-lecture on the restoration of Harkness Gardens and Mansion in Waterford will be given each day between 2 and 4 P.M.
Admission to the show will be $5, and admission to a preview party on Thursday from 6 to 8 P.M. will be $30 a person or $50 a couple. The museum is at 625 Williams Street in New London. Call 443-2545 for more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

LENGTH: 1605 words

HEADLINE: Community Colleges Gain Students and Some Respect

BYLINE: By JOHN McQUISTON 

 BODY:
OVER half of all freshmen entering public and private colleges across the country this fall are enrolled in community colleges, and at the top of the list are Nassau and Suffolk Community College.
"We're part of a national phenomenon that's occurred over the last two years," said John F. Cooper, the president of Suffolk Community College, which got its start 35 years ago in makeshift classrooms in Sachem Junior-Senior High School in Ronkonkoma. 
 "We're now the largest multi-campus college in the state, with more than 22,000 students, plus an additional 22,000 noncredit students," he said.
Nassau Community College, which held its first classes 35 years ago in the basement of the Nassau County Court House in Mineola, is also in the running for first place, with a total of 44,000 students, half noncredit.
 
Long Island's Largest
 From its campus in Garden City on the site of the old Mitchel Field Air Force Base, Nassau is the largest college on Long Island, according to Sean Fanelli, the college's president.
"There is no doubt that there's a growing trend. Students are making more and more use of community colleges as a means to prepare themselves for four-year institutions," Dr. Fanelli said. "When you compare the cost of tuition and the quality of education available at our community colleges, there is no contest."
"We're hoping the trend will help end one of Long Island's biggest exports, its students," Dr. Fanelli said. He was encouraged by the fact that 6,600 students -- one of every three college-bound students who graduated from high schools in Nassau in June -- were registered at Nassau Community College this fall.
"We've gone from a school of last resort for many students, to their first choice," Dr. Fanelli said.
A similar turnaround in attitudes occurred among high school graduates in Suffolk, Dr. Cooper said. "It's taken two or three generations, but we finally seem to have become legitimate."
"This is a change that's occurred nationwide," he said. "For the first time in the history of education in the United States, the community college is being accepted and people are discovering what it's all about."
Both Dr. Cooper and Dr. Fanelli attributed the change to a variety of reasons, with the cost of education topping the list.
With tuition and fees at both Nassau and Suffolk totaling about $2,000 a year, it remains the least expensive of all public and private colleges on the Island.
 
Numerous Changes
 The recession of the 1980's, the restructuring of the Long Island economy brought on by the end of the Cold War, and a rapid shift from defense-related manufacturing to a service economy, have had a heavy impact on family budgets and left less money available for education, educators say.
There has also been a demographic change in the population of Long Island, a shift reflected in the changing student enrollments at both Nassau and Suffolk Community College. Minority students, including African Americans, Asians, and Central and South American immigrants, make up more than a third of the student body.
"For those just entering our society, the community college remains an affordable path to become a part of our way of life," Dr. Fanelli said.
"More and more immigrants are arriving on Long Island from other countries, and for them to become productive citizens, they need an opportunity to educate themselves. We can provide that opportunity."
"We have a large campus and lots of flexibility in the courses that we offer," he said. "We also have a very talented faculty and a curriculum tied to career opportunities."
"For example, we have a nursing program that has a very strong enrollment of nearly 400 students, with placement in all local hospitals, that's envied nationwide," he said.
A variety of other health-related programs are also available at both Nassau and Suffolk colleges, primarily as a response to community demand.
Because of the shift away from military-related manufacturing at once-large employers like the Grumman Corporation, courses in engineering technology, tailored to the changing job market, are offered by both colleges to many older noncredit students.
"We're willing to set up classrooms almost any place where we are needed," Dr. Cooper said, noting that the college served more than the traditional two-year transfer student. Suffolk's main campus is in Selden, its western campus is in Brentwood and its eastern campus is in Riverhead.
The college opened a satellite facility, the Technicenter, in an industrial park in Hauppauge in 1985, designed specifically for business and industrial training.
 
Most Students Are Women
 The average age of a student at Suffolk is now 27, while at Nassau it is 26. And more than 60 percent of the students are now women, a complete turnaround from 20 years ago.
"As more and more women have emerged into the workplace, they have become aware of what's available to them, and that includes higher education," Dr. Cooper said. "It wasn't all that long ago that many people believed women ought not to go to college."
While both Nassau and Suffolk college are open to any high school graduate, it's now first come, first served.
"It's not as if we're turning anyone away, but if the classes are full -- and we like to keep a ratio of 21 students per class -- then those students who register late lose out," Dr. Fanelli said. "But if they look around, they'll no doubt still find something open to them."
The success of both colleges has, however, come at a price that lawmakers in both counties no longer seem willing to pay.
 
Critics Among Supervisors
 The Nassau County Board of Supervisors late last month grudgingly approved a $111 million dollar budget for the 1994-95 academic year for Nassau Community College, up from $107 million last year and nearly double the budget 10 years ago. But the supervisors said they would reject a proposed faculty contract unless the school made cuts totaling $850,000, or raised tuition by $100, a move that Dr. Fanelli said would "not be fair to the students."
"Over the last four years, the student share has gone up and up, but the county's share has stayed the same," Dr. Fanelli said.
Suffolk and Nassau Community were established under the provisions of the New York State Education Law. They operate under the policies of the Board of Regents and the supervision of the State University of New York.
According to the education law, the financing of a community college is to be divided into three parts, with a third from the state, a third from the county or sponsor, and a third from tuition paid by students.
In both Nassau and Suffolk, the students' share in recent years has increased to between 32 percent and 33 percent, while the counties' share has dropped proportionately.
This and other cost increases have caused tuition to nearly double at both colleges over the last 10 years, but students believe it is still a good deal when compared to private college tuition.
Among the more vocal critics of the teachers' contract was Lewis J. Yevoli, supervisor of the Town of Oyster Bay. He said teaching salaries at Nassau averaged $76,000 a year and were higher than at Harvard or Yale.
"If the teachers' union is serious about entertaining thoughts for another contract, they're going to have to be prepared to give back more than they have," Mr. Yevoli said.
But the teachers' union said the supervisors were using the faculty as scapegoats, arguing that the school budget had not required a tax increase for Nassau voters in six years.
 
'A Slap in the Face'
 "To be blindsided like this at the last moment by the Board of Supervisors, which hasn't even taken a close look at the contract, is a slap in the face to collective bargaining," said Robert Karmon, a vice president and spokesman for the union.
The Suffolk County Legislature late last month approved Suffolk college's $84 million budget for the new school year, but not without first demanding job cuts totaling $900,000.
During a meeting on Aug. 26, trustees at the college agreed to half of the cuts by approving a job freeze on eight vacated positions. However, the trustees voted unanimously to restore 13 of the other job cuts -- all administrative positions.
To pay for the restored positions, the trustees ordered an organizational review of the college by Dec. 1 in hopes of coming up with a plan to save an additional $450,000. Since the salary of the average teacher at Suffolk is $49,100, the Legislature has been less critical after comparison with the teaching costs at Nassau.
The cost to the average property owner in Nassau County is currently $51.80, while the tax bill for a homeowner in Suffolk is $8.40. School administrators say the main reason for the difference is the higher cost for teachers at Nassau.
"But the majority of our teaching staff has been here far longer than the staff at Suffolk, which has had a greater turnover," said Dr. Fanelli, defending the high salaries at Nassau. "If we were talking about the salaries of doctors and lawyers, no one would complain. Why should the teaching profession be underpaid?"
"There are those who say, 'Well, it's just a two-year community college, why should its faculty be so well-paid?," Dr. Fanelli said. "That kind of thinking angers me."
"But I can understand that many taxpayers are now retired, that the population of the Island is aging and that many young people are moving out," Dr. Fanelli said. "But for about 10 cents a week, a taxpayer can invest in one of the great stabilizing forces in our society: education."

Below, Candice McEvilley, a freshman, scans a list. (Photographs by Maxine Hicks for The New York Times); Lisa Sealy, who is from Jamaica, waits for her daughter to enroll.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Signs of Stability Keep Sao Paulo Hot

BYLINE: By James Brooke 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
WITH one month to go before Brazil's presidential election, a centrist candidate has decisively overtaken his socialist opponent in all opinion polls, setting off a frenzy of investment and pushing Sao Paulo's stock index up 67 percent since the beginning of July.
This year, in fact, the Sao Paulo stock exchange has risen faster than any other exchange in North or South America, thanks in part to foreign investors who pumped $1 billion into the exchange in August alone. 
 Sao Paulo's market has been driven by opinion polls in the Oct. 3 presidential election. Back in May, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva, a socialist trade unionist, was leading in the polls with more backing than all other candidates combined. That month, the Sao Paulo index lingered at $10, the year's low point. (The index is valued for foreigners at the dollar exchange rate for a composite basket of stocks.)
By late August, when the polls showed Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a Social Democratic candidate of Brazil's establishment, far ahead of the other candidates, the Sao Paulo index reached a high of $23.
"The market clearly believes that Cardoso is the next President," concluded Wayne A. Perkins, vice president for equity investment of Chemical Bank's affiliate here, Banco Norchem S.A.
Behind Mr. Cardoso's surge in the polls is the short-term success of a new economic plan that he designed as Finance Minister before stepping down in April to run for president. On July 1, Brazilians adopted a new currency, the real. Backed by $42 billion in reserves and a precariously balanced federal budget, the real actually appreciated against the dollar. From even parity on July 1, the real now trades for 88 American cents.
At the same time, the real delivered a blow to inflation in an economy where prices rose by 5,000 percent in the year ending on July 1. Monthly inflation plummeted, from 50 percent in June to 5.5 percent in August.
"The election of Fernando Henrique Cardoso and the success of the real plan would be the best news of the decade for Latin America," Argentina's Economy Minister, Domingo F. Cavallo, said last Monday in Buenos Aires. With monetary stability, he predicted, Brazil will grow by 7 and 8 percent a year for the rest of the decade.
Once markets found the real credible, long-term credit returned to Brazilian stores. Manufacturers of goods like color televisions and motorcycles are operating at capacity, breaking production records.
"Market agents are operating with a future dollar below a real in February," said Alvaro Augusto Vidigal, president of the Sao Paulo stock exchange, Bovespa. "This means a great success."
The combination of economic and political stability has been ambrosia to investors in emerging markets. Foreign participation accounted for 28 percent of Sao Paulo's market in August, up from 16 percent in June. Daily trading averages nearly doubled in August, rising from $258 million in the first week, to $493 million in the fourth week.
On Aug. 15, investors in the Sao Paulo market set a record for trading in one day, $2.38 billion. The following Monday, Aug. 22, investors set another record, for the number of transactions, 17,978.
"Before, people said, 'I won't invest in a country with 50 percent monthly inflation,' " recalled Roberto Serwaczak, director of sales and trading at Baring Securities do Brasil. "Then they said, 'I won't invest because of the political risk.' Now, inflation is down, and Cardoso is going to be elected."
Last September, Brazil's markets suffered a downturn as emerging market money managers sold millions of dollars in holdings to lock in profits. This year, market analysts predict that managers will hold on to their shares in anticipation of a continued rise after a Cardoso inauguration on Jan. 1. Even if Mr. Cardoso fails to win a majority of valid votes and the election goes into a second round on Nov. 15, all polls indicate that he will still win the presidency.
"The market is mirroring the growth of Cardoso in the polls," said Mr. Vidigal of the Sao Paulo market. "The market is acting as if he already has won." This is because investors see a Cardoso administration as offering continuity in the anti-inflation fight and an accelerated program to privatize Brazil's unwieldly state enterprises.
With privatization looking possible in 1995, analysts are recommending stocks in state-run telephone and electric power companies, like Telebras and Electrobras. Low inflation also means increased consumption of paper for packaging and cement for construction.
Some fund managers predict that a Cardoso victory would attract $5 billion more in foreign investment into Brazil's stock markets. From an opening to foreign investment in late 1991 to the middle of this year, net foreign investment in Brazil's markets rose to $10.5 billion.
Predictions are often difficult to make because of Brazil's history of volatility, .
"If there is an economic disaster, like a violent spurt of inflation, the markets will go through an earthquake," Veja, the nation's leading newsweekly, cautioned last week.
In early August, Baring Securities was recommending that investors "take profits in the short term," noting that the market looked overextended.
One week later, Baring was predicting that the index could hit $25. "With Cardoso's phenomenal rise in the polls and almost certain victory in November," it wrote, "Brazil is a BUY."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Confidence Dip Imperils Stocks And Clinton

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
THE American economy is growing at a nice clip. But public confidence is not. And because many do not think the future will be better than the present, both investors and Democrats may be in for disappointments.
The lack of optimism may seem puzzling. Since President Clinton's election, the number of people with jobs has grown by 4.7 million, or 4.2 percent. Not since Jimmy Carter has a presidential term begun by producing so many jobs. 
 The problem is that Americans are not at all confident that the recent past is prologue. On the job front, they are far less optimistic than they were just after the election. In December 1992, the Conference Board's monthly survey of consumer confidence found that 21 percent thought there would be more jobs available in six months. Now the figure is 13 percent.
Why the change? "A lot of the gains in employment have been in jobs at the low end of the pay spectrum or that don't have as much security," says Jason Bram, an economist at the Conference Board.
At a similar point in the first Reagan Administration, the economy was in recession, and employment was down 1.4 million since the election. But the three forecast questions asked by the Conference Board -- whether there would be more jobs and better business conditions in the economy, and whether the respondent expected higher earnings in six months -- got more positive replies then than they do now. Even in recession, the middle class then felt confident. Now, with white collar layoffs continuing, the Government deadlocked on health care reform and GATT ratification in jeopardy, the future seems less certain.
It is not just consumers who are fretting. Many on Wall Street see signs the economy is slowing. Those concerns probably are misplaced -- David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, notes that the seers wrongly feared weak fourth quarters in both 1992 and 1993 -- but for some purposes perception is reality.
The Conference Board has been surveying consumer sentiment since 1969, and has developed two indexes, one reflecting consumer views of the present situation, and one reflecting the future outlook. In forecasting, what matters is the relationship of the two indexes.
In August, for the first time since 1990, the future index slipped to a point where it is just under the current index. Historically, if it falls to at least a nine-point difference, the stock market suffers. That happened, for example, in September 1987.
In addition, the relationship of the two indexes at the time of mid-term elections has forecast the coming presidential race. If the future looked better than the present, the incumbent party kept the presidency. And vice versa.
If those historic relationships are believed, it poses an interesting dilemma for Wall Street Republicans, which is to say most of those on Wall Street. Should they hope that the mood will improve, providing a positive sign for stocks? Or that it won't, providing a negative sign for President Clinton?

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Merger Made in Heaven? For Now

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla 

 BODY:
IT WAS just hours after the engagement was announced, and the two executives conversed with all the deference and high hopes that are typical of the just-committed couple. "We both offered to step down" as chief executive officer, said Norman Augustine, C.E.O. of Martin Marietta, in an interview on Tuesday. Instead, an office of the chairman would be created to include both of them because, as every starry eyed couple can tell you, "two heads are better than one."
"If we don't (agree on things), Norm's the boss," offered Daniel Tellep, C.E.O. of Lockheed Corporation, which is merging with Mr. Augustine's company. 
 But from the sound of things, such a showdown might never be necessary. The two corporate cultures couldn't be more compatible, Mr. Tellep said, and the companies' technologies, products and services were most complementary.
Prospects frequently look rosiest to the key players when the romance of the deal is fresh. And last week, with heady deal-mania in full bloom all around them, who could blame the two executives for assuming that their companies would be, as they say, a perfect strategic fit?
Indeed, observers of the merger scene are bullish as can be about the prospects for success among Corporate America's latest unions. Equally certain to the merger bulls is that even more deals will ensue in the years ahead. "M&A feeds M&A," said Laurence S. Grafstein, a director at Wasserstein Perella & Company. "Big deals generate activity because they're usually not perfect fits," setting off further combinations.
But will most of them work?
To hear most people talk on the subject, the answer is yes, today's mergers can't lose. So-called strategic deals, in which two compatible corporations -- like Martin Marietta and Lockheed -- become one, make business sense, the argument goes. This is not the indulgent stuff of the late 1980's, where financiers took over and stripped companies to exploit (read: sell) their assets and move on to dismember the next victim.
These are deals that produce improved companies, the optimists argue. And because they largely are deals in which the two companies combine their stock, they lack the 1980's twist of burdening corporations with excessive debt. Or at least so far.
Samuel Hayes III, investment banking professor at Harvard Business School, said that, for the moment, the nation's banks are flush with money but are being choosy about whom they lend it to. "They're going for proven names with particularly convincing stories to tell about a restructuring," he said.
But with the merger movement "straining at the gate ready to pop out as soon as it finds an opening," Mr. Hayes figures that, sooner or later, the banks will lower their standards and begin to rationalize reasons for dicey loans.
Meanwhile, though, Wall Street is full of persuasive explanations that the deal craze is justified, and that it's sane. Leaving aside the question of how you pull off a sane craze, investment bankers say that the increasing pace of mergers is partly a function of pent-up demand during the recession, and partly a response to external factors, such as a gutting of the defense budget or the prospects of a national health care system. There is also the lure of becoming a behemoth, like Lockheed Martin or the combo of Federated and Macy, at a time when lower anti-trust barriers seem to make such mergers easier.
And companies are resorting to mergers because they've squeezed all they can out of their costs, and are aching to find a way to grow revenues at a time when they can't raise prices. "If unit growth is at the two-to-three percent level, and you want to jack that up, you can only do it through M&A," said Steven Wolitzer, co-head of mergers and acquisitions at Lehman Brothers.
But companies are paying dearly for those revenues in some cases, raising the question of whether shareholders are getting their money's worth. "Companies are saying 'Holy cow, I've got institutional investors on my back because I'm not growing,' " said one investment banker who requested that his name not be used. "But prices are not cheap, and you may see some shareholders pay too much" for those revenues.
Along with their due diligence on how much is too much to pay for revenues, the firms tying the knot now had better take care to check one another for financially transmitted diseases. That doesn't just mean checking whether there is too much debt on the books, said Lawrence A. Cunningham, a professor at Cardozo Law School. Because of the losses some companies have suffered from their use of financial instruments know as derivatives, Mr. Cunningham said that merger partners should carefully examine any hedging strategies.
Analyzing what's on the books, while perhaps not easy, is at least a more scientific process than that of assessing whether two cultures can mesh -- the big wild card of the mergers boom of 1994. "Whether a specific deal makes sense depends partially on whether personalities can work," said Robert Lessin, vice chairman in charge of investment banking at Smith Barney. "At the end of the day, there is an expectation in these deals that personalities can mesh."
How often does it work? Reflecting a far more pessimistic outlook than most of his peers on Wall Street, Hamilton E. James, chairman of DLJ Merchant Banking, said his guess is that merging companies attain all their synergistic goals about ten percent of the time. Executives in the merger mode aren't much different from the soon-to-be-married man and woman who couldn't imagine they might one day be an entry in the nation's grim divorce statistics, Mr. James said. "Everyone thinks 'It won't happen to me,' " he said. But the stars can vanish from a C.E.O.'s eyes too. And shareholders can be left wondering why the magical synergies that were to have made them richer never quite gelled.
