HEADLINE: Business Diary: August 28 - September 2

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring 

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
The Economy Cools as It Coasts Into Labor Day
In the last flurry of statistics before Labor Day forces everyone to start acting like a grown-up again, the economy is looking pretty much as it has for a while now: it's slowing, but not too much. Consumer confidence eased for the second month in August, and the housing market is still heading down -- as people kick themselves for missing those rock-bottom mortgage rates. As for the unemployment rate, it's coasting along at 6.1 percent -- about where it's been for four months after plunging early in the year. But the slowing trend showed up in a report that just 179,000 payroll jobs were added in August -- fewer than expected. And inflation? Nowhere on the horizon: average hourly earnings rose just 2 cents last month -- nothing to set off a spending spree. Given all this, it seems unlikely that the Federal Reserve will feel the need to raise interest rates again at its policy meeting this month. But you never know. 

Scalper's Price for the Garden?
The folks with calculators decided Madison Square Garden was worth $600 million to $800 million, but Cablevision wanted it badly, so when the smoke from a high-priced bidding war cleared last Sunday, the price to be paid by an ITT-Cablevision partnership had hit $1.075 billion. In cash. For Viacom, which got the Garden as part of its Paramount purchase, that'll make a welcome dent in its debt. But why was Cablevision so eager? Simple: It craves New York sports. It will now own the Knicks and Rangers, plus the cable rights to the Mets and Yankees and sundry other teams -- such a stranglehold on the market, in fact, that New York's Attorney General, G. Oliver Koppell, raised antitrust eyebrows.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Irish Stocks Are Smiling
What's a body to do when, after 25 bloody years, hopes of peace burst forth in Northern Ireland? Some surely raised a toast in the local pub last week, while others -- the type who see a sunset and want to know the investment angle -- found at least one way to put their money where their hearts were. Shares in the Irish Investment Fund, a closed-end fund that has nearly 95 percent of its assets in Irish common stocks, shot up on word of the I.R.A. cease-fire, with daily volume jumping above 100,000 from the usual 15,000 or so.
 
Visiting China, Seeing a Market
When Commerce Secretary Ron Brown traveled to China last week, he added weight to his visit -- a push for "commercial diplomacy" -- by asking 24 American chief executives to tag along. Those executives were properly awed, both by the huge market they saw and by the huge tasks ahead. "This is the largest power market in the world," said one utility executive. But as another put it, "If there is one thing we have learned, it's that the Chinese don't move fast on anything." As the visit ended, Mr. Brown reiterated his theme that he wanted to get going on building commercial ties between the two nations.
 
Times Square on a Diet
You don't think of Times Square as a low-cal sort of place. Everything's big, overdone, high in artery-clogging glitz. And while smoking is practically an endangered pastime, there above the boulevard Joe Camel puffs merrily away. But wait: Joe Camel's gone. (The billboard had served its purpose, R.J. Reynolds said; its removal last week was unrelated to assertions that it enticed children to smoke.) In its place is a very different message, in giant letters: "Cut Fat Intake and Live Longer!" It is a celebration of new nutrition labels by a man named Phil Sokolof, who had once needled fast-food chains for their cholesterol-laden offerings and who now, in addition to renting the billboard for two months, is offering $1 million in a supermarket sweepstakes.
 
A Million-Dollar Leer
Sexual harassment is no big deal. What are a few lewd remarks, the occasional groping, as long as the almighty dollars flow in? At worst, a wrist will be slapped, a few pennies paid. . . . Yes, some people still believe that (probably male people), but they got an ear-splitting wake-up call last week. A former secretary at Baker & McKenzie, the world's largest law firm, was awarded $7.1 million in punitive damages after asserting that a Baker partner had harassed her and that the firm had turned a tolerant eye. It was a staggering sum -- twice what even the woman's lawyer had sought. But as one juror put it, "When you get religion, you should tithe" -- so the jury figured 10 percent of the firm's capital was about right. Now that's a message.
 
Making Sure Directors Care
This is the way it's usually done: a company hands a director a check -- $50,000 or $100,000 a year, say -- and even if the stock disintegrates, that check is good. But Scott Paper had a different idea (well, Travelers had it first): give board members a solid, pocketbook reason to care what happens to a company. Last week Scott said it would give outside directors 1,000 shares a year, period. No fees, no bonuses, no options, no perks. At the news, the stock jumped more than $2 and now stands at $65.50, up from $37.25 since April.
 
COMPANIES
 
Pair of Networks for Sale
In television land, nothing is forever -- or even for very long. A year ago, cable was king and networks the beggars. But price controls have trimmed cable's sails, while those geriatric networks are moving more briskly. So last week there was talk of two deals in the works: Time Warner in talks to buy NBC, Disney looking fondly at CBS. Both deals seem naturals, for NBC has disappointed its owner, General Electric, while it's clear that Lawrence Tisch is more than ready to get rid of CBS. And both Time Warner and Disney would love guaranteed programming outlets.
 
A Cup Too Hot
Many people agree that good coffee at the perfect temperature is, well, one of nature's wonders. And McDonald's, obsessed with giving people what they want, consistently, thought it had found that perfect temperature: 180 degrees. Perfect for drinking, maybe, but not for dumping on your lap -- all too likely in this meal-juggling age. That's hotter than most restaurants serve it, and can cause bad burns far more quickly. And a jury just awarded $2.9 million to an 81-year-old woman who'd scalded herself on McDonald's coffee. Absurd? Let the drinker beware? Perhaps. But the jury was convinced that in spite of previous scaldings, McDonald's didn't seem properly concerned. Pass the iced coffee.
 
The Survivor: Lockheed Martin
Forget those vague descriptions of the post-cold-war world. Here's what it really comes down to: a nation of Fritos and soft drinks. The Lockheed-Martin Marietta merger, announced last week, will create a company about the size of Pepsico. Not that it's a small deal: the $10 billion merger is the largest ever among military contractors. But in these "Darwinian times," as Martin Marietta's chairman put it, joining forces was the only way to survive. The Pentagon's shopping list is awfully short these days, and Lockheed Martin (the new name) will rely on the Government for 60 percent of its revenues. Does the deal raise antitrust issues? Of course. But economic realities may well outweigh them.
 
If Detroit's So Hot, Why Sell?
Times have rarely been better in the American auto industry; Detroit can barely get cars to dealers fast enough. So why would top officers of one of the Big Three be unloading stock? That's exactly what investors asked themselves on Wednesday when they heard that in late July 13 Chrysler vice presidents had sold nearly 150,000 shares -- more than a third of their holdings. Investors quickly dumped Chrysler stock -- and then G.M. and Ford. But maybe the summer bills were just piling up, or tuition was looming, for many analysts saw no end to the good times.
 
Galeries Lafayette Heads Home
Galeries Lafayette thought it could barge into the classiest shopping neighborhood in New York -- the corner of 57th and Fifth -- taking over the old Bonwit Teller site. But last week, less than three years later, it threw in the silk scarf, paid its landlord -- a fellow named Trump -- $20 million or so to get out of its 15-year lease, and started packing up. The verdict was that the store never quite found its market, that it didn't travel well -- that, basically, New Yorkers had plenty of places to buy similar stuff. So what's coming to that high-profile spot? Nike Town, described as a multimedia retail extravaganza. Not, presumably, just a place to buy sneakers.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Facing the Currency Risk Question

BYLINE: By Carole Gould 

 BODY:
INVESTING overseas is a two-part equation: the stocks or bonds you bought must perform well, and so must the currencies of the country where they were issued.
This year has proved to be a good lesson in the second half of the equation. The currencies of Japan and Europe soared against the dollar, lifting the returns of mutual funds invested there that had not hedged currencies back to the dollar.
But when the dollar strengthens, unhedged funds could make money abroad in local market terms but lose when the profits are converted into dollars. Hedging would allow the same fund to earn the market return but would neutralize the currency component. 
 Currencies are "volatile and unpredictable," said Mark W. Headley, director of international investments for Litman/Gregory in San Francisco. But whether it pays to erase their impact from your portfolio "is a very gray area," he added.
Mutual fund managers fall into three camps. Some accept currency risk because currency movements cannot be predicted and hedging is a big distraction from picking equities or bonds. More important, some managers argue, currency movements are neutral over long periods.
A notable proponent of this view is Sir John Templeton, who started the Templeton group, which is now owned by Franklin.
"If you intend to keep stock 5 to 10 years," it won't matter whether currency goes up or down, because what you are buying is a share in a business," Sir John said, and what counts is the success of that business.
But even he has had second thoughts. Eight years ago when Sir John bought shares in Cifra, a large Mexican supermarket chain, he wavered in his conviction not to hedge, he said, because he thought Mexico's currency would fall. It did, but the price of groceries outpaced the peso's slide, "and in terms of American dollars, the stock price went up to 20 times what we had paid for it."
By contrast, Sir John does hedge short-term equity investments, which he defines as shares held less than five years, because currency volatility does not have sufficient time to play itself out.
As for fixed-income investments, "If you invest in bonds, you need to hedge because changes in the currency will change the value of the bonds," Sir John said. For example, because British bonds are denominated in pounds, the principal is repaid in that currency when the bonds mature in 10 or 20 years. If the pound is down against the dollar at payment time, investors will lose money.
Nearly all overseas bond funds hedge their investments. The sole exception is the T. Rowe Price Overseas Bond Fund, which normally has very little exposure to the dollar, making it the top-performing overseas bond fund -- down 1.7 percent in 1994 through July, compared with -5.5 percent for its group.
"If one hedges bonds all the time," said George A. Murnaghan, a vice president at Price, "you increase the correlation of overseas bonds to U.S. bonds, factoring out the currency potential and losing some diversification." Even so, the Price Overseas Bond Fund was hedged in 1992-93, up to its legal limit. "On the fixed-income side, hedging is a more complicated question than on the equity side," Mr. Murnaghan said.
Hedging is done with forward contracts or currency options. These have two costs: dealer expenses and premiums pegged to differences in short-term interest rates. The bigger the spread in interest rates between two countries, the bigger the premium; therefore, the more expensive it is to hedge.
Some equity fund managers like David Herro of Oakmark International accept currency risk unless there's a compelling reason not to. Mr. Herro has hedged since the fund's inception two years ago, for instance, because "the economic evidence suggests that the U.S. dollar is strongly undervalued."
To decide whether to hedge, Mr. Herro, a value investor, looks at the differential in short-term interest rates here and abroad, relative economic growth levels and "purchasing-power parity" differentials (the costs of similar goods in various countries).
His analysis was muddled this year as the dollar fell, hurting the fund's performance. He recovered somewhat in mid-July as the dollar firmed, but Oakmark International is still down 1.5 percent through July, compared with +1.5 percent for all foreign stock funds.
The third camp, which includes some excellent fund managers, can't decide whether hedging pays off. "Very mixed feelings," is the way Jean-Marie Eveillard, who runs Sogen International and Sogen Overseas, describes his current position.
Mr. Eveillard, who did not hedge currencies for 14 years, began just over a year ago, as he increased his exposure to foreign equities. "It's one thing if the portfolio is 10 to 15 percent invested abroad, but something else if it's 25 to 30 percent, particularly in Europe," where currencies are not pegged to the dollar. (Many Latin American and Asian currencies are dollar-linked, making hedging unimportant except during turmoil when the link might break down.)
In fact, academic studies show that currency swings have little impact on performance when overseas investments account for less than 10 percent of a portfolio.
So Mr. Eveillard hedged two-thirds of his exposure to European currencies and "at least since the beginning of this year, that's been wrong," he said. The portfolio is still hedged, "probably," he said, "because of sheer inertia."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Siberia Awaits the Onslaught

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER 

DATELINE: YAKUTSK, Russia

 BODY:
TO a traveler flying in the wake of the turbulent Lena River as it snakes deep into the richest forests of Siberia, the wilderness looks vast, utterly untouched. It must be one of the last places on earth where it is possible to race above the tree tops for hours without seeing anything made by man.
Bear, tigers, sable and wolves roam free here. The physical treasures in the region -- 5 million square miles if one measures from the Urals to the Far East -- are unparalleled, and to many eyes, so is its harsh beauty. 
 But if no place in Russia -- or the world -- is bigger or less developed than Siberia, perhaps no place is under greater threat from oil companies, timber concerns, industrial combines and mining outfits.
Siberia has been Russia's great cash cow for more than 300 years, since Westerners started shipping pelts out of here by the boatload. As diverse as it is large, Siberia has long provided Russia with almost 20 percent of the world's gold and silver, more than a third of its iron and almost that much of its timber.
The exploitation has only deepened over the decades, partly because Siberia has so much to offer and partly because it is almost impossible to grasp how much of it there is. Almost every tropical rain forest in the world could fit within the 2.3 million square miles of forest land in the Russian Far East alone. In Lake Baikal, Siberia doesn't just have the world's largest and deepest lake, but a body bigger than Belgium that holds more than 20 percent of all the fresh water on earth. If the promise of a place this rich has always astounded naturalists, however, it has also caused industrialists to tremble in anticipation.
"This place could become the greatest environmental disaster area ever created by man," said Mark M. Shatz, deputy director of the Permafrost Institute here, which studies the fragile ecology of the massive layer of ice that lies beneath most of Siberia. "The only thing that is saving Siberia right now is we are too big to destroy very easily and Russia is too poor to rip it apart. But they are trying as hard as they can."
There is not much argument on that point. The they he is talking about -- Japanese eager for timber, Americans hungry for oil and Russians thrilled to sell it all to them -- have swarmed across the taiga in search of its great riches. Few people talk about the consequences for the environment. Mining methods most people discarded in the days of the California gold rush are in vogue here: tens of thousands of acres of topsoil have been ruined by methods that rake the earth until it spits out diamonds, gold or silver.
That causes erosion, pollutes rivers and makes land unstable. And in the north -- where the ecosystem is so fragile that it can take 40 years for a birch to grow 10 feet high -- it is particularly devastating.
But mining techniques aren't the only problem. From the fisheries of Magadan to the logging camps outside Khabarovsk, from Mirnyi, where diamonds are as plentiful as anywhere on earth, to the oil fields of western Siberia, which holds almost 20 percent of the world's hydrocarbon reserves, Siberia is slowly being ravaged by developers who have neither laws, regulations nor popular opposition to hold them back.
Oil drilling technology is primitive. There are virtually no safeguards to detect leaks. Millions of trees have been hacked away in places where they are needed most for preservation of the soil and protection of the rivers. Land is wasted on a scale that is hard to comprehend.
 
Patrimony for Sale
 There is little publicity about environmental hazards. Russia has no Environmental Protection Agency, no Occupational Health and Safety Administration, no Bureau of Land Management. If zoning laws did exist they certainly wouldn't mean much in Siberia. Advocates, however vociferous, are often poorly trained, separated by thousands of miles, and rarely effective.
The Government is desperate to earn hard currency, and nowhere can it do that more effectively. Siberia, home to 18 percent of the nation's people, produces nearly 70 percent of its hard currency export earnings.
And the easiest way for Russia to earn money in Siberia is to dig it out of the ground or chop it down. There is always a tension between jobs and the environment -- particularly in ecologically sensitive areas. But there is no strong voice to protect the snail darters and the spotted owls of this country.
Dozens of endangered species are put in greater peril every year on the taiga, the sensitive belt of thinly forested land between the arctic permafrost and the sturdy forests of the more temperate south. When anyone does speak up, he or she is usually drowned out by pleas for the money, money that they hope will appear once Hyundai or Weyerhauser provide new jobs.
"This part of Russia has been in a depression for a very long time," said Aleksei N. Makhinov, director of the Institute of Water and Ecological Problems at the Far East Branch of the Russian Academy of Sciences in Khabarovsk. "People will sell anything they can for security. The forests, the animals, the fish in the sea. Its all money now, and there just aren't many people who want to talk about the consequences."
 
And Now for the Good News
 The only good news for the environment is bad news from other perspectives: the economic problems that have beset the nation since the Soviet Union died are so severe that rapacious development has actually slowed. That has helped alleviate the threat to Lake Baikal, which only a few years ago was starting to feel the strong polluting effect of an enormous paper mill on its southern shores.
But the green light for development is on, and to some degree it has been for 20 years. Oil has invaded the lakes of western Siberia. Reindeer herds have been driven by man and development farther north than they have been in 100 years. Forests have been burned and gouged to make space for villages that were home to workers in oil towns and mining villages. Many of those villages are dying now, thanks to a lack of money from Moscow to finance their endeavors. But no matter how many people leave, their departures don't bring the trees back.
And environmental officials from Moscow to Magadan agree that it won't be easy to fashion a practical safety mechanism for Siberia -- not when there are so few good environmental laws on the books. And when a large company shows up offering jobs to workers who have not been paid in months, it is unrealistic to expect them to put their pristine environment first.
"We want to do it right," said Nikolai T. Yakouba, general director of Russian Far East and Siberian Trade for JK International, an American timber company. "But we can't exactly go in and construct American standard safeguards when competitors are doing things at a third of the price. And we can't be a timber company and stay out of the biggest market on earth. So tell me, how would you protect Siberia?"

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Taking Sausage;
The Art of Reprocessing the Democratic Process

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ALREADY, some pundits and politicians are weaving a tidy narrative around the collapse of health care reform. The Clinton Administration overreached, they say. After a long and vigorous debate about the Clinton plan, people gradually turned away from the idea of a comprehensive overhaul and Congress responded to their will. The Framers, in other words, would be pleased; the system worked.
But there is another case to be made: That the system was simply overwhelmed by millions of dollars worth of lobbying, polling and advertising. That it was whipsawed by two years of strategizing and manipulation by the top consultants and theoreticians in both parties. That Americans were taken on an emotional, 18-month journey that produced not a new consensus but an exhausted paralysis -- and is likely to feed their already corrosive cynicism toward their government. 
 In short, there is substantial evidence that the deadlock on health care is a monument not to the Framers' system, but to what we have done to it: a harrowing example of what happens when the tools, techniques and philosophy of the modern campaign are brought to bear on the policy-making process.
Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster who tracked the health care issue for NBC and The Wall Street Journal, said: "The worst of the process worked. Yes, there was a dialogue, but it was so influenced and affected by the special interest groups that the public didn't get a true and honest debate. What they learned is everything they had to fear -- and very little about what they could hope for."
Bob Blendon, an expert on public opinion and health at Harvard, said the public still wants to do something about the faults and failings of the health care system. They grew wary of the Clinton plan, he said, and worried that Congress was rushing to slap together a new one. "But what they say in all the polls is, 'We want an alternative plan, less threatening, less bureacuractic, but still a major plan,' " Mr. Blendon added.
They might not get it. Congressional leaders say they still hope to find a modest, scaled-back alternative when they return after Labor Day. But when policy-making is played out by the rules of modern politics, as the health care struggle has been from the start, it makes compromise -- especially bipartisan compromise -- very hard to reach.
This is hardly the first time that a public policy dispute spilled out of the Capitol and into the venues ordinarily used for election campaigns. The fight over Medicare in 1965, and over President Harry Truman's proposal for national health insurance in 1949, prompted a wave of leafletting and advertising. The fight over the North American Free Trade Agreement had the feel of a campaign. But campaign technique keeps developing, in a kind of arms race, and rarely has there been a more avid group of practitioners than there was in the health care struggle of 1993-94.
Modern politics exalts the grass roots, so interest groups spent $50 million in advertising to cultivate "grass-roots" sentiment, much of it simply to raise fears about the risks of various plans. A study by Darrell M. West and Diane J. Heith, political scientists at Brown University, estimated that "groups opposed to the Clinton program outspent those that favored it by a 4-to-1 ratio in the advertising area." They concluded that "the one-sided nature of the ad expenditures had important consequences for the health care debate."
Modern politics also reveres the lawmaker who is quiveringly sensitive to the folks back home, so the best-organized interests -- like the National Federation of Independent Business, which targeted small businesses in numerous Congressional districts -- have become as powerful as any committee chairmen searching for a compromise.
Modern politics is prefaced on the idea that taxpayers are fundamentally tax-averse, so all the efforts to achieve a major expansion of coverage have been stymied by the fact that almost no one will propose a broad-based tax increase to pay for it. "Rather than educating our constituents about the tough choices, too many politicians in both parties are once again pandering to them -- promising the impossible and then feigning shock when the Congressional Budget Office inevitably weighs in with the painful truth," Representative Dan Rostenkowski wrote not long ago.
"The fact is, if we want more Americans to have better insurance, we're all going to have to pay for it," the Illinois Democrat added.
More than anything, modern politics never goes off campaign footing, which has proven to be particularly damaging to the prospects for health care legislation. Republicans note -- correctly -- that even before the Clinton Administration had a health care package, it had a deeply political strategy to sell the plan, and allies touting it in partisan terms. William Kristol, a strategist for conservative Republicans, asserted in an interview: "That authorized the use of political means to oppose their campaign. And in some respects, it delegitimized them."
The stakes for each party -- as a party -- became very clear very fast. Democratic strategists were telling lawmakers that a health care bill was critical to their re-election efforts; a much-circulated memo by Mr. Kristol in December warned Republicans that passage of the Clinton plan "will revive the reputation of the party that spends and regulates, the Democrats, as the generous protector of middle-class interests."
The news media slipped into the campaign mode as well, said Tom Patterson, a politial scientist at Syracuse University. Much of the coverage focused on whether Mr. Clinton was winning or losing, "as opposed to the merits of health care reform," he said.
The debate, by midsummer, was unrelentingly partisan, evocative of the last days of the 1988 Presidential campaign -- not fertile soil for a bipartisan deal. There are those, of course, who argue that it was a healthy debate, particularly if the alternative is the smoke-filled room. "The alternative to a political debate that engages the public is an interest group-dominated, behind-closed-doors Congressional process of making deals," Mr. Kristol said.
And it can be stipulated that change of this scale is inherently hard. Joseph A. Califano Jr., who lived through the successful effort to pass Medicare in 1965, noted that Lyndon Johnson had just won re-election with 61 percent of the vote, had a 68-vote Democratic majority in the Senate, had Everett Dirksen as the Republican leader and was himself "probably the most effective legislator we've ever had." Even so, Mr. Califano said, "we had to give the doctors and hospitals what they wanted to get it passed."
Still, Mr. Califano said, "the climate is much more partisan today, and the lobbyists are richer and more sophisticated." He added that in 1965, "there was a great deal of confidence in the capacity of government to do something."
 
The Atwater Doctrine
 Today, the public reflects a 30-year trend of lost faith in government. The consultants and the politicians -- and Mr. Patterson would add the press -- responded to that cynicism in the health care struggle and in many instances fed it, as they have in one campaign after another in recent years. "The American poeple are cynical and turned off about all the institutions, and politics is only one of them," said Lee Atwater, the late Republican consultant, arguably the most influential of his era, in an interview in February 1990. "Bull permeates everything."
Now the voters have something else to be cynical about: a two-year-long, fiercely partisan, bitterly divisive campaign that has ended -- at least so far -- in a confusing deadlock. "We had to overcome the fear of change and I think we were unable to do that," an Administration official said sadly this week. While people "intuitively know" that they are being victimized in the current system, the official said, "they're very fearful of government and very fearful of change."
Of course, the problems in the health care system remain: the 39 million who are uninsured, the gaps in coverage for millions of others, the costs that consume a greater and greater share of the Federal budget and the gross domestic product. There are still legislators on Capitol Hill who remember this. In the tactical din of the modern campaign, it is easy to lose sight of the reality outside.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
How the Serbs' Serb Began To Look Like a Diplomat

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: POZAREVAC, Yugoslavia

 BODY:
FOR Bozidar Babic, a designer of window displays here in Slobodan Milosevic's home town, it is quite clear: the Serbian president has become a traitor by abandoning his brother Serbs in Bosnia.
"What President Milosevic has done amounts to an act of treachery," Mr. Babic said. "He has committed high treason by suddenly turning on the Serbs he supported. I have always voted for him, but now I really don't know if I would again." 
 The dismay of this solid citizen of Pozarevac, a provincial town east of Belgrade that is typical of the rural communities that have provided the bedrock of President Milosevic's support, underlines the political risk taken by the Serbian leader in denouncing the Bosnian Serb leadership as war profiteers and severing land and telephone links with the more than one million Serbs waging war west of the Drina River.
The risk is not immediate: President Milosevic's control of state television, the police and the army make his position secure. But it is profound: President Milosevic's near-mythical authority was tied to Serbian nationalist aspirations, his determination to back Serbs marooned in Croatia and Bosnia by the breakup of Yugoslavia, and his image as a man who does not bend. Now, it seems, he has blinked.
The change of heart has proved as perplexing to the international community as it has to the inhabitants of Pozarevac. Russia, apparently trusting the Serbian leader, wants to reward Mr. Milosevic immediately by easing trade sanctions. Opposed to the Clinton Administration's threat to lift the arms embargo on the Bosnian Muslims next month, Russia sees its approach as an effective way to isolate the Bosnian Serbs permanently from their former patron and ultimately end the war.
But the Clinton Administration is suspicious and wants several hundred international monitors placed on Serbia's border with Bosnia before there is any talk of ending Serbia's isolation.
The debate is an important one. Reward the Serbian leader too quickly and he has begun to escape the world opprobrium linked to the war crimes of the Bosnian Serbs he armed and long supported; moreover, he may take his prize and resume discreet aid to the Bosnian Serbs' war effort. But rebuff his gesture, by maintaining the sanctions or setting politically unacceptable conditions for lifting them, and a potentially decisive turning-point in the Balkan conflict may be squandered.
Faced with this choice, Western diplomats in Belgrade have resumed their favorite game of trying to analyze the motives of the inscrutable and reclusive 53-year-old Mr. Milosevic, who cultivates the air of a deity by remaining largely invisible and offering rare pronouncements designed to carry the force of revelation.
In the most cynical view, Mr. Milosevic's decision to back the latest international peace plan for Bosnia -- and break with the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, for rejecting it -- was completely in character for a leader interested only in his own hold on power and now convinced that economic sanctions must be eased if the Serbian economy is to survive another winter.
"Serbian nationalism was never more than a means to an end for Milosevic, a way to satisfy his lust for power," said Milan Bozic, the dean of the mathematics department at Belgrade University and an opposition member of Parliament. "If he has to sacrifice 15,000 square kilometers of land for that power he will do so, because he is above all a brilliant apparatchik and tactician. Now, in time, he will simply crush Karadzic, as he had crushed others before him."
Other views are that the Serbian leader is merely maneuvering for short-term gains and that he will inevitably resume his drive for a "Greater Serbia." Or that he has never really been interested in "Greater Serbia" -- words he has never publicly pronounced -- but only in assuring that the large Serbian minority in Bosnia and the smaller one in Croatia secured adequate protection and political representation.
"It's simple," insisted Mihailo Markovic, a senior member of Mr. Milosevic's Socialist party. "Milosevic believes half of Bosnia is enough for the security of the Serbs in Bosnia, and that is all he has sought." The American-backed peace plan offers 51 percent of Bosnia to the Muslim-led Government and 49 percent to the Serbs.
But amid all the debate about the Serbian leader, a more fundamental issue appears to have been largely overlooked. It is that over the past two years, the Serbs of Serbia and those of Bosnia and Croatia have simply grown apart. Already divided by their histories, they have found themselves with less and less in common. In this sense, President Milosevic's decision was merely a reflection of the facts on the ground, and, as such, may prove durable.
During the Second World War, the Serbs of Croatia and Bosnia bore the brunt of the genocidal assault on the Serbs by the puppet-Nazi Croatian Ustashi and later formed the initial backbone of Josip Broz Tito's Communist Partisan movement. Their unbending attachment to the land they now occupy and the often barbaric violence they have shown in defending it are linked directly to this memory and this trauma.
For Serbs in Serbia, the experience of the war was somewhat different, and many joined the royalist Chetnik movement, which clashed with the Partisans. Thus, even during the Second World War, Serb fought Serb.
The issues, of course, are different today. But it remains true that while many Serbs in Serbia may see a roughly 50-50 division of Bosnia as reasonable, the Bosnian Serbs react in a much more visceral way.
 
Growing Apart
 Moreover, their societies have been evolving differently over the past few years, with Mr. Karadzic stressing traditional Serbian values and the role of the Orthodox Church -- he has introduced compulsory religious teaching in schools -- and Mr. Milosevic retaining the traits of a Socialist and a secular man. Thus any "Greater Serbia" would almost certainly lead to a power battle between them over real ideological splits.
"When in history has a state willingly decided on a course of self-extinction?" asked Jovan Zametica, a close aide to Mr. Karadzic. "And yet, that is what Mr. Milosevic wanted to force on us. This will not be forgotten by the Serbs of Bosnia."
His remark underscored the fact that a profound rift has arisen, rooted in history and now exacerbated by the war. It therefore seems unlikely that Mr. Milosevic will reverse course, however much he has shifted in the past.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Reaching for the Stars in the New Military

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN the 1960's, a hard-charging, freshly minted second lieutenant wanted to go to Southeast Asia to experience combat in the Vietnam War. In 1990 and 1991, commanders turned away many young officers who volunteered for action in the Persian Gulf region.
For generations of American warriors, there has never been much of a question: the essence of soldiering is fighting and winning. Officers have been willing, even eager, to put themselves in harm's way, because the surest route to high rank and regard has been to lead troops into battle. But today, in the absence of old-fashioned wars with clearly defined front lines, soldiers who have toiled largely in anonymity are coming to the fore to deal with many non-traditional missions, from combatting drug dealers to pulling riot-control duty. People mastering these skills can be well on their way to the general or admiral rank once largely reserved for the battlefield veterans. 
 The end of the cold war and a spate of peacekeeping and humanitarian missions have thrown open a new set of opportunity-filled fields in unlikely areas. The gulf war made famous an obscure Army logistician named Gus Pagonis, a major general who moved six million tons of equipment into the war zone. Logistics wizards, like those now building tent cities for Cuban boat people at Guantanamo Bay or hauling relief supplies to refugees in Rwanda, have been held in higher regard ever since.
The warriors of the future will also include computer nerds and intelligence geeks guiding troops on a digitized battlefield. Even the once-dreary acquisition corps has acquired cachet as Defense Secretary William J. Perry tries to streamline how the Pentagon buys $50 billion a year in weapons and parts. Suddenly, buying blankets and combat boots is a lot sexier.
 
Less Room for Missteps
 While opening doors in some fields, the cold war's demise has meant smaller forces and fewer opportunities over all. Career paths are more competitive for young officers who need to punch the right ticket at the right time in a system that is less straightforward and far less forgiving than it was a decade ago.
For instance, some young Navy and Marine Corps officers who were investigated in the Tailhook sexual-harassment scandal fell behind their peers, and even those who were cleared now face an uphill struggle. And with America's nuclear arsenal shrinking, officers who supervise missile silos under North Dakota wheat fields -- a prestige-filled mission a few years ago -- may be looking for work. "If you don't hit gates when they swing open, you may never get a chance to do it again," said one Navy commander, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. (Almost everyone interviewed insisted on anonymity to avoid violating a cardinal rule of rung-climbing: no self-aggrandizement in the press.)
Fast-trackers with their sights set on the Joint Chiefs of Staff will still come from the combat arms branches: armor, infantry and artillery in the Army and Marine Corps; submarines, carrier jets and warships in the Navy, and warplanes in the Air Force.
But what's hot and what's not in the military mirrors which branch of each service is on the cutting edge in war-fighting strategy. Because of the Battle of Midway in June 1942, ambitious young Navy people wanted carrier duty -- and indeed for decades carrier men rose to the top more than the brass from other naval branches. In the 1980's, American submariners who waged silent underwater duels with their Soviet counterparts rose to the top of the Navy's chain of command.
Bomber pilots dominated the senior ranks of the Air Force until Vietnam, when fighter jocks shoved them aside, seizing a stranglehold they still hold.
Since the Revolutionary War, the ticket to the top has been command of troops in the field. And if the officer is lucky enough for a good war to come along, all the better. "Command is still the ultimate test of an officer's abilities, and it's as important a factor as it's ever been," said Rear Adm. Patricia Tracey, the personnel director for the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
Leading troops in a popular war has always produced instant heroes. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf was counting down his final days in the Army at the United States Central Command in Tampa, Fla., a backwater post, when Iraq invaded Kuwait in August 1990.
 
Soldier-Statesman Is Ideal
 Now, for the first time since Navy gunboats plied the rivers of Vietnam, young naval officers are getting a crack at early commands, this time in small patrol boats like those now helping enforce the economic embargo against Haiti.
The raft of relief and peacekeeping operations has upped the ante for soldier-statesmen. Lieut. Gen. Anthony Zinni of the Marine Corps has conducted relief missions in Russia, Iraq and Somalia and is considered such a poster boy for peacekeeping that he testified before a House committee on the Rwanda operation.
In today's grudgingly politically correct military, an officer's record on opening opportunities for women also counts toward promotion. The new emphasis has opened new doors to women themselves -- ushering in female fighter pilots and warship officers. The new Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. Jeremy M. Boorda, notched his warrior stripes directing NATO operations in Bosnia. But he also won the top Navy job because of his progressive views on opening more combat jobs for women.
This attitude has yet to reach the Marine Corps and Army, where crusty generals perpetuate their self-selective club by freezing women out of the only three branches of the service that produce commandants and chiefs of staff: armor, artillery and infantry.
There is no magic formula to the top, a journey that typically alternates field assignments with desk jobs and military schooling. But officers say a few tips help to navigate the shoals of promotion boards.
Tip No. 1 -- Excel at the desk or in the field, but try to get field assignments as often as possible, from anti-drug operations in the Caribbean to peacekeeping duty in Macedonia, and earn command of troops early on. "With things so much more competitive now, there's no real time to grow into a new job," said Capt. Frank Dobrydney, the Navy's head of career-management policy. "You have to hit the deck running."
Tip No. 2 -- Angle for high-visibility staff jobs in major commands or at the Pentagon, where senior civilians as well as the military brass can see your work. Build political connections, a la Brent Scowcroft and Alexander Haig. In the Army and Navy, senior generals and admirals adopt promising young officers as their "sons" and "daughters" and help manage their careers. But avoid tying yourself too closely to one mentor.
Tip No. 3 -- When the time is right, earn a graduate degree and jockey for a position at one of the military colleges, preferably the National War College in Washington. Winning a White House fellowship, as Colin L. Powell did as a young lieutenant colonel, is a career booster. A tour on the military's Joint Staff, the administrative arm of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, helps enormously.
By the time an officer reaches general or admiral, politics and talent figure equally in promotions. It doesn't hurt to hitch your star to a top civilian. Adm. Paul David Miller, the commander of American forces in the Atlantic, leapfrogged over dozens of more senior admirals in the late 1980's when Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. tapped him as a favorite. It pays to have a little luck.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
A Diplomatic Question: Embargo or Embrace?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NO wonder foreign policy debates these days seem so dull and muddled. "Hawks" and "doves" are out. All anyone wants to know is whether you are an "embargoer" or an "embracer" -- whether you think the way to deal with Bosnia, China, Haiti, Iraq or Cuba is by embargoing them into better behavior or embracing them with trade and tourism until they evolve into good citizens.
But let's face it, it's hard to get excited about denouncing your opponent as a "lily-livered embracer," or as a "neo-conservative embargoer." When one school in a foreign policy debate sounds like an aftershave and the other sounds like a service offered by Fedex, you know you've got trouble. 
 Worse, nobody knows who's on anyone's side anymore. Each day the editorial pages bring a new surpise as the most unexpected people line up in the embargoer and embracer camps. Sigh. Whatever happened to the days when foreign policy was primarily about titanic issues like the use of force and the clash of values, and you could tell the players without badges reading: "Hi, My Name Is. . .and I Stand For. . .?"
Sure, force is still an option today, but no one wants to use it because nothing seems worth using it for, save possibly for nearby brushfires like Haiti. We now have foreign policy by calculator. Hence the constant refrain from American politicians: "How many American lives is Cuba worth?" "How many lives is North Korea worth?"
It has almost become comical, as with Friday's headline: "Pentagon Estimates It Will Cost $427 Million To Invade Haiti." There is no way anyone could know how much an invasion of another country is going to cost with such exactitude. What did they do, put it out for bid?
Such stories matter, though, when American interests in a region are so ambiguous, and the justification for sacrifice so unclear, that people hope a price tag will tell us what our strategists cannot: whether it's worth it. Also, there is something about a spreadsheet that gives the illusion that the uncertainties inherent in any invasion can really be controllable.
But the prospect of using force in Haiti is the exception. For now, American foreign policy seems to have been reduced to the same two options on virtually every issue. One is to impose economic sanctions -- as with Iraq, Serbia, Iran, Haiti, North Korea and Cuba -- and hope that over time these embargoes produce the sought-after political change, with little cost in American treasure and no cost in American blood.
The other is to hold our noses, opt for the embrace, as with China or Vietnam, and hope that by trading with these authoritarian countries, engaging them diplomatically and luring them into political and economic reforms that they will crumble from within.
Both sides point to the cold war as proof that they are right. The embargoers argue that economic sanctions enabled the Jews to leave the Soviet Union, drove the Soviets out of Afghanistan, forced the Vietnamese to adopt capitalism and will eventually bring Fidel Castro to his knees.
The embracers argue that it was actually the web of diplomatic, touristic and economic relations with the Communist world which set in motion reforms that leaders like Mikhail S. Gorbachev thought they could control but eventually consumed them. But policymakers advocating either approach have to know a lot more about the world -- particularly the inner workings of different countries and what happens when you connect the blue wires with the red wires. How would economic sanctions affect political reform in China? In the old days it was easy to be a lawyer or politician and become Secretary of State. The only question you had to ask about the world half the time was "Whose side are they on, ours or the Soviets'?"
 
It's All a Matter of Detail
 To conduct foreign policy today requires a much keener sense of history, an intuitive feel for the rhythms of certain societies and an instinct for what can go wrong when engineering the politics of someone else's country.
This is doubly true now when the main challenge for American foreign policy in many places is not to influence relations between states but rather to influence events within states. To solve the crises in Rwanda or Bosnia or Cuba means getting under the hoods of those countries and manipulating forces within them to produce certain political outcomes. Not only do American diplomats often lack the skill to do that, but they are woefully divided on what the outcomes should be.
In the cold war, everyone agreed that the goal was either to prevent Communists from winning or to oust them from power. Today, there is no agreed-upon purpose in intervening. Should America intervene in Bosnia to produce one multicultural state or a small collection of ethnically pure statelets? It is baffling questions like this which explain why in three years America has gone from the cold war to cold feet. Stanley Hoffmann, a professor of international affairs at Harvard University, calls it the "new humility" of American foreign policy.
This new humility seems to have affected what the public wants from its leaders. As the cold war was coming to a close there was a lot of talk about "the vision thing." A 45-year era was ending and people wanted to know what the future held, what it looked like on the other side of the hill. Well, now they know. It looks messy.
People don't seem to want vision anymore, in large part because they sense that no one has a vision that can encompass a contradictory world, a world that is simultaneously fragmenting politically and consolidating economically. What people seem to want most now is competence, or, more specifically, the ability to protect American interests and prestige in a world where each problem is uniquely difficult and requires a uniquely deft response.
Indeed, if one listens to the Republican critiques of the Clinton foreign policy, it is clear that they have no particular global vision, either. All they offer is a different style of pragmatism and the assertion that "we could manage better."
So the American people find that they are no longer choosing between great architects or ideologues on foreign policy. They are choosing between managers. It is Dale Carnegie does diplomacy, and we are present at the downsizing.

HEADLINE: U.N. Is Facing Angry Debate On Population

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Already mired in an angry debate over abortion and women's rights, the United Nations Conference on Population and Development will confront other equally volatile issues when it opens here Monday.
Can the earth sustain its present rate of population growth? Who is to blame for the destruction of natural resources, profligate consumers in industrial nations or the desperate poor in overcrowded, underdeveloped countries who strip the land of vegetation to survive? If a plan of action is adopted, who will pay for it? And where will the money go, to governments or to grass-roots groups working in villages? Will donor countries try to attach human rights or other conditions to aid? 
 Cultural and political tensions, as well as religious ones, are built into population debates. And while delegates will face urgent and sometimes conflicting demands to cut population growth while also fostering human development, the 20,000 or more people assembling here officially and unofficially know that international agencies and governments work slowly. This will be the third United Nations conference on population in 20 years; in that time, the world has added about 2 billion people.
Resolving at least some conflicts here is crucial to the adoption of a plan that would open the way for governments to spend billions of dollars on programs intended to stabilize runaway population growth.
"This conference is playing for very high stakes," said J. Joseph Speidel, president of Population Action International in Washington, a nonprofit research group that advocates population stabilization. "This is not just another meeting. The long-term fate of this planet is in the balance."
First, there are the alarming numbers. More than 90 million people are being added to the population each year, the highest numerical growth in human history. In only 11 years, from 1987 until 1998, world population will grow from five billion to six billion, adding more bodies to feed, house, clothe and educate than the present combined populations of Europe and Latin America.
By contrast, it took 123 years for the population to grow from one billion to two billion, and at far higher fertility rates. Even in 1950, when the population was half of what it is now, women were having 5.3 children on average worldwide. Though the total fertility rate has since dropped to 3.4 children, the number of new people added each year has doubled because the base has expanded significantly and infant mortality has declined.
More than 90 percent of the growth is in the developing world, much of it in the poorest nations of South Asia and Africa. The developing countries add a million people every five days to lands that are often already overworked and depleted of water and cheap sources of energy.
Because this is the first of the United Nations population conferences to include "development" in its title -- the earlier two were in Bucharest in 1974 and Mexico City in 1984 -- the agenda is open to discussion of the environment, the economy, trade and education.
Carefully covering all the issues the developing countries want on the list of causes to be addressed, the conference's draft program of action says, "Around the world many of the basic resources on which future generations will depend for their survival and well-being are being depleted and environmental pollution is intensifying, driven by the unprecedented growth in human numbers, widespread and persistent poverty, social and economic inequality and wasteful consumption."
 
Effect on Governments
 Will the conference really mean anything to governments, especially if it adjourns without agreement on the most contentious issues? Nearly every delegate and unofficial observer interviewed said it would.
"Conferences and documents like these never get out ahead of where the people who agree to them are comfortable," said Rachel Kyte, an analyst for the International Women's Health Coalition. "What these conferences do is take an aerial snapshot of where we're at. A document like the program of action lets donor countries base policies on it, or go out ahead of it if they want."
Only if the richer nations accept some of the blame for the earth's distress will poorer countries acknowledge their shortcomings in family planning.
The Clinton Administration, in contrast to the Reagan and Bush Administrations, accepts the premise that consumption is an issue for discussion here.
"We wouldn't be where we are today in the conference document if the United States hadn't changed its position," Ms. Kyte said. She said the American position could help build a consensus on the relationship of population growth to poverty and economic development.
 
Debt Relief Sought
 But the task will not be easy. Among demands made by developing countries are an end to trade barriers, access to technology and debt relief.
Mahbub-ul Haq, a former Finance minister of Pakistan and now an adviser for the United Nations Development Program, says population increases in rich nations coupled with their patterns of consumption is the world's primary problem, "not population increase in the poor countries."
"Let us recognize clearly that rapid population growth in developing countries is their national problem, not a global issue," he wrote in April in Earth Times, a New York periodical devoted to environmental issues.
But many Western researchers insist that population is a global issue. Lester R. Brown, president of the Washington-based Worldwatch Institute, says world food supplies are threatened as the supply of irrigation water reaches its limits, seas are overfished and agricultural land in some of the poorest and most densely populated nations is turned over to industry.
"We are also in a situation where farmers are pushing against the limits of the fertilizer existing crops can use," Mr. Brown said in an interview from Washington. "More fertilizer in a lot of places now doesn't make any difference."
 
No Growth in Rice Harvests
 He said there had been no growth in rice production in Asia in four years. In that time, 56 million people were added to the population of Asian countries, led by India, whose population of more than 900 million is expected to grow by 590 million people in the next four decades.
"We have entered a new era, one in which satisfying the needs for seafood, for example, of 90 million people being added each year requires reducing consumption for those already on earth," he said. "Satisfying the demand for grain also means reducing the consumption of those already here."
Migration caused by overpopulation or the social fragility it creates has been studied by the United Nations Population Fund. The organization's 1993 report found the lines blurred between political and economic causes of internal migration and the outward flow of refugees and immigrants. Western nations have already begun to feel the pressures of economic migration, which can reduce tolerance and sympathy for truly persecuted and especially needy immigrants.
Concerns about land use are not limited to Westerners. M. S. Swaminathan, one of India's leading agricultural scientists and the head of a commission that studied population policy for the Indian Government, wrote recently that with land and forests dwindling and 18 million people being added to the Indian population each year, the time had come for an aggressive approach to population and social development.
"If our population policy goes wrong, nothing else will have a chance to go right," he concluded.
But here in Cairo, India is among a group of developing nations -- which also includes Brazil, Egypt, Indonesia, Malaysia and Nigeria -- that strenuously opposes language in the draft plan that would call for "the guarantee of all human rights, taking into account that democracy, development and respect for human rights are interdependent and mutually reinforcing."
 
Western Imposition Opposed
 These countries and others say the richer nations should not be allowed to impose their ideas of rights, democracy and acceptable population growth on others. The developing nations want a greater voice in institutions like the United Nations Security Council, the World Bank and International Monetary Fund so they can better oppose conditions on aid and loans.
Women's organizations from developing countries, whose primary aims at this conference are to expand protections and rights for women in reproductive choice, health care and other areas, have nonetheless joined the call for Western concessions.
Many organizations and government officials will be listening closely on Monday to Vice President Al Gore, who is leading the American delegation, for hints to how far the United States may go in accepting economic disparity as an issue central to population policy.
If the United States is willing to accept at least vague language stating all nations have the right to development, progress is likely, said Gita Sen, an economist at the Indian Institute of Management in Bangalore, India.
"This would be more a statement of principle than any specific commitment of resources," she said in an interview.
 
Cost of Contraception
 Also on the agenda at the conference is the potential cost of providing basic contraceptive services to the millions of people who do not have access to family planning. Estimates put the cost at $10 billion to $17 billion annually well into the next century.
In addition, the draft plan says, money will be needed for more health coverage, education and other human resource development. The proposed plan also asks for more money to deal with AIDS and to insure child survival. Poor families often have a large number of children in the fear that several will not live.
Traditionally, up to three-quarters of the money for family planning programs in developing nations has come from the countries' governments. They are now suggesting a sixfold increase in outside assistance, including help in improving social systems with new technologies.
Despite the disputes over abortion and other issues, the conference organizers and the unofficial lobbyists on the fringes say they are not concerned.
Maher Mahran, Egypt's Minister of Population and Family Welfare, said that even if the conference did not take place, it had already done 80 percent of its job by drawing attention to and providing information on world population to the public and policymakers.

LENGTH: 1539 words

HEADLINE: DEMOCRATS GLUM ABOUT PROSPECTS AS ELECTIONS NEAR

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
As they take to the stump this Labor Day weekend for the traditional opening of the fall campaigns, politicians of both parties share a like-minded view of the electoral landscape: The prospects for Democrats at all levels are bleak. The only unknown is just how bleak.
Democrats held high hopes earlier this year that they could boast to the voters of a major overhaul in the health care system and maybe even the welfare system. At the very least, they thought, they would be able to point to an economy on the mend. 
 But 65 days before Election Day, health care is stuck in Congressional gridlock, welfare restructuring is still a dream, and voters are in no mood to give Democrats more than grudging credit for helping create new jobs. That has left Democratic incumbents clinging to the passage of a crime bill as their only evidence of late that a Democratic majority in Congress can accomplish something of lasting significance. As a result, they can do little but portray the Republicans as obstructionists.
The Republicans, who would have had an upper hand anyway because the President's party almost invariably suffers in a midterm election, now see the Democratic woes as their best opportunity in decades to make gains. Since Democrats have far more seats to defend, the Republicans are counting on the discontent with incumbents to take a much bigger toll on the majority party.
The stakes are high. Although no leading analysts have predicted that the Republicans will gain the 7 seats necessary to win back the Senate, or the 40 seats needed to take control of the House after four decades of Democratic control, they acknowledge that shifts of such magnitude are not inconceivable.
Even if the Democrats retain control of both houses, heavy Democratic losses would dramatically affect President Clinton's ability to govern in the second half of his term. Despite the Democratic majorities he enjoyed in the first half, he was unable to win enactment of his centerpiece health care plan and barely marshaled enough votes for passage of his crime and budget proposals.
Republicans also have high hopes in the races for governor, where the Democrats, who hold 21 of the 36 offices at stake, are again on the defensive. The Democrats' biggest nightmare -- one whose realization is unlikely but possible -- is that the Republicans will keep or win the statehouses in the five most populous states: California, Texas, New York, Florida and Pennsylvania.
Things are so unsettled that Democratic stalwarts like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley of Washington and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts face the toughest races of their careers. In the New York metropolitan region, two Democratic Senators -- Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut -- are considered safe bets for re-election. But a third, Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey, is vulnerable.
 
John Glenn the Scolder
 Senator John Glenn of Ohio said that at a recent private luncheon many of his Democratic colleagues were in such despair -- some fretted that they would in fact lose control of the Senate -- that he wound up scolding them.
"When everybody gets their moods so down in the dumps, then I think some of the doom and gloom may become self-fulfilling -- that's what I commented on," said Mr. Glenn, who is not up for re-election this year. "People were saying, 'We're going to hell in a hand basket around here.' But I got rather impassioned. I said, 'If we get our heads so far down, we'll never pick them up again.' "
Beyond the many crucial races that could go either way, the election on Nov. 8 promises answers to other important political questions: Just how powerful have religious conservatives become at the ballot box? Will the voters who chose Ross Perot in 1992 side with one party or another this time? Will they affect the outcomes of races? Will any of the independent candidates for governor who are waging vigorous campaigns in at least five states change the outcome, or even win? Will the election produce a leading contender for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination, perhaps Gov. Pete Wilson of California or Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts?
Then there are some races bound to draw attention during the final nine-week sprint of campaigning simply as particularly spirited clashes. Will Senator Charles S. Robb of Virginia, a Democrat whose first term has been marred by personal scandal, survive a challenge from the Republican nominee, Oliver L. North, and an independent bid by his longtime rival, former Gov. L. Douglas Wilder? Will two sons of former President George Bush win races for governor in Texas and Florida? Will Kathleen Brown, a Democrat, unseat Governor Wilson in California and follow her father and brother to the Statehouse?
 
Outlooks in Congress
 In the Senate, the Democrats now have a majority of 56 to 44, and so the Republicans need a net gain of seven seats to dominate the upper house for the first time since 1986. At least nine Democratic seats at stake can be considered tossups, as against three Republican seats. Most analysts are now predicting that the Republicans will pick up three to five.
In the House, where there are now 256 Democrats, 178 Republicans and 1 independent, a Republican gain of at least 20 seats is predicted by most experts. Some put the number closer to 30, a result that would still leave the Republicans 10 seats short of the number they need to end Democratic control that has been a constant since 1954.
But the Democrats have a special reason to be nervous. The anti-incumbency sentiment of 1994 notwithstanding, the advantages of incumbency, particularly in fund-raising, have long been a powerful advantage for members of the House, and this year there are 50 districts, an unusually high number, where the incumbents are not running. Thirty of those districts are now represented by Democrats.
Adding to the nervousness is that nearly a dozen of those districts are in Southern and border states where Mr. Clinton is particularly unpopular with increasingly conservative voters.
Although House races are not generally decided by the popularity of the incumbent President, it does not help the Democrats that Mr. Clinton's approval rating was only 40 percent in a Time/CNN poll taken on Wednesday and Thursday of last week, the lowest level at this point in a Presidency in four decades.
 
An Earlier Start
 The unsettled political environment has already affected the intensity with which campaigns are being waged. Candidates are putting television commercials on the air earlier than in past years, and they are stockpiling more money. (House and Senate candidates had raised $388 million by the end of June, compared with $369 million at the corresponding point in 1990, according to the Federal Election Commission.)
And it is striking, although hardly surprising, that Democratic candidates' advertising does not feature the President.
"The difference between this year and two years ago is like day and night," said Representative Jon Kyl, an Arizona Republican who is running for the Senate. "The malaise in the Republican Party two years ago was palpable. The encouragement this year, by contrast, is equally palpable."
Donald R. Sweitzer, who as political director of the Democratic Party has spent much of the year advising candidates around the country, put it this way: "There's anywhere from a cynicism to an apathy out there. I've had a lot of conversations with candidates who say, 'I'm in the race of my life. This is the race of my career. They're really coming after me.' "
Besides the local issues that often decide Congressional races, crime has arisen as an overriding theme almost everywhere. Candidates on both sides are trying to demonstrate that they can build more prisons and keep more offenders off the streets.
Even Senator Harris Wofford, a Pennsylvania Democrat whose upset victory in 1991 led other politicians to emphasize health care, now finds himself stressing crime instead. With a vast health care overhaul all but dead for this year, Mr. Wofford has gone so far as to say that his own state's voters may favor the slower approach that could still be in the offing. "A good first step," he said, "is going to make a lot of sense to people in Pennsylvania."
If the public is dissatisfied with Democrats, it has not absolved the Republicans. A Gallup poll taken in mid-August suggested that Americans were just as exasperated by one party as the other. Asked whether they leaned toward voting for the Democratic Congressional candidate in their district or the Republican opponent, the respondents were almost evenly divided.
And not every Democrat is particularly glum. "I don't think the sky is falling by any means," said one, Representative Martin Frost of Texas. "I don't sense that things are as bad as people are suggesting."
That is easy for him to say. Mr. Frost's district has enough loyal Democrats that he is a safe bet for re-election. "I'm in good shape," he said.
But just in case, he added, he has significantly increased his budget for television commercials this year.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Across the Nation: Senate and Governor Races Considered Tight"
 
Senate
Democrats now control the Senate 56 to 44, so the Republicans would need a net gain of seven seats to become the majority party. There are 35 Senate contests in November; 22 of the seats are now held by Democrats, 13 by Republicans. Nine incumbents are not seeking re-election. Of those nine races, the seats in Arizona, Maine, Michigan, Ohio, Oklahoma and Tennessee are held by Democrats; the seats in Minnesota, Missouri and Wyoming are held by Republicans.
 
Democratic-held seats
 
Arizona
Representative Jon Kyl was unopposed for the Republican nomination to run for the seat held by Senator Dennis DeConcini, who is retiring, giving Mr. Kyl a jump in the campaign. The Democrats will pick a nominee Sept. 13, but so far no Democratic candidate has dominated in this relatively conservative state.
 
California
Senator Dianne Feinstein is still the favorite, but a win is far from certain because of a multimillion-dollar television advertising campaign being waged by her Republican opponent, Representative Michael Huffington, a freshman Congressman who is digging into his personal fortune for the campaign.
 
Maine
Representative Olympia J. Snowe, a Republican, is coming on strong in the race for the seat held by the Senate Democratic leader, George J. Mitchell, who is retiring. But no one is counting out her Democratic opponent, who is also in the House, Representative Thomas H. Andrews.
 
Michigan
Representative Bob Carr won the Democratic primary for the seat held by Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., who is retiring, but the victory was not decisive. However, Mr. Carr's Republican rival, Spence Abraham, a former state party chairman, also did not win his party's nomination by a large margin. Mr. Carr is a more telegenic candidate, but Mr. Abraham is trying to portray him as an insider who is too much a part of the Washington establishment.
 
New Jersey
Republicans won back the State House here last year, and now they have set their sight on two-term Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, who is being challenged by state Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian. Mr. Lautenberg hopes to save his seat by using his large financial advantage and by playing up his chairmanship of the Appropriations transportation subcommittee, a post that has helped him bring projects to the state.
 
Ohio
Joel Hyatt, the Democratic candidate, is the son-in-law of Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, who is retiring. But Mr. Hyatt, who has a chain of low-cost legal clinics, barely won the primary and seems to be having trouble gaining support. His Republican opponent is Lieut. Gov. Mike DeWine, who won his primary by an impressive margin.
 
Oklahoma
Senator David L. Boren has announced that he will retire from the Senate to become president of the University of Oklahoma. That has set the stage for a hard-fought contest between two House veterans, Representative Dave McCurdy, a Democrat, and Representative James M. Inhofe, a Republican.
 
Pennsylvania
Senator Harris Wofford won an upset victory in 1991, in an election to fill the vacancy caused by the death of John Heinz, by emphasizing health care. This year, Mr. Wofford is in a tough position now that the White House and Democrats in Congress have given up on a major health care overhaul this year. He faces Representative Rick Santorum, a Republican who is an aggressive campaigner.
 
Virginia
Senator Charles S. Robb is in a bitter battle with the Republican nominee, Oliver L. North. Mr. Robb is trying to overcome damage resulting from publicity about what he acknowledges were personal indiscretions when he was Governor; Mr. North is trying to overcome the tarnished image that resulted from his role in the Iran-contra scandal. Two independent candidates have not gained much support: L. Douglas Wilder, a former Democratic Governor, and J. Marshall Coleman, a former Republican state Attorney General.
 
Tennessee
 Representative Jim Cooper, a Democrat who is known for an alternative health care proposal, faces Fred Thompson, a Republican counsel during the Senate Watergate hearings, who is also a movie actor. The seat is now held by Senator Marian Mathews
 
Republican-held seats
 
Minnesota
Democrats have identified this Democratic-leaning state as one of their best shots at winning a Republican seat, that of Senator Dave Durenberger, who is retiring. But the race has not fully taken shape because the primary is not until Sept. 13. But freshman Representative Rod Grams, a conservative, won the endorsement of the Independent-Republican Party, while the Democrat-Farmer-Labor endorsement went to Ann Wynia, a former state House majority leader.
 
Montana
This has never been a particularly strong state for Republicans, and Senator Conrad Burns faces a vigorous challenge from Democrat Jack Mudd, a largely unknown yet appealing law school professor. Mr. Mudd's advisers hope he will not be hurt by President Clinton's popularity problems in the state.
 
Wyoming
Gov. Mike Sullivan was one of the Democratic Party's most sought-after recruits for the seat held by Senator Malcolm Wallop, who is retiring. He is in a spirited contest with Representative Craig Thomas, the Republican candidate. President Clinton is very unpopular in the state, which may hurt Mr. Sullivan.
 
Governors
There are now 29 Democratic governors, 19 Republicans and 2 independents. There are 36 contests in November; 21 of the seats are now held by Democrats, 13 by Republicans and 2 by independents. In 14 contests, incumbents are not running. Of those 14 races, the seats in Hawaii, Idaho, Kansas, Maryland, Oklahoma, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Tennessee and Wyoming are now held by Democrats; the seats in Maine, South Carolina and South Dakota are held by Republicans and the seats in Connecticut and Alaska are held by independents.
 
Democratic-held seats
 
Florida
The fortunes of Gov. Lawton Chiles have improved considerably as a result of his leadership in prodding President Clinton to act to stem the flow of Cuban refugees. Still, he will face a strong challenge from Jeb Bush, son of former President George Bush, or other possible Republican nominees.
 
Texas
Gov. Ann W. Richards is popular, but she is facing a tough challenge from George W. Bush, another son of the former President and a former baseball team owner.
 
Kansas
Representative Jim Slattery, a Democrat, is running about even in the polls with Bill Graves, the Republican Secretary of State.
 
New York
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's performance ratings are down, and George Paraki, a state senator who is the likely Republican nominee, could give him his toughest challenge yet.
 
Pennsylvania
Representative Tom Ridge, a Republican, is about even in the polls with the Democratic Lieutenant Governor, Mark S. Singel. Mr. Singel is threatened to lose anti-abortion voters from an independent, Peg Luksik.
 
Tennessee
This rates pits two well-known politicians, Representative Don Sundquist, a Republican, against Mayor Phil Bredesen of Nashville, a Democrat.
 
Republican-held seats:
 
Iowa
The voters may be tiring of Gov. Terry E. Branstad, who is seeking a fourth term and won the Republican primary by just a small margin. He faces a strong challenge from the Democratic candidate, Bonnie Campbell, the state Attorney General.
 
Minnesota
Gov. Arne Carlson faces a challenge within the Republican Party from Allen Quist, a former State Representative who has the strong backing of religious conservatives. Mr. Carlson is favored to win the primary, but if he loses, the Democrat who emerges in the Sept. 13 primary could have a good shot at the seat.
 
Maine
The political landscape was turned upside down with the unexpected retirement of Senator George J. Mitchell. The Democratic candidate for Governor is Joseph Brennan, a former Governor; the Republican candidate is Susan Collins, a former state official. Angus King, a well-financed independent who is going after the large concentration of Ross Perot voters in the state, adds to the uncertainty.
 
House
All 435 seats are up for election. The current breakdown is 256 Democrats, 178 Republicans and 1 independent. So far, there are 50 departures -- 27 retirements, 2 defeated in primaries and 21 seeking other offices.
