HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS SEE FEW ALTERNATIVES TO HAITI INVASION

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
As the United States moves down its checklist of military and diplomatic preparations for a possible invasion of Haiti, top Administration officials have concluded that the Haitian junta will not be scared into leaving by tough talk and economic sanctions.
Since the spring, United States policy toward Haiti has been driven as much by the hope that preparations for military action would persuade the ruling generals to step down as by the actual need to plan an invasion to restore the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 But Administration officials are more pessimistic than ever about avoiding an invasion, especially after a week in which a Catholic priest and close ally of Father Aristide was slain, the junta refused to arrange a meeting with United Nations envoys and United States officials made their toughest warnings to date.
"We have to plan for the fact they're not going to respond and they're not going to leave," one senior State Department official said.
In a sense, this week's amplified threats by Administration officials merely restated Washington's position that the junta must go. A final decision to invade rests in the hands of one man -- President Clinton.
But a growing number of officials in the Pentagon, State Department, White House and intelligence agencies concede that recent events have produced a momentum that will not very likely be stopped. Most American officials involved estimate that an invasion is most likely to take place in early October.
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott said this week that options other than invasion were nearly exhausted. Deputy Defense Secretary John M. Deutch said, "The multinational force is going to Haiti."
Earlier this week, a 183-foot Navy patrol boat zoomed across the edge of Port-au-Prince harbor and Navy surveillance planes hovered off shore.
While there are differences between the White House, Pentagon and State Department on aspects of the Haiti policy, agreement on the junta's disinclination to leave is widespread.
"It's almost universally believed both on the policy and intelligence sides now that the Haitians are intransigent and are ignoring all the signs, a State Department official said.
The official said that the ruling generals have "convinced themselves they're home free," that Washington will delay a decision to invade as long as they take steps, as they did this week, to release fuel for relief purposes and allow some Haitians to leave and seek asylum in the United States.
The United States intelligence community, including the Central Intelligence Agency, the Defense Intelligence Agency and the State Department's intelligence branch, first concluded more than a year ago that sanctions and threats of invasion probably would not budge the Haitian dictators, officials said.
 
A One-Year Process
 The junta's position hardened for good last October after the U.S.S. Harlan County, carrying 200 Canadian and American military trainers, was turned back by armed demonstrators from the docks of Port-au-Prince just two weeks before the negotiated date of Father Aristide's return. Ever since, Haiti's rulers have not taken American threats seriously, intelligence officials said.
But to gain public support for a possible invasion, and in the hope of that it somehow could be avoided altogether, the Administration felt compelled to exhaust all other alternatives. In May and June, the United Nations Security Council and the United States adopted tougher sanctions, including a comprehensive trade embargo, a ban on flights in and out of the country and tight restrictions on financial payments between Haiti and the United States.
In addition, Washington lobbied hard for the Security Council to approve in late July a resolution supporting an invasion to restore Father Aristide. This week, the 13-member Caribbean Community and Common Market supported using military action as a last resort, and four of the seven countries with armed forces pledged a token force of 266 troops to join an American-dominated invasion force of more than 10,000 soldiers.
Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said this week that any diplomatic efforts were virtually dead. Early this week, Administration officials held out a glimmer of hope that the new sanctions and tighter enforcement might coax the generals to give up. But by today, that optimism had all but vanished.
"The Haitians still think we just aren't going to do anything," said a senior intelligence official.
 
A No-Win Situation
 Given the threats made by Mr. Talbott and Mr. Deutch this week, ostensibly with White House approval, Mr. Clinton has left himself few options except to invade. A policy reversal would only worsen his foreign policy credentials. Opponents of invasion said Mr. Clinton loses either way.
"If we don't invade now, the Administration will be accused of being wishy-washy," Senator Richard Lugar, an Indiana Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, said on the CNN program "Newsmaker Saturday." "If we do invade, it will be a historical mistake."
Moreover, Haitian parliamentary elections are scheduled for early November, and many Administration officials want Father Aristide in place by then to avoid having the junta's candidates elected in a rigged ballot.
So the only question now seems to be timing. How long does the Administration officials give tighter sanctions enforcement a chance to work? Will the United States give the junta a final ultimatum, as Mr. Talbott suggested this week? Is Mr. Clinton really willing to commit United States troops to a cause that has little support in Congress or from the public?
"They may have a lot of questions about it, but they'll accept it," Representative Lee Hamilton, an Indiana Democrat who heads the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said about Congress on "Newsmaker."
Some practical details also still need to be worked out before any invasion could likely happen. Training for the 266 Caribbean troops begins in the next two weeks, and will last two to three weeks. They would join the main vanguard in 10 days.
This initial force would be responsible for establishing a "safe and secure environment" in Haiti, and would require several thousand military police and police trainers. Most of the Caribbean troops would do these jobs, but they will not be enough; and Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, strongly opposes using American troops as police, largely because of the ill-fated experience in Somalia.
So American officials are scrambling to recruit military police from other countries, including Canada and Britain, for the initial force.

HEADLINE: Political Notes;
Statistics Cast Doubts On Pataki's Job-Loss Ads

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
State Senator George E. Pataki, Republican candidate for governor, seems to be relentless in his politically motivated reading of job losses in New York.
 Mr. Pataki has repeatedly said in speeches that New York lost more jobs than any other state in the recession. A television advertisement for him last month maintained that the state was "No. 1 in lost jobs."
 
 But even after acknowledging news reports that showed that New York actually ranked second in lost jobs since July 1990, when the national recession began, Mr. Pataki has persisted. In a radio commercial that he started broadcasting last week, Mr. Pataki says: "New York State lost a half-million jobs since 1990. That's the most jobs of any state in the nation."
 Rankings provided by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics show that New York trailed California in the number of jobs lost since July 1990 and trailed Connecticut in the proportion of jobs that it lost.
 Caroline Quartararo, Mr. Pataki's campaign spokeswoman, began her defense of the campaign's use of the erroneous statistic by citing a chart in Forbes magazine that showed that New York's job losses surpassed those of California from June 1990 through June 1992, a period at variance with the "since 1990" claim.
 Then she said the campaign had used the period of June 1990 through June 1994, contending that New York's job losses ranked first during that period. They did not, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
 Finally, Ms. Quartararo said the campaign had consulted with Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, the bureau's regional commissioner, who had pointed out that the Government's methodology for collecting some employment data had changed and that accurate comparisons could not be made between figures before and after January of this year.
 Ms. Quartararo said New York was first in job losses from June 1990 to December 1993. Mr. Ehrenhalt said that was true, but only for statistics gleaned from the bureau's survey of households, which he said was less reflective of economic conditions than its survey of employers. The employers' survey shows that California's job losses exceeded New York's from June 1990 to December 1993.
 Mr. Ehrenhalt added that the Pataki campaign did not get in touch with him until Wednesday, after the advertisement was on the air and after reporters had started questioning the statistics.
 
A Former Speaker Signs On As a Vice President at Nynex
 Stanley Fink, the former Speaker of the New York State Assembly, wasted little time in finding a new job after his law and lobbying firm, Bower & Gardner, announced in late July that it was disbanding.
 Mr. Fink, who remains highly regarded in Albany and New York City political circles, said last week that he would become senior vice president for regulatory and governmental affairs at Nynex.
 Mr. Fink, who was Speaker from 1979 to 1986, compared the work he will be doing there to his legislative involvement in improving New York's infrastructure. "I see a very exciting opportunity where the telecommunications infrastructure is going to have to be built, in how an information highway with entrances and exits for everybody will be built," he said.
 He said his job might include occasional lobbying of former colleagues. "I don't intend to be in Albany, Washington or City Hall on a regular basis," Mr. Fink said. "Will I be there from time to time as the job and circumstances require? That's a real possibility."
 
A Shift Toward a Stronger Bill For a Sex-Offender Registry
 In the wake of 7-year-old Megan Kanka's murder in New Jersey in late July, New York State lawmakers have begun blaming one another for their failure to pass legislation requiring sex offenders to notify local authorities when they move into a community.
 Before they recessed in July, the lawmakers considered a variety of such bills, including one proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that would have required prison, health care and parole officials to notify local police when convicted sex offenders are released into their towns.
 A version of that proposal, sponsored by Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Republican of Nassau County, passed the Republican-controlled Senate in June, but died in the Democratic-led Assembly. Both Mr. Skelos and the bill's Democratic sponsor, Assemblyman Daniel L. Feldman of Brooklyn, said they thought their bill had been rejected by Assembly leaders because it was considered a threat to civil liberties.
 "My leadership gave me a clear message that my bill was too strong and I should work on a compromise," Mr. Feldman said.
 But in the wake of Megan's murder, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver of Manhattan said he would propose stronger legislation than Mr. Skelos's bill. Mr. Silver said his bill would make public a registry of convicted sexual offenders living in a town -- so-called community notification. Mr. Skelos's bill would have allowed only the police to review such registries.
 Mr. Skelos and Mr. Feldman said they were perplexed by Mr. Silver's apparent change of heart. "Silver is talking about going beyond the original bill," he said. "I don't have a problem with that. But I find it hard to understand why they were worried about confidentiality before."
 Mr. Silver said the Skelos-Feldman bill did not provide for enhanced supervision and treatment of sexual offenders, as his bill would. He said he did not propose community notification earlier because no one was pressing for it.
 "There was no great push," he said.
 "There might have been," he added, if the New Jersey murder had occurred during the legislative session.

HEADLINE: Inadequate U.N. Effort Seen Against Killers In Rwanda

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KIGALI, Rwanda, Sept. 3

 BODY:
United States officials and relief workers here say that before any effective rebuilding of Rwanda can begin, those responsible for massacres in the civil war must first be brought to justice soon. But, the officials add, United Nations efforts toward this goal have so far been inadequate.
A small team of United Nations experts investigated the massacres this week, but they said they had been hampered by a lack of staff and resources. Their final report is not expected until the end of November, and there will be further delays before an international tribunal can be established. 
 "There is a need to set up an international tribunal as quickly as possible," the United States Ambassador to Rwanda, David P. Rawson, said in an interview on Thursday.
He said the establishment of such an international judicial process would contribute significantly to the return of the refugees from Zaire, whose Government on Thursday called for them to leave by the end of September.
John Norris of the United States Agency for International Development said, "There can be no solution to the refugee crisis, no chance for development, no chance for normalization of society until those responsible for the egregious offenses are brought to justice."
 
Uncertainty for Hutu
 Most of the nearly one million refugees in Zaire are Hutu, and a major impediment to their return has been uncertainty about what will happen to them at the hands of the new Government, which is dominated by the Tutsi-led Rwandan Patriotic Front. The Government has said all those who took part in the massacres will be prosecuted, but it has not defined criteria for culpability.
Many Rwandans, perhaps in the thousands, were among the Hutu mobs that carried out the massacres. But many of them say they were forced to go along out of fear of being killed themselves if they did not. Others worry about being unjustly accused of taking part in the massacres by individuals with personal grudges.
On May 31, in report to the United Nations Security Council, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali said that what had happened in Rwanda "constitutes genocide."
On Wednesday, representatives from the United States Embassy, several international relief organizations and United Nations agencies met to discuss a long-range strategy for rebuilding Rwanda. They later drafted an agenda for what is needed for "development in Rwanda." There are eight items on the agenda, including the call to assist Rwanda in developing its economy, repairing the country's basic services and providing financial support for agricultural projects and education. The first item on the agenda, however, pertains to human rights.
 
'Acts of Genocide Occurred'
 "Widespread acts of genocide have occurred in Rwanda," the statement says in reference to several hundred thousand Rwandans, mostly from the Tutsi minority but including moderate Hutus as well, who were killed by Government soldiers and militia.
"Fully responding to these crimes against humanity is absolutely critical if Rwanda is to move forward," it says. "The response from the international community has been entirely inadequate in dealing with these human rights issues to date."
Last month, the new Government called for the establishment of an international tribunal to try those responsible for the massacres.
"We wish the international community would get moving on this," a senior official of the Rwandan Patriotic Front, Maj. Emanuel Ndahiro, said on Thursday.
On July 1, the United Nations Security Council called on the Secretary General to establish "as a matter of urgency" a commission of experts to investigate the massacres in Rwanda, "including the evidence of possible acts of genocide." A commission of three experts held its first meeting on Aug. 18-19 in Geneva. On Aug. 27, the commission arrived in Rwanda to begin the investigation.
The experts said at a news conference on Friday that they would recommend an international tribunal, and that they would need a staff of at least 200, including forensic specialists and investigators, to carry out an adequate inquiry into the massacres.
 
U.S. Aide Asks More Funds
 In their statement on "development in Rwanda," the diplomats and relief workers acknowledged that the commission "is seriously lacking the resources, personnel and expertise needed to produce a satisfactory inquiry."
Kim Maynard, a member of the United States Office of Disaster Assistance team here, said the investigation and the establishment of an international tribunal must be expedited and adequately staffed and financed.
"There must be internationally recognized human rights lawyers, not just U.N. volunteers," Ms. Maynard said. "Compared to what the international community will spend on the refugees and the relief effort -- probably a billion dollars -- what is needed for the human rights investigation is pretty cheap."
She said that the cost of one C-130 flight with relief supplies was $1 million but that not even that much had been allocated to the human rights investigation
"If the international community is serious about preventive diplomacy and disaster prevention, there must at least be some accountability for those responsible for the human rights violations here," Ms. Maynard said. "This is our chance to show the world we are serious about human rights."

HEADLINE: Cuba Calls U.S. Refugee Offer Inadequate

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

 BODY:
Cuba's chief negotiator in the immigration talks with the United States said yesterday that the Clinton Administration's offer to grant entry rights to at least 20,000 Cubans a year was inadequate. He suggested that this amount would be too small to stop Cubans from setting out in rafts for Florida.
The negotiator, Ricardo Alarcon, said in an interview that his Government would like the United States to admit for a specific time, perhaps a year, all Cubans who have expressed interest in moving to the United States. 
 One way to measure this, he said, was the number of Cubans -- 134,000 -- who applied for travel visas to the United States last year.
According to Mr. Alarcon, letting in so many people would defuse the pent-up pressures for illegal immigration by boat people.
 
Conflict Over Numbers
 During talks in New York on Thursday and Friday, the Administration presented an offer that would vastly expand the number of Cubans granted entry rights each year -- to at least 20,000 -- if Fidel Castro promised to halt the flood of boat people. Over the last 12 months, the United States granted visas to 2,700 Cubans, making Havana complain that this was far below the ceiling of 27,845 visas allowed under American law.
United States and Cuban officials said the Cuban delegation has not made a formal response to the 20,000 figure, suggesting that the talks could continue for several days.
In the interview yesterday at the Cuban Mission to the United Nations, Mr. Alarcon acknowledged that he had not put forward a specific number of how many Cubans Havana wants the United States to allow in each year.
The talks are schedule to resume today at the United States Mission to the United Nations.
Mr. Alarcon declined to predict when the talks would end, reiterating that they should address Washington's three-decade-old embargo against Cuba.
 
'I cannot be optimistic'
 "I cannot be optimistic," he said. "To find a real solution you have to deal with the causes of the emigration and that remains the economic embargo. The other side has refused to talk about the embargo."
Nonetheless, Mr. Alarcon, a 55-year-old former Foreign Minister who is president of Cuba's National Assembly, did not rule out an agreement that did not address the embargo.
"I'd be prepared to accept something on immigration matters even if the economic embargo stays in place -- if the other side shows flexibility on immigration matters," he said.
Mr. Alarcon said Cuba was eager to see legal immigration increased because Havana was convinced this would reduce the pressures behind the exodus, which he said was a destabilizing force for Cuba. As of 9 P.M. yesterday, the Coast Guard had picked up 850 more refugees in the waters between Cuba and Florida.
 
A Veiled Warning
 Mr. Alarcon is widely considered to be one of Cuba's shrewdest politicians and diplomats, and it is hard to tell whether the position he staked out today was a steadfast bargaining position or posturing aimed at exacting more concessions from Washington.
In what appeared to be a veiled warning, Mr. Alarcon said Washington should not expect any slackening soon in the flow of refugees. He said that after three decades of granting entry to all Cubans, President Clinton's decision to keep boat people at the Guantanamo Bay Naval Station would not in a matter of one or two weeks dissuade Cubans from heading to Florida by raft.
It was to be expected, he said, that many Cuban refugees remain convinced that their relatives in Florida would pull strings to get them into the United States.
Mr. Alarcon said Mr. Castro's decision to let Cubans emigrate freely was a response to a series of boat hijackings. Those hijackings, he said, were fueled by Washington's longtime policy of not prosecuting Cubans who head to Florida after using violence to steal boats.
'It's not a matter of 'Castro' putting a halt to the exodus," he said, using his hands to make quotation marks. "It's a matter for both sides to accept their responsibilities."
 
Strangling Cuba's Economy
 Repeatedly during the hourlong interview, Mr. Alarcon returned to the embargo and his assertions that it was strangling Cuba's economy and pressuring people to flee.
He argued that it was unwise for Mr. Clinton to maintain the embargo because Cuba is opening its economy to investors worldwide and United States businesses are missing out.
"Cuba is not as big as China in terms of market or territory, but it is a potential market of a few billion dollars that is right across the street," he said.
Mr. Alarcon insisted that Cuba is embracing economic reforms, but he said that the embargo, combined with the collapse of trade relations with the former Soviet bloc, has created such hard times that it is undermining the Government's ability to experiment.
"The main obstacle to the reform process is the United States embargo," he said. "Those who want us to change are doing their utmost to make it impossible."
Mr. Alarcon seemed to enjoy tweaking the United States as he puffed on his thick, six-inch cigar. He chided the Administration for its temerity in pressing his Government to halt the exodus. That meant, he said, Washington was urging Havana to violate his people's right to travel -- although he failed to mention that Mr. Castro has for years stopped Cubans from setting to sea.
Mr. Alarcon scoffed at the belief, espoused by many Administration officials and Cuban-American leaders, that Mr. Castro's Government is on its last legs. Such an attitude, he said, was pushing President Clinton to foolishly embrace tougher sanctions that increase the pain for the average Cuban, even as Mr. Castro remains firmly in power.
"If I were an adviser to the North American Government, I'd remind them that there are people in Florida who have forecast for 35 years the end of the Castro regime," he said. Then, in an allusion to the Bay of Pigs invasion of 1961, he added, "United States policy against Cuba has had some well-known failures because of such inaccurate perceptions."
"We have severe difficulties, serious problems, but it would be dead wrong to assume that the country is blowing apart," he said.

HEADLINE: Summer Travel Across Nation Shows a Surge

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Inspired by low air fares, economic confidence and the unshakable lure of the road, Americans have been traveling this summer like never before.
Preliminary figures strongly suggest that, from the New Jersey Shore to the Las Vegas Strip, the number of summer vacationers will set a record. 
 Even the long-beset airline industry, with a record 89 million passengers in June and July, is headed toward its busiest year ever. And the nation's hotels and motels are reporting their highest occupancy rates since at least the early 1980's.
"For the first time in a long time, you didn't hear that big, loud snap of pocketbooks and wallets being slammed shut," said Jerry Cheske, a spokesman for the Automobile Association of America. "This summer, people were spending again."
Almost 16 percent of travel agents had their best summer ever, according to a recent poll conducted by the American Society of Travel Agents, while another 50 percent classified the summer as "very good." Bookings were 35 percent higher than last summer at Thomas Cook Travel agencies, and 70 percent of the Carlson agencies said summer travel was "significantly" ahead of last year.
Many industry officials attribute the surge to pent-up demand and confidence that the economy is improving, or at least not getting worse.
"Right after the recession, people bought durable goods," said Shawn Flaherty, a spokeswoman for the Travel Industry Association, based in Washington. "Now they decided it was time to take vacations."
Before the season started, the United States Travel Data Center projected that this summer there would be 230 million person trips (one person traveling 100 or more miles from home), compared with 220 million last summer. That alone would have been a record, higher even than the 222 million in 1992, when the airlines put a frenzied half-price sale on domestic tickets. But the center said on Friday that the final tally would probably exceed 230 million.
There are many reasons. "Instead of putting money into our house, we're living and enjoying our kids," said Gail Hoefer, who works in commercial real estate and was visiting San Francisco the other day with her two young sons.
"We're spending differently," she added. "You change with the times. After the riots, fires and earthquakes, I think people want to get away."
Kevin and Patty Foster and their two children, who live in Newport, R.I., usually take several small trips and one big one during the year, but last year they skipped the big trip. This year they made up for that with a trip to Florida. "The economy is a little stronger," Mr. Foster said. "It's making people feel a little better about their prospects."
Low fares offered by discount airlines and specials offered by the major carriers contributed to the surge in air travel.
Bargain prices helped fill 75 percent of airline seats this summer, compared with an annual industry average of 64 percent in recent years, the Air Transport Association said.
 
International Flavor
 The increase in international travel was particularly dramatic.
"Lots of our domestic flights were heavily booked," said Chris Chiames, a spokesman for the Air Transport Association, the carriers' trade organization. "But bookings on many of our international routes were at or near capacity all summer long."
International air fares accounted for almost 42 percent of total airline commissions in July, compared with 35 percent last year. "Our international business grew tremendously this summer," said Christine Santos, branch manager at the Thomas Cook Travel Agency in Braintree, Mass. London and Italy were especially popular destinations, she said.
Many overseas tours were paid for before the dollar plummeted early this summer against European currencies, travel industry officials said, thereby insulating those American travelers from the currency equivalent of sticker shock.
Ted and Carolyn Leutzinger of Los Angeles, who have visited all 50 states and 100 countries, took two vacations this summer instead of their usual one. They traveled through eight European countries early in the summer. Then they cashed in their frequent flier miles for a trip to New England to wrap up the season.
At every stop they noticed more tourists than usual. "London was quite crowded," said Mrs. Leutzinger, 60, who teaches kindergarten. "Geneva was quite crowded, too. There were many Americans."
 
From Boston to Branson
 In the United States, summer vacationers, who typically account for about a third of all vacation travel during the year, seemed to be everywhere. Two perennial top attractions, Orlando and Las Vegas, retained their drawing power, helped by a new economy hotel at Disney World and by the new MGM theme park in Las Vegas, a gambling city that is rapidly transforming itself into a family destination as well.
The Gulf Coast states of Alabama and Mississippi had a big summer, as did San Antonio, the most popular destination in Texas, and Branson, Mo., the Ozark town that continues to draw families and tour groups in record numbers. In Boston, the Bull & Finch Pub, famous as the exterior of the bar featured in the television show "Cheers," attracted a record number of tourists this summer even though the show's final episode was almost a year and a half ago. "It's gangbusters," said Eddie Doyle, the manager. "We had a record day on a Saturday maybe three weeks ago. Over 5,000 people came in."
In New Jersey, merchants from Ocean City to Cape May have reported a banner season. In New York City, tourism has also been strong, although an influx of visitors from other countries is a major factor.
 
National Parks Popular
 The number of people visiting the country's 50 national parks rose 2.5 percent in July compared with the same month last year, to 11.1 million. Use of the overall National Park System, which consists of 365 sites, including the parks, national monuments, historic sites and seashores, rose 2.8 percent in July compared with the same period last year, to 42.8 million visitors.
But the number of visitors to Grand Canyon National Park fell 12 percent in June and 9 percent in July from the same months a year ago, and the figure was down 4 percent for the first seven months of the year. That falloff was felt by restaurateurs and hoteliers in the nearby Arizona communities of Williams and Flagstaff.
Tom Wade, an analyst with the National Parks System in Denver, said that proposed restrictions on vehicles in the parks might have held down park use, even though those restrictions are still only proposals.
 
Fear and Florida
 Overall, tourist travel to Florida continued to drop, probably because of fear after 10 foreign visitors were killed in the state from October 1992 to April 1994. More recently, another fear has hurt Florida tourism: travelers have been worried that the coastal towns are swamped with refugees from Cuba. Last Sunday the Monroe County Tourist Development Council took out advertisements in six Florida newspapers emphasizing that the Florida Keys are open and eager for tourist business.
But the huge number of travelers this summer suggests that Americans who shun a particular city or state go elsewhere, rather than stay home. And some people seem not to care where they are going.
Thus when Northwest Airlines recently offered 300 same-day-return tickets to mystery destinations for $59 ($99 for two), 2,000 people showed up at the airport in Indianapolis hoping to buy them. Not until flight time a few days later did ticket holders learn whether they were bound for Boston, Miami, San Antonio, Rapid City, S.D., or one of 11 other cities.
One winning couple said it was an inexpensive way to dine out in unusual surroundings. Others may just have been bitten by the travel bug, the same bug that moved Robert Louis Stevenson to write: "For my part, I travel not to go anywhere, but to go. I travel for travel's sake. The great affair is to move."

HEADLINE: Russia and China Act to Cut Arms, Widen Ties

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SPECTER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 3

 BODY:
Formally ending an era of tension between two of the world's most powerful countries, Russia and China agreed today not to aim nuclear missiles at each other, never to use force against each other, and to sharply limit the number of troops stationed along their border.
The declaration was signed at the end of talks at the Kremlin between President Jiang Zemin of China and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia. The two men also agreed to work harder on developing economic ties. 
 The Russia-China relationship has been rocky and traumatic. In the early 1950's their leaders dreamed of fashioning a world of Communism. Indeed, it has only been 40 years since Mr. Jiang trained as an engineer in Moscow at the giant Zil automotive factory.
But by the late 1950's, the two Communist giants had entered into such a fierce and dogmatic battle for supremacy that they became bitter enemies. The bloody clashes along their border in the 1960's led many to believe that if there was another World War it would begin there.
"The signing of these agreements are achievements of historic scope," said Mr. Yeltsin today, just back from Germany where he watched the last Russian troops withdraw from Europe. "For the first time in the history of Russian-Chinese relations the border between our two countries is legally fixed."
Tensions had cooled a while ago. Chinese ballistic missiles are not targeted in advance, according to Western military officials, so the agreement is largely symbolic. The Chinese missile system is built largely for retaliation. And the Russians have made a great show of limiting their targeted missiles over the last two years.
The economic agreements signed today were more important than those reached on arms control. China -- despite its stridently Communist political system -- has proven far more flexible economically than Russia was under Communism, or Russia is today. Many Russians now say they look to China as a model of how to apply phased economic reforms.
This is an ironic twist for two countries that have taken such divergent paths. Struggling to find the right route to a successful market economy, Mr. Yeltsin and others sometimes seem to look wistfully at China's remarkable economic growth over the past decade. "We pay much attention to studying the experience of economic reforms in China," Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Jiang.
China has become Russia's second largest trading partner after Germany. Trade between the two almost doubled in the last three years, and according to Chinese statistics, accounted for $7.68 billion last year.
This is tricky ground for a Russian President who must appeal to Western leaders even as he seeks increased partnership with China. Russia has carefully avoided joining the United States and other Western countries in attacking China's human rights record, which most Westerners consider abysmal.
Wu Jianmin, a Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman, said after today's meetings, "Both leaders stressed that the international community should acknowledge that there is no single pattern for the development of all countries and that all countries should be equal." He said the subject of human rights had not come up.

HEADLINE: Russia Warns Clinton Not to Allow Bosnia Arms

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Sept. 3

 BODY:
In a new sign of division over the path to peace in Bosnia, Russia has issued a strong private message to President Clinton warning him not to lift the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government, Administration officials said today.
Mr. Clinton said last month that he would press for a lifting of the embargo if the Bosnian Serbs had not accepted a peace settlement drafted by the Western allies and Russia by Oct. 15. The embargo bars arms shipments to all sides in the conflict, but hurts the Bosnian Government most because the Bosnian Serbs are much better armed. 
 A possible opening of the way to arms shipments to the Muslim-led Bosnian Government is among the steps that have been held out since early summer by members of the so-called contact group -- Russia, Britain, France, Germany and the United States -- to induce the Serbs to agree to the peace terms.
But in a diplomatic presentation at the State Department on Friday that Administration officials described as frank, a Russian envoy was emphatic in saying his Government would never agree to that step.
The envoy, who said he was delivering a message intended for Mr. Clinton, said Russia wanted the President instead to permit an immediate easing of economic sanctions against Serbia, Moscow's traditional ally, as a reward for Serbia's new efforts to persuade the Bosnian Serbs to accept the peace terms.
 
Potential Trouble Seen
 After several months in which members of the contact group have maintained a facade of unanimity, Administration officials familiar with the new Russian appeal described it as potentially troublesome.
They said it might reflect stark differences between the United States and Russia over what steps the group should take next in its efforts to impose a settlement in Bosnia that could bring an end to 29 months of war.
The new Russian stance was conveyed to the State Department only by the charge d'affaires at the Russian Embassy in Washington, and White House officials at Mr. Clinton's vacation residence here would not say whether he had been briefed about its contents.
But Administration officials said that Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev of Russia delivered an identical message on Wednesday in a meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, and that high-level meetings to review the status of American policy toward Bosnia would likely be convened by the National Security Council staff next week.
"We've got to decide whether we can hold the contact group together now that Russia is beginning to veer in a different direction," an Administration official said today.
In what will serve as an effort to see if the two sides can find common ground, Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, is to meet in Moscow with Mr. Kozyrev on Monday, Administration officials said today. That meeting will be followed on Tuesday with a working-level meeting of the contact group in Geneva, scheduled in large part in response to a Russian request.
 
Summit Meeting Ahead
 But even as Mr. Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin prepare to hold a summit meeting in Washington at the end of the month, Administration officials said the failure of their joint efforts toward peace in Bosnia appears to have left the two countries increasingly at odds.
In Friday's diplomatic presentation, known as a "nonpaper," and in recent appeals to other Western governments, Russia has argued that it is time to reward Serbia and its President, Slobodan Milosevic, for moving to block shipments of arms, fuel and food to the Bosnian Serbs. Mr. Kozyrev and other Russian diplomats have said the United Nations should move at least to ease the economic sanctions they imposed on Serbia to punish its Government for the overt support it gave to the Bosnian Serbs in the past.
But the United States has questioned whether Mr. Milosevic and his Government have truly turned against their former clients. Today Administration officials said they would continue to insist that armed monitors be stationed along the Drina River between Serbia and Bosnian Serb-controlled areas of Bosnia before any sanctions are eased against Belgrade. That is a step that both Russia and Serbia have said they would steadfastly resist.

HEADLINE: Newark's New Subpoenas Barely Raise an Eyebrow

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Once again the Newark city government and its dealings with private companies are under investigation by Federal law-enforcement officials, who said last week that they were looking into whether companies had paid bribes to city officials in return for obtaining municipal contracts, tax abatements and zoning changes.
 Federal subpoenas were served in the last week for all of the Newark City Council's records since 1989. After the holiday weekend the records, along with some members of the City Council, will start arriving at the Federal office building a block from City Hall.
 
 That one law-enforcement agency or another wants to examine Newark city records is barely viewed as news around City Hall, because the repeated forays into the files have often resulted in indictments and convictions.
 "The investigations sometimes continue for years, if not decades," said Glenn A. Grant, Newark's business administrator.
 Twice in the last two years investigators subpoenaed city records. Prosecutors later charged three members of the Council with corruption in two cases. One case, which has not yet gone to trial, involves accusations of kickbacks for a towing contract; the other resulted in the conviction of a councilwoman for misusing city money.
 
9 Indicted in Conspiracy Case
 One of the longest-running investigations began during the administration of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and culminated years later in January 1993 with the indictment of nine people, including reputed members of organized crime and the manager of Newark's Division of Sanitation. They were accused of conspiring to steal more than $2 million over the previous decade by billing the city for supplies and services that were not delivered.
 In announcing the indictment last year, Michael Chertoff, who was then the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said, "I don't know if this is an indictment of the concept of privatization, but it suggests that no method of delivering municipal services should escape the need for diligent supervision. There will always be a small minority of people seeking to enrich themselves."
 The indictments led to guilty pleas.
 Mr. Gibson, who served three terms before losing to Mayor Sharpe James in 1986, took in stride the attention the city was receiving in the mid-1980's from law-enforcement agencies during an interview more than a decade ago.
 At that time, the United States Attorney was investigating the city's Housing Authority, the Essex County Prosecutor was looking into payments made by the city to some of the companies hired to salt city streets after snowstorms and the State Attorney General was examining the city's purchasing practices.
 
Used to the Scrutiny
 Mr. Gibson said he had become accustomed to such inquiries and was not concerned. "In my 13 years in office, there has never been a month when we're not being investigated," he said then. "But I would point out that not one person in my administration has ever been convicted of any wrongdoing in all that time."
 Corruption charges leveled against his predecessor, Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio, contributed to Mr. Gibson's first election victory in 1970. Eight days before a mayoral runoff with Mr. Gibson that year, Mr. Addonizio went on trial on charges of conspiring to obtain $1.4 million in kickbacks from contractors on city projects. He continued his campaign from a Federal courtroom, but lost the runoff to Mr. Gibson.
 Two months later, Mr. Addonizio and four other defendants were each found guilty on 63 counts of extortion and one count of conspiracy. During the trial, he was linked to two reputed members of organized crime, Ruggierio Boiardo and his son, Anthony.
 
$28 Million Tax Abatement
 The latest investigation by both state and Federal prosecutors focused initially on whether Mr. James had lobbied the Council for a $28 million tax abatement for a project financed by Metrobank, a now-failed savings and loan association, in exchange for a $10,000 contribution by Metrobank to a party sponsored by the Friends of Sharpe James, a group of his supporters.
 Mr. James, who was on vacation last week, has said that he knew nothing about the contribution and never met with officials from Metrobank. He has also noted that tax abatements, an incentive used by many cities to spur economic development, must be approved by the Council.
 George Branch, a Councilman from the Central Ward, said that the tax abatement granted for Metrobank's real-estate project was legitimate.
 Mr. Branch said that the abatement had been carefully reviewed and that a vote had even been postponed at one Council meeting to allow more time for study. Asked whether Metrobank channeled campaign contributions to some Council members before the tax abatement was granted, Mr. Branch replied, "Not to me."
 "I don't know what others may have done, but I got no contribution," he said.

HEADLINE: Bradley Combs Jersey Shore for Voters' Opinions

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MANASQUAN, N.J., Sept. 2

 BODY:
Each summer Senator Bill Bradley shakes the dust of Washington from his shoes, then kicks them off and dons an old pair of sneakers for a long walk along the New Jersey shore.
 Most of the four days of walking this week on beaches from Cape May at the state's southern tip to Sandy Hook in the north was spent shaking hands, making small talk and signing autographs on every size, shape and color of ball and baseball cap.
 
 But Mr. Bradley said he finds enough people who tell him what's on their minds to enable him to deal more confidently with the issues of the day when he returns to Washington. "It's like a walking town meeting," he said. "Polls can give you the narrow view, the statistics, but only through something like this do you hear the stories and meet the people."
 "For the past three years most of the talk was about the economy, but this year it was health care, crime and beach erosion," said Mr. Bradley, who has made similar journeys along the shore for more than a decade. "I heard countless stories of people being denied health coverage."
 
Skepticism About Health Plan
 There also were many who thought President Clinton's proposed overhaul of the country's health insurance system was too cumbersome and would prove to be expensive. Douglas Coppole of Kinnelon, who was on the sand at Bradley Beach with his four young children, said, "There really is a level of universal health care in the country already, but politicians want to give everybody everything."
 Carol Ciccarella of Newton, a registered nurse visiting the beach at Ocean Grove, told the Senator that the Clinton plan would put the country on the road to "socialized medicine, like they have in England, and then we won't get quality health care out of our physicians."
 To Tony Marra of Chatham, who was sunning on one of the state's broadest beaches at Sandy Hook, the Clinton plan is a "disaster."
 "All it will do is build a bigger bureaucracy," he said.
 Mr. Bradley told them that he thought there was not time to pass the President's plan in the few weeks left in the current session of Congress and that all that could be done was to make some improvements in the current health insurance system. But he said that unless a system were eventually created that would cover everyone, there would be no opportunity to control costs.
 
Boy Outgrows Braces
 He also wondered how to help the owner of a small business whom he had met a day earlier on another beach. "He has 10 employees, and not only doesn't he have insurance for them, he can't afford it for himself," Mr. Bradley said.
 He also met Leo and Liz Menard of Lebanon, N.J., whose 12-year-old son, Joshua, is outgrowing the leg braces he got through Medicaid that enable him to stand. Joshua suffers from a birth defect affecting the bones called arthrogryposis, Mr. Menard said, adding that the braces were paid for only after a protracted fight with Medicaid officials. Mr. Bradley promised to intercede if the Menards have problems getting larger braces.
 Mr. Bradley also said that Mr. Clinton had tried to do too much too quickly on health care. "You can't do massive changes like that in one and a half years," he said. "It took four and a half years to get tax reform, six years to pass the crime bill; eight years to pass banking reforms and four years to pass a clean-water bill."
 
Assault Weapons Ban
 The crime bill adopted last month got mixed reviews on Mr. Bradley's walk, with some bathers and baskers congratulating him on its passage and others saying they did not like it. Mr. Bradley quizzed the opponents on their reasons and often found that their main complaint was the ban on assault weapons. "Well, you seem to agree with 90 percent of the bill," he told them.
 Many visitors talked with the Senator about the beach erosion that is still evident in some areas following damaging northeast storms of the last two years and an unusual summertime loss of sand caused by southerly winds this year. Mr. Bradley said he would see if a beach replenishment project under way from Sea Bright to Barnegat Light could be accelerated.
 There were other questions of varying import, many involving his former team, the New York Knicks, and whether they would finally manage to win a professional basketball championship next season. "They need a shooter who can score at the end of the game," he said, echoing the thoughts of thousands of Knicks fans.
 "What about the baseball strike?" a beachgoer asked.
 
'We Never Had a Strike'
 "I was a union representative for my 10 years in the National Basketball Association," Mr. Bradley said. "We never had a strike and had pretty good results. I think a long strike endangers support by the fans. I wish they'd go back and play ball."
 He deftly turned aside a challenge to play one-on-one basketball for $100, saying that if he won it might hurt his challenger's feelings. And he heard numerous suggestions, including one for teaching students the techniques of transcendental meditation to improve their test scores.
 One question came from a blond 5-year-old boy who had obviously been coached. "What's a politician?" he asked.
 "Someone who is elected by the people," Mr. Bradley replied.
 "Thanks," the youngster said, as he wheeled and ran back to the wet sand at edge of the surf.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Bill Bradley talking to some of his constituents Thursday at Ocean Grove, N.J. Each summer he spends the better part of a week walking on the beaches signing autographs and talking to people. "It's like a walking town meeting," he said. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Triumph of Faith, and Just in Time

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
The Jewish New Year has long been known as the Season of Renewal, but recent events at Congregation Derech Emunoh, the landmark synagogue of the Rockaways, have infused the term with vivid new meaning.
 Eight weeks ago, the 90-year-old synagogue was seriously damaged by a suspicious early-morning fire that tore open holes in its roof, ceiling and walls. Both the neo-Georgian building, set amid a wasteland of empty urban-renewal blocks, and its congregation had begun to crumble years before, and the fire seemed likely to disperse the tiny remnant of members forever.
 
 But after the fire something happened that has amazed even those who bravely bluffed the membership into believing that it could hold together after the destruction. First, the city, which bought the property in the Arverne section of Queens back in the days of land clearance, agreed to pay thousands of dollars for emergency repairs, which synagogue leaders had despaired of affording.
 Then, week after week, dozens of Jewish families from the Rockaways, many of whom had no ties to Derech Emunoh or any other synagogue, began to show up on Sundays to pitch in with the cleanup. And after they had hauled out bags of charred debris, they came back the next Saturday morning for Sabbath services, holding prayer books that had not been opened in years. A group of parents even decided to start a 15-student Sunday school, unknown within the synagogue walls for three decades.
 
Sermons of Hope
 Now, a 600-seat sanctuary that could barely attract the quorum of 10 men was regularly filled with the voices of 25 or 30 congregants. And when Rosh ha-Shanah services begin on Tuesday morning, as many as 80 worshipers are expected to hear the blowing of the ram's horn.
 All talk of the synagogue's demise has ended, and its officials are now daring to contemplate the possibility of raising money to repair the building's earlier structural problems. David Cohen, the synagogue's rabbi, is not ashamed to sprinkle his conversation with risen-from-the-ashes metaphors, since they are rarely so appropriate.
 "For thousands of years, every time the Jewish people felt they were near the end, they found their blessing in their punishment," said Rabbi Cohen, who is having no trouble preparing his sermons this year. "The key to Jewish survival is discovering the solution amid the ashes."
 Many new members said they had long driven past Derech Emunoh (the name means "the way of faith") but had never imagined that the battered old building at Beach 67th Street and Rockaway Beach Boulevard contained a congregation they might find appealing. After learning about the fire, many stopped by to see if they could help, and discovered other families with similar interests doing the same thing.
 "My husband and I had not gone to temple since we were married 10 years ago," said Elise Nadel, who lives about 20 blocks away in Rockaway Beach. "But I'm a Rockaway girl, and it just pulled your heart out to see a temple looking like that. So we started going every Sunday, washing all the soot and tacking down the carpeting, and now it feels good to be back in the faith."
 Ms. Nadel and her husband, Stuart, and her parents will all be in the pews this week, and the couple has enrolled their daughter in Sunday school. Although the previously nonobservant family members are slightly startled to find themselves in an Orthodox synagogue, where men and women sit separately, they have adjusted quickly.
 
The City as Partner
 Those who attend High Holy Day services will see a 20-foot hole in the ceiling, just in front of the altar, but the roof and the exterior walls have been patched by the city to keep out the elements. Mara Neville, a spokeswoman for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, which owns the building, said the city spent $5,000 to $8,000 to repair the exterior, pull down the hanging portions of the ceiling, and remove debris. If the synagogue can raise some of the money to renovate the rest of the building, she said, the city will consider giving it the title to the building for a nominal fee.
 "We are very pleased with the city's cooperation," said Robert Wein, the congregation's president and a third-generation member. "Without their support I doubt if we would have been able to open up for the holidays. And of course I hope they'll go a little further with us."
 The building has no heating system -- vandals stole most of it a few years ago -- and normally closes for the winter after Yom Kippur. But because so many new members now rely on it for regular services, generating some of their own heat through song and prayer, Rabbi Cohen said it would stay open this year for as long as members can tolerate the chill.
 "Who would have imagined that this fire would have a good side?" he said. Invoking the name of the great Biblical prophet of renewal and hope, he added, "Only someone like Isaiah -- he would understand."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
The End of 'the Movement'

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES 

 BODY:
How much influence would the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. wield today had he not been assassinated? Not much, I suspect. Dr. King's moral authority rested upon the indisputable fact that African-Americans in the South were disfranchised by a white power structure that stopped at nothing to keep its power. The savagery was evident on the evening news, as when children were set upon with dogs and water cannons in the streets of Birmingham.
The passing of racism's most visible forms -- and the corresponding rise of a black elite -- would have required Dr. King to become more than just a champion of the African-American oppressed. His condemnation of the Vietnam War foreshadowed what might have become a broader strategy. So did his failed fair-housing campaign in Chicago in 1966. There were no dogs and water cannons in Chicago to inspire public outrage. Civil rights rhetoric by itself was no match for a patronage machine that could appear in blackface when it needed to. Dr. King's rallies were anemically attended. The machine, with black underbosses like the legendary Congressman William Dawson, sent Dr. King home defeated. 
 African-American political empowerment nationally would have forced Dr. King to transform himself from a roving savior without portfolio into something less grand -- a Congressman, say, from Georgia. That same empowerment has rendered traditional civil rights rhetoric implausible. African-Americans cannot sing "We Shall Overcome" when so many of them already have.
The black middle class, barely evident in the 60's, is now thriving and clearly visible. At the time of the "I Have A Dream" speech, African-Americans were still struggling to secure the vote, and there were probably fewer than a thousand black elected officials nationwide. Today there are more than eight times that many, including a 40-member Congressional Black Caucus.
The poor have not disappeared. But what afflicts them is not remediable through traditional civil rights strategies. Homicide, drug addiction, adolescent pregnancy, illiteracy -- and the economic despair that drives them -- are not "civil rights" problems per se. Marches and rallies and sit-ins can never reach them. It is not surprising, then, that the civil rights establishment is losing its influence or that the alphabet soup of civil rights organizations -- S.N.C.C., C.O.R.E., even Dr. King's S.C.L.C. -- have ceased to be important.
Enter the N.A.A.C.P., with a declining membership, the largest budget deficit in its history and a growing identity crisis. The Rev. Benjamin Chavis deepened the crisis with his spendthrift style and his bid for an alliance with the black Muslim leader, Louis Farrakhan. But the crisis of purpose predates Mr. Chavis. Consider the deficit. Nearly half -- $1.4 million -- results not from scholarships for the poor or guidance to wayward boys, but from expenditures for the annual N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards, essentially a televised celebrity party. The organization that helped win Brown v. Board of Education has been reduced to sponsoring social activity for the beautiful people.
Mr. Chavis also fell for the delusion that an alliance with Mr. Farrakhan would spark a new, 60's-style movement. Mr. Chavis and Kweisi Mfume, the chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, apparently envied Mr. Farrakhan for the tens of thousands of people who are said to appear at black Muslim stadium gatherings. At work here was nostalgia for massive crowds like the one Dr. King addressed in Washington 30 years ago. But nostalgia is a liability considering the job at hand.
The N.A.A.C.P. and what is left of "the movement" need fresh direction. Some sound suggestions were laid out in a speech last month by Hugh Price, the incoming president and C.E.O. of the National Urban League. "We must not let ourselves and, especially, our children fall into the paranoid trap of thinking that racism accounts for all that plagues us," he said. Mr. Price proposed a national Youth Development Fund, paid for partly by successful African-Americans, that would broaden opportunities for children of the poor. "We African Americans who have made it must tithe . . . to see to it that those of our children whom the civil rights movement hasn't yet touched also have a real chance to succeed."
The N.A.A.C.P.'s next executive director needs to take a close look at that speech. BRENT STAPLES

HEADLINE: U.S. Broadcasts Keep Cubans Posted in Crisis;
Far From a Failure

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"It should be clear after 35 years to Fidel Castro and his Government that the way he has been managing the affairs of the island is a failure" -- Under Secretary of State Peter Tarnoff (news article, Aug. 25).
In the last 35 years, Cuba has achieved universal health care, something the United States has been unable, or unwilling, to do. It has a higher literacy rate (near 100 percent) and a lower infant mortality rate than many places in the United States. A larger percentage of its population graduates from college. There is no problem of homelessness in Cuba. Until recently, everyone received basic goods and services, although there have never been many luxuries. Now everyone suffers the same hardships, although priority is given to the care of infants and pregnant women, the elderly and the sick. 
 All this was achieved not because of aid from the Soviet Union, but despite the economic embargo. Similar amounts of aid from the United States to El Salvador during the 80's achieved no such progress -- if El Salvador had the same social agenda as Cuba there would not have been a civil war. By any standards other than the United States Government's, Cuba cannot be called a failure.
American foreign policy is not about democracy or humanitarian concerns; Cuba policy is no exception. It is, however, usually in our perceived self-interest; in this case Cuba is an exception.
There is a persuasive argument that the interests of the United States would be better served by opening trade and allowing American companies to take advantage of the opportunities as they are doing in Vietnam. But our Cuba policy serves no one's interests -- it is simply the implacable vendetta of a schoolyard bully toward the "weakling" who won't knuckle under.
 
EILEEN ECKERT
Stafford Springs, Conn., Aug. 29, 1994

HEADLINE: BOAT SHOWS;
For the Revived Boat Industry, There's Blue Seas, Nothing but Blue Seas

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
The boating industry woke up last winter from a deep recessionary slumber. And now, with sales still looking lively, marine dealers have developed a relatively upbeat mood for this year's fall boat show season.
With industry predictions for a 15 to 20 percent increase in boating retail sales for 1994 -- a figure approaching $13 billion -- manufacturers plan to flood the shows with new models and marine accessories. While the market still is a long ways from its $18 billion peak in 1988, retailers are mixing caution with equal parts of enthusiasm. 
 "It's the old pinch-me theory," said Greg Proteau, spokesman for the National Marine Manufacturers Association, an industry trade group. "Is it really this good? Barring any world calamity -- which could throw ice water on all this real fast -- we think there's another year in it."
Among the first of the fall exhibits is the New York In-Water Boat Show this week, Thursday-Sunday, at the South Street Seaport Museum in lower Manhattan. More than 100 craft are expected to be on display, an increase from about 60 boats at the show's debut last year.
Hemmed in between the museum's historic tall ships, the Peking and the Wavertree, the new boats will include the 72-foot Inspiration, a $500,000 German sailboat that has five staterooms, and the Lazzara 76, a $1.2 million custom powerboat built in Tampa, Fla., with three decks and twin 1,000 horsepower engines. There will also be small boats at the show, including fishing boats, multihulls, inflatables and daysailers.
Display tents at the South Street site will exhibit marine equipment and accessories and will offer information on how to finance and insure a new boat.
"The feeling is that everyone is very positive," said Jeff Holland, spokesman for the New York show. "Everyone certainly has had a very busy summer." Holland's group, Annapolis Boat Shows, also has scheduled its regular shows in Annapolis, Md., this fall: the United States Sailboat Show, Oct. 6-10; and the United States Powerboat Show, Oct. 13-16.
"Virtually every major production sailboat manufacturer has five or six models in the Annapolis shows," Holland said. Hunter Marine, one of the largest American sailboat manufacturers, plans to take 11 models to the Annapolis sailboat show, he said. Among them is the Hunter 26, an innovative sailboat that includes an electric auxiliary engine.
 
Fishing With the Captains
 Besides an increase in volume, the industry also is coming up with new ideas to keep its new-found momentum going. At the Norwalk International In-Water Boat Show Sept. 22-25 in East Norwalk, Conn., a four-day round of fishing seminars by experienced boat captains is scheduled.
And at the Newport International Boat Show, Sept. 15-18 in Newport, R.I., organizers plan to make sailboats and powerboats of 20-40 feet available for cruising by novice boaters. Instructors will be on board.
The Atlantic City In-Water Power Boat Show, this Thursday through Sunday, plans to show new sport fishing boats as well as performance motor yachts at the Frank S. Farley State Marina. For the first time, the show also will have a special section of pre-owned, late-model boats for sale.
 
 
 
MAKING WAVES
 Seven sailors are slated to be inducted Saturday into the America's Cup Hall of Fame at the Herreshoff Marine Museum in Bristol, R.I. Among those being honored are VICTOR A. ROMAGNA, a former member of the New York Yacht Club's America's Cup Committee. Romagna, of Severna Park, Md., was also a crew member on three successful 12-Meter cup defenders: Columbia, in 1958; Weatherly, in 1962, and Intrepid, in 1967. Also being inducted is SIR JAMES HARDY, the Australian cup skipper who raced the 12-Meter Gretel II in 1970; Southern Cross in 1974, and Australia in 1980. Other yachtsmen to be enshrined, all deceased, are: Edward Burgess, W. Starling Burgess, C. Sherman Hoyt, C. Oliver Iselin, and John Cox Stevens.
Twenty skippers from five countries are expected to gather Saturday in Northeast Harbor, Me., for the 1994 International One Design Class World Championship. The 33-foot boat, better known as the I.O.D., was designed in the 1930's by Bjarne Aas of Norway and introduced to racing in the United States in 1938. Twelve of the original 14 I.O.D.'s are sailing in the Northeast Harbor Fleet. The Maine chapter has 27 boats competing on a regular basis, making it the largest fleet of I.O.D.'s in the world, said SYDNEY ROBERTS ROCKEFELLER, an I.O.D. race organizer and competitor from Northeast Harbor. The world championship also is drawing sailors from other United States fleets, as well as from Norway, Scotland, Sweden and Bermuda.

HEADLINE: N.F.L. '94;
25 Years Later, Monday Night Is a Fall Classic

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
At its silver anniversary, ABC's "Monday Night Football" is a certifiable institution. When the Raiders play the 49ers tomorrow night, the game will get its predictably high rating. If form holds, Year 25 will find "M.N.F." in the top 10 of all prime-time series, as it has been since the 1990-91 season.
But before "Monday Night Football" stormed the football kingdom in 1970, before the first team of Keith Jackson, Howard Cosell and Don Meredith yielded after Year 1 to Cosell, Meredith and Frank Gifford, the National Football League entertained thoughts of "Friday Night Football," or "Monday Night Football" on CBS or NBC. 
 "I remember Pete Rozelle and I going to meet Lee Iacocca, when he was at Ford, to sponsor 'Friday Night Football,' and he showed great interest," said Art Modell, the Cleveland Browns owner and longtime chief of the N.F.L.'s television committee. "But then Congress prohibited Friday night football until high school and college games were over for the year. They passed a law."
Roone Arledge, then the president of ABC Sports, first suggested that football air Mondays in prime time, but Rozelle, the N.F.L. commissioner, offered the slot to CBS and NBC. "It was tantalizingly close that we wouldn't get it," said Arledge, now the president of ABC News. But NBC and CBS passed.
 
Back Then, Who Knew?
 Back then, there was no expectation that pro football would work on a prime-time, work-and-school night. Would people stay up for a 9 P.M. (Eastern) game that lasted until midnight? Would sponsors buy? Would viewers accept three in a booth? Would they accept Cosell? Would women watch?
"ABC was a poor third and had nowhere to go but up," said Modell. ABC acquired "Monday Night Football" for a first-season payment of $8.5 million. Inflation and success has caught up with ABC's rights payment: last year, ABC renewed the tenure of "M.N.F." for a four-year total of $920 million.
The "M.N.F." era began on Sept. 21, 1970, with the Jets playing the Browns.
"No one else in the league wanted to host the darned thing," said Modell, who remained nervous until a record crowd of 85,000 fans jammed Municipal Stadium and he knew something different was happening.
"It was about the third week," said Arledge. "Dallas was losing 30-0 to St. Louis. I had had a problem getting Don to be himself. Then Don started talking about what it was like playing for Dallas when they were losing big." The Cosell-Meredith rapport came alive. "And the ratings were great," Arledge said. "It proved you could have an awful game and still have an audience watch."
"Monday Night Football" became more than watching the game. How much would fans love and hate Cosell? When would Meredith sing? When would Gifford get a word in edgewise, or make a factual blunder? Could Alex Karras replace Meredith? What were Fran Tarkenton, O. J. Simpson and Joe Namath doing there? Could Dandy Don return? And on and on.
Since 1987, "Monday Night Football" has had its longest period of stability, with Gifford, Al Michaels and Dan Dierdorf the threesome. When Michaels and Gifford were a one-year duo in 1986, Gifford had to give up his play-by-play role.
"It was difficult," Gifford said. "Dan and I in our first year had a difficult time finding where we belonged." Added Dierdorf: "When you share a job, you don't say everything that comes to your mind. It's very difficult. There's a lot of sacrifice in how we do our job."
Arledge, who still watches, is intrigued by how the threesome works together.
"It's remarkable how they've fit three in the booth when their roles aren't as distinctive as Howard, Don and Frank were," he said. "You really don't need three in the booth, and it only works rarely."
 
A Little More Low-Key
 The Michaels-Gifford-Dierdorf combination is less combustible than the Cosell-Meredith-Gifford trio, with the focus trained far less on trying to be outrageous than the earlier team. Michaels is the best play-by-play man the series has ever had, Dierdorf a highly prepared analyst who rubs some the wrong way with his blunt candor. Gifford continues earnestly, retaining the easygoing affability he has had since he was a Giant.
"In a way, I think this is the Golden Age," said Michaels. "I won't diminish what was done in the past, because if it wasn't good then, it would have gone away. The only numbers to go by are the ratings. In prior years, 'Monday Night Football" was a huge success when it was 24th out of 54 prime-time shows. Now we're in the top 10 of 120."
Added Gifford: "We do the game so much better than it was done then. Our memories are clouded with nostaglia. But I was there back then and let me tell you, it wasn't all that good."
ABC nearly altered the "Monday Night Football" chemistry this season when it bid for John Madden. It was virtually a done deal, until NBC bid more, then Fox even more. The move would have shifted Dierdorf to college football, which was not a promotion, but one he never complained about publicly, to his credit.
"Dan is very valuable to us," said Dennis Swanson, the president of ABC Sports. "Whether on 'Monday Night Football,' college football, or in boxing."
ABC has altered "M.N.F." a bit. Halftime will be given over to Brent Musburger and Sports Illustrated's Peter King for an update program. In addition, Lynn Swann will be the game's sideline reporter, and country singer Hank Williams Jr. will be back to sing the opening theme song.
Even in its slightly altered state, "Monday Night Football" is the bell cow, as Jackson would say, of ABC Sports. It's a prime-time vehicle, commanding prime-time dollars.
"We've circled the wagons around 'Monday Night Football' because it's our highest priority," said Swanson, "more than buying Olympic rights, which are an every four-year package, not every week in prime time."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The most-celebrated "Monday Night Football" announcing crew was, from left, Don Meredith, Howard Cosell and Frank Gifford, the former Giant who remains on ABC's current broadcasting team. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economists Know About Bias in Lending

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Redlining Under Attack" (Business Day, Aug. 30) leaves the impression that most informed economists do not believe there is any discrimination in mortgage lending. This impression is wildly inaccurate. The Boston Fed study is highly respected by most experts. Although a couple of studies, such as you cite, have found ways to manipulate away the Boston Fed's findings, the most careful re-examination to date of the Boston Fed data by Carr and Megbolugbe in the Journal of Housing Research (1993) confirms the conclusion of bias.
Moreover, the Boston Fed study addresses only discrimination in mortgage acceptance. Other studies provide clear evidence of discrimination in applications procedures, branch office locations and other aspects of lender behavior. 
 Some economists may, as you say, conclude that discrimination does not exist because it is "implausible" according to their models of lending behavior. They have it backward. Their models clearly are contradicted by the evidence.
You also perpetuate the unsubstantiated conclusion that programs to increase loans to minorities will automatically require subsidies from other borrowers and will "waste capital." Discrimination is denying loans to qualified minorities or setting up branch offices in a way that discourages minority applications. Eliminating these types of discriminatory acts would not require subsidies.
Moreover, the evidence indicates that lenders often rely on outmoded rules of thumb and do not take advantage of all available opportunities to make money. Lending programs around the country based on nontraditional underwriting criteria for evaluating credit risks in low- and moderate-income communities often have rates of return at least as high as traditional loans have. Most of these programs would not exist without the Community Reinvestment Act and other legislation designed in part to increase loans to minorities.
Though you say that incentives to encourage investment in minority neighborhoods may "make lenders more aware of the profit opportunities in neglected areas," you largely perpetuate the scare tactics that some commentators have used to undermine badly needed improvements in the enforcement of fair lending legislation. We should be bending over backward to provide credit opportunities for minority families, not thinking up excuses for retaining the status quo.
 
JOHN YINGER
Professor of Economics and
Public Administration
Syracuse University
Syracuse, Aug. 30, 1994

HEADLINE: What 2.5 Million Jobs?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I wish Robert Reich would tell us where he gets the 2.5 million new jobs figure (Op-Ed, Aug. 31). Are those more minimum-wage jobs like the 400,000 that President Clinton is fond of quoting?
Those of us who run businesses don't see where all these new jobs are. What we do see is a continuous and persistent dismantling of the middle class. 
 Perhaps our political leaders don't get it; it's the middle class that pays the bills. What happens when this source of revenue is gone? On Labor Day 1994 let the Government commit itself to saving the American middle class.
 
WILLIAM WONDRISKA
Farmington, Conn., Sept. 1, 1994

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;
Neighborhood Picks Its Issue, And Differences Run Deep

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
The West Side fights itself over a highway project. The East Village implodes between anarchists, neo-punks and young professionals. But there will always be a harmonious Upper East Side, or at least so it seemed until a plan surfaced to hire 500 security guards to patrol from 59th to 96th Streets.
The ensuing clash among Upper East Siders has cast their neighborhood's diverse elements into relief and underlined the inherent tensions between them. Although no one predicts a new era of hostility, the differences run deep. 
 For instance, division over a proposed property tax to finance the plan, which would cost some $20 million a year, has revealed an economic and geographic split between the wealthy areas along Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues, and more modest sections east and north.
Despite the Upper East Side's tony image as New York's wealthiest neighborhood, with multimillion-dollar co-ops, many residents there are middle class, and 6 percent fall below the poverty line.
"Most people say the Upper East Side: isn't everybody there rich, famous and white?" said Nancy Wackstein, director of Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, a charity. "But it's not all Jackie O. We have a homeless shelter, 80 families enrolled in Headstart with a waiting list and many more needs." To win broad support, proponents hope to exempt low-income buildings from the tax and charge others a range from $5 to $35 a month per apartment.
The security plan is the project of a major Upper East Side player: Howard Milstein, a developer whose empire includes Emigrant Savings Bank, the Milford Plaza Hotel and the Douglas Elliman firm, which manages more than 100 Upper East Side coop and condo buildings.
Many of the Upper East Side's block associations and grassroots tenant groups have a populist stripe; to them, the plan's origins made it instantly suspect. Dr. Georgette Bennett, a criminologist for Douglas Elliman, said: "We have to get rid of this elitist bugaboo -- this is not for Park Avenue matrons and their grandchildren, but for everyone on the Upper East Side, poor and rich."
While some Upper East Siders wield influence around the world, they hold no monopoly on neighborhood decisions. Power is split among constituencies like the many civic groups, prominent schools (Dalton, Brearley), the business community and hospitals and museums.
Elected officials have the final say on the security plan, but many are uncommitted as they track the controversy and monitor Community Board 8, the local sounding board.
Of course, the proposal also raises issues that cut across economic lines, like crime and taxes.
Philosophical divisions are also at play. Some see the proposal as a community walling itself off, and as an unseemly display of wealth. Some fear that a large security program, with limited public control, would become a major new force overshadowing existing groups.
"They're afraid we're some sort of monolith that's going to steamroller them, but we're really not in competition and want to work with them," said Dr. Bennett. But Elizabeth Ashby, president of Carnegie Hill Neighbors, which raises donations for its patrol, said: "We don't want to sacrifice what we have now." BRUCE LAMBERT
