HEADLINE: Banish Bulldozers, Save the Community

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
Yolanda Garcia leans back in her battered white Camaro and points to a vacant lot surrounded by a fence topped with razor wire. "That's the senior center," she says calmly, surely. "It will have 72 units, and we want to maybe add small rooms to each unit because so many grandparents have children now." Her gaze moves across the street and stops on the line of decrepit two-story storefronts. "That's our one-acre park."
On the scale of obsession, she ranks in the serious business category somewhere between Che Guevara and Carrie Nation, with her highest scores on practicality and the sense of meaning. Her passion is not only Melrose Commons, the development plan for 35 square blocks of the South Bronx that she has worked to modify since she first heard of it in November 1992, banishing bulldozers and bringing in socially aware architectural designs. Her passion is the community she knew the original plan would destroy, a community, threatened by drugs, poverty and disinvestment, that she means to resurrect, if not outright create. 
 It has meant rising at 7 A.M. to work a full day at her family-owned carpet store before going to meetings -- hundreds a year -- that stretch deep into the night. With the group she founded to fight to modify the original plans, We Stay/Nos Quedamos, the meetings go the longest. "We had to make an agreement that the meetings would stop at midnight, because before you knew it, it would be 2 in the morning," she says, amused somehow by her own tenacity.
It means working with few resources beyond her own vision and commitment, and the trust in finding the same in others. And it means outarguing, outsmarting, outwaiting and outlasting some of the city's most accomplished bureaucrats.
"I basically lived at City Hall in late April, May, part of June," says Ms. Garcia, an unprepossessing woman in her 40's whose brown hair is secured with a silky ivory tie.
That was when Joseph B. Rose, the head of the City Planning Commission, tried to amend the review process, inserting language that the commission felt would add necessary flexibility. But Ms. Garcia saw it as an attempt to remove adequate review periods. "That would have torn down everything we created," Ms. Garcia says in her not-surprised, not-tired, not-willing-to-do-anything-but-prevail voice. "I had to meet with everybody!"
Kevin Davitt, a spokesman for the commission, said, "She certainly is a visionary. We could use more of them."
By turns, she could be confused with an urban sociologist, a political economist, a city planner or a politician. This last prompts a knowing laugh.
"They would kick me out," she explains. "I have too many new ideas. I would be pro-people, not pro-party." ANDREA KANNAPELL

HEADLINE: DRIVING SMART;
2 Experts' Collectible-Car Picks

BYLINE: By Charles McEwen

 BODY:
Each year, two experts on collectible cars, Dave Brownell and Rick Cole, put together lists of vintage automobilies that they think are good buys right now.
 The collector-car market has been particularly hard hit in the last few years. Prices had become overheated in the 1980's, driven up by speculators, and once the recession took hold the market deflated.
 Amid the relatively good buys, which are the best of the good?
 Mr. Brownell, the editor of special Interest Autos magazine and Hemmings Motor News, a monthly compendium of ads for old cars, parts and services for collectors, has chosen some "sleepers" that could prove to be solid investments while providing some fun in the meantime.
 Here are Mr. Borwnell's selections and comments:
 1961-67 Lincoln Continental four-door convertible -- "Impeccably understated styling, constructed to nearly Rolls-Royce standards. Current asking prices range from around $2,000 for shaggy unrestored cars to about $17,000 for show-ready restorations. Buy the best one your budget allows because they are very complex and therefore expensive cars to restore."
 1968-70 Dodge Charger R/T -- "A muscle car with some luxurious touches, as opposed to stripped-down corporate cousins like the Plymouth Road Runner." A partly restored '68 was offered in a recent Hemmings ad for $3,500, while on the same page a "recently restored" rust-free car from California, had an asking price of $8,000.
 1961-73 Volvo P1800, 1800S, 1800E and 1800ES -- "Built mainly for style rather than speed, these handsome coupes and sport wagons were Volvo's flagship in the United States for a dozen years." Early models are somewhat underpowered and badly susceptible to rust, he said, and the 2-liter 1800E is known for fuel-injection problems. Prices range from $4,500 to $11,500 depending on condition.
 1973 Corvette L-48 -- "Offers impressive performance even when measured against today's cars. The big difference is that a good '73 L-48 convertible will cost about one-fifth the sticker of a new Vette drop-top." Cars with removable 'T-tops" cost even less than the convertibles. The average asking price for a ready-to-drive L-48 is about $12,000.
 1969-73 Porsche 911T -- "These attractive coupes seem like a giveaway at around $10,000 for excellent examples. To be fair, the 911T is hardly perfect. Older Porsches are no stranger to rust, sometimes chronically so, and such cars should be strictly avoided because they cost the earth to restore.
 Every year for the last 10 years, Mr. Cole, a partner in the World Classic Auction and Exposition Company in Danville, Calif., has published his 'Gold List" of cars that he expects to appreciate significantly in the next five years. Here are his recent selections:
 1972-74 BMW 3.0 CS Coupe -- Current value: $8,000 to $14,000. Five-year projection: up to $25,000.
 1940's woodie sedans and wagons -- Current value: $22,500 to $27,500. Five-year projection: up to $35,000.
 1951-62 Mercedes-Benz 300 sedan -- Current value: $8,000 to $15,000. Five-year projection: up to $30,000.
 1955-62 MGA 1500 and 1600 roadster -- Current value $8,000 to $12,000. Five-year projection: up to $25,000.
 1950--51 Mercury Monterey coupe -- Current value: $8,000 to $12,000. Five-year projection: up to $20,000.
 1961-67 Chevrolet Impala and Impala SS convertibles -- Current value: $10,000 to $15,000. Five-year projection: up to $35,000.
 1963-65 Alfa Romeo Giulie, Spider and Spider Veloce -- Current value: $13,000 to $16,000. Five-year projection: up to $25,000.
 1956-67 Volkswagen microbus -- Current value: $1,000 to $8,000. Five-year projection: up to $25,000.
 1969-71 Jaguar XKE roadster -- in average condition (to be driven rather than displayed at car shows). Current value: $18,000 to $25,000. Five-year projection: up to $35,000.
 1959-64 Plymouth Fury and Sport Fury convertibles -- Current value: $8,000 to $16,000. Five-year projection: up to $25,000.

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
Seeking Classrooms That Are Classless

BYLINE: By Anne Thompson; Anne Thompson is a writer based in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
FOR Hollywood executives, deciding where to send their children to school is a test of values.
The fancy private schools are falling into disfavor among many liberal parents searching for educational environments that de-emphasize power, prestige and wealth. Some have opted for alternative schools with progressive curriculums. But as those schools, too, burgeon with student bodies largely from the upper crust of Hollywood, a new group of entertainment decision makers is choosing lesser-known private schools or, of all things, public education. 
 Like New York, Los Angeles offers a range of private schools with traditional programs designed to give students the best chance get into the best colleges. Parents in the Los Angeles area who seek admission for their children to venerated institutions like John Thomas Dye, Curtis and the Harvard-Westlake preparatory school must do the requisite hustle of admissions tests, power-recommendations and promises of large donations on top of tuition that can be close to $10,000.
One movie mogul, whose children went to Harvard-Westlake, described it as a "snob school" where "every kid knew what their fathers did." He remembered hearing the son of one player brag, "My Daddy's movie really opened well last night."
But many entertainment baby boomers who take pride in their liberal credentials reject the prep-school classroom in favor of a more progressive "developmental" education. They send their children to a new breed of private institution that has sprung up in the last 20 years, represented by schools like Crossroads, Wildwood or the Center for Early Education. At these schools, one studio executive said, teachers "talk about the inner child as opposed to getting into college."
Even those schools, however, cost from $7,000 to $10,000 a year and, without large endowments, are highly dependent on generous parents. "At our 7 A.M. interview at Crossroads," one studio production executive recalled, "it was made clear we'd have to write a large check. We liked the school, but my wife and I said, 'forget this.' "
Many entertainment executives have no problem sending their sons and daughters to school with the offspring of other industry heavyweights. One producer proudly confided that he had a top-secret list of celebrity home phone numbers from his child's school, the Center for Early Education, which a less enthusiastic producer called "the Center for Early Materialism." Some parents love to boast that their children go to school with the children of -- it always seems to be -- Steven Spielberg and Bruce Springsteen.
"These kids have more money than they should have," said a screenwriter whose children attend Crossroads and who, like a number of executives, requested anonymity.
"You go to their houses, and they have more toys than they know what do with," the screenwriter said. "There's no getting around it. You work very hard in L.A. to keep realistic values in your kids and not let them feel entitled to this enormous privilege."
One studio president seeking a more "normal" school for his daughter said he refused to send her to Wildwood because it would be "like going to the studio commissary." So he and his wife enrolled her in the Santa Monica private school P.S. 1, "an unpretentious liberal hippie school," he said. "I want her to be someone who likes to learn."
When the producer Dawn Steel ("Cool Runnings") was checking out private schools for her daughter, Rebecca, she realized she was looking for a more socially conscious educational message than what she said she had heard at an orientation for several hundred parents at the Curtis School. When a social studies teacher announced that she told her economics class that "Daddy makes the money, and Mommy spends it," Ms. Steel said she angrily bolted from her seat, turned to her friends in the crowd and said, "If any of you send your children here, I'll never talk to you again."
She selected a private school, Oakwood, in the untrendy San Fernando Valley. "It was recommended by my sister-in-law who was not in the business," Ms. Steel said. "The entertainment industry makes up about 5 percent of the students. There's an economic balance across the spectrum, from middle class to scholarship kids. I don't want my child to have unhealthy values."
Surprisingly, many entertainment industry parents looking for a broader educational experience for their children find the answer in the public schools of Santa Monica or Beverly Hills or even the beleaguered, underfinanced Los Angeles Unified School District. These parents would rather spend the money to move to a neighborhood with a good public school than enter the private school rat race.
One studio production president, who is relocating to Santa Monica for just that reason, said, "I want my kids to stay out of the Hollywood scene."
Caldecott Chubb, an executive at Alphaville Productions who was educated at East Coast private schools, is moving to Beverly Hills and going public.
"I find the private school situation repugnant," he said. "I'm repulsed at the idea of sending our 4-year-old on admissions interviews or to school with the children of people in this business. I want a school where social values are taught."
Rachel Pfeffer, production chief for Robert Redford's Wildwood Productions, said when she tells acquaintances that her daughter goes to Roscomare Road public school, near their home in Sherman Oaks, "people look at me funny. They can't believe the education could be as good as private schools." Not all public schools, she acknowledged, "are this good," adding that she and other parents put money and effort into the school.
One family opted to leave the city altogether to escape the industry influence. Tom Pollock, Universal Pictures chairman, and his family moved up the coast from Los Angeles, and his children now attend Santa Barbara's more diverse public schools.

HEADLINE: New Tourist Lure: Dolphin Watching

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY 

DATELINE: SEA ISLE CITY

 BODY:
IT was a show that almost seemed to be choreographed by Sea World in California, but these leaping, tumbling dolphins, only 10 feet from the bow of Capt. Rich George's excursion boat, Princess, were local performers just being themselves. They are part of New Jersey's latest tourism splash -- dolphin watching.
On a cruise along the shoreline of Ocean City, north of here, the boat came upon two pods of the bottle-nosed dolphins. For 40 minutes, the two dozen or so mammals cavorted along a mile-long strip of the beachfront to the delight of about a thousand people gathered at the water's edge. 
 Each time the dolphins breached, they were met by cheers and screams usually associated with Fourth of July fireworks or roller-coaster rides. Surfers tried to keep up with them, but it was the dolphins that were catching the waves, pulling out only yards from the beach to go back and do it all again.
"What I like best is when they flip over on their backs and go backward," said Jessie Serdikoff, 4, of Brigantine, who was on the Princess with her parents, Beth and Michael, and her 7-year-old sister, Molly.
One of those who caught the dolphin act from the boardwalk in Ocean City was Kimberly Huston of Ashtabula, Ohio. "I was surprised to see dolphins in New Jersey, especially that close to people," she said.
Boat captains, including Captain George, say the dolphins have become so popular that they have converted their sea fishing operations to dolphin- and whale-watching cruises over the last four years. Ron Robbins, owner of the Whale Watcher in Cape May, said this new segment of eco-tourism, concentrated mostly along the state's southern coast, is producing "annual revenues in the millions" for captains and local economies.
In Cape May and Wildwood alone, fewer than a dozen dolphin boats will have collected more than 60,000 fares before the end of summer. Mr. Robbins said his boat would take in $400,000 in passenger fares. The two- or three-hour trips cost about $15 for an adult, less for children.
Although the bottle-nosed dolphin (Tursiops trunkatus) has been the subject of intensive studies, scientists and other observers are just starting to collect data on its population and behavior in New Jersey. Some say the migratory and predatory animals breed, calve and feed here from June to late September; others say April to December.
Nor is there consensus on whether there are hundreds or thousands of dolphins along the coast. Attempts to count them have been mostly local and sporadic, officials say.
"There is not a lot of in-depth information on them," said James Hall, assistant commissioner for natural resources in the State Department of Environmental Protection.
Robert Schoelkopf, the founder and director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center, a private nonprofit organization at Brigantine, said there are about a dozen dolphin strandings each year, up from an average of only two a year in the late 1980's. Strandings of all sea animals -- including giant sea turtles, seals and whales, which, like the bottle-nosed, are endangered -- totaled 123 last year, up from about 30 in 1986.
"The total this year for all mammals is already 91," Mr. Schoelkopf said, adding that "many of our strandings come in the fall and winter, so we're far from through." How much of the increase is a result of reporting of stranding through public awareness or growth in the animal populations is not known, Mr. Schoelkopf said.
The rising popularity of dolphin watching has not been without its problems. The Stranding Center, which is the only group in the state licensed by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to rescue or even touch these creatures, says commercial and recreational boaters are killing two or three dolphins each year. Boats, as well as water scooters and helicopters, are injuring or harassing many others, Mr. Schoelkopf said.
At the request of the Stranding Center, Assemblyman John F. Gaffney, a Republican from Atlantic County, has introduced a package of three marine mammal protection bills. One would establish state regulations and distances for viewing dolphins and other mammals from the air or water. It sets up penalties of $100 to $3,000 for each offense.
Another measure would provide operating money for the center by creating a $5 renewal fee on state-issued wildlife conservation license plates, which cost $50. Each renewal fee would provide $3 to the center and $2 for research. The other bill would allocate $25,000 to the center for the purchase of a heavy-duty ambulance to replace the 1982 model now used by the center to transport stranded mammals.
Opponents of the measures include the Department of Environmental Protection, which contends that enforcement of the provisions at sea would be almost impossible. "There is a general concern about the ability to actually enforce those regulations and the sense is that there may not be a significant problem to begin with," Mr. Hall said.
All three measures cleared the Assembly's Environment Committee last month and are expected to go to the full Assembly in several weeks.
Although the dolphins and even larger members of the whale family have been playing in the New Jersey surf for hundreds of years, the sightseeing cruises, like the stranding reports, have multiplied significantly only in this decade.
Captains and marine mammal experts said in recent interviews that coastal pollution problems of the 1980's, many of which persist, have been drawing widespread public attention to the health of the Atlantic and its denizens of the deep.
 
Sightings Rare to the North
 Rhona St. Claire, assistant curator of marine mammals for the New Jersey State Aquarium at Camden, said the stranding of four dolphins in the Shrewsbury River in Monmouth County last winter, and the recovery of their carcasses there by the Stranding Center, had increased public awareness of the animals in New Jersey.
Linda Riley, a spokeswoman for the aquarium, which has a living ocean exhibit with 45 species of New Jersey fish and mammals, said an excursion sponsored by the aquarium earlier this summer had been a big success. The group spotted 34 dolphins, she said.
Both dolphins and whales and the availability of excursions appear to be more common as one travels south along the state's 127 miles of Atlantic coast. While the mammals are plentiful in Cape May County, for instance, they are said by National Park Service officials and boat captains to be rare at both Sandy Hook and Manasquan Inlet, in Monmouth and northern Ocean Counties.
"We have not had any reports of dolphins this year either by the public or our staff," said Frank Mills, the chief ranger at the Sandy Hook unit of Gateway National Park.
John Bogan of Bogan's Basin in Brielle said that one of the four fishing vessels there goes whale watching in the winter about 15 miles offshore, but that there are not any dolphin-watching boats in the entire Manasquan Inlet area.
 
A Mysterious Ailment
 Mr. Schoelkopf said the fascination with dolphins and whales in the state began in 1987 when 742 of the animals along the East Coast of the United States succumbed to a mysterious ailment and washed ashore. About 90 beached themselves in New Jersey. The cause, he said, was later found to be a viral infection.
Although no one has been able to prove it, there is lingering suspicion among scientists that the virus was carried by pollution.
Bottle-nosed dolphins are now considered a barometer of the quality of the state's ocean water, Mr. Schoelkopf said. The average person attributes their presence to an observably cleaner ocean in this decade, he said.
Boat captains say pods of bottle-nosed dolphins usually range from 3 to 50 individuals. There were more than 2,000 sightings of the animals along the coast last summer but "we don't know yet if that is the number of animals or that each animal is being counted two or three times," Mr. Schoelkopf said.
Bottle-nosed dolphins grow up to 12 feet long and can weigh more than 400 pounds. They feed on blues and menhaden and mate in spring and summer. Ten to 12 months later, they deliver young that weigh up to 25 pounds.
 
Highly Developed Brain
 The animal is famous for its highly developed brain and ultrasonic echolocation ability, whereby it locates and determines the size of its prey and predators from afar with astonishing accuracy.
The bottle-nosed is the quintessential dolphin popularized in movies and in the television show "Flipper." Even though the animals are playful and seem to have an affinity for humans, Ms. St. Claire of the aquarium cautioned swimmers about getting too close.
"People who see the big smile on the dolphin and jump in the water thinking it is Flipper," she said, "may not realize that they could be getting next to a male that weighs several hundred pounds and is in a bad mood. They could really get hurt."
Then there is the tale, told to the passengers by Captain George, about the young male surfer who decided to jump off his board and grab hold of a dolphin beyond the breakers. Apparently perceiving that the swimmer was in trouble, the dolphin rather violently butted him, pushed him through the water and flipped him out of the water and across his surfboard.
"You can bet the guy never tried that again," the captain said.

HEADLINE: A TRY AT A TRUCE OVER POPULATION

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 4

 BODY:
A day before the start of the United Nations population conference, United States and European officials said today that new language was being prepared to assuage Vatican and Islamic fears that the gathering will enshrine abortion as an international right or as a means of family planning.
The European Union has formulated "reinterpretive language" on the use of the word "right" in the conference's preparatory documents because of Vatican complaints that proposals using the word were intended to impart a binding international right to abortion, said Timothy E. Wirth, the Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs and a dominant voice for the United States in preparations for the conference. 
 "The question of quote right unquote has been a controversial issue," Mr. Wirth said at a news conference. "Some people had interpreted the use of the word 'right' in the document as establishing an understood right as is the U.N. Declaration of Human Rights, and there is a language that is being proposed by the European Union to define what is meant by 'right.' "
With agreement obtained on most of the conference's guiding document, the diplomatic effort by officials from the United States, Europe and Canada is driven by a desire to prevent Vatican and Islamic concerns from derailing what is seen as a broader agenda: the management of resources as the planet faces potential disaster from population growth.
Since preparatory discussions began in April, the European Union has sought to serve as a moderating influence, whereas the Clinton Administration has been singled out by the Vatican for harsh criticism on proposals on family planning, abortion, contraception and sexuality.
Michael Bohnet, a senior German official whose country holds the rotating presidency of the European Union, said the organization's position would be presented on Monday . "The document before the conference is 92 percent agreed," he said. "I think we are very close to having language that will move us from 92 percent to close to 100 percent."
While the debate may seem to be a matter of semantics, Vatican officials have been in the vanguard of an intensive campaign by Pope John Paul II to prevent the conference from issuing what could be a formal document with broad international legitimacy directly contradicting Roman Catholic doctrine on the sanctity of life from the moment of conception.
 
An Influence on Spending
 The conference will also carry serious financial weight, since its proposals foresee billion-dollar spending to support measures to stabilize the earth's population at 7.27 billion over the next 20 years from the current estimate of 5.66 billion.
"President Clinton and I think this is a unique and historic opportunity to address one of the world's most demanding challenges," Vice President Gore said when he arrived here tonight. Mr. Gore, who is leading the United States delegation, came under direct, personal criticism last month from the Vatican over United States proposals on abortion.
Today, the conference chairwoman, Nafis Sadik, appealed to the delegates from 170 nations attending the eight-day conference not to permit issues over abortion and adolescent sexuality to "obscure its main purpose," which many delegates and officials here say is the status of women in economic development and the regulation of family size.
The Vatican offered no response today to Mr. Wirth's suggestion that a showdown might be averted by quiet diplomacy. Vatican diplomats were not available to clarify their apparently two-track strategy toward the conference, which has so far focused on abortion while ignoring what the Pope has depicted as equally contentious proposals endorsing the distribution of contraceptives and the use of condoms to fight sexually transmitted diseases.
"There are a number of issues that are being worked on," Mr. Wirth said, "and one of those, for example, is abortion, to make sure the abortion is described not in the area of family planning."
The dispute has in large part distracted attention from many areas where the Vatican has raised no objection, like improvements in health care for women in developing countries and in the quality of family life. Nonetheless, the Pope sounded a fresh warning today from his summer residence south of Rome.
"I view the Cairo conference as an historic occasion to focus international policies and economies towards the achievement of worldwide objectives," he said. "But it is necessary to resist the temptation of a dangerous shortcut -- focusing all efforts on the reduction, by whatever means possible, of the birth rate."
While Vatican diplomats have lobbied furiously against conference proposals on abortion, they have refrained from other clauses in the preparatory documents speaking of the need to supply condoms in the battle against AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases and of a requirement for the supply of "essential high-quality contraceptives."
Vatican officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the tactic, devised to focus the full energies of the Pope's campaign against abortion, had divided the Vatican delegation between those who believed that objections should have been registered and those who thought that the antiabortion effort was more important.
The maneuvers do not apparently mean an endorsement of contraception and condoms since any of the 170 delegations may register individual objections to specific proposals, decline to sign off on the final package or, Vatican officials say, force a vote to avoid the appearance of consensus.
"The Vatican has never signed," Dr. Sadik said, referring to the last two world population conferences, in Romania in 1974 and in Mexico City in 1984. "They registered their disagreement and therefore did not join the consensus."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Helping Video Makers To Find Their Niches

BYLINE: By PETER M. NICHOLS 

 BODY:
At National Video Resources, they are eager for the future, and wary of it, too. Set up by the Rockefeller Foundation in 1990, N.V.R., as it is known to independent film and video makers across the country, helps the little guys to produce and market their videotapes. To appreciate that challenge, imagine trying to land a documentary about the Eskimo Olympics on the shelf between "Aladdin" and "Sleepless in Seattle."
N.V.R. works with alternative video: the films and tapes of artists, educators, members of all kinds of minorities and advocates of all sorts of causes. Those kinds of things are not found in video stores. "Of all the entertainment media, video has the narrowest selection," Timothy Gunn, executive director of N.V.R., said. "It's 90 percent movies." 
 Mr. Gunn acknowledges that stores do not have room for everything and that most people would not be interested even if they did. N.V.R. helps producers to get thousands of tapes on a wealth of subjects into the hands of specialized audiences.
 
'An Endless Shelf'
 Until now that has meant cultivating libraries, universities and similar outlets that harbor niche markets within large communities. But Mr. Gunn sees new opportunities ahead in digital technology that will enable a virtually limitless amount of programming to be stored in computers and make videos about everything available to anybody.
"Video on demand would solve the access problem," he said in a recent interview at N.V.R.'s spacious headquarters in a loft in lower Manhattan. "It's virtually an endless shelf."
But, he added, because nothing comes easily for independent video makers, even that prospect is unclear. Just as supply is currently restricted by commercial gatekeepers, so it could be limited by a different set of masters in the future.
While N.V.R. monitors technological developments, it continues to serve as a counselor to independent producers and distributors and as a link between video makers and their audiences. The nonprofit organization, which has a staff of three, including Mr. Gunn, is backed by money from the Rockefeller Foundation and occasionally joins with groups like the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation to develop outlets for hard-to-place videos. It spends about $600,000 annually.
N.V.R. does not finance individual productions. Instead it uses its resources to help video makers find the means to produce their tapes and distribute them on their own. That might mean making technical assistance grants to allow distributors to research markets, find audiences and improve their own business practices. One recent grant, for example, helped a distributor of African-American films to develop a catalogue and get its titles to high school teachers.
N.V.R. helps in other ways. One of its biggest ongoing projects is showing distributors how to place videos in libraries. In another effort, N.V.R. negotiated with 16 film archives to provide discounts on their footage for video documentary makers.
N.V.R. also gathers advice from other consultants, commissions studies and then dispenses the information. For example, a series of N.V.R. reports offers counsel on topics like how to make profitable use of an "800" number, the role of video in the college textbook industry and the impact of new digital technology on production and distribution.
"N.V.R. is terrific at organizing discussions with very smart people to show us how to do business," said Kate Horsfield, the executive director of the Video Data Bank, a Chicago distributor of alternative videos.
Ms. Horsfield's nonprofit organization places tapes with museums, colleges and universities. "They aren't mainstream titles," she said. "Mostly it's difficult work, intellectually based, people playing with ideas."
Representative of the 2,500 tapes in the company's collection are "Video in the Villages," about teaching video technology to indigenous peoples in Brazil as a means of preserving their way of life; "Delirium," a video about women, madness and family, and "It Wasn't Love," about fear, violence, lust and guilt.
 
Assistance in Marketing
 Ms. Horsfield said she used a recent N.V.R. grant to identify her market better and upgrade her company's data base -- "what corporations have been doing forever," she said. The result, she added, was that revenue has sharply increased.
While N.V.R. helps independent video makers market their tapes, Mr. Gunn looks ahead to electronic distribution through networks put together by cable, telephone and computer companies. He distrusts the prospect of 500-channel cable systems, several of which are being tested, because access will remain chained to the old commercial rules. "They'll be filled with pay-per-view movies, the kind of thing we have already, only repeated more often," he said.
True video on demand, however, would open the window. "These aren't channels, but a library of videos housed in a giant computer," he said. "Potentially that's much more promising for independent work because there's no space problem."
But there are other difficulties, some of them familiar to independent video makers. "Programs will have to be used with a certain frequency to justify the cost of inclusion," Mr. Gunn said.
There is also the persistent problem of publicity..
 
Preparing for Future
 As part of its preparation for new technologies, N.V.R. helped put together a 30-hour package of children's programming to be used by Bell Atlantic during tests of a video delivery system in Virginia.
Many of N.V.R.'s constituents are skeptical about how their work will fare on such systems. "My vision is that the economic interests will always win out," said Debra Zimmerman, who received an N.V.R. grant in the past and is executive director of Women Make Movies, a New York company promoting female film makers.
"In the new technological scheme of things," Ms. Zimmerman continued, "they might give us a small slice, like we were supposed to get a slice of public television. It will be no larger."
David Rosen, a consultant who helped N.V.R. with its Bell Atlantic package, said that Mr. Gunn's organization was uniquely positioned to be of service. "N.V.R. has no vested interest," he said, "and it has the time and resources to explore the issues, the finances, how it works, how to get access to video-on-demand trials, how to stimulate audiences."

HEADLINE: Surprise in Idaho Governor's Race: Leader Is a Democrat and an Indian

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TWIN FALLS, Idaho, Aug. 30

 BODY:
To be a Democrat in this state, where Bill Clinton barely nudged Ross Perot for second place in the 1992 election with just 29 percent of the vote, is to be intimate with the word underdog.
And to be anything other than a white candidate in Idaho, where racial minorities make up only about 7 percent of the population, would seem a challenge to a politician of any party.
So it comes as a surprise to many people that Larry EchoHawk, a Pawnee Indian and Democrat who counts President Clinton as a friend, is holding a steady double-digit lead in the polls in the race to become Idaho's next governor. 
 Mr. EchoHawk does not shy from acknowledging his ethnic background or his party affiliation. But as he travels between the two time zones that divide this mountainous, lamb-chop-shaped state, he stresses other parts of his background. He is now the State Attorney General. He was a county prosecutor, a Brigham Young University football player and a United States marine.
He is also a Mormon. And while that may help him here in Idaho, which is second only to Utah in the percentage of people who are members of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, it has caused trouble among some other Indians.
Even as the tribes here welcome the likely prospect that Mr. EchoHawk will become the nation's first American Indian governor, some of them say his opposition to expanding gambling in the state could deprive them of significant economic opportunity. The Mormon faith has tenets against gambling. But many American Indians see it as their economic salvation and have been using their status as nations within a nation to develop lucrative casino operations around the country.
 
At Odds Over Gambling
 Idaho has a constitutional amendment against casino-style gambling, a law written in part, and defended in court, by Attorney General EchoHawk.
"We have our differences with Larry EchoHawk," said Charles Hayes, chairman of the Nez Perce Indian tribal council. "There is a sense of honor and pride that he might be elected. But there is also real frustration."
Two years ago, the Nez Perce passed a resolution that accused Mr. EchoHawk of working against the interest of Indians because of his anti-gambling stand. The Coeur d'Alene Indians have expressed similar criticism.
Choosing his words with care, Mr. EchoHawk, a trim 46-year-old marathon runner who is extremely soft-spoken, says gambling is not the best way to help Indians, even though it has brought full employment to some tribes in other states.
Idaho's three big Indian reservations have not shared in the enormous prosperity that has come to this state in the last five years, driven in large part by a surge of people from California and growth in high tech jobs and food processing.
"I told the tribes when I ran for attorney general that I could not be the tribal attorney in the Statehouse," Mr. EchoHawk said. "I care very deeply about their issues. I was raised with Indian values. And the strongest of those is family. That's what we have to look at, making the family strong."
Whether being an Indian in a conservative, mostly white state will hurt him is something that still concerns Mr. EchoHawk, even though he won the Democratic primary nearly 3 to 1. His Republican rival in November, Phil Batt, a former legislator and party chairman, asked people in a recent poll how they felt about the possibility of Idaho's electing the nation's first Indian governor. He will not say what the results were.
But Mr. Batt has said he will not make Mr. EchoHawk's ethnicity an issue. During a debate here this week, he mentioned it only in passing, noting that American Indian tribes were among the "outside" influences that were making claims for a share of Idaho's water. The state is in the eighth year of a drought, and farmers, fishermen, environmentalists, industrial users and Indians are all fighting over water use.
Outside Idaho, Mr. EchoHawk's candidacy has energized Indians throughout the West and become a cause for some Hollywood luminaries. Dustin Hoffman, for example, donated $50,000 to his campaign.
At a recent Seattle fund-raising event for Mr. EchoHawk, a Mandan Indian, Tony McGrady, said, "I'm going to move to Idaho and declare citizenship just so I can vote for Larry."
A distant relative presented him with a picture of Mr. EchoHawk's great-grandfather, the warrior Echo Hawk, who posed in the uniform of an Indian scout. Mr. EchoHawk was visibly moved.
"My great-grandfather was known for his bravery," he said. "He was called Hawk, and they echoed his praises, so he became Echo Hawk.
"The Pawnee used to have 23 million acres of land, almost all of Nebraska. Then they were marched to a small reservation in Oklahoma. I never knew Echo Hawk, but I can imagine what it must have been like to be removed to Oklahoma."
One of six children, Mr. EchoHawk was born on Aug. 2, 1948, in Wyoming and grew up in Farmington, N.M. His father, a full-blooded Pawnee, was a land surveyor and worked in the oil supply business. His mother is of German ancestry.
His brother, John EchoHawk, the director of the Native American Rights Fund, remembers his family being harassed on occasion but said the harassment often came from other Indians. "That was Navajo, Apache and Ute country," he explained. "There just weren't very many Pawnees."
Larry EchoHawk says his father struggled with alcoholism until 1962, when a Mormon missionary converted the family. Mr. EchoHawk was a high school quarterback and a standout athlete at Brigham Young. He earned his law degree from the University of Utah. All six EchoHawk children went to college, and three became lawyers. Larry and his wife, Terry, have six children of their own.
"I believe in the promise of America," Mr. EchoHawk told the Indians gathered in Seattle. "My political credo is very simple: to return something for what you've received."
His hero, he said, is Robert F. Kennedy. "In the early years of my life, I never thought I would even go to college," he said. "But in my formative years, I heard Robert Kennedy say: 'Some men see things as they are and say, 'Why?' I see things as they could be and say, 'Why not?' "
He became a tribal counselor to the Shoshone-Bannock tribes in Idaho and was then elected a county prosecutor. In his first year as a state legislator, in 1982, he was one of 17 Democrats out of 84 members of the House.
"If I were to just run as a Democrat, it would be over," he said. "You've got to offer something else."
Idaho Democrats tend to be pro-gun and anti-abortion, a mold that has well served Cecil Andrus, the departing Governor, during a 40-year political career. Mr. EchoHawk takes the same position as Governor Andrus on those two issues.
This year there is an anti-gay ordinance on the state ballot. Both Mr. EchoHawk and Mr. Batt oppose it as unnecessary, but they are both against expanding rights for homosexuals.
"Like many Idahoans, I am opposed to teaching homosexuality as an alternative or normal life style," Mr. EchoHawk said during a debate in Twin Falls. "But that anti-gay proposition is absolutely unconstitutional."
He is also presenting himself as tough on crime, a big issue here as gangs have arrived with the influx of newcomers.
Mr. EchoHawk has been vilified for his friendship with President Clinton, who is extremely unpopular in Idaho. But the President was the host of a fund-raising event for him last spring in Washington.
While disagreeing with Mr. Clinton on some Western issues, Mr. EchoHawk said, "I will make no apologies for my friendship with him."
In recent years, Idaho has received national attention for a small but vocal group of neo-Nazis and white supremacists who live in pockets of the woods, mostly in Northern Idaho. Mr. EchoHawk says he is proof that the state is far more tolerant than it has been perceived.
Idaho, he told the group of Indians assembled in a tribal cultural center overlooking Puget Sound, was the first state to elect a Jew as governor -- sending Moses Alexander to the Statehouse in 1914.
"We can make history again," he said.

HEADLINE: Parents Take Less of a Role As Pupils Age

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA 

 BODY:
A nationwide study of families and schools released today shows that many parents, consumed by making ends meet, are far less involved in the high schools than in the elementary schools, leaving their children with less guidance in the face of a destructive peer culture.
A private research organization in Washington, Child Trends Inc., conducted the study, "Running in Place: How American Families Are Faring in a Changing Economy and an Individualistic Society." It highlights several facts about American families in the 1990's. Among them are these: 
 *Nearly half of American high school students have parents who do not volunteer at school and do not attend Parent-Teacher Association meetings, back-to-school nights, class plays and varsity football games.
*Contrary to worries that conditions for families disintegrate as more mothers work, the study found that working mothers are just as involved in their children's schools as those who stay at home. And many states with the highest percentage of working mothers rank highest on indicators of family well-being like low child poverty rates and fewer births to teen-agers.
*Parents want their children to do well in school and to refrain from smoking or drinking, but these aims are subverted by an adolescent culture that mocks high achievers and promotes cigarettes and alcohol.
*Most families are working hard to stay in place, with wages stagnant; meanwhile, the wages of married women rose much faster than those of married men.
*Asian-American parents tended to be less involved in organized school activities -- 38 percent as against 62 percent of white, non-Hispanic parents. But their children still did better on the whole in school, leading the study's researchers to conclude that Asian parents may supervise schoolwork at home.
 
Drawing on Several Surveys
 The study draws on new analyses of several nationwide surveys, including the 1990 census, two national education surveys and vital statistics like birth certificates, and was conducted by Dr. Nicholas Zill, a psychologist, and Christine Winquist Nord, a demographer.
Dr. Zill said he was struck by the sharp drop in parental supervision of children's education. Involvement in schools falls to 50 percent of parents when children are ages 16 or older, the study said; but when children are ages 8 to 11, the figure is 73 percent.
Dr. Zill said these findings indicated a need to pay more attention to adolescents, particularly in the face of a peer culture made more powerful by television and music and adults who are less confident of exerting authority.
He also said that the study's findings contradicted widespread fears about working mothers. "By no means is there the kind of conservative stereotype that maternal employment means the death of family," Dr. Zill said.
For example, states like Iowa, Nebraska and Kansas, which had high percentages of employed mothers of young children, also ranked well on several indicators of family well-being. These included rates of child poverty, births to teen-age mothers or those with less than high school education, parental unemployment, parental involvement in schooling, and levels of student respect for teachers. The states ranking lowest over all on these indicators were Louisiana, Mississippi, New Mexico and South Carolina.
Over all, the study found, states like Iowa, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Hampshire, Utah and Vermont offer the best conditions for family life, with the lowest rates of child poverty and repeat births to teen-age mothers and the highest rates of parental involvement and student respect for teachers.

The study, by the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, is the first to determine that wages of the college-educated lost ground to inflation even after the United States economy began to recover from recession. The Media Business
A subplot to last week's rumors about the possible sale of one or more television broadcast networks is the remarkable financial comeback of the network TV business. HEADLINE: The Scrambling Is On For Off-Season Tourism

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
With the summer vacation season ending today, many tourist spots that used to board up for the year are no longer content to hibernate. Instead, in what travel officials describe as making applesauce out of apples, many cities and states are trying to lure tourists in the off-season.
Alaska is selling itself as a winter wonderland, tempting tourists with the Northern Lights and trips by dog sled. Ocean City, N.J., a seaside resort, is about to start a campaign marketing the city as a year-round destination, complete with performances of "The Nutcracker" in late November. Coastal towns in Oregon and Washington, which draw sports fishermen in the summer, are urging tourists to come enjoy the thunder and lightning storms that batter their beaches in the fall and winter. 
 "You can't believe how many people flock to our oceanfront hotels, where you can watch the coastline erode right before your very eyes," said Patricia Shea, the director of the Chamber of Commerce of Bandon, Ore.
The reason for the strategy is obvious: Travelers spent about $397 billion in the United States last year, according to the United States Travel Data Center, and tourism is among the top three industries in 37 states. This fiscal year, state governments will spend $364 million to promote tourism, compared with $190 million nine years ago. With states seeing off-season tourism as a way to increase jobs and tax revenues, industry officials say a growing percentage of promotional budgets will be going to encourage off-season visits.
Texas, for example, spends about 18 percent of its $3.1 million magazine advertising budget to promote off-season travel. Officials estimate that the state brings in $21.4 billion annually from tourism, with only a small fraction of the total from visitors during the winter. Now tourism officials are analyzing their first comprehensive study of off-season travel.
 
'We Operate Like a Business'
 "Now that oil is not the be-all, end-all, state officials realized how important tourism is," said Michael Kardos, a spokesman for the tourist agency of Texas. "Even though we're a state agency, we operate like a business. We're looking for every opportunity to generate money and jobs, and off-season tourism is an important, growing part of that."
Hundreds of other cities and states also want in on the off-season. Phoenix and its neighboring cities in Arizona's Valley of the Sun, packed with tourists during the winter, are positioning themselves for summer, when temperatures routinely rise into the 100's but five-star resorts and luxury hotels can be booked for two-star prices. The city has hired a London-based tourism agency to pitch summer visits to the British and the Germans, who each account for more than 100,000 visitors a year to Phoenix.
Off-season tourism is also a growing part of Alaska's strategy, spurred by airline and hotel packages that help make the 49th state a bargain in winter -- at least for visitors whom Tina Lindgren, the executive director of the Alaska Tourism Marketing Council, describes as "the more adventurous tourists, who want to experience such uniquely Alaska activities as dog sledding, ice carving and viewing the Northern Lights."
 
 
New Year-Round Resort
 Last week, the first year-round resort in Alaska opened in Girdwood, a snowball's throw from Anchorage (which for two years has used the advertising slogan, "Anchorage, Where Winter Is Wonderful").
When fully open next month, the resort, the Alyeska Prince Hotel, owned by the Seibu Corporation of Japan, will have 307 guest rooms, an indoor pool, a 16-person whirlpool, a 60-passenger aerial tram, an 18-hole golf course and almost 500 acres of skiable terrain available from November to May on Mount Alyeska.
But Alaska will have a lot of competition this fall and winter, and not just from traditional warm-weather playgrounds like Florida, Hawaii and the Caribbean.
San Francisco, hoping to attract more visitors from October through March, is offering, without charge, a visitor's kit that includes discounts and special offers from airlines, rental car agencies, hotels, restaurants, attractions, shops and sightseeing companies.
"And for the first time ever, we'll be promoting ourselves on TV, as a way to attract more visitors," said Lovester Law, vice president of marketing for the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau. The $1.5 million promotion, on cable television, will begin on Sept. 19.
 Across the continent in Ocean City, whose population of 15,000 swells to 150,000 in the summer, the city recently renovated its venerable boardwalk Music Hall for year-round use. And it will soon mail 10,000 brochures promoting fall and winter events, from big-band dances to string-band performances to "The Nutcracker."
"We're trying to extend our tourist season, and help fill our hotels and restaurants," said Joanne Delvescio, the executive director of the Ocean City Tourism Commission. "We want to become more than just a three-month resort."
 
Foliage and History
 Rhode Island reaps $1.4 billion from tourism, its second-largest industry. Hoping for more, it is aggressively promoting off-season travel, in part by piggybacking on the popularity of the fall foliage season in neighboring states.
"We don't have as much leaf-changing as the rest of New England," said David C. DePetrillo, associate director of the Rhode Island Department of Economic Development. "So we try to get those tourists to visit Rhode Island, too, for our rich history and cultural activities."
Rhode Island has also induced group tour buses to add the state to their New England itineraries. And it will soon go after individual tourists through ads in 11 magazines and 8 newspapers, mostly in the Northeast. "With the big investments required for hotels and attractions, seasonal tourism is vital," Mr. DePetrillo said.
 From October through February in the Pacific Northwest, whenever bad weather threatens, tourists -- including large contingents of Canadians -- show up at seaside towns to watch Mother Nature's fury.
At Lincoln City, Ore., 1,800 of the town's 2,000 motel rooms provide an ocean view of storms that generate 20-foot-high waves and lightning bolts that illuminate the ocean for hours. "Storm watching is so popular our hotels send out storm-watcher lists offering discounts, and occupancy has increased 40 to 50 percent," said Terry Cowling, the executive director of the Lincoln City Visitor Bureau.
Washington, Idaho and Texas promote environmental tourism in the off-season. Such tourism, which can include bird-watching expeditions and visits to national forests, is especially popular with seniors, who can pursue it at odd times.
"It's also popular because with new technology you can do many things without being uncomfortable," said John Hunt, a professor in the department of resource recreation and tourism at the University of Idaho. "These days, there's everything from snowmobiles to snow-making equipment, and clothing and camping gear that make it livable outdoors year-round."
Another reason for the growing success of off-season strategies is that "states have become a lot more sophisticated with their data bases," said James V. Cammisa Jr., a travel industry analyst in Miami. "They know where the peaks and valleys in their tourism operations are, and they know how to market the off-season effectively."
Kentucky's data base showed that only 350,000 of the 2.5 million Canadians who drove through the state last year stayed overnight.
"Our research showed that 83 percent of them come from January to June, headed for Florida, South Carolina and the beaches of Alabama and Mississippi," said Robert Stewart, the Commissioner of Travel Development for Kentucky. To entice more of them, Kentucky officials will soon hold a news conference in Toronto and Canadians will be offered a card giving them discounts at hotels, restaurants and attractions along three of Kentucky's interstate highways.
Also for the first time, Kentucky is using direct mail to bolster anemic winter occupancy rates in its 15 resort parks that offer overnight accommodations year-round.
"Summer will still always be the biggest vacation time," Mr. Cammisa, the travel industry analyst, said. "But it's been years since the plant closed two weeks in the summer, and the whole family had to take its vacation then. Now you can go pretty much any time of year, so you can be sure states and cities will do what they can to attract you."

HEADLINE: Rethinking a Model Incentive Plan

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: EUCLID, Ohio

 BODY:
For two decades the Lincoln Electric Company, the nation's largest maker of arc welders and welding supplies, has been studied by Harvard Business School students as a model of how to motivate workers.
Each year thousands of managers from other companies, even some rivals, journey to Lincoln's modest headquarters and huge factory complex in this blue-collar Cleveland suburb for free seminars on the company's incentive system. 
 They are intrigued because Lincoln has gone further than any other large manufacturer in matching compensation to each employee's productivity and to the profitability of the company. Indeed, since 1934 Lincoln has parceled out almost as much in bonuses as in salaries.
The bonus pool is divided among employees on the basis of ratings of each one's output, quality, dependability and degree of cooperativeness with other workers. The system includes a no-layoff guarantee that the company has never violated. But the system is also brutally demanding, forcing workers into constant competition with each other to produce more with fewer mistakes.
Lincoln offers few of the fringe benefits that many workers take for granted: no pay for sick days or holidays, for example. And managers operate without perquisites like reserved parking or club memberships.
 
An Overseas Mess
 These days, though, problems at Lincoln are forcing Harvard to update its case study. Many stem from the mess the company made of a rapid buildup overseas in the late 1980's. The most immediate concern is how the company can keep domestic productivity growing at past levels while workers here see their bonuses shrink, offsetting the strategic errors and naivete of senior management as to how easily the Lincoln system could be exported.
The resentment was tempered in 1992 and 1993 when Lincoln paid sizable bonuses to American workers despite posting the first overall losses in its 99-year history. Now comes the harder part. Donald F. Hastings, the company's chairman and chief executive, has made a video telling the more than 3,000 workers in the company's main factory here and a sister plant in nearby Mentor that bonuses might decline this year, even though sales seem headed to more than $900 million for the first time and the company expects record profits.
Mr. Hastings, a marketing expert who became the first nonengineer to lead the company when he was elevated to the job at the height of the financial crisis, said shareholders had already given up year-end bonus dividends for two years. He said the workers would have to carry a bigger share of the burden this year to let Lincoln reduce its debts from the expansion abroad and invest in new equipment. Otherwise, he warned, the company could be bankrupted by the next domestic downturn.
 
A Warning to Companies
 "People understand that Mr. Hastings is trying to bring things back in line, but there's a lot of disgruntlement," said Percy Robinson, a tool and die maker for the company. "A lot of people feel ripped off."
Lincoln's predicament is a warning to American companies about how easy it is to underestimate the challenges of other cultures and problem subsidiaries. Lincoln's woes also show how success can allow a company to develop bad habits like continuing to rely on internal promotion even when a change in strategy calls for an infusion of executives with broader experience.
Lincoln's confidence in its vision going into the foreign misadventures was understandable. Lawrence O. Selhorst, chairman and chief executive of the American Spring Wire Corporation and one of several new board members recruited by Mr. Hastings, admiringly calls Lincoln's legendary compensation system "the Babe Ruth of incentive programs."
Under Lincoln's system, line workers generally receive no base wage and are paid only for what they produce. Those without the kind of piecework production jobs that fit easily into such a system get hourly wages or salaries pegged to Lincoln's calculation of the average for similar jobs in the Cleveland area.
If production is interrupted for an extended period of time for reasons having nothing to do with the line workers' performance, supervisors can assign them to other jobs, like sweeping, at an hourly rate.
 
No-Layoff Policy
 On the other hand, a high proportion of the profits go into the bonus pool. The bonuses sometimes lift the income of the most successful production workers to more than $100,000. The average compensation in 1993 was about $51,000.
An even more compelling carrot for many is the no-layoff policy that has been faithfully observed since the pay-for-performance system was installed in 1934. It applies to all workers with three years on the job and guarantees at least a 30-hour week. In the early 1980's, when all of Lincoln's large clients slumped simultaneously and sales plunged by more than 40 percent, Lincoln sent production workers on the road as additional salesmen rather than lay anyone off.
"When you talk about job security, you can't beat Lincoln Electric," said Mr. Robinson, adding that he had been through layoffs and several strikes at unionized Caterpillar and Alcoa plants in this area.
About 25 percent of Lincoln's employees quit during their first year, but the number who drop out after that is lower than average. Absenteeism is low because of its direct impact on take-home pay.
"I don't work for Lincoln Electric; I work for myself," said Lester Hillier, a 17-year welder at the company. "I'm an entrepreneur."
Mr. Hillier figures he turned in nearly 50 cost-reduction suggestions during the spring and early summer, about 30 of which were accepted. Previously, he and a co-worker agreed to treat the daily output of the four machines in their work area as one pool to be split evenly in their records. Both men come out ahead, he said.
 
Preying on a Downside
 By encouraging such initiative, Lincoln grew slowly but steadily for decades. The company had a reputation for high-handed dealings with its distributors, but the quality and price of its products were hard to beat.
Many small companies and a few large ones, including General Electric and Westinghouse, were driven from the market. But some managed to prey upon the downside of Lincoln's system. To maintain its no-layoff pledge, Lincoln was slow to develop new products that required less labor to make, and slow to expand during boom periods.
Those policies let Miller Electric Manufacturing, a family-owned company in Appleton, Wis., until its sale last year to Illinois Tool Works, become the leading supplier of welding equipment, slightly ahead of Lincoln's 35 percent market share.
Miller did not take on Lincoln in its bigger business, the production of the supplies used by welders. As Lincoln saw it, the only true threat it faced from a full-line welding company as it entered the 1980's was from ESAB of Sweden.
As ESAB acquired European rivals, Lincoln, which had small operations in Britain, France and Canada, became increasingly concerned that the Swedish company would establish a fortress on its home ground and then invade the United States market.
From 1986 to 1992, Lincoln expanded from 5 plants in 4 countries to 21 plants in 15 countries. "We did it too fast, paid too much; we didn't understand foreign markets and cultures, and then we got hit by recession," Mr. Hastings said of the strategy in his video presentation.
The extent of the problems was a sobering experience for the company. Mr. Hastings recruited outside board members to bring fresh perspectives to planning, including Mr. Selhorst; Edward E. Hood Jr., the recently retired vice chairman of General Electric, and Paul E. Lego, the former chairman and chief executive of Westinghouse. Mr. Hastings, who is 65, has also moved recently to hire more outsiders for key positions and appointed a younger generation of top managers.
Lincoln has also focused on building a more cooperative relationship with its distributors. And it loosened some rules, like a ban on investing in equipment that could not pay for itself within a year.
The dark cloud over all this is the debt piled up to finance overseas expansion. Initially, the debt load made the company more determined to cram the labor system so successful at home down the throats of its new foreign employees.
But Brazilians, by law, can regard any bonus received for two years as part of base salary. In Europe, workers valued vacation time more than large bonuses, and unions at the acquired companies would have nothing to do with a system that sought to make workers feel like independent entrepreneurs.
In France, the system began to take root but fell apart after a rapid expansion left the subsidiary with no profits to distribute as bonuses, infuriating employees.
Mr. Hastings said the system worked best in "immigrant cultures," noting that Lincoln's Australian unit had used it for decades.
Still, Mr. Hood said, "I doubt that Lincoln's system is exportable."
This year, with the worst foreign operations closed and others trimmed, Lincoln has earned nearly $23 million on sales of almost $445 million in the first six months. It called on workers to give up August vacations to keep up with demand; hundreds did.
The overtime may help those counting on big bonuses. But for many, working more has added to the building discontent, despite the $100 million in bonuses paid during the last two years when the company was in the red.
 
Backed by Heirs
 "The employee attitude has been, 'We didn't create the problem, so why should we pay for it?' " said Richard Sabo, assistant to the chief executive.
Whether that thinking can survive challenges like the need to deal with customers and competitors globally remains in doubt. The current system has the backing of the Lincoln family's heirs, who collectively own about 51 percent of the stock. At least 30 percent more is held by employees.
But some new board members may be interested in chipping away further at the bonus structure until the balance sheet is cleaned up. "Lincoln certainly knows how to motivate people," Mr. Hood said, "but you can make an argument that shareholders get the short end of the stick."

HEADLINE: Hollis B. Chenery Dies at 77; Economist for the World Bank

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Hollis B. Chenery, an economist who served the World Bank and the Agency for International Development and was a Harvard professor, died on Thursday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 77.
The cause was pneumonia, and he had been suffering from Parkinson's disease, said his daughter Teresa Seamster. 
 Mr. Chenery was the World Bank's vice president for development policy from 1972 to 1982. In 1977 the bank, which then administered $40 billion of loans, made a fundamental change in its development strategy by trying to focus more on projects meeting the needs of the very poorest people.
In an interview then, Mr. Chenery said: "We're looking at what governments are doing on income distribution. It's one of the considerations now in making project loans."
Mr. Chenery joined the United States Agency for International Developent in 1961, and rose to become an assistant admnistrator. He left in 1965.
He was a professor of economics at Stanford from 1952 to 1961, a Guggenheim fellow in 1961 and a professor of economics at Harvard from 1965 to 1970, and again after leaving the World Bank.
The books of which he was author or co-author include "Industrialization and Growth," "Patterns of Development" and "Studies in Developmental Planning."
Mr. Chenery was born in Richmond, grew up in Virginia and Pelham Manor, N.Y., and earned bachelor's degrees from the Universities of Arizona and the University of Oklahoma. He was an Army Air officer in World War II and received master's degrees from California Institute of Technology and the University of Virginia. He was awarded a Ph.D. by Harvard in 1950.
His 1942 marriage to Louise Seamster ended in divorce in 1964. In 1970 he married Mary Montgomery; she died in 1993.
He is survived by two daughters, Mrs. Seamster of Santa Fe and Sister Hollis Ann Chenery, a Holy Rosary Sister, of Nova Maraba, Brazil; a granddaughter; a sister, Helen Chenery, of Lexington, Ky., and three stepsons.

HEADLINE: A Degree's Shrinking Returns

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Despite the creation of more than four million jobs since President Clinton took office, many of them for college graduates, the wages of men with bachelor's degrees have continued to deteriorate, a study by a Washington research organization has found. Administration officials say the findings are probably accurate.
The study, by the Economic Policy Institute, is the first to find that the hourly wages of the college-educated lost ground to inflation even after the economy began to recover from recession in the spring of 1991. The deterioration continued at least into 1993, despite an increasingly robust economy. Previous studies had found that wages of college-educated men -- but not women -- slipped during the economic stagnation from 1989 to 1991.
 
A Lingering Pattern
 "I don't see any reason why this trend should have changed since 1993 or will change in the near future," said Lawrence Mishel, research director of the Economic Policy Institute. 
 One message that emerges from the study by the institute, which issues a book-length report on "The State of Working America" every two years, is that the bachelor's degree, like the high school diploma before it, is no longer a ticket to a rising standard of living. Only college-educated women have gained ground on inflation, but their wages are still lower than those of men with bachelor's degrees, whose median hourly wage in 1993 had slipped to $17.62, the study found. Adjusted for inflation, the decline was about 3 percent since 1989.
 
Quantity vs. Quality
 Another message from the study is that putting people to work -- President Clinton has promised to create at least eight million jobs during his four years in office -- no longer translates easily into higher living standards.
Indeed, college graduates have taken jobs in rising numbers, and as a result, the total wages paid to all college graduates have risen, Mr. Mishel said. "But because the money has to be spread over so many people, the typical college graduate finds that his income has not kept up with inflation," he said. And this remains the case even when the amounts that employers pay for pensions and health insurance are added in.
The Economic Policy Institute, which campaigned for Mr. Clinton's election and now criticizes his economic policies, argues that wages have become resistant to a prospering economy, so other steps must be taken to improve them.
Wages, Mr. Mishel said, are held back by "structural" factors -- including weak unions, a proliferation of low-wage industries, competition from foreign labor, too little improvement in productivity or efficiency and a minimum wage that is too low. This in turn pulls down the entire pay scale, he said.
The Administration, and many economists, disagree with Mr. Mishel's diagnosis, although they do not challenge the institute's finding that the hourly wages of college-educated men continued to deteriorate during the recovery. It is a finding that challenges the Administration's view that a growing economy will eventually produce enough wage gains to raise the living standards of those who possess the education and training to function in a high-technology workplace.
"There is a danger in using the Economic Policy Institute's figures as a report card on the Administration," a senior Administration official said. "The institute's wage data are probably accurate, but they go only through the middle of 1993, which is the President's first six months in office. During that time, the priority was to facilitate job growth by lowering interest rates to get the economy growing. And, historically, a growing economy has led to wage growth."
That was certainly the case in the early 1980's. From 1979 through most of 1982, a period of recession, the median wage of the college-educated lost ground to inflation. But from 1983 through 1988, with the economy growing again, the median wage of the college-educated rose by more than enough to improve their standard of living.
During most of the 1980's, the median hourly wage of those with a high school education fell, particularly during the recession early in the decade. Many of the high-school-educated were blue-collar workers in manufacturing, where employment declined.
The two trends gave rise to a huge college-high school wage gap. It grew until 1989, when the nation entered another period of weak economic growth and recession, one that lasted until the spring of 1991. This time, however, the wages of the college-educated did not bounce back when the recession ended. The recovery is now three years old, and the median wage for a man with a bachelor's degree has deteriorated for at least two of those years and probably all three, Mr. Mishel says.
Others argue that Mr. Mishel may be too pessimistic. "The forces at work could be structural or they could be cyclical," said Robert Hall, an economist at Stanford University, referring to Mr. Mishel's view that they are structural and the Administration's that they are cyclical. "We don't know yet. We have to wait a few years."
Whatever the answer, the gap between the median wages of college-educated and high school-educated men is no longer widening, the Economy Policy Institute reports. From 1989 through mid-1993, both groups lost ground to inflation at the same pace, roughly 3 percent annually.
Specifically, the median wage of a man with a bachelor's degree fell to $17.62 an hour in 1993 from $18.16 in 1989, after adjustment for inflation, while the median for a man with a high school education was $11.19 an hour in 1993, down from $11.83 in 1989. The median hourly wage of men with postgraduate study -- $21.71 an hour in 1993 -- has also fallen, the institute says, but only slightly since 1990. The study did not examine women's wages in any detail.
"Yes, it is clear that education is not the only factor at work here," said Lawrence Katz, the Labor Department's chief economist until late last month, when he returned to Harvard University to teach. "But the gap between those who went to college and those who didn't is still huge. You would be crazy not to go to college."
The Administration has argued in recent weeks that a growing economy and rising employment levels have made annual incomes, if not hourly wages, of individuals grow. "Working Americans are much better off than they were one Labor Day ago," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said at a news conference last week.
The Economic Policy Institute's findings, based on analyses of Government data, do not dispute such claims. But Mr. Mishel argues that the income growth has come because more people are working and therefore have salaries and because people are working longer hours to offset their deteriorating hourly wages. The result is higher total annual income for all Americans.
But how much rise is there in the wages at each job? In late August, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics issued an analysis of the quality of the four million jobs that have been created. The study found that many of the jobs were in high-paying occupations, but those occupations were in low-paying industries. "The result is that the trend in wages has basically been pretty flat," said Thomas Nardone, an economist at the bureau.
