HEADLINE: Politicians Still Courting Perot's Leaderless Army

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CUSHING, Me., Sept. 1

 BODY:
At the height of the bitter battle over ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Ross Perot held a Washington news conference to denounce the pact. Representative Olympia J. Snowe was right there beside him.
And when Mr. Perot's organization, United We Stand, holds a candidate forum this fall, Ms. Snowe, a nine-term Republican from northern Maine now running for the Senate, will be there as well. 
 It is not the power of Mr. Perot himself that draws politicians like Ms. Snowe to his side. His popularity ratings have been sinking for months. It is not the strength of United We Stand. While its officials say they have millions of members, they have stopped releasing the hard numbers, and many doubt their figures.
What does matter, in the gubernatorial, Congressional and legislative elections across the country this fall, is the potentially pivotal position of the mass of voters who supported Mr. Perot for President two years ago -- almost 20 million of them, 19 percent of the national total.
Once an army, they are now a rabble, without leaders and without marching orders, but still armed with their ballots.
In many states, including this one, where Ms. Snowe's Democratic opponent is Representative Thomas H. Andrews, they may well decide the outcome of important races. Maine was Ross Perot's best state in the 1992 Presidential election; he finished second, pushing George Bush into third, even though Mr. Bush has spent almost every summer of his life in the state.
Indeed, Mr. Perot carried three of the state's counties -- Waldo, Somerset and Piscataquis -- all in Ms. Snowe's Second Congressional District.
Senator William S. Cohen, a moderate Republican from Bangor, said he was persuaded that former Perot voters "will probably tilt the Senate race for or against Olympia." The desperate poverty of much of northern Maine, he said, "make Perot's ideas appealing to a lot of very angry people."
"They don't demonstrate or anything, because Maine is not that kind of place," Mr. Cohen said, "but they seethe with anger."
Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster who worked for Mr. Perot, said: "United We Stand is basically ineffectual in most places. Maine, Florida, parts of Texas, parts of Michigan, it might count for something. But what you have here is like an iceberg; what's interesting is the 85-90 percent below the surface, the people no longer personally loyal to Ross Perot, no longer active, if they ever were, in the organization, but still profoundly committed to his issues."
National surveys show that the former Perot voters are angry, frustrated, disillusioned with both major parties, still yearning for basic political change and still convinced that neither major party is likely to supply it.
Steve Bost, a former Democratic legislator who is now the full-time executive director of United We Stand in Maine, says Perot supporters "think that Clinton has fought for change all right, but in the wrong direction, and they think the Republicans have completely failed to offer any realistic alternatives to Clinton programs like Nafta and health care reform and the assault-weapons ban."
"They're watching and waiting," Mr. Bost said.
Although others disagree, Mr. Luntz is convinced that they will vote this fall. If he is right, and if they vote preponderantly for one party or the other, then Mr. Perot's boast a year and a half ago that the Perotistas would make or break many Congressional candidates may prove true, even though he will have very little to do with it.
Mr. Perot squandered much of his popularity in a television debate on Nafta with Vice President Al Gore. He was widely thought, even among his backers, to have looked ill-prepared and superficial.
A more recent gambit intended to keep him in the limelight also failed. Mr. Perot offered $1 million to the Republican Party, which it agreed to accept, for a television program attacking President Clinton's health care proposals. Anne Gavin, a spokeswoman for the Republican National Committee, said the networks refused to sell the large blocks of time that would have been required.
United We Stand is precluded, because of its status as a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization, from formally endorsing candidates or contributing to their campaigns. Instead, it holds forums at which candidates make their pitches and it sends out questionnaires intended to win commitments from candidates on issues like deficit reduction, Congressional pay cuts and changes in campaign spending laws.
 
'Haven't Heard a Peep'
 Politicians in Maine report little organized activity by the Perot forces. For example, Peter Hastings, a former legislator who lives in Fryeburg, a small town in the southwestern corner of the state, said: "I haven't heard a peep from them anywhere in rural Maine, which is where they should be strongest. That's where economic discontent is greatest."
Mr. Bost concedes it is not easy to measure the group's effect, but it informally backed candidates in special Congressional elections in Kentucky and Oklahoma this year, and both of them won.
In Texas, both Senate candidates are hotly pursuing the Perot vote. Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, a Republican, was strongly supported by the Perot forces in winning her seat in a special election last year, and her Democratic opponent, Richard Fisher, was active in the Perot campaign in 1992.
In Virginia, Oliver L. North, the Republican nominee, has been bidding for support from Perot voters in his "outsider" campaign for the Senate. In other states, including Connecticut, former Perot campaign officials have mounted campaigns of their own this year.
But Ben Coes, the executive director of the Maine Republican Party, who is himself a member of United We Stand, says the organization's best days are behind it.
"As an entity, it's really a paper tiger," Mr. Coes said. "But the voters are still out there, milling around, looking for candidates. They are going to vote for the candidates who can define themselves as anti-politics-as-usual, anti-Washington. They are going to vote this fall, of that I'm absolutely sure, but for whom?"
Among those in this state who hope to benefit are candidates who identify themselves with Maine's history of backing independents. One is Angus King, a former talk-show host on public television, who is running a serious campaign for governor, and James Longley, the Democratic nominee in the First Congressional District. His father, a former governor, was elected as an independent.
Douglas Hodgkins, a professor at Bates College who has studied the Perot phenomenon, sees Perot supporters as swelling the ranks of a whole new class of Maine voters prepared to vote for independents. That group, Mr. Hodgkins said, "is built into our political culture here, and with the powerful antipartisan mood in the nation, I think it will soon be duplicated nationwide -- we're just a little bit ahead."

HEADLINE: President Begins a Campaign to Avoid Losses for the Democratic Party in November

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BATH, Me., Sept. 5

 BODY:
President Clinton opened a campaign today to fend off heavy losses in the November elections with a Labor Day address that called attention to what the White House hopes will save Democrats: the creation of jobs.
At the huge shipyard here that is Maine's largest employer, Mr. Clinton pointed to the 4.1 million jobs by which the nation's economy has grown since he became President and called that a measure of a vitality that his critics have overlooked. 
 Speaking to hundreds of workers and their families, who huddled under umbrellas in a cold, driving rain, Mr. Clinton jabbed his finger repeatedly for emphasis as he declared that his Administration was "not promising you miracles, but promising you progress."
In traveling here from his vacation on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., Mr. Clinton was in part conducting a rescue mission for the Senate seat being relinquished by George J. Mitchell, the Democratic leader. Representative Thomas H. Andrews, the Democrat who hopes to succeed Mr. Mitchell, is trailing Representative Olympia J. Snowe in the polls, and on a podium heavy with Democratic candidates and labor leaders, Mr. Clinton sought to give Mr. Andrews's campaign a much-needed boost.
 
Seeking a Second Look
 But the thrust of the President's remarks looked ahead to what promises to be an autumn-long bid to shore up other foundering allies. Mr. Clinton hopes to persuade dissatisfied voters to take a second look at just how much he and his fellow Democrats have achieved.
In remarks drafted by the White House, Senator Mitchell began today's rally with a reminder that Mr. Clinton had confounded the Republican critics who warned last summer that his package of tax increases and spending cuts could cripple the economy. In fact, Mr. Mitchell declared, the budget deficit has declined, economic growth has soared and more jobs have been generated than under "the two previous Republican Presidents put together."
And Mr. Clinton himself called that steady job creation the signal product of what he portrayed as his battle "against some very, very powerful enemies of change."
"For the first time," he shouted, wearing a baseball cap and a machinists' union windbreaker in the downpour, "manufacturing jobs in America have increased now for eight month in a row." He said he would look beyond Labor Day by renewing his dedication "to keep this economic recovery going."
 
Visiting 6 States
 Mr. Clinton, of course, will not face a re-election fight for two more years. But the White House is already bracing for Republicans to score major midterm gains in the House and the Senate, and Mr. Clinton's visit here was the first stop on a heavy autumn schedule as he tries, despite his own dwindling popularity, to use whatever influence he can muster to prevent Democratic losses from becoming disastrous.
With some Democrats trying to distance themselves from Mr. Clinton, it is an open question whether he can make much difference. But after returning to Washington on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton is scheduled to travel to Louisiana, California, Illinois, Minnesota, Missouri and New York in the coming three weeks to raise money for his allies and campaign on their behalf. Before Mr. Clinton's speech today, some advisers of Mr. Andrews had expressed some anger about the President's visit and a possible scheuduling conflict, but Mr. Andrews was here with Mr. Clinton.
The shipyard he chose as his setting today, Bath Iron Works, has built vessels for the United States Navy for 110 years. Cutbacks in defense spending have reduced employment there to 9,000 from a peak of 12,500, but the yard has been kept alive by contracts to build Aegis guided-missile destroyers, a project that Mr. Clinton championed.
At the same time, the workers, who are members of the International Machinists' Union, and management have now settled on a contract intended to give the shipyard new flexibility as it begins to seek the nonmilitary business on which it will soon be forced to rely. Calling that step a model for the ones many other American enterprises must now take, Mr. Clinton suggested that the shipyard's efforts to complete its post-cold-war conversion should be seen as evidence that "we can build the economy on the strength of your example."
 
Finishing His Vacation
 Before delivering his speech this morning, Mr. Clinton toured the Aegis destroyer Laboon, which was named for a Vietnam War-era chaplain with the Marines and is still under construction. He then stood by as showers worsened while the shipyard's owners, labor leaders and Senator Mitchell took turns extolling him and his Administration.
By the time the President reached the microphone, the wind and rain kicked up by a northeaster that blew into the region overnight had turned so heavy that he was shouting to be heard. He spoke for only 10 minutes before telling the crowd that it was time to leave "or we're going to raise health care costs by staying in the rain too long."
By midafternoon, Mr. Clinton was back on Martha's Vineyard, hoping to take advantage of the last few days of a vacation that was busy through the weekend with golf, book shopping and a dinner Sunday night with Maurice Tempelsman, the late Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis' longtime companion. Mrs. Onassis' children, John F. Kennedy Jr. and Caroline Kennedy Schlossberg, joined the President for dinner at the house they inherited from their mother.
This afternoon, Mr. Clinton bade farewell to his 14-year-old daughter, Chelsea, who was returning to Washington to prepare for the first day of school, and he then celebrated that new independence by inviting his wife, Hillary, to join him on the golf course -- gusty wind, driving rain and all.
"This is good weather compared to what we play in at home," Mr. Clinton insisted as he teed off in a blue jogging suit to begin his sixth round in the last 10 days.

HEADLINE: Steel Mill Is Shadow Of What It Once Was

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FONTANA, Calif., Sept. 1

 BODY:
It was a symbol of America's industrial might, one of the world's biggest, most sophisticated, most expensive steel mills, employing thousands of workers and producing 2.3 million tons of high-grade carbon steel a year when it went on line in 1979.
But almost immediately, the 23-story-high Kaiser Steel Corporation plant, built at a cost of $287 million, became a symbol of wrenching changes in the economy, its roaring furnaces burdened by international competition, environmental regulations, labor disputes and the encroachments of corporate raiders. 
 Within three years it was closed. This desert town 45 miles east of Los Angeles, once home to citrus groves, then part of Southern California's industrial engine, slipped into the shuttered slowdown that has gripped the region.
Now, since early last year, the mill has been the scene of one last burst of activity: 300 Chinese workers from the Shaogang Steel Corporation in Beijing have been cutting, unbolting, dismantling, marking and crating the 55,000-ton mill and shipping the pieces to southern China for reassembly.
Amid sprays of sparks from cutting torches and the roar of giant cranes, each piece -- some nearly 200 tons -- was photographed and chalk-marked in Chinese characters to be matched with blueprints and painstakingly fitted back together.
 
$400 Million Moving Job
 Shaogang Steel, otherwise known as the Capital Iron and Steel Corporation, estimates the operation will cost $400 million. California Steel Industries Inc., which bought the plant, along with related steel-finishing operations, from Kaiser Steel in 1983 for $120 million, will be paid just $15 million for it. The main plant never resumed operation in part because of competition from low-cost Japanese and Korean steelmakers, who were accused of dumping steel at prices below cost in the Western United States.
"That was the only offer there was with people that had the money to pay for it," said Don Duffy, vice president for operations for California Steel. "The price they are paying us is a pittance by comparison with the total costs for them."
Nevertheless, the deal makes good sense for the Chinese, who do not have experience in building sophisticated steel mills, said Matt MacFadden, California Steel's vice president for human resources.
"Ten years ago this was the very best in the world," he said. "There haven't been that many dramatic improvements. Looking at this facility, knowing that it ran, knowing that the configuration worked together, knowing its heat, its tonnage per hour -- why try and reinvent the wheel?"
It has been a long ordeal for the Chinese workers, who have lived virtually sequestered in a motel in nearby San Bernardino with little contact with American society other than occasional visits to places like Disneyland and Chinatown. Their own cooks have trucked lunches to the work site.
As they began to arrive, the Chinese were the subject of protests by labor unions here, angry that the dismantling jobs did not go to American workers in the struggling economy of Southern California.
"These jobs don't belong to those Chinese guys," Joe Perez, executive secretary of the Building and Construction Trades Council in Riverside, said at the time. "They belong to us. We put this thing up, and we should be able to take it down. We want those 300 jobs."
But the protests soon died; the sale of the plant was contingent on employing Shaogang workers, so they could become intimately familiar with the structure they would rebuild.
 
Land to Be Swept Clean
 The deal with Shaogang includes a promise that the 76 acres on which the massive plant stood will be thoroughly cleared and leveled. The last components are being loaded onto railroad flatcars and onto 175-foot-long trucks so big they can only travel the highways after 10 P.M., headed for the Port of Los Angeles.
Two sea shipments have already arrived in China. The last will leave soon.
At the dismantled plant, the last members of the Chinese work crew, with their yellow plastic hard hats, are breaking its concrete foundations into chunks of no bigger than 10 square inches that will be used as fill.
Other members of the crew are already in China working on the early stages of the reassembly of the plant, which is known as the No. 2 Basic Oxygen Process and Caster Operation, or "BOP 2."
"It was like peeling a banana," Mr. MacFadden said. "First the outer structure came off. Then the equipment itself. The casters. The last thing left was the furnaces, huge ladles."
He looked around at the dusty site, where one crew, using a crane, was loading a section of steel frame onto a flatcar, another was knocking down the concrete base of the last of six 12-story elevator shafts and a third was pulling iron reinforcing bars from piles of broken concrete.
"This is what's left: massive rubble," Mr. MacFadden said. "They've gotten the ladles out of here, the bag house, the water-treatment facility. It's wild. I couldn't believe it would come down so quickly. We're to the point where everything's come down and nothing is up in its place yet."
Now that the plant is gone, he said, it is still not certain how the land will be used. There is talk of building a mini-mill to process scrap steel, or the area might be used as a transport and loading yard for the smaller steel-processing mills that surround it.
 
Big Appetite for Steel
 In China, where the economy grew by as much as 13 percent last year, the plant will add to a burgeoning industrial base and feed a voracious appetite for steel.
Richard S. Masco, project engineer for the Diversified Packaging Development Corporation, an American subcontractor for Shaogang Steel, said the Chinese could have the plant up and running in as little as two years.
"These are some of the finest engineering people I have ever run across," said Mr. Masco, who coordinated the work of crews of American subcontractors including heavy equipment operators, technical advisers and truck drivers. "They are fantastic, organized, everything in its place, everything in its order. The heavy lifts were all engineered to the point of exactly what angle the booms on the cranes were to be."
There was a note of poignancy in his words. It is the Chinese workers who now embody the energy, know-how and optimism that have been a part of this region's lore.
While California Steel thinks about what to do with the vacant land, Kaiser, which is now out of the steel business, has plans to build an auto raceway on an adjacent tract.
A decade and a half ago that outcome would have seemed impossible. The mill, built with more steel per square foot than any other building in the country, was meant to withstand the harshest onslaughts, including an earthquake up to 8.6 on the Richter scale of magnitude.
"This was meant to be here in perpetuity," Mr. MacFadden said. "When the earth ended, this thing was going to be here."

GRAPHIC: Photo: One of the last pieces of the modern steel mill in Fontana, Calif., that was sold to a Chinese company, awaiting shipment by sea to China. The Chinese dismantled the equipment and will reassemble it at home. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Gay Presence Leads Revival Of Declining Neighborhoods

BYLINE: By KAREN DE WITT, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
As cities around the country continue to shrink, urban planners say the neighborhoods molded by homosexuals in recent decades are taking on a new importance as bastions against further decay.
Although there are no authoritative statistics to track the migration of homosexuals to various urban neighborhoods, their presence -- and with it their economic power -- has become increasingly visible. 
 In addition to well-known areas like Greenwich Village in New York and the Castro district of San Francisco, predominantly gay neighborhoods have arisen in a dozen major cities over the last two decades, at once bolstering those cities' sagging tax bases, pumping thousands of dollars into the economy and sometimes making tired neighborhoods safer and more attractive to heterosexuals.
 
Rehabilitation and Stability
 "They've stabilized a lot of neighborhoods where they've stayed," said Dianne Welchko, a real estate agent in Chicago for 25 years.
Seattle's Capitol Hill section, for instance, has in the last 15 years seen an influx of gay men and women who have rehabilitated houses in the working-class area. The Montrose neighborhood in Houston, once a declining working-class section, is now the geographic center of a lively gay community. In Miami, there is South Beach, in Denver the Cheesman area, in Cincinnati Liberty Hill and Northside, and in St. Louis the South Grand Street area. There are also concentrations in smaller cities throughout the heartland.
"We surprise a lot of people," said Howard Harris, a technician who works with the Federal Aviation Administration in Oklahoma City. "And we're the buckle in the Bible Belt."
George Chauncey, a social historian at the University of Chicago, said data on gay neighborhoods had been elusive, largely because the Census Bureau did not identify them as such. But he said anecdotal indicators pointed to their growth. "The evidence comes from gay and lesbian voter drives, the proliferation of gay-oriented businesses and the addresses of people on gay mailing lists or political action committees," said Mr. Chauncey, the author of "Gay New York: Gender, Urban Culture and the Making of the Gay Male World, 1890-1940" (Basic Books, 1994).
William Frey, a demographer who studies minorities at the Population Studies Center at the University of Michigan, said, "These neighborhoods are like earlier ethnic enclaves."
Perhaps nowhere is the phenomenon of gay neighborhood as urban pillar truer than in the Dupont Circle section of Washington, a half-mile north of the White House. In the past 20 years it has been transformed from a rundown area of stores and apartments badly in need of renovation to one of the most vibrant and desirable places to live in the District.
 
'We Need a Realtor'
 Today, a lively mix of restaurants, nightclubs and businesses keeps the area awake long past the time the rest of the city has closed its eyes and rolled up the sidewalks.
Robert Bray, who travels around the country for "Fight the Right," a grass-roots project of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force, summed it up with a twist on a recent war cry of advocates for gay rights: "We're here. We need a realtor."
In 1970, commercial space in the area cost about $15 a square foot, according to figures from Washington Realty Group Inc., a large real estate agency. During the mid-1980's, at the height of the real estate boom, commercial space went for $25 a square foot. During the same period, a $350,000 town house in Dupont Circle would have increased in value to $750,000. And monthly rents for a one-bedroom apartment there rose to $750 from $400 during the period, the last for which figures are available.
"The gays get a lot of the credit for turning this area around," said City Councilman Jack Evans, whose district includes Dupont Circle. "You see the same thing happening in the 14th and U Street corridors, which are just now recovering from the urban disturbance of the 1960's."
 
Born of Crisis
 Sociologists and demographers alike say the concentration of homosexuals in core neighborhoods has grown in the last two decades out of gay political advocacy and the AIDS crisis, as well as from generally more tolerant attitudes toward homosexuals.
That visibility has translated into demarcated gay neighborhoods whose residents demand recognition. Today, dozens of large and midsize cities have gay pride events each year, and proposals to ban discrimination against homosexuals appear regularly as local ballot questions. New York City and Cincinnati, for example, have passed such legislation in the last five years and other cities have such legislation pending, like Oklahoma City, where the International Gay Bowling League and the International Gay Rodeo Association stage annual events.
Steve Collier, the executive director of the Oklahoma City Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the two events accounted for hotel bookings of several thousand rooms. Mark S. Schwartz, a member of the Oklahoma City Council whose ward has the most visible gay population in the city, said: "They bring in a lot of people, and that helps the local economy. Their deposits look the same, their taxes look the same."
The Rev. Kit Cherry, public relations associate of the Metropolitan Community Church in Los Angeles, said the influx had benefited urban areas as much as homosexuals. The church, whose members are mostly homosexual, has 270 congregations in the United States.
 
Political Involvement
 "We've offered cities faith in themselves," Ms. Cherry said. "We went into cities at a time when many people were abandoning them for the suburbs. We fixed up buildings that were falling down and got involved in local and regional politics to insure the well-being of cities."
The concentration and visibility of gay men and women in urban neighborhoods have not come without cost. Such distinct neighborhoods also attract hostile outsiders.
Stuart Michaels, a research sociologist at the University of Chicago, lives in Lakeview, an area that has been steadily gentrified into a gay enclave. "People looking for gay people to bash know where to come," he said. "If you're walking down the street, it's not unusual for some young kids in a car to yell, 'faggot' at a man or 'dyke' at a woman with short hair."
In addition, as buildings and housing in these areas are revived and property taxes increase, some lower-income residents are being driven out. And not everyone is enthusiastic about living in a neighborhood with a large homosexual population.
 
Some Feel Discomfort
 "There have been times when I've felt uncomfortable in my own neighborhood," said Pam Taylor, who works for the Voice of America and lives in Dupont Circle. Ms. Taylor said she was happy to hear from gay friends that the area was no longer the city's only gay neighborhood.
"There are places, particularly on 17th Street and P Street, where heterosexuals avoid walking down those streets because of what they feel is an in-your-face attitude by gays that they don't belong there," she said.
Because homosexuals in neighborhoods like these are so visible, experts say they give rise to inaccurate images of gay men and women. The wealth on display in upscale neighborhoods like Lakeview and Dupont Circle, where houses typically sell for $500,000 and up, promote the notion that all homosexuals are rich.
Two recent studies have challenged that stereotype. In June, Yankelovich Partners Inc. released a study showing that homosexual couples have about the same household incomes as heterosexual couples of similar educational levels. And a study by Lee Badgett, an assistant professor at the University of Maryland, that was released last month showed that homosexuals generally earned less than their heterosexual counterparts, because of discrimination.
The assumption that they earned more, Ms. Badgett said, was based on market research that had focused on white, high-income homosexuals who lived in neighborhoods like Dupont Circle. Ms. Badgett found that gay men nationwide earned 11 percent to 27 percent less than heterosexual men in comparable jobs. Lesbians earned 5 percent to 14 percent less than heterosexual women.
Other distinctions have emerged in studies of homosexual communities done by Bob Bailey, a professor at Rutgers University, for Strubco Inc., a marketing research firm in New York that compiles, categorizes and sells lists of people, and Voter News Service, which conducts exit polling for the television networks and The Associated Press. The study showed that gay men were likely to concentrate in densely populated, gentrified inner-city areas near bars, restaurants and social-service institutions, while lesbians were more likely to be dispersed and live in working-class neighborhoods.
In addition, homosexuals who are members of ethnic or racial minorities often settle in neighborhoods where their ethnic and racial groups are concentrated.
There is also a shift away from traditional gay and lesbian neighborhoods in New York City. For example, people who track homosexual-population trends say that many homosexuals are eschewing identifiable gay neighborhoods for more diverse areas, like Park Slope in Brooklyn and Jackson Heights in Queens.
"There is a portion of our community that wants to be separatist, to have a queer culture, but most of us want to be treated like everyone else," said Dick Dadey, executive director of Empire State Pride Agenda, an organization that lobbies for homosexual rights. "We want to be the neighbors next door, not the lesbian or gay couple next door."
That increasingly means that homosexuals are choosing to stay in the suburbs or in the small towns and midsized cities they come from, Mr. Dadey said. "As people exhibit individual acts of courage by coming out," he said, "we're finding out how diverse we are."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Many homosexuals are settling in enclaves in large and medium-size cities across the United States, renovating buildings, fostering businesses and generally breathing new life into urban neighborhoods like the Cheesman section of Denver, left, and the Montrose neighborhood in Houston. (F. Carter Smith for The York Times)

Companies
Wall Street's big question is not whether Kidder will be sold, but when and how. Wall Street is now convinced that General Electric will let its troubled brokerage firm go -- either by shutting it down, selling it or spinning it off to shareholders -- even as the company works to fix up the firm. News Analysis. [Page D1.]

Because of new paperwork and inspections, health and safety requirements, anti-dumping suits and rules of national origin, on top of incidents of violence in the border region, some businesses find themselves little better off than they were without the trade accord, a report for the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas says. HEADLINE: Postal Service Says Troubles In Chicago Are Being Resolved

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 5

 BODY:
In May, firefighters responding to a blaze in a suburban condominium found more than a ton of mail inside dating back nearly seven years.
The letter carrier who lived there, Robert K. Beverly, has since pleaded guilty to stealing and delaying mail and was recently sentenced to 21 months in prison. It was one in a string of cases since February that led to Chicago's postal service being rated the worst in the country, but officials there now say the things are getting better. 
 "You don't hear those egregious kinds of reports much anymore," said the postmaster, Rufus Jones, 46, who assumed leadership of the Chicago district in May. "We've made a conscious effort to identify and ostracize those kinds of individuals, ending their employment or disciplining them."
Mr. Jones said that 60 postal employees had been suspended or discharged since February, and that "52 percent of the top staff had been replaced."
The United States Attorney's office said six letter carriers had been successfully prosecuted on criminal charges since February, including Mr. Beverly.
Mr. Beverly, who asserted that his workload was overwhelming, was charged with delaying and stealing 3,396 pieces of first-class mail, 1,138 pieces of second-class mail and 22,439 pieces of bulk mail, as well as 4,364 compact discs from two music clubs, valued at $65,460, according to court records. It has cost the United States Postal Service $69,380 to reimburse advertisers and deliver the first- and second-class pieces that accumulated in his apartment.
Starting in February, Chicago residents heard one story after another about their post office, including ones of mail accumulating in delivery trucks of letter carriers who did not deliver and of mail being thrown in a viaduct and set afire.
The Chicago postal district, which handles nearly 10 million pieces of mail each business day, has 4,250 mail carriers. The local chapter of their union, the the National Association of Letter Carriers, refused to comment on the suggestion that their workload had been overwhelming. But a spokesman said that they were working with postal authorities to upgrade service.
 
Workers Are Retrained
 Mr. Jones said more than 2,000 postal employees of all ranks had been retrained since May, attending classes on the theoretical concepts of mail delivery as well as practical how-to classes on casing and delivering mail.
"In terms of worker productivity and service, there has clearly been an improvement recently," said Sam Peltzman, an economics professor at University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business who has studied the postal service.
Yet, Mr. Peltzman added that the post office needed to address larger questions of coping with emerging technologies as well as its future role. "It will be obsolete if present cost trends continue," he said. "Their rates have gone up over time in a business where their competitors' rates, particularly in the electronic media, have gone down."
But that is a far-off concern for Mr. Jones, who says, "We're not where we want to be by any stretch of the imagination, but I'm cautiously optimistic."

HEADLINE: Asian and European Markets Off in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Asian and European stock markets were mostly lower yesterday in trading thinned by closed exchanges in the United States. All financial markets in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday for the Labor Day holiday.
Stocks in Japan followed the dollar lower yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 244.65 points, or 1.18 percent, at 20,409.18. But traders in Tokyo said the drop was exaggerated by thin trading volume. In trading early today, the Nikkei had gained 28.41 points. The dollar fell to 99.05 yen in Tokyo, from 99.20 in New York on Friday, but it later rose back to 99.20 yen in trading in London. 
 Hong Kong stocks closed firmer but below the psychologically important 10,000 level after a sharp rally that drove the Hang Seng index of 33 stocks up to a peak of 10,064.86 ran out of steam. The Hang Seng closed up 60.48 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, at 9,962.04. In trading early today, the Hang Seng had fallen 63.80 points.
In London trading, the dollar slumped against the German mark, falling to 1.5545 marks, down from 1.5537 marks in New York trading on Friday.
In Frankfurt, German stocks ended sharply lower. The DAX index of 30 issues closed at the lowest level of the day, falling 30.19 points, to 2,174.52.
French stocks ended a choppy day as traders sought a new resistance level after the CAC index of 40 issues broke the psychologically important level of 2,000. Buying was depressed by a lower dollar and a sharp fall in bond futures. Interest rate cuts in Europe are now seen as less likely because of a strong growth outlook. The CAC index closed down 22.17, or 1.1 percent, at 1,998.20.
Swiss shares were flat, with the Swiss Market Index up 2.50 points, at 2,674.50. Dutch stocks closed lower. The Amsterdam EOE index of 25 leading issues closed down 1.17 points, at 417.17.
But the London Stock Exchange, Europe's largest, surged yesterday, brushing aside the gloom in other European markets. A late rally helped the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading issues close up 18.8 points at 3,241.5, after having been down more than 16 points earlier.
Oil prices, meanwhile, fell sharply in London yesterday as a strike by oil workers in Nigeria ended.
North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery fell 32 cents, to $16 a barrel, having dipped as low as $15.85 earlier in the session. Oil prices were last below $15.90 in May.
Prices fell on the news that thousands of Nigerian oil workers returned to work yesterday. Union officials said a two-month-old strike to protest the arrest of an opposition leader had ended.

HEADLINE: The Case for a Sale of Kidder

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
If General Electric is trying to sell NBC, can Kidder, Peabody, the company's troubled investment bank, be far behind?
Like the television network, Kidder is a G.E. acquisition that never really worked. And even as reports of G.E.'s efforts to shed NBC trickled out last week, the conventional wisdom on Wall Street was that G.E. would not or could not keep Kidder. There are at least four reasons: 
 *Kidder is not No. 1 or No. 2 in its industry, the cardinal criterion for any business in the G.E. pantheon in the era of John F. Welch Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive.
*As an investment, Kidder has been a dud.
*G.E. has proved beyond reasonable doubt that it cannot manage a Wall Street firm.
*Mr. Welch has a record of admitting defeat and cutting his losses.
 
 
Managers Forced Out
 Mr. Welch has spent a good deal of time trying to fix Kidder already. And his job has been tougher since April, when the firm said $350 million of the profits it thought it had earned were fictitious creations of Joseph Jett, Kidder's chief trader in government bonds. Mr. Welch promptly forced out Kidder's top management and sent two of his top lieutenants, Dennis Dammerman, G.E.'s chief financial officer, and Denis Nayden, G.E.'s top financial trouble-shooter, to steady the firm while taking a hard-nosed look at each of Kidder's businesses.
Kidder and G.E. would not comment on Kidder's track record or plans for the future, but a Kidder spokesman said Mr. Dammerman and Mr. Nayden expect to share the results of their examination -- and the broad outlines of an action plan -- with Kidder employees later this month.
Mr. Welch has also started to look for a new Kidder president with a track record in the securities business, something neither Kidder's former chief executive nor the new G.E. team had.
 
 
Preventing the Worst
 The intervention by G.E. -- with its triple-A credit rating, sterling reputation and skillful damage control -- has prevented the worst from happening. Kidder has not been spurned, as were Drexel Burnham Lambert and E. F. Hutton after their scandals, by the lenders who finance Kidder's huge inventory of securities.
Nor have large institutional investors suspended business with Kidder, as the California Public Employees Retirement System, the World Bank and others did with Salomon Brothers after its bond trading scandal in 1991.
But all of this activity may be only a prelude to casting Kidder adrift, either by shutting it down, selling it or spinning it off to G.E. shareholders, many analysts and Wall Street competitors say. It is not as if G.E., which bought Kidder in 1986 to gain a foothold in booming financial markets, was happy with the firm before the scandal. And now Mr. Welch, who does not brook failure, is clearly feeling even worse.
Kidder would not be an easy sell, what with the Jett scandal, the end of the bull market in bonds and a dearth of buyers with both the cash and the compelling need to own an investment bank. "This fiasco with Jett doesn't make it a very salable property right now," said Kent A. Newcomb, a securities analyst at A. G. Edwards.
The investment bank would be a big bite to swallow for even the biggest American commercial banks. And the European banks that want to deepen their involvement in United States capital markets have had some discouraging experiences with previous acquisitions.
So it appears that for the time being, G.E. has little choice but to hold onto Kidder while it tries to fix it up -- to revive confidence in management and to show that Kidder can make money. G.E. faces a situation similar to that of American Express a few years ago, when that company decided to part with Shearson Lehman Hutton after a long but lackluster association. It took several years and hundreds of millions of dollars in cash infusions before American Express was able to get rid of the brokerage firm.
"None of the options seem particularly attractive," said Guy Moszkowski, a securities analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein.
For all the attention G.E. is lavishing on Kidder, however, it is still likely the unit will go.
 
 
The Business
Not Big Enough, And Slipping
 Kidder, with its $60 billion in assets, $5 billion in revenues and about 5,000 employees, is the nation's 12th-biggest securities firm, based on assets. But its main claim to fame is its astonishing dominance of the market for mortgage-backed securities. That business has accounted for more than two-thirds of Kidder's profits in recent years, people at the firm say. But it has shrunk quickly this year as rising interest rates choked off new issues, which were down nearly 30 percent through August, compared with the first eight months of 1993.
And, more recently, Kidder seems to be having trouble getting the business. According to the Securities Data Company, Kidder was the lead manager on just seven new mortgage bond deals in August, helping to raise $1.25 billion, compared with nine deals worth $6.3 billion a year earlier.
While the flow of talent from Kidder has been a trickle rather than a waterfall, there are signs of edginess. Some of Kidder's most productive brokers -- those who cater to clients with deep pockets -- have left.
And traders in Kidder's huge fixed-income operation are said to be spending a lot of time on the phone with friends at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, First Boston, Union Bank of Switzerland and other concerns that have hired Kidder people in the past.
The most valuable players are not likely to make their exits yet, because that might cost them big year-end bonuses. "By the end of this year, if people are not treated as they think they should be, that would be a good time for the trickle to become a waterfall," said a recruiter who spoke on condition of anonymity. And much will depend on G.E.'s ability to hire executives who inspire confidence, including the new president Mr. Welch is looking for.
 
Lackluster Profits
A Weak Return On G.E.'s Money
 Absent the Jett dealings, which Kidder said had caused it to report $350 million in phantom pretax profits over 28 months, the company has returned only $270 million on G.E.'s total investment of $1.3 billion since 1986. (The investment includes the $600 million purchase price plus capital infusions of $500 million or so in the late 1980's and early 1990's plus a $200 million infusion in April.)
Kidder's average profit margin in the last eight years, in the low single digits, has not only paled beside that expected from other G.E. businesses -- GE Capital's profit margin has been in the double digits for years -- but has also looked sickly beside those of other Wall Street firms. And in 1993, a blockbuster year in which profits of the top 11 firms spurted 20 percent, Kidder's earnings fell 6 percent.
If the investment bank could not soar in the biggest bull market of the decade, prospects look distinctly unappetizing during bleaker times on Wall Street. Kidder has been losing money this year as interest rates have climbed and the bond market has soured. Not counting Mr. Jett, Kidder lost $40 million in the first six months of 1994, G.E. said, making it all the less likely that Kidder would achieve the break-even performance that G.E. predicted in June for the final two quarters of 1994.
 
 
The Management
The Perils Of a Rich Parent
 G.E. proved it was not adept at managing a Wall Street firm in several ways. For starters, there was Mr. Welch's choice of Michael A. Carpenter, a management consultant from headquarters with no experience on Wall Street, who ran Kidder for five years until he was dismissed in June after the Jett scandal.
Mr. Carpenter was able to stanch the defections from Kidder, control costs and oversee the firm's leap into a mortgage powerhouse. But he was not able to transform Kidder the way new management transformed other second-tier firms like Smith Barney and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
And Mr. Carpenter headed a management team that was sharply criticized for failing to supervise Mr. Jett.
Just steadying the organization is proving to be difficult, even with G.E.'s enormous resources. Kidder's interim leaders, Mr. Dammerman and Mr. Nayden, have spent most of their time either with the regulators and the United States Attorney who are investigating the Jett scandal, or with key Kidder clients and creditors.
"They aren't close to stabilizing the situation," said one executive close to Kidder. "They may have stabilized it in terms of controls and investigation, but I'm sure they are not even close to having a lock on key people."
The thought has occurred to many analysts that G.E. may have inadvertently contributed to Kidder's management problems. "Maybe it's the business of people having a big parent with lots of money," said Perrin H. Long, a securities analyst at First of Michigan. "Maybe that breeds a feeling of, 'I don't worry too much; I'll let G.E. worry about it.' "
 
The Chairman
Not Sentimental About Laggards
 Mr. Welch, the G.E. chairman, has no tolerance for businesses that do not perform up to his expectations. In the last decade, he has shed nearly two dozen major G.E. businesses that were worth $11 billion and that employed tens of thousands of workers.
The businesses that he shut or sold included some that he was, for a time, enamored of, including a large factory-automation business. And now he is apparently thinking of getting rid of NBC, another business he was enthusiastic about when he bought it in 1986.
Of course, Mr. Welch says that G.E. thinks Kidder still has a great franchise and that G.E. has no intention of abandoning the firm.
But as a potential seller who has no interest in driving down the value of his property, Mr. Welch's assurances have all the persuasiveness of a finance minister's promise, on the eve of a devaluation, that he will never, ever debase the currency.

HEADLINE: Boeing Expects 737 Orders

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The Boeing Company announced plans today for a longer version of its 737 jets and said it had obtained commitments from four customers who wanted 40 of the jets at a total price of nearly $2 billion.
Boeing also announced today -- the opening day of the 1994 international air show here -- that it had four firm orders for its 767-300ER jetliners. Those planes, valued at $384 million each, will be leased to KLM Royal Dutch Airlines by the International Lease Finance Corporation. 
 The new version of the 737, called the Boeing 737-800, will be 9 feet, 2 inches longer than the 737-400 and able to carry 164 to 189 passengers. The first deliveries are expected in 1998, the company said.
Boeing, based in Seattle, declined to disclose the names of the expected customers for the 737's, saying it had yet to enter into contracts.
One customer, it said, also plans to buy eight 737-700's, which would bring the total package to about $2 billion. Those jets can be configured for as many as 144 seats.
Last year Boeing announced that Southwest Airlines would take delivery of the first 737-700 in 1997.
At the air show, Ron Woodard, president of the Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said, "We expect to see airplane orders and deliveries recover during the second half of the 1990's."

HEADLINE: Labor Day: When Summer Wanes and the Race for Governor Begins to Heat Up

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

 BODY:
In raucous parades in Rochester and Crown Heights, on blustery boardwalks in the Rockaways, and in 30-second attack ads aired from Long Island to Buffalo, New York's gubernatorial candidates yesterday kicked off the traditional start to the fall campaign that this year will determine whether Mario M. Cuomo is written into the state's political lore for winning a fourth term.
Within nine weeks, as New York voters resolve whether to keep or dump Mr. Cuomo, a one-time Democratic Presidential aspirant, they could also set the state on the path toward radical changes in its policies on taxation, welfare and the death penalty. In the process, they may send a message, along with voters in California, Texas, Florida and other large states, about the health of President Clinton's coalition and his own prospects for re-election in 1996. 
 But as Labor Day marked the fading of the summer campaign, New York's gubernatorial contest remained a race that has yet to take full form.
First of all, both parties and their leading candidates -- Mr. Cuomo for the Democrats, State Senator George E. Pataki for the Republicans -- face primaries on Sept. 13. But more importantly, perhaps, is the view held by leaders of both parties that Mr. Pataki has not used the last two months to establish his political persona.
Despite Mr. Cuomo's vulnerabilities, Democratic and Republican strategists agree that the Republicans cannot simply run against him without offering a credible alternative, both in a candidate and a platform. And some Republicans are concerned, and Democrats are cautiously optimistic, that nine weeks may not be long enough for the Republicans to do that.
 
A Landmark Date
 "I think he is up to the task of running the state," Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Kinderhook Republican, said of Mr. Pataki, his legislative colleague. "But I don't think he has yet made a convincing case of that."
In reality, the campaign has been chugging along for nearly a year. But political strategists use Labor Day as a landmark date when voters return from vacations and begin to concentrate on the choices that loom two months down the road. In addition to the gubernatorial race, New Yorkers face decisions about other statewide offices, the Legislature, the House of Representatives and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
The acceleration of political energy was palpable yesterday, at least partly because candidates knew that the primaries are only a week away and that campaigning will be compressed by the Rosh ha-Shanah holiday.
While the candidates walked beaches and streets, the real work of their campaigns was being waged on the airwaves, where Mr. Cuomo, Mr. Pataki and Richard M. Rosenbaum, another Republican candidate, all have placed aggressive new television commercials that take on at least one opponent. In some television markets, the ads appeared back-to-back during evening newscasts, potentially leaving viewers confused about who was assailing whom.
Although they have not yet won their primaries, both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki are neck-and-neck in some polls and are focusing on each other in their advertising. Mr. Cuomo's new commercial, his first to mention Mr. Pataki by name, accuses Mr. Pataki of saying he supports a ban on assault weapons while voting against it in the Senate. In his ad, Mr. Pataki blames Mr. Cuomo for raising taxes and vetoing the death penalty.
 
Out Among the Voters
 Mr. Rosenbaum, a former state Republican chairman who is considered a long-shot to defeat Mr. Pataki in next week's primary, was preparing to begin a $400,000 statewide advertising campaign today that will depict both Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki as Albany dealmakers.
At a Labor Day parade in Mr. Rosenbaum's hometown of Rochester yesterday, and in Brooklyn, where he campaigned on Saturday, there was evidence that previous ads had helped New Yorkers recognize the candidate, whose gravelly bulldog voice is as distinctive as his hairless head.
"Hey, the party's over," Tioga Cherry, a Rochester bus driver, yelled at Mr. Rosenbaum, echoing the slogan of a Rosenbaum ad about forcing delinquent fathers to pay child support.
Mr. Pataki's campaign has largely ignored Mr. Rosenbaum, and his aides have publicly predicted an overwhelming victory in next Tuesday's primary. Indeed, Mr. Pataki originally planned to take the Labor Day weekend off, feeling it would be his last chance to rest and spend time with his wife, Elizabeth, and their four children.
He changed plans after deciding he did not want to convey any signs of complacency, and attended a volunteer fire department parade in Broad Channel, Queens, before searching for votes at a cabana club in the Rockaways.
 
The Coats Are Coming Off
 Mr. Pataki spent most of the summer raising money for the fall, quite successfully. But rather than using his time and resources to detail his views, he has made vague promises about cutting taxes and spending and imposing welfare restrictions in the mold of his gubernatorial role models, William Weld of Massachusetts and Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey. He also says he will sign legislation approving the death penalty.
"We don't want to lay out a plan that sounds good politically but that you can't realistically adopt next year," Mr. Pataki said yesterday, discussing tax cuts. "What we are going to tell the people this fall is exactly what we are going to do next January, very much like Governor Whitman, who told the people what she was going to do and is doing it."
Perhaps the most enthusiasm of the day was shown by the 62-year-old Mr. Cuomo, a 12-year incumbent who would break Nelson A. Rockefeller's modern record for longevity by completing a fourth term. (Only George Clinton, New York's first Governor, served longer.)
Marching in the West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn, Mr. Cuomo suddenly picked up the pace and shed his blue coat, walking at a speed that left other politicians behind. As Mr. Cuomo raced ahead, Reginald H. Bowman, a candidate for Assembly in Brooklyn, shouted into a portable microphone: "That's right, Mario is running for his life."
Mr. Cuomo's aides say he has been energized by his acceptance of the Republican threat, both to his personal legacy and, in his mind, to the state. He was quoted recently as saying in an editorial board meeting that New York could lose its "humanism" and "civility" if he is not re-elected.
 
Increasing Criticism
 In an interview after leaving the parade, Mr. Cuomo stepped up his criticism of the Pataki campaign's characterization of his record.
"I'm not going to allow them to do what they have done for six months, which is talk about Cuomo, lie about Cuomo and not tell the truth about the state," he said.
Mr. Cuomo said his campaign would begin to expose Mr. Pataki's record, beginning with the assault weapons ad. "The test is not so much, Is it negative?" he said of his advertisements. "Is it honest? Is it useful? Is it relevant? Most of all, is it honest? Are you telling the truth? These people say we're No. 1 in job losses. It's not true." (In fact, Federal statistics show that New York ranks second in job losses since July 1990, when the national recession began).
Mr. Cuomo continued: "They tell you they are going to give you a huge new tax cut. I'm the only person in the race that said we'd give you a tax cut and did it. Nobody else ever did it. I did it. When my opponent was mayor, his taxes went up 20 percent. So we'll simply tell the truth."
But in fact, Mr. Pataki was responsible for tax increases of only 8.4 percent during the three years he served as Mayor of Peekskill in northern Westchester County, according to Peekskill officials. In the past, the Cuomo campaign has tried to saddle him with responsibility for a 21 percent increase that took effect in his first year but had been enacted the previous year.
Asked about Mr. Cuomo's use of the higher figure yesterday, Mr. Cuomo's spokesman, Joel R. Beneson, said, "The Governor was mistaken. And unlike them, when we're mistaken we clarify it immediately."

HEADLINE: Washington Public Schools Set to Open One Week Late

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The District of Columbia decided today to delay the start of school by five days, until Sept. 12, after a judge turned down a stopgap plan to put fire patrols in the hallways at dozens of schools that do not meet fire codes.
Most of the District's schools are in compliance with the codes, but education officials have said it would be too confusing to keep some schools closed while opening others as scheduled on Wednesday. The school board ordered the officials to draw up plans to accommodate the students whose schools will remain closed next Monday. 
 For a few weeks, the school system has been struggling to complete work ordered in June by Judge Kaye K. Christian of District of Columbia Superior Court. She told officials they had until Aug. 30 to correct thousands of fire code violations in the city's 166 school buildings, where more than 80,000 students attend classes. The city had been sued by a group of parents over the violations.
Although the delay in opening the schools is, on its face, a matter of safety, education officials including Superintendent Franklin L. Smith said the real problem was the chronic underfinancing of the school system in the nation's capital, which is beset with budget problems.
With a backlog of $500 million in needed repairs and an annual capital budget of less than $15 million, the schools continue to deteriorate and their perennial safety problems are swept under an ever-more-ragged carpet.
 
Time of Political Upheaval
 In this sense, the travails of the schools here resemble those in New York City, where schools opened 11 days late last year because of concerns over exposing students to asbestos.
The problems of the local schools also come at a time of political upheaval in the city, with a Democratic mayoral primary race considered too close to call. The incumbent Mayor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, has fallen well back in the polls behind her two opponents, John Ray, a City Councilman who is critical of her management of the city, and former Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who left office after being convicted on drug charges.
Amid confusion over when particular schools would open, fire officials and repair crews worked through the holiday weekend to bring as many schools as possible into compliance, but about 50 schools have still not be cleared for opening by the judge.
And officials acknowledged that some schools would not be ready for weeks. Some schools lack working fire alarms or fire doors, or have other serious violations that are costly and time consuming to correct.
Judge Christian continued to receive reports from fire officials who were inspecting the schools, and in the next few days, she will grant or deny their requests for individual schools to open.
To avoid a citywide delay in opening school, lawyers for the city had proposed a plan endorsed by the city's fire marshal in which schools with violations of the fire code could open, as long as an adult trained to watch for and report fires was on duty at all times.
But Judge Christian rejected that proposal, calling it mealy-mouthed. To approve the plan, she said, would be "to ignore everything the court heard throughout six days of trial."
 
Plan Accepted by Parents
 The lawyers for parents who won the court case calling for the city to bring all the schools into compliance said they would reluctantly accept such a plan, viewing it as a temporary expedient that would balance the needs for safety against those for education.
But Judge Christian, in a hearing this morning, disagreed. She said the law made no such provision for what she considered a waiver of the fire codes, and she insisted that each school pass inspection before opening.
The plaintiffs, in effect, got more than they bargained for today from the judge, who over the course of the legal proceedings has been sternly laying down the law like a tough principal dealing with unruly adolescents.
"The judge has said that 100 schools could open, and as far as we are concerned, that's fine with us," said Alfred M. Mamlet, a lawyer for the parents' group. He said the group would not support any effort to teach classes in alternative locations, like churches, because they also might not meet fire safety standards.
One parent at the hearing this morning, J. E. McNeil, a self-employed single mother who was not a party to the lawsuit, said that the plaintiffs had run amok and that she was distressed to find that her son's school would not open even though it had been found in compliance with fire rules.
She said school board members who urged parents to share child-care duties for a few days did not understand the economic pressures on parents, or the risks to students of staying home from school in a city that is plagued with violent crime.
"Some parent, somewhere, is going to have to stay home and take care of my child -- probably me," she said. "I am concerned for all the children who see school as a safe zone."

HEADLINE: Entrepreneurial Company Defies Singapore Model

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
Sim Wong Hoo, white-shirted, bespectacled and voluble, is something of a rare species in this corporate city-state -- he is a high-tech entrepreneur.
"I guess I stick out like a sore thumb," laughed Mr. Sim, who at the age of 39 pilots a billion-dollar company, Creative Technology Ltd. His company has brought music to the personal computers of America and the world in the form of the Sound Blaster, a stereo soundboard that is inserted in the computers. 
 Visitors to Singapore, and many American multinational companies who base their regional headquarters here, speak of its immaculate streets, manicured lawns and very modest crime problem, thanks to a culture of hard work and obedience and the liberal use of the cane for petty offenders.
Singapore, though, has been inhospitable to individualism -- that indispensable ingredient of entrepreneurial culture. The intrusive hand of government -- almost all major companies are run by, or have major shares owned by, the state -- has made Singapore a particular economic success story, yet has all but squashed innovative, start-up companies.
"Singapore can be a tough environment for entrepreneurship," Mr. Sim said, "but if you can get by the tough part, you become very tough."
The climate is so tough, in fact, that when he decided to take his explosively growing company public two years ago, he had to turn to the Nasdaq market in New York, because the stock exchange in Singapore seemed unprepared to cope with what he was trying to do. Not until two months ago, when Creative Technology had achieved a market capitalization of more than $1.6 billion, did he finally list the company in Singapore.
"It's like a son coming home," Ngo Get Ping, a senior vice president at Nomura Securities, said of the company's listing here.
Mr. Sim is struggling to use his success to confront other challenges like increased competition, falling profit margins and swiftly advancing technology. His products still sell well, but he acknowledges it is still uncertain where the next frontier and the next big profits lie.
Some analysts also wonder.
"They took a Singapore company and made it a billion-dollar company," said Kevin Scully, the research director at Schroder Securities here. "But the question is: How do you find another Sound Blaster? It is very hard to make the next quantum leap."
The story of Creative Technology, founded in 1981, shows that while missteps and setbacks have been frequent, Mr. Sim's unwillingness to concede defeat and a knack for nimble shifts in strategy and product development have propelled him and his company forward.
"We knew from the beginning that we wanted to have our own technology," explained Mr. Sim, who earned an associate degree in engineering from a local college. "We wanted to have our own products. But it is very hard in Singapore because the Singapore market just doesn't support it."
His first product was a computer. "I looked at the PC and said it was dumb," he recalled. "I said computers should talk. Computers should play music.
He continued: "I believe in sound. I believe in music. But in the early days, the technology was not there."
 
Cheap and Plentiful Competition
 That first personal computer, called the Cubic CT, was aimed solidly at the Singapore market, and it almost sank him. Swarming around were cheaper PC clones being manufactured in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore.
"All this originality, and people just did not appreciate it," Mr. Sim said. "This was just not the business to be in despite all the effort we put into it." He was left with a handful of engineers and a few technicians, and in 1986, the future looked bleak.
Mr. Sim and his engineers looked at the Cubic CT and began playing around with the machine's sound board. "I took the thing out and made it into a very simple, low-cost music board, which we heavily protected," he said. "And it turned out to be good business because nobody had it."
He took the board to a computer exhibit in the United States that year, and the rest was history. "The money we made on a few hundred boards," he said, "was the equivalent to the money we made on the PC."
The next year, Mr. Sim moved to the United States and badgered manufacturers of games to incorporate his music standard into their games. Within a few years, his sound card, the Sound Blaster, emerged as the industry standard for sound in personal computer software around the world. A company was born.
"Today, we just totally dominate the market," he said. An American competitor, Media Vision Technology, has filed for bankruptcy protection, and Creative Technology is involved in litigation against another Singapore company, Aztech Systems Ltd., contending patent infringements.
On the fourth and seventh floor of a plain, concrete building in a Government-sponsored manufacturing zone, Mr. Sim's company churns out about 600,000 sound cards a month. The most basic card sells for less than $50 in the United States.
About 65 percent of the market in sound boards is in the United States, with the rest evenly split between Europe and Asia.
"Margins on the Sound Blaster are coming down," he said. "It's becoming a commodity, but we are over 60 percent of the market."
 
Strong Results Taper Off
 The company's annual results, released last month, for the fiscal year that ended in June, showed a surge in profit to $97.9 million from $44.8 million on sales of $657.9 million. But fourth-quarter results reflected the decline in margins, with profit down nearly 12 percent over the fourth quarter of the preceding year.
Mr. Scully of Schroder said he was impressed by the earnings report, but he added: "The strong earnings growth will be difficult to sustain. They are in a mature product cycle. The product they are making is a mass commodity and there is price erosion, about 5 percent per quarter."
Now, as Mr. Sim confronts the question of where to go next, he says, "The next frontier is to merge the telephone function together with the sound function."
He offered an example in which someone stuck in a traffic jam could call the computer at home, ask it to read any electronic mail and have it record and dispatch the reply.
Mr. Sim said the technology to do so was available and coming down in cost. "We're less than a year away," he said. "The pieces are all over the place. You just have to glue them together."
Creative Technology already offers a system for conferences between personal computers. Using a small video camera mounted atop a monitor, two users can see one another, talk and work on a single, shared spreadsheet together, all over a single telephone line.
But another product used to edit full-motion video, called Video Blaster, has failed to generate much excitement in the marketplace. Of Creative Technology's 3,000 employees, 400 are engaged in research and development.
"We're very good at putting a lot of things together, integrating a lot of technology," Mr. Sim said. "We have built the research and development to do this. That's how we succeed."
