HEADLINE: Developers Seek Profits in Polluted Land

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ELIZABETH, N.J.

 BODY:
If the 166-acre tract of scraggly, garbage-strewn undergrowth here seems an unlikely place for a new shopping mall, consider what lies beneath its scarred topsoil. For decades, almost all of this city's trash was buried here.
In the parlance of environmentalists, the site is a brown field -- something less polluted than a toxic waste dump, but still needing more extensive cleanup than the undeveloped greenery of the nation's suburbs and rural areas. 
 That is just what Peter Aagaard, a Danish builder who specializes in the reuse of polluted land, was looking for when he paid $10 million for the property in 1992. Now, as he prepares to clean it up and build a factory outlet mall with 200 stores and 7,300 parking spaces, he has joined a broad effort by planners and government officials to steer development to abandoned, polluted urban land and to loosen government regulations that are defended fervently by environmentalists.
 
Like a Walk in the Park
 "This site really isn't that complicated," said Mr. Aagaard (pronounced AAY-gard), who has built large projects on polluted industrial sites in Denmark and Spain but never before in this country. In Europe, where undeveloped land is scarce, builders must remove centuries of garbage and industrial residue. Cleaning up a landfill like this one would be a walk in the park, he said.
For developers like Mr. Aagaard -- and the Ikea company, which four years ago built a store here atop a landfill -- the attraction is simple. Because American banks are often unwilling to lend money to develop such land, the prices are relatively cheap.
Mr. Aagaard, 37, says his total costs of acquisition and cleanup will be just under $200,000 an acre, which he said was about half what developers would expect to pay for a large plot of unpolluted, ready-to-use land next to a busy highway. And in his case, the highway happens to be the New Jersey Turnpike, one of the busiest in the nation.
"There are lots of good New Jersey locations that could be redeveloped," said Mr. Aagaard, who is now looking for another polluted site in the state. "Unfortunately, most people won't take the risk."
His project has attracted unusual interest across the region, where developers, fearing the high cost of environmental cleanup, have bypassed places like Elizabeth, and where a long history of industrial expansion and decline has created the nation's largest concentration of abandoned brown-field sites.
But the interest is not confined to partly polluted areas like the Elizabeth landfill. New Jersey and several other states have already scaled back some of their regulations for environmental cleanup, and Congress is considering broad changes in the Federal Superfund regulations for the cleanup of the nation's most severely polluted sites, changes that might make even them more attractive for reuse.
 
Changes in Store for Superfund
 When it was enacted in 1980, the Superfund law required that severely polluted land covered by the legislation be cleaned up to a standard suitable for housing, playgrounds and other uses that would bring people in close contact with the soil. Some officials in Congress and large urban areas have complained that those standards sacrificed potential redevelopment of troubled industrial areas.
The Superfund rules will expire this year, and, judging from the bills before Congress, the new version of the law is likely to bring big changes. One provision being considered would create different cleanup standards for sites that are not to be used for housing, but rather for commercial developments like warehouses, factories or shopping malls.
Another provision would reduce the potential liability of banks that agree to finance the development of less polluted sites like the landfill here. Under current law, banks that are forced to foreclose on a developer of a polluted site could end up being held liable for the cleanup.
"The pendulum has swung too far in the direction of protection from theoretically harmful environmental affects," said H. Claude Shostal, president of the Regional Plan Association, which studies land-use issues in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. "We have created enormous barriers to redevelopment that need to be lowered."
The association has spent three years putting together an inventory of brown sites in Union County, which includes Elizabeth, and is helping Mr. Aagaard with the environmental review for his project. The group has found 185 sites, totaling 2,500 acres, that it says could be reclaimed.
 
'Polluters off the Hook'
 But some environmentalists say that reducing the level of environmental regulation, either through the Superfund law or state rules, would be a mistake.
"The argument that you can apply laxer cleanup standards for industrial users is simply a way to let polluters off the hook," said Steven A. Romalewsky, toxic prevention coordinator for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a private monitor of government.
"If the polluters don't pay, taxpayers will," he added.
Others maintain that it is precisely because brown sites tend to be concentrated in poor areas, like Union County, that tough environmental safeguards are necessary.
 
In Wake of Love Canal
 "These sites are often next to residential areas that are occupied by people of color, and it is not going to be the government or industry that lives there in the future," said Vernice D. Miller, an environmentalist with the Natural Resources Defense Council.
No one denies that Federal and state regulations on environmental cleanup, most imposed over the last 15 years in the wake of the Love Canal contamination near Buffalo, have discouraged redevelopment of partly polluted brown-field land, especially in and around New York City.
"Banks take the position that they don't want to get involved," said Hugh O'Neill, a New York City environmental consultant who, in a study of industrial land in South Brooklyn earlier this year, found 20 abandoned brown-field sites along the Gowanus Canal, in Red Hook and in Sunset Park, most of which he said could be redeveloped.
Except in Union County, there is no complete list of the region's brown-field sites. But the Superfund program, which deals with the nation's worst hazardous waste sites, offers one measure of the region's legacy of industrial pollution.
 
New Jersey Has the Most
 Of the 1,232 sites on the National Priority List to be cleaned up under the Superfund program, New Jersey has the most -- 108 or nearly 9 percent of the total. New York, with 85 sites, ranks fourth, behind Pennsylvania and California. Connecticut, with 16 sites on the list, is among the 10 states with the fewest priority sites.
The Superfund list does not include the brown fields, but urban planners say areas with the highest concentration of toxic waste sites also tend to have many abandoned brown fields.
Several measures have been taken over the last year by cities and states in the region to identify and reclaim the brown-field sites. In late August, the city of Bridgeport was given a $200,000 grant from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to identity sites, determine how much pollution they contain and promote them to private developers.
The Federal grant came a year after Connecticut's Department of Environment Protection was authorized to raise $25 million through the sale of bonds to clean up polluted sites across the state. Unlike previous state cleanup programs, the new "Urban Site Remediation Program" is intended to speed the cleanup of urban property needed for economic development, not necessarily the most polluted.
 
Bergen County Has Most
 In New York State, private companies have announced plans this year to clean up an abandoned incinerator site in New Rochelle, a site polluted by oil in Syracuse and the sites of 33 idle coal-gas plants across the state.
And in New Jersey, the state's Department of Environmental Protection on Wednesday released a detailed list of 6,000 contaminated sites across the state. Although it said the list did not include every suspected area of pollution, it said the highest number of sites were in Bergen County, with 591 sites, and Middlesex County, with 541 sites.
A 1993 New Jersey law, the Industrial Sites Recovery Act, has provided state grants and loans for cleanup, changed state rules to allow different cleanup standards for housing, commercial and industrial uses and provided other incentives for brown-field development.
More than anywhere else in the region, Elizabeth has emerged as a laboratory for brown-field projects.
The first began in 1980, when officials here decided there was no hope of attracting private developers to a polluted 18-acre stretch of waterfront on the Arthur Kill, overlooking Staten Island.
So, with environmental grants from the state, the city began a 10-year effort to remove oil, metal and other pollutants from under the ground and and transform the site into a park, now called Veterans Memorial Waterfront Park, with manicured lawns, walkways and a marina.
"This site did not have a market," said J. Christian Bollwage, Elizabeth's Mayor, who said $6 million had been spent on the project. "The only thing that made sense was reclaiming it as open space."
The next project came in 1988, when, after years of effort, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey found a private company to develop an an abandoned landfill site the Port Authority owned here next to the New Jersey Turnpike.
 
Ikea Steps Into Breach
 The company, Ikea USA Inc., the Swedish chain of furniture and household goods stores, opened a new store on the site in 1990. Although the Port Authority had already paid for an extensive cleanup of the site before it tried to sell it, officials said no American company could obtain bank financing to buy it.
"Invariably, when we would find prospective buyers, they would go to their banks and tell us thanks, but no thanks," said Myron Ronis, a Port Authority manager who negotiated the sale to Ikea (pronounced eye-KEY-ah).
Then, in 1992, came Mr. Aagaard, who purchased his Elizabeth tract from a British company. Like Ikea, he said, he plans to develop it without American bank financing, and will spend $300 million, including $33 million to buy and clean up the site.
Linda P. Morgan, director of the Regional Plan Association's New Jersey Office, who was in charge of its Union County study, said some of the county's other brown sites pose problems for developers, including difficult highway access, but she said the sites could be cleaned up for less than builders assumed.
 
Surprise at U.S. Red Tape
 Mr. Aagaard said Regional Plan's help did much to speed the approvals necessary for cleaning up his site and building his mall, which he said he expects to open in early 1997. Nonetheless, he said, he was surprised by the amount of American red tape.
"When I met with agencies, there might be 25 people at the table, including me and two or three others I brought along," he said. "Isn't that a waste of taxpayers' money?"
Still, Mr. Aagaard, who moved with his wife and three children to Princeton, said he planned to spend at least two more years in New Jersey and would seek another large project on one of the state's polluted sites.
"I see all this land as an opportunity," he said.

HEADLINE: New Limits Are Seen to Freer Trade

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 31

 BODY:
In El Paso and across the Mexican border in Juarez, they call it the milk war. As soon as the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect on Jan. 1, American milk, freed from Mexican licensing requirements, flooded across the Rio Grande. It was competitive in price, and unlike most Mexican milk, it was date-stamped for freshness.
Angry dairymen in the Mexican state of Chihuahua won a 9 percent tax on milk imports in the border region. But 9 percent proved too small to deter local consumers. Now the Mexican milk producers, complaining that health rules in the United States block them from sending their milk across the border, are pushing to require stores selling American milk to sell theirs, too.
 
Dispute Becomes Nastier
 In recent weeks, the struggle has intensified. Trucks delivering milk from El Paso to Juarez have been trashed and torched, their drivers beaten. 
 A recent report to the Federal Reserve confirms what the El Paso milk producers have learned: new trade barriers -- sometimes disguised, sometimes blatant -- are eroding the benefits of the new trade agreement's lower tariffs.
Because of new paperwork and inspections, new health and safety requirements, new environmental and labor standards, new anti-dumping suits and new rules of national origin and labeling requirements, some businesses are little better off than they were without the trade agreement, the report's authors say.
 
Boon to Protectionism Seen
 While they note that the pact has promoted the overall flow of goods and services, they argue that in the long term, many of its provisions will serve protectionist ends.
Mexican and United States trade officials agree that as tariffs have come down, many other obstructions to trade, including new duties in all but name, have arisen in their place.
Even as Mexico has pulled nearly even with Japan as the United States' second-largest export market -- behind Canada -- industry groups in both countries have successfully put pressure on their governments to impose new protection for the steel, meat, dairy, cement and lumber industries, among others. Government help for producers of oilfield pipe, paper and wheat are pending.
The report avoids blaming either Mexico or the United States. But its authors, William C. Gruben, a research officer for the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, and John H. Welch, a former Fed economist and now a market analyst at Lehman Brothers in New York, point out that Washington has led the way in creative protectionism.
"I hate to point a finger at the Mexicans, when the past masters of countervailing duties and anti-dumping charges have been agencies of the United States Government," Mr. Gruben said in an interview.
The report appears in the most recent issue of the Dallas Fed's quarterly Economic Review. Although the magazine's routine disclaimer says that articles do not necessarily represent the Fed's point of view, Mr. Gruben and Mr. Welch's manuscript was reviewed by top officials in Dallas and Washington.
The pact's sheer complexity, with hundreds of pages of cross-referencing clauses and formulas, has befuddled even many customs agents. But these difficulties are diminishing.
Over the long run, Mr. Gruben and Mr. Welch say, what seemed like muscular free-trade measures will accumulate flab, as industries learn how to defend themselves. "Any agreement can get middle-aged spread, just like the rest of us," Mr. Gruben said.
With elections completed in Mexico and coming up in the United States, and a new world trade treaty before the United States Congress, neither American nor Mexican politicians have wanted to confront each other publicly.
But the obstacles hardly come as a surprise. Canada signed the North American Free Trade Agreement, too, but the impact has been greatest on commerce between Mexico and the United States. Washington and Ottawa reached a trade accord in 1988, which brought down tariffs but was followed by a host of new trade barriers.
 
View Toward the Millennium
 "The history is that as tariffs are reduced, nontariff barriers are raised to substitute," said Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, in a recent interview on trade with Mexico. "Then nontariff barriers are reduced. But it takes a long time."
Winning a global agreement on reducing barriers to agricultural trade took 20 years, Mr. Garten said. But, he quickly added, "In the year 2000, the economic historians will be able to write that the integration of the North American market proceeded faster than anywhere else."
This, however, is 1994, and eight months into the new era, Mexican officials concede that they have introduced a swarm of new inspections, regulations and anti-dumping cases -- in no case tougher than the Americans impose, they add. "When you compare nontariff barriers coming into Mexico with nontariff barriers coming into the United States, you will always find ours are not as restrictive," Jaime Serra Puche, the Mexican Secretary of Commerce, said in a recent interview.
More of the latest trade barriers appear to have been erected on the Mexican side, but in many cases the Mexicans are just catching up with the lobbyists and lawyers north of the border. The United States steel industry has filed carloads of anti-dumping complaints, contending that Mexican and other foreign producers were selling their goods for less than at home or below American costs of production.
When the Mexicans imposed anti-dumping duties as high as 79 percent on American steel a few weeks ago, American producers were left in the awkward position of quarreling with Mexico's dumping calculations but supporting its right to protect its steelmakers. In the United States as in Mexico, said Curtis H. Barnette, the chairman of Bethlehem Steel, "We have the continued right to use our trade laws if we feel there has been injurious trade."
And meat? The Mexicans have imposed new inspections and labeling requirements, often creating more border delays than before the trade agreement took effect. United States packers contend that the new procedures are redundant for meat that has already met Ariculture Department standards. The Mexicans respond that they require nothing more than the United States has long demanded for meat and other food that they ship north.
Lumber? Mexico now demands proof that it is not infested, even when it has been dried in kilns at temperatures up to 280 degrees Fahrenheit, hot enough to kill almost any bug. The United States charges $30 a truckload for the sanitary certificates, and the Mexicans charge $32 more to validate them.
 
Pact Didn't Solve Everything
 "These are the problems that people had hoped Nafta would eliminate, but it hasn't," said Sam Vale, a rancher who owns a border toll bridge in Rio Grande City, Tex. "It hasn't been a panacea by any stretch of the imagination. The paperwork is a nightmare."
The United States has begun a dumping inquiry on Mexican pipe used in oil production. And in May, Washington raised its anti-dumping tariffs on Mexican cement to 60 percent from 43 percent.
The authors of the Dallas Fed report say that while environmental, labor and health rules can serve their stated ends, they often disguise protectionism. Using a regionalism, Mr. Gruben refers to the unlikely link between labor leaders and environmentalists as the "Baptists and bootleggers phenomenon."
Anti-import furor in Mexico appears to have the support of the Government and industry groups. Public service television commercials show an imported car breaking down or a stuck zipper on an imported dress turning romance into comedy.
Even youngsters are conscripted into the battle. At a grade school in Patzcuaro, in central Mexico, a Children's Day party this spring offered dancing, singing and feasting in a courtyard festooned with banners warning the children and their parents against foreign toys.
In Juarez, the largest city in a dairy and meat region, the fight against imports has turned ugly. In recent weeks, a Farmers Dairy truck delivering El Paso milk to a Juarez supermarket had all its tires slashed, its refrigeration lines severed. Another driver was pulled from his cab and beaten, while his truck was driven away, wrecked and abandoned.
Three other trucks, parked at a Juarez warehouse and filled with Price's Creameries milk from El Paso, were doused with gasoline and consumed by fire. Borden trucks have also been hit.
"It's not in the spirit of free trade," said Gene Carrejo, Price's vice president for sales. So far, he added, Mexican authorities have found none of those responsible.

HEADLINE: An Immigration Puzzle;
Crises in Cuba and Haiti Resurrect Debate About Newcomers and Employment in U.S.

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
With Cubans piling up at Guantanamo and an invasion of Haiti seeming inevitable, the United States is once again facing the prospect of a tide of huddled masses -- only this time many Americans seem decidedly uneasy.
And while their feelings are a product of everything from racism to fears of cultural change to the end of the cold war, economics surely plays a big part. 
 "Americans think immigrants are stealing their jobs and lowering their standard of living," said William Alpert, an economist at the University of Connecticut -- thoughts that have a special resonance in an era of widening gaps in income between the skilled and unskilled.
Are the politicians and policy makers who see economic peril in continuing immigration correct? Research in the area has been less than conclusive, a fact that Orley Ashenfelter, an economist at Princeton University, says is feeding passions on both sides. "Some try to exaggerate" findings of job and wage losses, he says, while "some try the opposite."
The perceived economic threat of immigration, notes Claudia Goldin, an economic historian at Harvard University, is no different today than it was in the 1890's, when Samuel Gompers of the American Federation of Labor was calling on Congress to "shut the doors." Unskilled immigrants compete with unskilled American-born, either reducing the wages of natives or putting them out of work.
 
Raising the Returns
 By the same token, if unskilled native-born citizens are made worse off by competition from immigrants, Americans with money are made better off. This is most evident in the availability of low-wage workers to wash dishes, mow lawns and tend babies.
Cheap, plentiful unskilled labor probably did (and still does) directly raise the returns to capital, both physical and "human." Machines and white-collar workers are presumably more valuable if it costs less to hire labor for the repetitive tasks of the assembly line. But does the scale of immigration currently being experienced in America portend such economic class conflict?
Ms. Goldin points out that the percentage of population growth attributable to immigration in the last decade is close to the spectacularly high peaks during the decades of the Great Immigration before World War I -- 33 percent in the 1980's, compared with 28 percent in the 1890's and 54 percent in the first decade of this century.
But David Card of Princeton surprised many fellow economists with his benign analysis of the most notable influx of immigrants in modern times, the 1980 Mariel boatlift, in which 125,000 largely unskilled Cubans flooded southern Florida in a matter of weeks.
Using other Sun Belt cities as a benchmark, he found that the Marielitos had no discernible impact on wages or unemployment. The local economy, he concluded, expanded rapidly enough to absorb the new immigrants without driving the largely black and Hispanic competition onto the unemployment rolls.
But the study hardly settled the question of whether immigrants make life tougher for American-born workers. Lawrence Katz of Harvard, who was formerly the Labor Department's chief economist, speculates that the American labor force is so mobile that the impact of excess labor supplies on localities quickly dissipates. Or to put it another way, more nonimmigrant workers would have come to Miami if the Mariel boatlift had never happened.
 
Not Off the Hook
 "There is now evidence," Mr. Katz said, "that where immigrants are going, natives are leaving" -- evidence that Mariel-style immigration is not necessarily traumatic for regional economies, especially rapidly growing ones like Miami's.
But this interpretation does not get immigrants off the hook in the national economic context. Indeed, it implies that in one place or another, more unskilled immigrants mean lower wages and fewer low-end jobs for those already here.
Mr. Katz, along with his Harvard colleague Richard Freeman and George Borjas of the University of California at San Diego, say the impact of unskilled immigrants has been substantial. They estimate that roughly one-fifth of the growth in the wage gap between the skilled and unskilled since the mid 1970's is linked to the growing supply of unskilled immigrant labor.
The United States is, of course, a nation of the descendants of immigrants who are reluctant to deny opportunities to a new generation of immigrants. Thus to many, the more important question is whether continuing immigration is adversely affecting the American economy's long-term prospects. But here, too, the evidence is ambiguous.
 
Cause for Celebration
 Mr. Borjas notes that the skills and cultural backgrounds that immigrants are bringing is "hollowing out" in the middle, with higher percentages of highly skilled college graduates and higher percentages of people with just the rudiments of education. Americans do not worry about the top end -- in fact, many celebrate the arrival of all those Indian computer whizes, Russian physicists and Filipino nurses as a revitalizing influence.
But over all, Mr. Borjas said, immigrants are far more likely to receive welfare than people born in America. In 1990, he calculates, the 8.4 percent of households with foreign-born heads received 13.1 percent of the total cash assistance. And he questions the capacities of low-income immigrants to assimilate into America's largely middle-class culture as rapidly as preceding generations did.
Before the 1970's, immigrants entered the country with smaller earning gaps, compared with their native counterparts, and made far more progress in closing the gap. Mr. Borjas projects that the wages of immigrants who arrived from 1970 to 1990 will never catch up, remaining 15 to 20 percent behind those of American-born workers. These (and less responsible) calculations are figuring prominently in the California gubernatorial election, where Gov. Pete Wilson, a Republican, has made an issue of the taxpayers' cost in supporting immigrants.
 
A Social Tragedy
 Other economists share Mr. Borjas' concerns, but put a different spin on their significance. Ms. Goldin notes that a disproportionate number of the economically distressed immigrants are political refugees from the wars in Indochina. Their problems constitute a social tragedy, but do not say much about the consequences of immigration driven primarily by economic incentives.
Barry Chiswick, chairman of the economics department at the University of Illinois at Chicago, points out that job opportunities for unskilled workers, native and immigrant, have collapsed since the 1970's. Hence, it is hardly surprising that immigrants facing language, cultural and racial barriers have had more trouble moving up in a society in which native-born are also having more trouble moving up.
Moreover, he emphasizes that only unskilled immigrants qualify as competition for Americans near the bottom of the economic pecking order. Thus, changes in immigration policy that discriminated in favor of the affluent and educated would defuse the problem.
American immigration laws were in fact revised in 1990, raising the number of visas for individuals in skills deemed in short supply and lowering the priority of reuniting families. The latter policy of giving preferences to the relatives of American residents, adopted in the mid-1960's, has been widely blamed for the decline in average skill and earnings levels of immigrants.
 
Economic Waste
 But Mr. Chiswick notes that Washington exercises enormous discretion in deciding which skills are needed, a process open to both bureaucratic inefficiency and political influence. He would much prefer a Canadian-style system, in which immigrant preferences were largely determined by a formula based on education and assets.
To some economists, the saddest aspect of limits on immigration (current and prospective) is the sheer economic waste of preventing labor from moving to where it is most productive. For in theory, part of the increase in productivity of, say, a Haitian who goes from making 20 cents an hour in Port-au-Prince to $8 an hour in New York, could be used to compensate the native-born who are made a bit worse off by competition from immigrants.
Immigrants might, for example, be made ineligible for beefed-up anti-poverty programs like earned income tax credits and food stamps. But that may not be constitutional; and it certainly does not mesh with notions of equality under the law. Even more to the point, Mr. Chiswick argues, it would add to the sorts of social problems that worry Americans most about low-end immigration.
What seems almost indisputable in the immigration debate, though, is the unfortunate coincidence of widening income inequality in America and the pressure on the United States to admit unskilled immigrants, legal and illegal. "It would be tough enough to make sensible immigration policy in the best of times," Mr. Ashenfelter concluded. "Today it's almost impossible."

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%); HAITI (94%); CUBA (92%);

HEADLINE: Film Ratings Under Attack From More Than One Angle

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Movie ratings seem like taxes: necessary but a source of irritation and anger. Within the last few days, debate over the 26-year-old film rating system has taken a particularly nasty turn.
"I've had a Maalox moment on this latest go-round," said Jack Valenti, chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America, the movie industry's lobbying arm, which controls the ratings classification board and is now locked in an angry dispute with the creators of a new film, "Jason's Lyric," about black teen-agers in Houston. 
 Mr. Valenti's Maalox moment includes accusations of racism against the ratings board, which Mr. Valenti furiously denies. The board insisted on the deletion of some sexual scenes and a change in the movie's promotion poster before it would rate the film R instead of NC-17.
Beyond this there are persistent charges that the ratings board is far more critical of films with sexual content than of those with gory violence; that the board allows itself to be bullied by big studios but deals aggressively with less powerful independent companies, and that it seems far more horrified about foul language in films than about foul and murderous behavior.
The Classifications and Ratings Board of the Motion Picture Association of America was founded in 1968 to replace the archaic and prudish Hays Production Code, which controlled the sexual content of movies for decades. The board's classifications were created, with the endorsement of theater owners, as guidelines for parents.
 
The 5 Categories
 Over the years, those ratings evolved into five categories: G, for general audiences, usually cartoons and children's films; PG, meaning parental guidance is suggested and some material may be unsuitable for younger children; PG-13, meaning parents are strongly cautioned and some material may be inappropriate for children under 13; R, restricted, people under 17 must be accompanied by a parent or adult guardian, and NC-17, a relatively new rating, meaning no one under 17 is admitted. Independent film companies also have the option of releasing unrated films, but studios who are part of the association are obliged to adhere to its rulings.
The 13-member ratings board is headed by Richard M. Mosk, a Los Angeles lawyer. The names of the other members, all in the Los Angeles area, are secret. Barbara Dixon, a spokeswoman for the association, said they are all parents and represent a diverse mixture of ethnic and economic groups.
Perhaps the criticism most often heard about the ratings board is that studio-made action films, which are often loaded with violence, rarely encounter problems. Even "Basic Instinct," one of the most aggressively violent and sexual studio-made films in years, was given an R rating. But film makers depicting sexual situations that seem believable (unlike "Basic Instinct") are often told to delete certain scenes.
"Double standards apply," said Doug McHenry, the director of "Jason's Lyric." "The ratings system has a proclivity for violence over sex." Other critics add that double standards exist even in terms of sex: the ratings board strongly objected to male frontal nudity in Bruce Willis's recent film called "Color of Night" and deletions were made in the film. But female nudity, as in "Basic Instinct" and "Short Cuts," is not so objectionable to the board.
 
Contrasting Cases
 The latest case in the violence versus sex issue involves Oliver Stone's "Natural Born Killers," which was given an R rating. The rating, which delighted Warner Brothers, which produced the film and is a supporter of the association, came only after Mr. Stone made many cuts. One of them was a scene in which prison inmates decapitate a warden, played by Tommy Lee Jones, and carry his head on a stick. Even without that particular bit of gore, however, "Natural Born Killers" is one of the bloodiest commercial films in decades.
On the other hand, the ratings board unexpectedly gave an NC-17 to "Clerks," a comedy that was a prize winner this year at the Sundance and Cannes film festivals. Because some video companies like Blockbuster refuse to buy NC-17 movies and some theatrical chains decline to show them, the rating is considered an economic death sentence.
The reason for the rating? The film focuses on two teen-age boys working at a convenience store in New Jersey, and their dialogue is often crude. Miramax, the producer, is appealing the decision on the film, which is set to open on Oct. 21.
Mr. Valenti, speaking by telephone the other day from Venice, where he is attending the city's film festival, defended the potentially damaging rating, saying that moviegoers in Iowa or Kansas probably have different standards from those in New York or Los Angeles.
"There are millions of Americans who become hysterical about the kind of bad language that may be de rigueur around dinner tables in the East Side of Manhattan," Mr. Valenti said, his voice rising. "But in the cities and villages and towns across this free and loving land it's not that way at all."
 
The Present Case
 What has led to the latest controversy, however, is "Jason's Lyric," a Romeo-and-Juliet romance against a backdrop of the urban ghetto. The film, scheduled to open on Sept. 30, has a cast that includes Allen Payne, Bokeem Woodbine and Forest Whitaker. The director, Mr. McHenry, who produced "New Jack City," a 1991 action drama set in New York, said in an interview that he agreed to make some deletions in the sexual content to gain an R rating for "Jason's Lyric."
"None of the things that I did were so heinous that it lost the integrity of the film," he said. But Mr. McHenry said that officials of the Motion Picture Association then strongly objected to a marketing poster for the movie, which showed the two leads embracing erotically.
Mr. McHenry said he was so angry at the board's objection to the poster that with the cooperation of Gramercy Pictures, the film's distributor, he made a 60-second radio spot that was broadcast in 25 urban markets in mid-August. "In this country you can kill 50,000 people in a film, but you can't have a tasteful, romantic love scene," the director said in the ad. "If you have two black people making love, somehow, that's steamier than other people." He also said that a double-standard had been applied to films with black actors.
"I'm not calling any one individual a racist," Mr. McHenry, who is black, said in an interview. "What I'm saying is the process leaves a pattern of discriminatory results."
"Clearly, African-American films have had a tougher time," said Mr. McHenry, 42, who graduated from Stanford University and Harvard Business School and Law School before becoming an assistant to Peter Guber, now chairman of Sony Pictures Entertainment, in the 1980's. He added that provocative movie ads with Sharon Stone in "Basic Instinct" and Madonna in "Truth or Dare" produced no difficulties for the Motion Picture Association.
Although Mr. McHenry altered the ad, which has now been accepted by the Motion Picture Association's advertising administration board, his allegations stung Mr. Valenti.
In a column in Daily Variety on Aug. 23, he wrote of Mr. McHenry: "A young African-American director cries 'racism' about the rating for his film, 'Jason's Lyric.' The film features full views of nude copulation; naked actors sprawl across its advertising posters.
"What I most admire about the young director is his chutzpah. When he was in diapers I was working every hour of every day in the White House by the side of Lyndon Johnson as he led the greatest revolution in our nation's history on behalf of civil rights and human justice for every citizen."
He called Mr. McHenry's comments "fraudulent blathering" designed to gain free advertising for his movie. (Mr. McHenry said he did not want to engage in a shouting match with Mr. Valenti.)
In the interview Mr. Valenti said one company, Miramax, now owned by Disney, has perennially tangled with the ratings board for the publicity. "Miramax has raised it to a level of artistry," he said. "They get millions of dollars in free publicity by accusing the rating system of everything but child molestation. It's a marketing gambit."
Harvey Weinstein, a co-chairman of Miramax, denied the assertion. "The question to ask is how does a picture like 'True Lies,' where maybe 75 people are killed, have no problem with the ratings board. But 'Clerks,' a comedy which is really harmless, where two guys use bad language, gets an NC-17. It's unjust. Let's face it, it's an inanity."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGNS;
Cuomo: The First Nod Towards Pataki

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:

CANDIDATE: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo
 
PRODUCER: The Garth Group, New York 

VISUAL: The ad opens with a still frame of Mr. Cuomo on the upper-left side of the screen, followed by a similar frame of Mr. Pataki on the right. The ad then alternates between snippets of video interviews with Mr. Pataki, a state Senator from Putnam County, on his vote on an assault weapons ban this year and yellow lettering commenting on the interview. The ad is 30 seconds long.
 
THE SCRIPT: Announcer: "Governor Mario Cuomo wants to ban assault weapons. His opponent George Pataki claims he agrees, but he voted against it. First, when asked in a TV interview if he had voted against a ban on assault weapons, he denied it."
Mr. Pataki: "No we have not had a vote."
Announcer: "Then he said it was just procedural."
Mr. Pataki: "There was a procedural amendment."
Announcer: "Finally they admitted it. It was a ban on assault weapons. Maybe that's why Newsday wondered what George Pataki really stands for. George Pataki. Politics as usual."
 
ANALYSIS: This is the first time Mr. Cuomo's campaign has mentioned Mr. Pataki by name, and the ad economically allows an attack on two fronts. The first front is thematic: Mr. Pataki is not trustworthy, a message the Cuomo camp has pursued for several weeks. The second is on a specific issue: Mr. Pataki voted against an assault weapons ban in a year in which fear of crime runs high among voters.
The ad also allows Mr. Cuomo to portray himself as being tough on crime, even as Mr. Pataki hammers home in his own speeches and commercials that he, unlike Mr. Cuomo, is with the voters in his support of the death penalty.
There are few facts to dispute in this commercial, though the Pataki campaign might argue that it is incomplete and misleading. On April 25, Mr. Pataki did vote against a gun licensing bill, which a Democratic Senator had amended to include sharp restrictions on a number of assault weapons. Since then, Mr. Pataki has given various explanations of his vote, which are reflected accurately in the ad.
Mr. Pataki has argued that the amendment, offered by a Democrat, was of the kind that the Republicans who control the chamber routinely oppose. Moreover, he has said he favors a more sweeping ban than the one included in the amended bill, which would have allowed licensing for some collectors and competitive shooters. -- IAN FISHER

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGNS;
Rosenbaum: Fighting as an Outsider

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:

CANDIDATE: Richard M. Rosenbaum
 
PRODUCER: Sandler-Innocenzi, Alexandria, Va. 

VISUAL: The 30-second ad begins with a poker game involving cigar-chomping card sharks in a smoke-filled room. As one player tosses down his cards, his face changes into that of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. A dealer gives him three deuces with these words super-imposed over them: "Taxes," "Welfare" and "Lost Jobs." Then the dealer gives another three deuces to a second player and these words appear over his cards: "Voted with Cuomo 90%," "Raised Taxes," and "Paid No Taxes on $400,000." That player's face then changes into Senator George E. Pataki, Mr. Rosenbaum's rival in the Republican primary. Suddenly there is a bolt of lightning, and Mr. Rosenbaum appears, gesticulating and talking directly at the camera about how he will cut taxes, sign the death penalty and reform welfare.
 
THE SCRIPT: Announcer: "The politicians are always dealing in Albany. Cuomo's deal? Taxes, welfare, lost jobs. Pataki's deal? Vote with Cuomo 9 out of 10 times, raise taxes then make more than $400,000 himself and pay no taxes at all. Pataki? New name, same game. But Dick Rosenbaum breaks up the insider game." Mr. Rosenbaum: "I'm Dick Rosenbaum. I'll slash taxes, pass the death penalty and make welfare fathers pay up." Announcer: "Dick Rosenbaum. Republican for Governor."
 
ANALYSIS: The spot is designed to underscore the central theme of the Rosenbaum campaign: that he is an outsider runnining against an entrenched and corrupt political culture where Republicans and Democrats are the same. But Mr. Rosenbaum is himself vulnerable to that charge because he was once a state Republican chairman and has worked as a lobbyist in Albany and Washington, D.C.
Mr. Rosenbaum's criticisms of the two leading candidates are also misleading on several points. Under Mr. Cuomo, the state has raised some taxes, such as on petroleum, cigarettes and businesses, but has reduced others, including the personal income tax. Welfare spending is up, but the lion's share of that has gone to cover the rising cost of Medicaid, which Mr. Cuomo has only limited control over. And while the state lost about half a million jobs during the last recession, it has had a net gain of 422,000 jobs during Mr. Cuomo's 12-year tenure.
Though the ad says Mr. Pataki voted with Mr. Cuomo "9 out of 10 times," the figure actually refers to the number of times he voted with Democrats in the Senate, where many votes are unanimous. Though Mr. Pataki has voted for Cuomo initiatives, he has also voted against Mr. Cuomo on more occasions than most Senators. Mr. Pataki is directly responsible for raising taxes by 8.4 percent as mayor of Peekskill in the early 1980s. But he has also voted against several state budgets that included tax increases. And though it is true that Mr. Pataki did not pay capital gains taxes on a $401,666 profit he made from a 1986 real estate transaction, he did so legally under a provision of the Federal tax code that has allowed him to defer that tax liability.-- JAMES DAO
endit

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGNS;
Pataki: Honing a Mantra Against Cuomo

BYLINE: By Kevin Sack 

 BODY:

CANDIDATE George E. Pataki
 
PRODUCER Russo, Marsh & Associates, Sacramento, Calif., and Alexandria, Va. 

VISUAL Alternating photographs of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mr. Pataki on half of the screen, as the text spoken by a narrator rolls on the other half. When the narrator announces, "It's time for a change," Mr. Cuomo's picture tumbles off the screen.
 
 THE SCRIPT "Mario Cuomo has consistently raised your taxes time and time again. As a State Senator, George Pataki voted against Mario Cuomo's tax-and-spend record every time. Mario Cuomo vetoed the death penalty 12 years in a row. Senator George Pataki fought for the death penalty, and as a Governor will sign it into law. Mario Cuomo has been in office 12 long years. It's time for a change. George Pataki, the new Governor New York needs."
 
 ANALYSIS This ad chants Mr. Pataki's campaign mantra: Mr. Cuomo has raised taxes and vetoed the death penalty; Mr. Pataki has fought against both in the Legislature; after three Cuomo terms it's time for a change. The Pataki campaign thus far has been premised on the notion that victory can be shaped on that anti-Cuomo message. This commercial does little to further define Mr. Pataki, a Republican legislator from Putnam County, or to detail his positions, particularly on how he would cut taxes.
Unlike some previous Pataki ads, which have relied on erroneous economic statistics, this commercial carefully avoids such blunders. But it commits a far more common sin of political advertising, that of omission.
It is true that Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature have raised certain taxes time and time again, particularly those on businesses, petroleum and cigarettes. But the Governor has studiously avoided raising broad-based taxes, and in 1987 he signed the largest cut in personal income taxes in state history. The last phase of that reduction has been cancelled because of the state's economic problems, but the top rate on earned income dropped from 9.5 percent to 7.875 percent.
With the election nearing, Mr. Cuomo pushed through a modest $475 million tax cut this year, reducing taxes on businesses and hotel rooms, among others. He has pledged to cut taxes further next year, but has not said how.
The most recent studies by the U.S. Census Bureau show that the state's tax burden, measured as a percentage of personal income, is about the same as when Mr. Cuomo took office. That is true even when state taxes are combined with local taxes.
It is also true that Mr. Pataki, who was elected to the Senate in 1992 after eight years in the Assembly, voted against the budget each year he was in the Senate. But he voted twice for the budget while in the Assembly, in 1985 and 1986, according to his aides, before adopting the practice of routinely voting no.
The claims about the death penalty are true. -- KEVIN SACK

HEADLINE: Health Care Debate to Shift To Federal Employees' Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Almost every health care proposal still pending in Congress complies with the politically potent demand -- expressed over and over in last month's Senate debate -- that all Americans should be able to get insurance as good as what Congress has.
In fact, there is no special health plan for members of Congress. They participate in the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program, along with nine million other Government workers, retirees and dependents. 
 The Federal program is not one insurance plan, but a supermarket offering 300 private health plans to Federal employees around the country. The Heritage Foundation, a conservative research center, calls it "a showcase of consumer choice and free market competition" that offers a much wider choice of health plans and has controlled health costs better than private employers.
The entire program, with premiums of more than $15 billion a year, is run by 164 people. Administrative expenses total $22 million a year.
The program's low cost, large size and sterling reputation make its expansion an attractive option in what has become a political minefield.
As a result, virtually all the major health care proposals that Congress will take up when it returns next Monday would open the Federal employees' program to millions of people who are uninsured, self-employed or work for small businesses. The bills differ in significant ways, but would vastly expand the program, adding 25 million to 50 million people or more.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said the purpose was simple: to "give the American people exactly what we have."
But how to achieve that goal, like so much else in the health care debate, is a devilishly complex question. And the idea has many critics, starting with Federal employees who worry that the program's expansion will come at their expense.
James B. King, who supervises the insurance program as director of the Federal Office of Personnel Management, said, "This is a wonderful working model, but it cannot be instantly duplicated."
Bills offered by the Senate and House majority leaders, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, would give the public an opportunity to buy the same health benefits that members of Congress and other Federal employees have.
At first, ordinary consumers would pay premiums based on local market conditions, and these premiums would differ from those paid by Federal employees. But eventually, Federal workers and other consumers would pay the same rates, all based on local market conditions.
Federal employee unions say they fear that their members' premiums would rise as a result. Diane S. Witiak, a spokeswoman for the American Federation of Government Employees, which represents more than 700,000 Federal workers, said, "Congress shouldn't ask Federal workers to pay more for fewer benefits."
A more modest proposal devised by a bipartisan group of 20 senators known as the "mainstream coalition" would permit uninsured people and businesses with fewer than 100 employees to enroll in many of the health plans offered to Federal workers. But under this proposal, premiums of Federal workers would be computed separately from those of other subscribers.
A bill offered by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, would open the Federal program to self-employed people and to private businesses with 50 or fewer employees.
 
14 National Plans Offered
 The Federal employees' health program, created in 1959, is now open to members of Congress and their aides, the President, Cabinet officers, Civil Service employees, Postal Service workers, Federal judges and Federal court employees.
Fourteen plans are offered nationally. Federal employees and retirees pay the same premiums for a given plan, regardless of where they live or how old they are. The biggest nationwide plan, offered by Blue Cross and Blue Shield, covers more than 3.5 million Federal employees, retirees and dependents. A retired 61-year-old Congressional aide in Washington and a 20-year-old employee of the Department of Agriculture working in Texas pay the same premium for this policy, $101 a month for family coverage, and the Government contributes $304.
In private industry, employees often do not have the slightest idea how much they and their employers pay for health insurance. But in the Federal program, employees are told precisely how much the Government contributes and how much they must pay for each plan. Armed with this information, Federal employees become sophisticated consumers, more conscious of health costs than most workers in private industry.
"Federal employees shop like crazy" to minimize their premium costs, said Alan P. Spielman, a vice president of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association.
Employee groups like the American Postal Workers Union sponsor health plans open to all Federal employees across the country. These plans allow Government workers to go to virtually any doctor or hospital. The unions have been phenomenally successful in marketing their health plans; some plans, like that of the mail handlers, dwarf the unions that sponsor them.
In addition, scores of prepaid health plans, including health maintenance organizations, are available to Federal employees in specific areas of the country. The H.M.O.'s generally require patients to use a select list of doctors and hospitals in a designated market.
The Federal Government pays, on the average, 72 percent of the premiums for its employees' health plans. Federal workers can reassess their needs and choose different plans in a five-week period each fall.
The Government negotiates with insurers on behalf of Federal employees, stipulating certain categories of benefits that must be provided, like hospital care, doctors' services and prescription drugs. Federal officials say they do not coerce insurers or write detailed regulations, but coach insurers to improve their plans by adding certain features.
The precise benefits, as well as the deductibles and other employee costs, vary by plan. The Government publishes a brochure giving details of each plan, and Federal agencies sponsor "health fairs" at which insurers market their plans.
"There's no fine print," said Mr. King, the director of the Office of Personnel Management. "It's all up front. Insurers are not permitted to do anything sleazy."
 
Nunn Urges More Audits
 But his agency and the plans themselves are clearly not prepared for a huge influx of subscribers. Senator Sam Nunn, a Georgia Democrat who recently investigated the program, said the Office of Personnel Management did not do nearly enough audits to detect fraud and overpayments. Some of the biggest plans are audited only once every seven years, he said.
The Mitchell, Gephardt and mainstream coalition bills all call for the Government to define a standard package of health benefits. Daniel C. Adcock, a lobbyist for the National Association of Retired Federal Employees, which has 500,000 members, said he worried that the standard package would be inferior to what Federal employees now had.
"We support the goal of universal coverage," Mr. Adcock said. "We understand why President Clinton and Congress want to give all Americans the same type of health insurance they have. But there should be safeguards to make sure the Federal employees' program is not degraded. We want to be sure that Federal employees and retirees don't lose anything."
Many Federal workers and retirees have insurance that pays 100 percent of their hospital costs, but under most proposals pending in Congress, patients would have to pay 20 percent, Mr. Adcock said.
 
Increased Costs Predicted
 Under Senator Mitchell's bill, workers in companies with fewer than 500 employees, welfare recipients and people who were self-employed or unemployed would have access to all the insurance plans available to Federal employees, including the ones offered by Blue Cross and Blue Shield.
Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, said this proposal would "wreak havoc with the premiums of Federal employees" and would increase costs for taxpayers, who pay most of the premiums. He predicted that many insurers would drop out of the Federal employees' program rather than accept tens of millions of new high-cost customers.
The Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association also opposes the Mitchell and Gephardt bills.
Alixe R. Glen, a spokeswoman for the association, said: "Senator Mitchell's proposal would have the same practical effect as abolishing the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program. There would be no nationally available plans with uniform premium rates throughout the United States."
Such national plans, which now cover 70 percent of the people in the Federal employees' program, would be carved up and offered through local health insurance purchasing cooperatives. Premiums would be set locally. The Office of Personnel Management would eventually blend the premiums for Government workers with those for other customers.

HEADLINE: Vatican Rejects Compromise On Abortion at U.N. Meeting

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 6

 BODY:
After a day of tortuous closed-door talks that pitted Vatican diplomats against many other delegates, the United Nations population conference failed tonight to reach a compromise on the contentious issue of abortion.
Standing alone, Vatican diplomats blocked a consensus on a formula sponsored by Pakistan, saying they found it unacceptable. The proposed formula itself took five hours of haggling among 15 countries. 
 The Vatican's decision drew a chorus of boos, according to delegates at the closed session. At the time, conference participants said, the Vatican delegation was represented -- unusually -- by a woman, an American whose name was not released.
The move by the Vatican reflected Pope John Paul II's ardent crusade against abortion. But many delegates have noted that abortion is only one element of the far broader issue facing the meeting -- averting a disaster in global population growth.
"The Holy See cannot give explicit or implicit support in those parts of the document regarding abortion, the weakening of several family-related terminologies, the effective encouragement among adolescents of a liberal sexual life style free of parental rights," a Vatican statement said, referring to the conference's draft document.
The decision came despite efforts by Vice President Al Gore, head of the United States delegation, to assuage the Vatican's fears that the conference would legitimize abortion as a right and promote adolescent promiscuity.
The conference's report will not be binding on any nation, but delegates say that the broader the consensus, the better the chances that population growth can be limited.
Mr. Gore, who came under personal attack by the Vatican last week for purportedly misrepresenting the conference's intentions, met at his own request today with Archbishop Renato R. Martino, the head of the Vatican delegation. Later Mr. Gore said: "The misunderstandings they've had before have been significantly dispelled."
However, he said, the United States and the Vatican would inevitably remain divided on abortion, which the Clinton Administration says should be safe, legal and rare.
The encounter did not bring the Vatican any closer to what Administration officials depicted as a gathering consensus that abortion should be left to legislation in each country.
"This is absolutely unacceptable," said the chief Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls. "We are dealing with an international document preparing policies for governments that deal with human beings."
Among other things, the compromise rejected by the Vatican said abortion should "in no case" be used as a method of family planning -- a distinction the Vatican has long wanted to the enshrined by the conference.
But the wording also said that "in circumstances in which abortion is legal, such abortion should be safe." Delegates said the Vatican could not agree to this because Roman Catholic doctrine forbids abortion as a violation of the sanctity of life from the moment of conception.
 
Longer-Range Goals
 The wording of the compromise was based on an earlier proposal by the European Union and maintained three essential principles: that abortion should not be part of family-planning policies, that it should be left to national governments to legislate and that all efforts should be made to reduce abortion.
The draft conference document is to form the basis of a 20-year plan as part of an ambitious attempt to foster economic development by promoting women's rights. By United Nations, World Bank and other estimates, the world's population will soar from 5.7 billion now, to 7.27 billion by 2015, which many regard as unsustainable.
"A billion people already struggle to survive on a dollar a day," the World Bank's president, Lewis T. Preston, told delegates today. "Two billion people are without clean water. The problem is that we are not doing enough quickly enough to implement the basic action that experience has shown to be effective."
Despite such worries, the gathering of more than 150 delegations here has diverted most of its energies since it opened on Monday to abortion, which has elicited opposition from Islamic delegates, too.
One Islamic newspaper, Al Shaab, said today, "On this pure land, delegates poured from different states hailing promiscuity, calling for abortion and extramarital sex, and pointing to an era with no morals, where all values are trampled underfoot."
When Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan spoke at the conference on Monday, she also called abortion unacceptable. Her comments helped define the division between religious conservatives and secular liberals like Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway, who said on Monday that decriminalizing abortion should be a "minimal response" to the deaths of women from unsafe, illegal abortions.
 
'Reproductive Health'
 But according to delegates, today's negotiations shifted the lines of this division when Pakistan and Benin, a Vatican ally, supported the compromise language. Countries as diverse in their approaches to abortion as Iran and Sweden also approved.
When the conference resumes on Wednesday, delegates said, the Vatican could win some support from Latin American countries that were not able to speak tonight because of time pressures. Such support could force further talks on a compromise.
Only when that is complete will delegates move to other contentious issues, notably a definition of "reproductive health," which the Vatican see as a cover for abortion on demand.
The only area in which the Vatican has come close to agreement is the question of adolescent sexuality. There, at the Vatican's insistence, proposals for confidential sex counseling for teen-agers have been balanced by the proviso that parents should exercise their "rights, duties and responsibilities" to provide "appropriate direction and guidance in sexual and reproductive matters."
The Vatican's stand on abortion suggested that when the conference ends on Sept. 13, the guidelines will not win a full consensus. "No one should have the illusion that there is going to be some kind of resolve that causes the Vatican to sign this document," Mr. Gore said today.

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Governor Cruises Election Road

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Mark Roosevelt, the front-runner in the Democratic primary for governor, was introducing himself to the men at the Eire Pub in Dorchester, a staunchly Democratic neighborhood in Boston.
Dennis Farrell, a lifelong Democrat, hardly took his eyes off the television. He seemed surprised that Mr. Roosevelt, a 38-year-old state representative, was campaigning. "Seems like a shoo-in for Weld," Mr. Farrell, who manages a post office, told a reporter. 
 Mr. Weld is, of course, Gov. William F. Weld, a patrician Republican. He barely got elected four years ago but is now heavily favored to beat whoever wins the Democratic nomination in the Sept. 20 primary, be it Mr. Roosevelt or two even lesser-known candidates: Michael Barrett, a state senator, and George Bachrach, a lawyer and former State Senator.
But if Governor Weld seems like a shoo-in for re-election, Democratic political analysts say, it is not because his performance has been so strong, but because the Democrats seeking to challenge him are so weak. Against a strong opponent, these analysts say, the Governor would not have it so easy -- not with his record, which they see as vulnerable to attack, and not in a state like Massachusetts, long a Democratic stronghold (if now a slightly more conservative one), where Republicans remain vastly outnumbered.
"This guy's performance isn't so wonderful that he can't be taken out," said Michael Goldman, a Democratic consultant who is not aligned with any of his party's candidates for governor. "Luckily for him, instead of running against a Joe Kennedy or any other serious Democrat, he ended up with the B-team. They've got no dough and no name recognition. And the reality is that you can't beat somebody with nobody."
Mr. Weld has a $2.2 million campaign chest, plus the $450,000 he has already spent on television commercials -- more than three times what any Democrat has raised. While the Democrats will take to the television airwaves this week, Mr. Weld has been running three television commercials for the past two weeks.
 
2-to-1 Favorite in Poll
 A recent poll shows him beating any of his Democratic challengers by a margin of 2 to 1. The prominent Democrats who might have given him a race, including Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, have decided not to take him on. In 1990, Mr. Weld won by only a four-point margin over John N. Silber, the president of Boston University and an unpredictable Democrat whom a lot of voters could not support.
"Weld's popularity is less a function of what he's done than what the Democrats have failed to do over the past three years," said James Braude, a Weld critic who is the head of the Tax Equity Alliance of Massachusetts, a citizens' group.
John Stenson, who owns the Eire Pub, agreed. "Whose fault is it but the Democrats' for putting up three guys nobody knows anything about?" he said.
Mr. Braude recalled a state Democratic fund-raising dinner last spring at which the speakers included President Clinton and Senator Edward M. Kennedy. The three candidates for the party's nomination for governor were introduced.
"It was clearly partisan," Mr. Braude said. "Clinton was there to attack Dole. Kennedy was there to attack the Republicans. But in four hours, Weld's name wasn't mentioned once. It was almost as if the party was conceding the gubernatorial race."
Mr. Roosevelt was the chief architect of a major education reform bill signed into law last year. But what recognition he has comes mostly from his name: he is a great-grandson of Theodore Roosevelt and a second cousin of Mr. Weld's wife, Susan Roosevelt Weld.
Like the Governor, Mr. Roosevelt graduated from Harvard and Harvard Law School. But Mr. Roosevelt, who earns $37,000 a year and owns a small town house on Beacon Hill in Boston, is from the poorer side of the family. His father, Kermit Roosevelt, was a longtime official of the Central Intelligence Agency who arranged the 1953 coup that brought the Shah of Iran to power.
Mr. Weld and his Democratic challenger also share political views. Both support the death penalty and an overhaul of the welfare system. But where the Governor is relaxed -- he takes pride in his thrice-weekly squash games and his regular vacations at the family camp in the Adirondacks -- Mr. Roosevelt is, in his own words, driven.
He rarely misses an opportunity to criticize the Governor. "He's indifferent, apathetic, feckless, aloof, passive and lazy," Mr. Roosevelt said in a recent interview. "Did I say uncaring? He's uncaring."
Mr. Weld promised not to raise taxes, and he has not. He is credited with bringing calm to a chaotic State Legislature, and trimming the state work force by 12 percent.
While he takes credit for balancing the budget, his job was eased considerably by two big tax increases won by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis near the end of his last term. In addition, voters rejected a 1990 tax rollback -- endorsed by Mr. Weld as a candidate -- that would have reduced state revenue by nearly $2 billion a year.
At a picnic in Fall River where Mr. Weld was campaigning a few weeks ago, Mike and Kimberly Brett, who described themselves as former Democrats now registered as independents, praised the Governor. "He's turned the state around," said Mrs. Brett, a state welfare worker. "He balanced the budget."
 
Weld Called 'Pro-Upper Class'
 Fewer voters seem to share the feelings of John Richards, who was at a recent Democratic fund-raising event in Dorchester where Mr. Roosevelt was campaigning. "Weld has brought a lot of things around on the backs of people in need," said Mr. Richards, a construction superintendent. "He's never had a tough time in his life. He's always been pro-upper class. He doesn't have to work."
Mr. Weld, a self-styled libertarian, describes himself as fiscally conservative and liberal on gay rights and abortion. But he has changed his position on several key issues. For example, he repeatedly declared himself against gun control -- and even sent The Boston Globe a snapshot of a boar he had shot and killed -- until last year, when he proposed tough gun control legislation that included a ban on assault weapons.
The Governor, a 49-year-old former prosecutor, portrays himself as "to the right of Attila the Hun" on crime. But his administration was embarrassed last year when a man who had been convicted of second-degree murder killed a police officer after walking away from a work release program. Mr. Weld said he had not been aware that second-degree murderers were eligible for release, and halted their participation in that program.
As the United States Attorney here, Mr. Weld opposed casino gambling. But he recently negotiated an agreement with the Wampanoag Indians of Gay Head to open a casino in New Bedford. Casino gambling, he said, will spur economic recovery.
In a front-page series of articles last year, The Globe explored the easy access the Governor gives to business and special interest groups that have helped his campaigns.
"Weld is intoxicated with big money," Mr. Roosevelt said.
Mr. Weld's chief fund-raiser, Peter Berlandi, is the consultant for the Bechtel Corporation, which is managing the Central Artery, a joint state and Federal highway project that is now the nation's largest public works effort. Mr. Roosevelt has demanded that Mr. Berlandi resign his job with Bechtel, saying it represents a conflict of interest.
 
'Forced Into Throwing Mud'
 The Governor's campaign manager, Ray Howell, says the Democratic accusations are acts of desperation. "The Democrats cannot argue with Weld's record or positions on issues that matter to people -- like jobs, taxes, crime and welfare," Mr. Howell said. "So they're forced into throwing mud."
Costs for the Central Artery project have risen to $7.7 billion from $5.7 billion in the last four years. In addition, the project has fallen six years behind schedule. Mr. Roosevelt blames the Governor. "I predict the Central Artery will be Weld's undoing," Mr. Roosevelt said.
Mr. Howell responded: "It's another lie. The biggest percentage of the cost increase occurred under Dukakis."
Despite the attacks, Mr. Weld's popularity continues to grow, according to the polls.
"Bill Weld is in his long Teflon phase," said Mr. Goldman, the Democratic consultant. "Nothing sticks. But it's all blue smoke."
The Governor has dismissed his Democratic challengers as "the three amigos," referring to the movie by that name about a trio of hapless cowboys.
 
Geographical Connections
 Oddly enough, each of them has some sort of connection -- familial, geographic or financial -- to Mr. Weld. Besides Mr. Roosevelt's being related to Mrs. Weld, Mr. Barrett and the Governor live on the same street -- Fayerweather -- in Cambridge, although at opposite ends.
Mr. Bachrach calls himself an unrepentant liberal, but in 1991 he raised money for Mr. Weld and gave a $300 campaign contribution to Lieut. Gov. A. Paul Cellucci and $100 to the state Treasurer, Joseph Malone, both Republicans.
"That's the only excitement in the race so far -- Bachrach's giving money to Weld and Cellucci," said Peter Lucas, a former political reporter and lifelong Democrat who is now a spokesman for the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority.
Politics in Massachusetts is like bullfighting in Seville or soccer in Rio. It's what people talk about. Mr. Barrett says it's not the candidates' fault if the race has not caught fire.
 
A Quotable Interview
 "Each of the three of us manages to be pretty quotable," he said. "I made a couple of convention speeches which were well received. They were tough and quotable, and even witty in spots."
Certainly, people are still quoting Mr. Roosevelt's interview with The Globe last March, when he declared that in seven years in the Legislature he had "a record of accomplishment probably unsurpassed by any legislator in the 20th century in Massachusetts."
Mr. Roosevelt now says he regrets the comment. "I can be sanctimonious," he conceded.
Whether voters see the re-election of Mr. Weld as a sure thing or not, Mr. Howell, the Governor's campaign manager, says his man is running hard.
"This is Massachusetts, where Republicans are 15 percent of the electorate," he said. "We absolutely do not see this as a shoo-in. This thing could turn around very quickly."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Continues Its Decline Against Both Mark and Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar weakened further against other leading currencies yesterday, extending its decline from late last week, on rising demand for German marks and pessimism about American-Japanese trade talks.
Trading volume was light, which exaggerated the extent of the dollar's moves. But American foreign exchange traders returning from the Labor Day holiday said the underlying selling pressure on the dollar was strong. They saw little reason to buy the dollar now or in the days ahead. 
 "The dollar picked up where it left off on Friday -- in a downward spiral against both the mark and the yen," said Tom O'Malley, foreign exchange analyst for Technical Data, a Boston-based financial research concern.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.5425 marks, down from 1.5561 marks on Friday, after trading as low as 1.5395 marks.
The dollar also weakened to 98.66 Japanese yen, from 99.20 yen in New York on Friday.
And the British pound strengthened to $1.5531, from $1.5475 on Friday.
The dollar began falling in Tokyo, where traders said large banks were sellers because of fears that the dollar would drop sharply if American-Japanese talks on reducing Japan's trade surplus faltered before a Sept. 30 deadline set by the United States.
Those fears appeared to be reaffirmed later yesterday by the United States Ambassador to Japan, Walter F. Mondale, who said in Washington that crucial issues in those talks remained unresolved.
"He said there was more work to be done," said Hubert Pedroli, manager of foreign exchange trading at the New York office of Credit Suisse, the Swiss investment banking firm. "He was less than enthusiastic about the prospects."
The Japanese-American trade imbalance is the most contentious issue confronting the two countries and the main reason for the dollar's protracted slide against the yen.
Sales of dollars accelerated in European dealings as traders shifted more holdings to German marks. Traders said there was growing sentiment in Europe that Germany was emerging from an economic slump. That suggests Germany's interest rates are likely to rise, which would make mark-denominated holdings worth more.
Traders were also reacting to a proposal from Germany's governing Christian Democratic coalition calling for the strongest nations in the European Union to integrate their economies at a quicker pace than the rest of the economic bloc.
"That made people buy marks and sell its weaker sister currencies," said David Wilson, a vice president at the New York office of Credit Lyonnais, the large French bank.

HEADLINE: Airbus Gets Large Order at Plane Show

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: FARNBOROUGH, England, Sept. 6

 BODY:
The European consortium Airbus announced today that it had received a big new order, but the overall outlook for civilian aircraft manufacturers remained cloudy despite glimmers of hope at the industry's showcase air show.
The four-nation Airbus group, archrival to the market leader, the Boeing Company, announced an $850 million order from the International Lease Finance Corporation for five extended-range A340-300 aircraft and nine new A320 passenger jets on the second day of the Farnborough air show. 
 It was the biggest single order so far at the fair, which is held every two years and in the past has seen many announcements of large orders.
 
 
Big Deal for Boeing
 The only other big announcement so far this year involved Boeing, which said on Monday that it had an order worth more than $380 million for four 767-ER jets to be used by KLM Royal Dutch Airlines.
 Boeing also said it had commitments for 40 of its new-generation 737-800 jets, which would allow the plane to go into production.
 With the focus these days on the civilian airline industry, the fight over an important British contract for 60 military transport aircraft, said to be worth 5 billion ($7.5 billion) rumbles on here.
 British Aerospace, one of the four members of the Airbus consortium, along with Aerospatiale S.A. of France, the Deutsche Aerospace unit of Daimler-Benz A.G. and Construcciones Aeronauticas of Spain, began a full-scale campaign this week for its European Future Large Aircraft consortium.
The consortium built a full-scale mock-up in the aircraft park here and trumpeted the plane's larger range and greater lifting capacity. The transport, which would haul troops, tanks, helicopters and other big loads, would move Airbus into the military, as well as the civilian, market. Deliveries are to begin in 2002.
 In response, the American competitor, the Lockheed Corporation, fresh from announcing its $10 billion merger with the Martin Marietta Corporation, accused its rival of promoting a "paper airplane" that has not yet been designed, while an updated model of its own C-130J Hercules, a troop and cargo transport plane, was already in production.
 France's military industry joined the battle today, with a call for European military ministries to "buy European."
 "Europe must buy European," said Serge Dassault, president of Gifas, a trade group for the French military industry. "It's an absolute principle we have to fight for."
 The industry has been hurt by reduced military spending after the cold war and by the recession, which curbed air travel. In 1990, just before the Persian Gulf war, 130 orders for civilian planes, worth $14 billion in total, were announced at the Farnborough show. Orders plunged two years ago, to $1.86 billion, and this year looks hard pressed to reach even that.
 Despite the sparse orders, there were some signs of hope for manufacturers, with the air travel industry starting to emerge from the recession, after losing more than $16 billion in the last four years.
 On Monday, Airbus challenged Boeing for a bigger share of the lucrative Chinese market.
 Airbus's president, Jean Pierson, told reporters at the air show that the aircraft group wanted a 50 percent share of the fast-growing Chinese market, in line with its worldwide target for jet sales.
 Boeing, based in Seattle, has 50 to 60 percent of world passenger jet sales with Airbus holding around 30 percent and McDonnell Douglas getting the rest.
