HEADLINE: Japan Raids Companies, Suspecting Bid Rigging

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 6

 BODY:
The Japanese Fair Trade Commission raided the offices of more than 20 prominent trading companies today on suspicion that they colluded on bids to supply material and equipment for the country's foreign aid program, news reports and officials here said.
The suspicions about bid-rigging come at a time when the United States Government has announced its intention to help American companies secure more contracts stemming from Japan's foreign aid expenditures, which total more than $10 billion a year. 
 There have long been assertions that the money Japan gives to less- developed countries as aid is used to buy Japanese equipment and services, to the exclusion of products and services from other nations. Tokyo has denied this, saying companies from all nations can bid for such contracts.
If the trading companies are charged with bid-rigging, it would raise new doubts about the awarding of contracts under Japan's official development assistance program.
In the last few years, the Japanese have seen many cases of bid-rigging on public works projects. The cases have led to arrests and resignations of politicians and construction-industry officials and have helped the United States in its push to open Japan's construction market.
The companies visited by Japan's antitrust enforcement agency today included the Itochu Corporation, the Marubeni Corporation, the Mitsubishi Corporation and Mitsui & Company.
 
Targeted Inspections
 Spokesmen for Mitsubishi and Itochu confirmed that their companies had been visited by officials from the Fair Trade Commission, the antitrust agency. At Mitsubishi, the agents went to the machinery division, which coordinates foreign-aid project bidding and some other offices. At Itochu, the agents visited the textile division and other offices.
But the spokesmen said they would have no further comment because they did not know exactly what the agency was seeking. A Fair Trade Commission official said the agency did not comment on investigations.
Robert M. Orr Jr., chairman of a committee dealing with Japan's foreign aid at the American Chamber of Commerce in Japan, said Tokyo's practice used to be to parcel out foreign aid grants to Japanese companies. But he said that had changed.

HEADLINE: Shawinigan Journal;
Quebec Libre? His Hometown Won't Think of It

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SHAWINIGAN, Quebec, Aug. 31

 BODY:
They have known him here for years, people like Marcel Brousseau, who as a boy played baseball with him, or the brothers Guy and Gilles Sauvageau, who run a coffee, magazine and tobacco shop where he still occasionally drops in to pass the time of day.
Prime Minister Jean Chretien, the son of a machinist at a local paper mill, comes home every few weeks, the way Harry Truman used to return to Independence, Mo. Mr. Chretien still owns a house in Shawinigan, has family here and knows many townspeople by their first names. 
 With his entourage of aides, bodyguards and reporters, he makes the rounds to try to show that despite years in Government and some off-years as a Bay Street lawyer, he is still, as he likes to call himself, "the little guy from Shawinigan."
On one recent visit, he ordered the daily special for lunch at the Bravo Pizzeria and then walked into the Moderne tavern next door. But he stayed only long enough to win a bet for Leo Sanscartier, another old friend who had wagered with the Moderne's owner Alain Lord he could get the Prime Minister inside the bar.
"He stayed several minutes," said Mr. Lord, "just long enough to shake hands and win Leo $10."
Mr. Chretien, who became Canada's leader last October, remains popular in Shawinigan, a river town at the southeastern edge of deep pine forests halfway between Montreal and Quebec.
It is a clean, tidy town. The Sauvageau shop is a few blocks from a riverside park where children are playing baseball. At one of the downtown squares, Place Mauricienne, their grandparents are playing the ancient French game of boules, a type of lawn bowling. Chez Sauvageau attracts just about everyone in town at one time or another, and Guy Sauvageau says 80 percent of his customers are "pretty happy with Jean Chretien."
But separatist feeling is strong, and a year ago, just before the general elections, polls indicated Mr. Chretien might lose his Shawinigan seat in the House of Commons to the Bloc Quebecois, a national party that wants Quebec to split from Canada.
But then people like Mayor Roland Desaulniers started asking whether the town, which has been severely depressed economically, could afford to pass up the chance to elect the next Prime Minister.
Prime Ministers' hometowns are usually able to dip deeply into the proverbial pork barrel.
The voters listened to their mayor. Mr. Chretien won 53 percent, making Shawinigan one of 19 Quebec seats that went Liberal, against 54 for the separatists. And Mr. Chretien did not let them down.
Smiling broadly, the mayor, a former local businessman, said Shawinigan was doing "a lot better today," acknowledging both a general improvement in economic conditions and a batch of new public projects, from waterworks, roads and sewers, to a new industrial theme park.
Mr. Chretien denies buying votes with federal largesse, but almost with a wink and a nod. He says no one knows how Ottawa works better than he and that therefore he "can make sure" his hometown gets "all the programs available.
Although activity is picking up, Shawinigan still has a long way to go to approach its former prosperity.
Early this century, electric power from the nearby Shawinigan Falls on the St. Maurice River had stimulated rapid economic growth, based on paper, aluminum and chemicals. But old industries have reduced or ceased activity, and few new ones have taken their place.
Many families have had to search elsewhere for work, slashing the population by one-third, to 21,000.
One of the more visible new projects is the $15 million theme park, the Center for the Interpretation of Industry, to highlight Shawinigan's industrial history, stimulate tourism and create local jobs.
The main exhibits are an old aluminum smelter, paper mill and hydroelectric plant, preserved to show what the industrial world looked like in the town's heyday. Plans are to charge tourists up to $10 each to visit the old buildings.
But a study commissioned by the Federal Bureau of Regional Development in Trois Rivieres, 15 miles to the south, concluded that the project was badly organized, would lose money and would close within a year unless bailed out with further grants.
Critics have already mockingly dubbed it "patronage park" and "Jean's World." Yvon Legault, the author of the critical federal study, compared the center to Montreal's ill-fated Museum of Humour, which closed last fall after less than a year.
But locally, the idea of the project is still very popular. It is scheduled to open by June 1996.
The project is also helping the campaign of Mr. Chretien's old friend, Yvon Lemire, a Liberal running for a third term in the Quebec Assembly. On Sept. 12, voters will decide whether incumbent Liberals or the separatist Parti Quebecois will run the province. Mr. Chretien, an ardent federalist, is hoping to see the separatists fail.
In canvassing, Mr. Lemire is using Mr. Chretien's generosity to promote himself as the candidate of jobs and prosperity. "There's been a 60 percent increase in the construction business," he says at the doorstep of Martin Pelletier, a railway brakeman. "This town is really catching up."
Mr. Pelletier gave a noncommital smile.

HEADLINE: Candidate Ties Gubernatorial Bid to Property Taxes

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Sept. 6

 BODY:
In a governor's race in which all the candidates talk tough on crime and promise to purge the government of waste, William E. Curry Jr. has seized onto the state's high property taxes as an issue that highlights his independence from the pack.
While several of his opponents have focused on cutting or eliminating an unpopular income tax introduced in 1991, Mr. Curry has pledged to return about $1 billion from state coffers to cities and towns for property tax relief. The details of the program have met widespread criticism, but Mr. Curry insists that his approach is the only one that challenges the status quo. 
 "If you put all the other candidates on sodium pentothal and asked them which tax hurts working people the most, it would be a no-brainer -- the property tax," he said at a news conference last week. He criticized the others for what he called sloganeering against a well-worn target, the income tax, and added, "I'm trying to move the debate in this election in the direction I think it belongs, in the direction of fundamental change."
 
Considers Himself an Outsider
 The attack was one of the latest in a campaign in which Mr. Curry, a 42-year-old Democrat and the State Comptroller, has cast himself as an irreverent and cerebral political outsider who claims to have enough experience in the trenches of government to succeed in bringing sweeping change.
Mr. Curry has defied the leadership of the state party organization and is running as an insurgent in a tough primary election against John B. Larson, the leader of the State Senate, who won the party's official endorsement in July. With assistance from Stanley Greenberg, the pollster who also counsels President Clinton, Mr. Curry has sought to portray himself in much the same way as the President did two years ago, as an "inside outsider."
In his campaign, Mr. Curry has displayed his governmental savvy with detailed policy proposals, such as the reduction of property taxes and a 32-point plan to fight crime, and stressed his administrative and management skills in running the Comptroller's office.
At the same time, he has positioned himself as an outsider, regularly describing his bid for governor as "the greatest challenge to politics as usual in this state in either party in a generation," and illustrating his campaign literature with a picture of a lightning bolt hitting the State Capitol.
Critics say that Mr. Curry, a former State Senator and the son of a prominent party leader in Hartford, has overstated both his outsider status and the contrasts between him and Mr. Larson.
Indeed, in a recent debate, Mr. Larson remarked: "We agree on an awful lot of things. I'm not sure what our differences are, but I know what makes me different." And then Mr. Larson discussed his personal background.
 
A Three-Way Race
 The winner of the primary next Tuesday will join a three-way race. One opponent will be the victor in the Republican primary between former United States Representative John G. Rowland and Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer; the other will be Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, the nominee of the A Connecticut Party, the party line on which Lowell P. Weicker Jr. was elected governor in 1990.
Mr. Curry has been something of an independent voice in Connecticut politics since he was first elected to the State Senate in the late 1970's and frequently earned the ire of his colleagues and Gov. Ella T. Grasso with his support for liberal causes. After losing an election for Congress in 1982, he became national director of the political action committee of the Nuclear Weapons Freeze movement, and also was an outspoken critic of United States support for the contra fighters in Nicaragua.
Today, Mr. Curry's base of support includes the state employees' unions as well as local citizens and environmental groups. In contrast to Mr. Larson, he supported pay raises for the state unions that were recommended last year by a labor arbitrator and rejected by the Legislature on the ground that money was lacking.
 
Campaign-Finance Laws
 Mr. Curry has called for the state to establish insurance-purchasing pools to help small businesses and self-employed workers reduce the cost of their coverage. He supports a tougher death penalty and stronger discipline in prisons, including requiring inmates to pursue an education.
He also advocates change in campaign finance laws, complaining that lobbyists have exerted undue influence on elections with their contributions.
And most notably, Mr. Curry has pushed his plan to reduce property taxes, showing a zeal for cuts often associated with conservative Republicans, while maintaining that his plan would be more progressive than competing proposals to cut the income tax.
In debating Mr. Larson, who supports a 25 percent income-tax reduction for families earning less than $100,000, Mr. Curry has argued that the property tax is a more serious burden for the middle class.
According to the Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, the state had the third-highest local property tax per capita in the nation in the fiscal year 1992. The Connecticut Conference of Municipalities reported that the state's property tax revenue almost equaled the combined revenue of the sales tax and income tax.
 
Property Tax Relief
 Mr. Curry has said that by the end of his first term in office, he would send $1 billion back to the towns and cities as property tax relief. The money would come from a variety of sources, including about $160 million in payments from two casinos operated by Indian tribes; more than $350 million in revenue that will be available when the state finishes payment on its economic recovery bonds; $200 million by eliminating unfinanced state mandates for municipalities, and a 5 percent across-the-board spending cut for state government.
Critics have pointed out that about $85 million in casino money is already being used as relief for towns and cities, and they note that the Legislature has already committed the money from the bond payments to other types of tax relief. Mr. Curry has also refused to specify what mandates he would cut to save $200 million and has not provided the formula he would use to distribute the money to the state's 169 towns and cities.
While Mr. Larson has called Mr. Curry's property tax proposal laudable, he said that it was not achievable and that he preferred to wait for a legislative commission to issue its recommendations on the matter in January. In the meantime, he said, a smaller income-tax cut would be easier to implement and would provide immediate relief.
But Mr. Curry said that cutting the income tax would preclude cutting the property tax, and he brushed aside the flaws as problems to be overcome once he takes office.
"I'm just trying to put this question at the center of the debate, where it belongs," he said in an interview. "Evening the playing field -- that's the goal here."
"And even if I can't come up with the $200 million in savings from the mandates, this would still be the largest and most important change in the state's tax structure in memory," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Industrial Robots Make the Grade

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
In the early 1980's, when Roger B. Smith, then chairman of the General Motors Corporation, described his vision for the auto industry's future, he imagined factory floors where, one by one, workers would be replaced by robots.
"Every time the cost of labor goes up a dollar an hour," Mr. Smith said, "a thousand more robots become economical." 
 But while hundreds of thousands of jobs were subsequently lost in the American auto industry and other manufacturing businesses, robots had little to do with it. Indeed, the early industrial robots were often expensive, more temperamental than the most recalcitrant worker and in many cases ill suited to the tasks assigned them. By the late 1980's, a steep decline in orders for robotic equipment had driven most American companies -- including G.M. -- out of the business of making industrial robots.
 
Sales Are Booming
 Fortunately for United States manufacturing industries, some small American robot makers stayed the course, as did the big Japanese robotics makers. Today, sales are booming for robots, which are cheaper, stronger, faster and smarter than their predecessors.
Industrial robots are hard at work in the industrial heartland, spot-welding car bodies on auto assembly lines, placing tiny parts on circuit boards in electronics factories and packing frozen hamburger patties into boxes at food-processing plants. And rather than replacing workers in droves, robots are reserved for tasks that either are ill suited to human hand and eye or are so onerous or strenuous that people don't want to do them.
"In the early 1980's robots were a fad and expectations were overly high," said Takeo Kanade, director of the Robotics Institute at Carnegie Mellon University. "Now I think views are a little more practical and realistic."
In the first half of this year, 4,355 robots with a total value of $383.5 million -- a record both in terms of units and dollars -- were sold in the United States, according to the Robotic Industries Association in Ann Arbor, Mich., the industry's principal trade group. That represented a 25 percent increase in value over the first half of 1993, the previous record.
And the industry's backlog of unfilled orders stands at $350 million, the highest in nine years, the association reported. The increase in demand is largely fueled by orders from the automobile companies, although other industries are showing renewed interest, officials of the trade group said.
Lower cost and greater reliability are the keys, said Steven W. Holland, a robotics specialist at General Motors. Prices today are about half what they were 10 years ago for comparable machines and reliability is four times better, he said.
Among other jobs, G.M. uses robots to lay a bead of urethane sealant around the windshield frames of its vehicles before installing the glass. Labor costs are not even an issue, Mr. Holland said. More importantly, it is a task whose uniformity and repetition would make it difficult for human hands to do.
"We use robots to put a urethane seal around windshields very precisely, because we don't want any leaks," Mr. Holland said. "We would install them even where the labor rate is like Mexico's."
And unlike simpler "fixed automation" machinery, designed and built to perform one task and one task only, like a conveyor line, today's robots can be reprogrammed for a new task, while a conventional automated machine would have to be replaced. "We can replace fixed automation with robots with a similar or lower investment," Mr. Holland said.
 
American Giants Pulled Out
 If today's robots are different, so is the lineup of companies making them. No longer in the business are American giants like G.M., Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the General Electric Company, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, all of which chose to bail out.
As a result, the robots that American auto makers and other domestic manufacturers are buying to help fend off the likes of the Toyota Motor Corporation, the Nissan Motor Company and the Honda Motor Company are largely machines that themselves are made in Japan. The Fanuc Robotics Corporation, a unit of Fanuc Ltd. of Japan, is the leader in the United States, with robotic sales expected to reach about $260 million this year.
A unit of the Swedish industrial conglomerate Asea Brown Boveri A.B. is second in the United States robotics market, with sales estimated at $120 million. But after that, the big makers of industrial robots are Japanese: Motoman , the Panasonic Factory Automation Company, Kawasaki Robotics, Sony Component Products and Nachi Robotic Systems, all of which do their manufacturing in Japan.
The only major American producer to have survived is Adept Technology Inc. of San Jose, Calif., which makes robots for light assembly work on circuit boards and electronic devices and was not tied to the boom and bust cycles of the auto business. Still, it has annual sales of only about $50 million in a $700-million-a-year market.
 
Japan's Heavy Use
 One reason that Japanese companies are so powerful in robotics is that they build a lot of the machines for use in their home market. According to the Robot Industries Association, there are about 300,000 industrial robots in use in Japan, compared with 52,000 in the United States.
"The Japanese build more robots each year than we have installed in the United States in total," said Joseph Engelberger, an American who developed the first commercial robot in the mid-1960's. Although Mr. Engelberger received a great deal of attention from Japan at the time, he eventually sold his company, Unimation, to Westinghouse.
He said that American industry's focus on short-run profit was what drove robotics offshore. "I have been to Japan 28 times, and I have never heard a discussion about return on investment" related to robotics, Mr. Engelberger said. "Their attitude is that if a robot can do a job better, then use a robot."
Mr. Engelberger is now developing mobile robots through his own company, the Transitions Research Company in Danbury, Conn. Like some other small companies, Transitions Research is working to improve "service" robots that might serve meals in hospitals or act as watchmen in warehouses. Such applications require finer sensing capabilities and vision systems than most industrial robots now have, which is why the field has yet to take off.
As for the industrial robots used in manufacturing and assembly work, the current leader, Fanuc Robotics of Japan, was not even in the American robotics market until G.M. brought the company into a joint venture in 1981. The initial plans called for joint development of new models of robots, which would be made in the United States. But G.M. ended up serving largely as a marketing conduit for Japanese-made robots, before selling its interest in the venture in 1992 at the depth of General Motors' financial troubles.
Dogged determination to grab market share, regardless of immediate profits, is the reason Japanese rather than American companies dominate the robot business in this country, said Vernon L. Mangold Jr., president of Kohol Systems Inc. in Dayton, Ohio. Kohol has survived as a small producer of robots for special applications, like hot, dirty jobs in the steel industry.
Mr. Mangold said his company had managed to stay alive by seeking out niche markets unattractive to larger producers, which prefer to make standardized machines that can be adapted to work in all sorts of factories. "We work in nasty environments like foundries that the other guys avoid," Mr. Mangold said.
For Adept Technology, the largest American company still in the field, success has come through adapting their robots to the needs of factory managers. Adept aims to make its robots flexible, able easily to learn new jobs, said Charlie Duncheon, vice president for sales and marketing at Adept. "There are products in consumer electronics and personal computers that have a life cycle of six to nine months," he said. "Those people need flexible automation that can be changed rapidly for a new product."
To make the change-overs as quick and painless as possible, robot makers have applied the lessons of personal computers to the "user interface." Instead of having to write new software code to adapt a robot to a new task, for example, users can use a computer mouse, point-and-click commands and successive pull-down menus to make the necessary changes.
"You no longer need a Ph.D. in computer science to program a robot," Mr. Duncheon said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Auto Sales Rose In August

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 6

 BODY:
Calming fears on Wall Street that weak July results signaled an end to the economic recovery, sales of cars and light trucks in the United States resumed their vigorous pace in August, rising 10.3 percent over the comparable month a year ago.
The results released today suggested that the auto makers were correct in attributing the July slowdown to production shortfalls, rather than to a drop in demand. As investors hurriedly bid up auto stocks late in the day, auto executives clearly felt vindicated. 
 "I guess the Street didn't believe it, but this proves that last month's analysis was valid," said William E. Hoglund, the General Motors executive vice president in charge of sales, service, and marketing. "Our story last month was availability."
There is no shortage of buyers, Mr. Hoglund added. "We see a confident consumer," he said. "At the gut level, on the showroom floor the dealers report that the customers are in a buying mood."
Placing a heavy bet that the recovery will continue, the auto makers are planning to raise their fourth-quarter North American output to 3.9 million units, 8.3 percent higher than last year's level, according to Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade weekly.
 
Stocks Rise
 That increase is consistent with solid economic growth, said David L. Littmann, chief economist for the Comerica Bank. "It's a continuing healthy economy," he said. "Not sluggish, not robust in the boom sense."
He predicted that increased exports of cars and trucks would offset any softening in the domestic market and help hold growth higher than 3 percent through 1995.
As the sales reports trickled in late this afternoon, shares of G.M. rose $2.125 to close at $52.25 in heavy trading. Chrysler rose $1, to $48.50, and Ford gained 37.5 cents, to $30.
"The momentum, at least in this segment of the economy, is pretty much intact," said Joseph S. Phillippi, auto industry analyst with Lehman Brothers in New York. The strong sales performance, he said, was "across the board."
Rising interest rates and a drop in mortgage refinancing have taken the edge off the recovery without stopping it, according to many auto analysts.
But interest rates have not risen enough to frighten away consumers who simply need to trade in their aging cars, said Gurudutte Baliga, assistant portfolio manager for IDS Financial Services in Minneapolis. Mr. Baliga said 25 percent of the vehicles on the road, or more than 40 million cars and light trucks, were more than 10 years old.
Production constraints continue to hold back sales. G.M., for example, was able to increase supplies of its popular Blazer sport utility vehicle and Lumina midsized car from July to August. But, because of plant shutdowns to prepare for new models, it still has no Chevrolet Cavaliers or Pontiac Sunfires, two small cars that are expected to sell in large numbers.
Similarly, Ford's car sales slipped 9.4 percent for the month, to 145,131, in large part because it had halted production of two small cars, the Ford Tempo and Mercury Topaz. Ford has not yet replaced them with two new, larger cars, the Contour and Mystique, which are to go on sale on Sept. 29.
Dealers reported that inventory shortages could prevent them from taking advantage of strong demand in coming months. Normally, dealers increase their sales in September and October as they clear out the previous year's models to make space for the new versions.
"Our tremendous sales in August almost wiped out our entire inventory," said John Kaestner, general sales manager at Evanston Toyota in Evanston, Ill. "There isn't anything left for cleanup. I'm begging for inventory."
During August, sales of all cars, whether built in North America or imported, rose 8.1 percent, to 782,583. Sales of light trucks -- a category that includes pickups, mini-vans and sport utility vehicles -- rose 13.8 percent, to 518,242.
 
Saturn Sales Up
 Within the generally strong market there were some notably impressive performers. At G.M., sales of Saturn small cars almost doubled, to 31,814.
While the Honda Motor Company posted a mild gain of 5.2 percent in car sales, total sales of its Accord surged ahead of Ford's Taurus for the first time this year. But a spokesman for Honda, Art Garner, said that because Ford could easily increase its fleet sales, the Taurus would probably edge the Accord for the sales crown again in 1994.
Toyota posted a gain of 23.4 percent in total vehicle sales for the month, to 127,129. Because of the high resale value of its cars, Toyota has offered generous lease deals, since people who lease pay only for the value of the car that they use during their contract, typically two or three years. Leasing has helped Toyota dull the price increases forced on it by the strength of the Japanese yen.
In addition, Mr. Phillippi the analyst said, buyers appear willing to pay premiums of more than $3,000 because of the perception of Japanese quality. "There's no question that there's still a fairly high owner loyalty out there among import buyers," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
American Express Offers New Card

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
The American Express Company, making a long-awaited drive for a market far larger than globe-trotters and executives on the town, introduced a new credit card yesterday, its first with no annual fee.
The new mass-market challenge to banks that issue Visa and Mastercard reflects a change of strategy at American Express. Under Harvey Golub, its chairman for the last year and a half, the company has chosen to play down the trademark green and gold charge cards, which require payment in full and carry a high annual fee. 
 Mr. Golub has concluded that there is more money to be made in the highly competitive card market by charging interest on unpaid card balances. The company plans to introduce 10 to 15 cards with various features in an effort to quadruple its credit-card balances to about $30 billion, which would earn $450 million to $600 million in interest and fees a year.
 
Grace Period Offered
 The first card in the line, called the Optima True Grace card, is intended to appeal to people who typically run high balances on their cards. Its most unusual feature is that interest will not be charged on any purchases until 25 days after the date the card holder's bill is printed. Most other card companies offer a grace period only if the account is paid in full; otherwise, interest is charged from the date of purchase.
After the grace period, American Express will charge the prime rate (now 7.75 percent) plus 8.75 percent. That rate is slightly less than that charged by large mass-market card issuers. Citibank, for example, the leading credit-card provider, charges the prime rate plus 9.9 percent on its most popular cards. For the first six months, American Express will offer the Optima True Grace card with a "teaser" rate of 7.9 percent.
Credit-card consultants said that the grace-period feature appeared to be designed to encourage consumers to use the card for both borrowing and spending. Many credit-card holders use one card for their revolving balances and another -- with a grace period -- for spending that they intend to pay off every month.
"The biggest problem banks have is that people transfer funds onto their cards and let them sit," said Stephen M. Szekely, a credit-card consultant with Payment Systems Inc. of Tampa, Fla. "American Express has come up with a nice innovation to maintain usage levels."
 
A Costly Feature
 It is a costly feature, however. Most banks earn interest on 90 percent of their credit-card balances, because 80 percent of the balances are rolled over from previous months and roughly half of new purchases are subject to finance charges, Mr. Szekely said.
Because American Express will not charge interest on any new balances, its earnings from the card will be cut by one to two percentage points, Mr. Szekely said.
The company will partly compensate for the lost interest, however, because it charges merchants a higher fee than banks that issue Mastercard and Visa cards.
Consumers will probably pay about 1 percent less a year using the Optima True Grace card than a typical card with the same nominal interest rate, experts said, although that could vary depending on how the cards are used.
The stock of American Express rose $1.375 yesterday, to $30.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
This is not the first venture by American Express into revolving-credit cards. In 1987, it introduced the original Optima card, which was successful in the marketplace, but the company ultimately lost more than $1 billion on unpaid Optima balances. That card was offered only to people who also had American Express charge cards, and as a result it attracted a disproportionate amount of customers who were in debt over their heads.
 
Learning From Mistakes
 American Express said it had learned its lesson and had invested in new loan approval systems.
"Good judgment comes from bad experience," said Phillip J. Reise, president of the company's credit-card group. "Let's say we now have excellent judgment."
The original Optima card is still being offered and has rates as low as the prime rate plus 6 points.

HEADLINE: Dow Posts a 13.12 Rise In Light, Aimless Day

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market edged higher yesterday, with trading thin as Rosh ha-Shanah began and the long Labor Day weekend ended.
General Motors' announcement in the late afternoon of strong August auto sales lifted the Dow Jones industrial average slightly, but there was little indication of the general direction of stocks. The dollar fell and so did bonds, eroding the limited gain in equity prices. 
 The Dow industrials rose 13.12 points, to 3,898.70, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 rose 0.87 point, to 471.86. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite was up 0.25 point, to 759.48.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 199.9 million shares, about 30 percent below this year's average of 286 million shares a day and 25 percent below the even more subdued summer volume of 266 million.
James B. Stack, president of Investech Research, predicted that the Dow would establish a trading range between 3,750 and 3,950 over the next three weeks or so. Between April and late August, the Dow generally traded between 3,600 and 3,800.
 
Qualified Gloom
 But Mr. Stack said that market prospects would darken in the fourth quarter as traders began to realize that contrary to current assessments, the economy was not slowing. The Federal Reserve, he said, would again have to raise interest rates.
He advises taking profits on technology stocks like Compaq, which gained 3/8 yesterday to close at 35 3/8, and Microsoft, which was unchanged at 56, as well as on military-related issues like McDonnell Douglas and Raytheon. And he urged cutting losses on stocks like Wall Street brokerage houses and electric utilities because of their vulnerability to rising interest rates. Investech, based in Whitefish, Mont., provides technical market research to institutional and individual investors.
Louis G. Navellier, a big portfolio manager and newsletter writer in Incline Village, Nev., said he was bullish, but not by much. "We're meandering higher," he said. "I'll make maybe 3 percent this month, and the market will make 2 percent."
The reason? "September is usually a horrible month because of profit taking and window-dressing," Mr. Navellier said, alluding to the kind of trading that takes place as the third quarter closes. "But it won't be as bad as usual because there aren't any profits to take, and there are too many dogs to throw out the window."
Three stocks -- General Motors, American Express and Eastman Kodak -- accounted for nearly all the rise in the Dow yesterday.
 
Statistics From Detroit
 G.M. was up 2 1/8, to 52 1/4, with almost all of the rise coming after the auto maker's announcement at 2:50 P.M. that August vehicle sales had been better than expected; domestic cars were up 17 percent and domestic trucks were up 15 percent, over the period a year earlier. Chrysler also reported strong growth, but Ford reported weaker than expected sales.
American Express, the most active stock, with 3.9 million shares changing hands, rose 1 3/8, to 30 3/8, after the company introduced a new version of its Optima credit card. The Optima True Grace card will have a 25-day grace period before interest is charged on outstanding balances.
Eastman Kodak rose 1 1/8, to 51 1/4, after announcing the $1 billion sale of its clinical-diagnostics business, which makes cancer-screening machines and other equipment, to Johnson & Johnson, which slipped 1/8, to 50.
Sears, Roebuck, which fell Friday despite reporting August sales growth of 5.2 percent, rose 3/4, to 47 1/2.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index rose 0.18 point, with 956 advancing stocks lagging behind 1,142 declining issues. The American Stock Exchange market value index rose 0.46 point, to 456.00.
Of the 30 stocks that make up the Dow industrials, 15 rose. Of the 500 component stocks that make up the S. &P. 500, 228 rose.

HEADLINE: MUSIC NOTES;
Orchestras Merge Business Resources

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
In an innovative managerial arrangement, the American Symphony Orchestra has taken the chamber orchestra Concordia under its wing. Concordia, founded 10 years ago by Marin Alsop to explore American music, particularly concert music with jazz influences, will retain its own board of trustees, keep its own books and pursue its own artistic goals. But the American Symphony Orchestra will oversee the presentation of its concerts, as well as its marketing and fund raising.
"What we're trying to do," explained Eugene Carr, the executive director of the American Symphony, "is to create a new way to manage the arts by combining resources. It seem ridiculous that if you have a dozen organizations, each producing a small number of events every year, you also have a dozen executive directors, a dozen office leases, a dozen marketing departments. None of the organizations can really afford to engage as much staff as it needs." 
 Concordia presents only four concerts a year. The American Symphony Orchestra presents six programs but is also in residence at the Bard Music Festival, has a chamber series and tours. Combining the two organizations allows for what Mr. Carr called "an economy of scale." Concordia will pay the American Symphony a fee for its management services for the next three years, but the arrangement should represent a saving of 40 percent in administrative costs for the orchestra.
What the American Symphony gets out of the relationship, in addition to the management fee, is a slightly expanded staff, which will work for both orchestras. Collaborative projects are also under discussion.
"Everybody is looking for ways to cut overhead these days," Mr. Carr said. "We think the way to do that is to work more efficiently. The American Symphony and Concordia are two different kinds of ensembles. But producing concerts, marketing, dealing with boards and raising money are similar from one organization to the next. By streamlining all these support functions, we are able to show foundations that more of the grant money they give us actually goes toward artistic programs, not toward light bulbs and rent."
 
Americans in Bucharest
 Contemporary American music has not had much of a presence in Romanian concert halls, but the composer Tobias Picker and the conductors Sergiu Comissiona and Cristian Mandeal, with sponsorship from the United States Embassy and Delta Airlines, plan to remedy that with a weeklong festival starting on Sunday at the Atheneum in Bucharest.
Music by few dozen American composers, representing virtually every contemporary style, will be performed in the festival, which will include three concerts by Mr. Mandeal's orchestra, the George Enescu Philharmonic, and two concerts of chamber and vocal works. Among the composers whose works are scheduled are John Adams, Leonard Bernstein, Samuel Barber, Elliott Carter, David Diamond, Conlon Nancarrow, Aaron Copland, Michael Daugherty, Ned Rorem, Jacob Druckman, George Gershwin, Joan Tower, William Schuman, Paul Schoenfield and Mr. Picker. Works by Warren Davidson and Regina Keane will have their world premieres.
"Romania has a great musical tradition," Mr. Picker said, "but they've hardly heard any American music, and with the exception of Copland and Bernstein, they don't even know the names of American composers." Mr. Picker, who is leaving for Bucharest on Sept. 4 to oversee the final preparations, is taking the pianist Ursula Oppens and the violinist Robert McDuffie, both well-known interpreters of American works.
Mr. Picker began thinking about presenting American music in Bucharest two years ago. He had been the composer in residence at the Houston Symphony, where Mr. Comissiona was the director. He proposed the idea of a festival to Mr. Comissiona, who is Romanian. Mr. Comissiona made the connection with Mr. Mandeal and his ensemble.
"When I was composer in residence in Houston," Mr. Picker said, "I spent my time bringing American music to Americans. And even then, I thought that the next logical step would be to export our music, to bring it to countries that have a Western musical tradition, but for whom our music would be completely new."
The concerts are to be recorded by the Romanian Composers Union, and there is talk of a highlights CD, although Mr. Picker was not sure whether it would be released in the United States.
 
Opera Guide
 For the itinerant opera fan who needs a way to know what's playing where, Opera America publishes an annual guide that lists schedules and production information (but not casts) for most American and a handful of foreign companies.
This year's edition, snappily titled "Season Schedule of Performances 1994-95," runs 128 pages (up from 104 last year) and lists the offerings of more than 100 companies affiliated with Opera America, a 24-year-old organization that provides information, advice and administrative services for professional opera companies.
The listings, arranged by company, include mailing addresses, administrative and box office phone numbers, and seating capacities. There is also a listing of world premieres and a works index that allows readers to track their favorite operas, or to see at a glance that Puccini's "Boheme," with 28 productions scheduled from Hawaii to Finland, is getting the best coverage.
The pocket-size book is available for $12 (plus a $3 handling fee per order) from Opera America, 777 14th Street NW, Suite 520, Washington D.C., 20005, or by fax, (202) 393-0735.
 
New Met Butterfly
 When the Metropolitan Opera announced its schedule for the coming season, Carol Vaness was listed in the title role of a new production of "Madama Butterfly," to be staged by Giancarlo del Monaco. But by the time the season brochure was ready to go to press, Miss Vaness withdrew, saying she had decided not to add the role to her repertory at this time. (She will still sing Elettra in "Idomeneo" and the title role in "Tosca" at the Met this season.) Last week the Met found a replacement: Catherine Malfitano, an American soprano who has lately been spending most of her time in Europe and has sung the role to some acclaim at La Scala, Covent Garden and the Vienna State Opera.
 
Hemidemisemiquavers
 *Patricia Racette, a soprano from New Hampshire who is to make her Metropolitan Opera debut this season (as Musetta in "La Boheme"), is the recipient of the 1994 Marian Anderson Award, a $25,000 stipend given annually to a young singer who has shown professional promise. The singers are nominated by critics, artistic directors and managers of opera companies and orchestras, and they do not know they are being considered for the prize. Miss Racette, the fifth winner of the award, has been singing at the San Francisco Opera since 1989 and has also performed since then with the New York City Opera, the Vienna State Opera and the Welsh National Opera.
*The finalists for the 1994 Kennedy Center Friedheim Awards for the best new American works are Leon Kirchner, for his Music for Cello and Orchestra; John Anthony Lennon, for "Zingari," a guitar concerto; Tison Street for "Bright Sambas," and Jay Alan Yim for "Rain Palace." They were selected from 125 entries. The final ranking (first prize is $5,000, fourth prize $500) is to be announced on Oct. 1, after the works are performed by the National Symphony Orchestra in a free concert at the Kennedy Center in Washington.
*James Ehnes, a Canadian violinist, was awarded the first Ivan Galamian Memorial Prize, a $25,000 career grant. The prize was established by the board of the Meadowmount School of Music, the retreat for string players that Galamian founded in 1944 in Westport, N.Y. Galamian, who also taught at the Juilliard School and the Curtis Institute, died in 1981.
*Mark Anderson, a pianist from California, won the $20,000 first prize in the 22d University of Maryland William Kappell Piano Competition. The prize includes a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Nov. 12. Stanislav Judenich of Uzbekistan won the second prize ($10,000), and Armen Babakhanian of Armenia won the third prize ($5,000).

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Living Desk 

LENGTH: 2704 words

HEADLINE: GREAT COOKS: Linda McCartney;
Lots of Smidgens, But Hold the Meat

BYLINE: By BRYAN MILLER 

 BODY:
"ARE you a veggie?" is the usual salutation of Linda McCartney, cookbook author, photographer, musician and wife of Paul McCartney, the songwriter and performer.
Mrs. McCartney recently went to the East Hampton, L.I., home of the chef Pierre Franey to discuss her passion for vegetarian cooking and to prepare a meal from her cookbook, "Linda McCartney's Home Cooking" (Arcade Publishing, 1989). Traipsing behind her was her vegetable-loving husband, wearing baggy plaid shorts, sandals and a blue sweatshirt and carrying a guitar. 
 "I grew up in a family that loved good food, but I was the one who really liked to cook," she said while quickly getting down to business by chopping onions, carrots and leeks for a vegetable soup. "When I was growing up in Scarsdale, we had a cook. Maybe because of my insecurity or whatever I used to hang around the kitchen and watch her."
Mrs. McCartney, 52, disarmingly earthy and outgoing, has been married to the ex-Beatle for 25 years and has four children: Heather, 31 (from a previous marriage); Mary, 25; Stella, 23, and James, 17.
She was wearing blue jeans and a colorful peasant blouse -- "I'm a peasant cook," she said -- that set off her straw-colored hair and pellucid green eyes. Mr. McCartney, also 52, watched his wife buzz around the kitchen for an hour before quietly carrying his left-handed Martin acoustic guitar into the den for -- what else? -- a songwriting session.
"Don't mind me," he said. "I'll watch for a while, then go into another room to play a little." The McCartneys spend a few weeks each summer in East Hampton, near Mrs. McCartney's stepmother, Monique Eastman.
"Paul really is a great bread maker," Mrs. McCartney said while assembling her soup. "During the bread strike in England he made it every day at home."
Mr. McCartney said: "My best dish is mashed potatoes. A little milk, some chopped onions -- that's the Liverpool version."
Mrs. McCartney's devotion to meatless cooking goes beyond her household south of London. Three years ago she introduced in England a line of frozen vegetarian entrees: lasagna, pasta, burgers, pot pies, goulash and more. Today the line, which bears her name, carries 18 items and has more than $40 million in sales annually. Once the initial investment is recouped, she said, she plans to give the profits to charity.
In this country, Linda McCartney's Homestyle Cooking entrees, produced by Fairmont Foods outside Minneapolis, were test-marketed in the Midwest this year and are to be introduced on the West Coast next month and on the East Coast by year-end. Single-portion entrees will cost about $3 each.
For the meal at Mr. Franey's home, Mrs. McCartney prepared vegetable soup, an eggplant casserole laced with fresh herbs, coleslaw and applesauce cake.
"Most people don't know how good vegetarian food can be," she said. "Look at this vegetable soup. You know where the flavor comes from? Sauteing the vegetables in a little oil first."
The McCartneys, who raise sheep for wool and have an organic farm two hours south of London, in Berkshire, have been vegetarians for more than 20 years. An abhorrence of animal slaughter is at the root of the couple's aversion to meat.
"It really all started with the animals," Mr. McCartney said. "We were sitting home having dinner one day, and there were some lambs running around outside on our farm. They were so cute, and we were sitting there eating meat. Before that it never occurred to us that maybe we should look into another way."
He added that for the first year of their meatless lives, "there was this big hole in the middle of the plate, you know, because we were so used to meals built around meat."
"Then gradually," he continued, "Linda started filling that hole by cooking vegetables in interesting ways."
At the drop of a scallion Mrs. McCartney cites statistics on animal carnage and on the global economic efficiency of vegetarianism. And she never misses an opportunity to underscore her beliefs. When she spotted some ceramic figurines of pigs and cows on Mr. Franey's windowsill, she remarked, "Oh, those are cute, but they sure look different when they're murdered."
Mrs. McCartney refers to meat as "flesh" or when giving extra emphasis to a point, "a slab of fear." The McCartney children, all raised without meat, poultry or fish, have remained vegetarians.
"When the kids were growing up I said: 'Hey, we're going veggie. I don't want to cook meat anymore,' " she recalled. "If they wanted to eat differently out of the house, fine. But as it turned out, they were all sympathetic."
Even though all the children except James are now on their own, the McCartneys describe themselves as homebodies. "We don't get out that much, unless we're on tour or something," Mr. McCartney said.
"Yes, but the house is always full," Mrs. McCartney said. "The kids come by; we have friends over." At their East Hampton rental house the week before, they had entertained guests -- including Paul Simon, Lorne Michaels and his wife, Alice -- with a vegetarian dinner.
Mrs. McCartney noted that she was working on an updated vegetarian cookbook. Her current book has sold more than 250,000 copies worldwide, she said.
As she spoke, she sliced fat late-summer eggplant for the casserole, which was liberally seasoned with fresh basil and oregano and onion. She is hardly Julia Child-like when it comes to precision with ingredients. Everything is added in handfuls, pinches, smidgens. Her favorite measurement is "lots of."
"Linda, should I add half a tablespoon of oregano or a whole tablespoon?" Mr. Franey said.
"Go ahead, throw it all in, Pierre," she replied with a wave of her hand. Mr. Franey chuckled and followed orders.
Mrs. McCartney clearly enjoys serving flavorful food. She undertook a daunting challenge two years ago while on a world tour with her husband's band (she played keyboards and sang) and road crew, a total of 140 people.
"Before the tour the promoter told us that we had to pay for our food on the road," Mr. McCartney said. "We thought, wow, we have to think about how to do this." Mrs. McCartney decided that it would be a good idea for both health and economic reasons to do a vegetarian tour.
Working with a caterer, Mrs. McCartney devised menus for every day, with several choices for each course listed on a blackboard.
"The food was so good that most people didn't miss meat at all," Mr. McCartney said. "We even got a few converts by the time it was over."
Mr. McCartney then indulged in some Beatles culinary nostalgia. "When the Beatles were starting and playing in clubs around Liverpool," he said, "my father, on his days off, would make a batch of mashed potatoes and stuff and bring it down so we would have something to eat."
Mrs. McCartney placed her eggplant casserole in the oven, then started on the applesauce cake. "Lots of lemon zest gives it flavor," she said while running a lemon over a grater. The simple, semisweet and moist cake was redolent of cinnamon and nutmeg and studded with Mr. McCartney's favorite nuts, pecans.
"Pierre, do you have any organic eggs?" Mrs. McCartney asked Mr. Franey, prompting a surprised look, as if he had been asked to sing a few bars of "Penny Lane."
While the nonorganic cake was being assembled, Mr. McCartney ducked into the den with his guitar to work on a song. Reading lyrics scribbled on a sheet of paper, he ran through two verses of a sweet-sounding ballad having to do with a poor boy in love.
"I do it very simply at first, just to get the feeling," he said. "It's just like cooking, you know -- a simple expression can be the best."
Back in the kitchen, Mr. Franey turned to Mrs. McCartney and said, "Mademoiselle, did you put the timer on before you put the cake in the oven?"
"No," she replied, unconcerned."We'll know when it's ready."
Aside from her culinary pursuits, Mrs. McCartney is a well-known photographer of rock stars and other subjects. In the mid-1960's, when she was known as Linda Eastman (no connection with the Eastman-Kodak Company), the daughter of a prominent New York entertainment lawyer, Lee Eastman, she worked as a receptionist at Town & Country magazine.
"One day, an invitation came in to the editors for an event called Meet the Rolling Stones," she recalled. "I snagged the invitation and put it in my drawer. I got caught, but they didn't want to go anyway, so they said I could go."
Carrying her Pentax camera and trying to look like a professional, she went to a pier on Manhattan's West Side, where the party was being held on a boat.
"When I got there they told me that there was not enough room on the boat for all the journalists and all the photographers, so they turned to me and said, 'O.K., you will be the only photographer on the boat.' "
The photographs she sold to magazines around the country instantly established her reputation. Mrs. McCartney used her newfound stature to photograph dozens of leading rock musicians in the 1960's and 70's -- including Paul McCartney, whom she met while photographing the Beatles in 1967. They were married two years later. In 1992 she published a coffee table book of her musician portraits and had a traveling exhibition of her work in the United States.
Back at Mr. Franey's, the finished meal was arranged on a table outside. Mr. McCartney eagerly strode out, sat down and tucked a napkin into the neck of his sweatshirt.
"You don't mind having photos taken?" his wife asked.
"Not if I get some soup," he replied.
Later, as the last of the apple cake was consumed, Mr. Franey declared the meal a great success: the soup was full flavored and perfumed with summery herbs, the eggplant well textured and tasty, the coleslaw bright and fresh and the applecake homey and moist. Mr. Franey had to concede that he initially had harbored doubts about Mrs. McCartney's free-form style of cooking.
"Next time, I want to invite you here and I will cook my own version of a vegetarian dinner," he said to Mrs. McCartney.
"Wonderful!" she replied.
"We're going home on Tuesday," her sated husband said. "Maybe we could do it before then?"
THE following recipes are adapted from "Linda McCartney's Home Cooking" (Arcade Publishing, 1989).

Vegetable Soup
Total time: 1 hour 30 minutes
 
 3 tablespoons olive oil
1 large onion, peeled and chopped
2 cups trimmed (greens included), cleaned and sliced leeks
2 cups chopped celery
1 clove garlic, crushed
1 1/2 cups unpeeled, sliced carrots
1 cup shredded cabbage
2 cups unskinned cubed new potatoes
1 teaspoon fresh thyme
1 teaspoon fresh rosemary
1 teaspoon fresh parsley
6 cups vegetable stock (fresh or canned)
8 medium tomatoes or 1 16-ounce can of crushed tomatoes
Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste.
1. Heat the oil in a soup pot over medium flame, and saute the onions, leeks, celery and garlic for 5 minutes. Do not brown the garlic.
2. Add the carrots, cabbage and potatoes. Stir well. Add the thyme, rosemary and parsley. Cover with vegetable stock and simmer, covered, for 1 hour. Stir occasionally, adding water if evaporation is excessive.
3. If you are using fresh tomatoes, place them on top of the simmering liquid for about 2 minutes, or until their skins can be easily peeled away. Remove the tomatoes with a slotted spoon, and when they are cool enough to handle, remove the skins. Gently crush the whole skinned tomatoes and stir them into the soup. If you are using canned tomatoes, stir them, liquid and all, into the soup.
4. Season to taste. Serve hot.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 230 calories, 9 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 145 milligrams sodium (before salting), 7 grams protein, 35 grams carbohydrate.
 
Eggplant and Herb Casserole
Total time: 2 hours
 
 2 1/2 pounds ripe plum tomatoes (or 1 28-ounce can crushed imported tomatoes)
 10 tablespoons olive oil
 1large onion, peeled and chopped
 2 tablespoons minced garlic
 1 6-ounce can tomato paste
 1 tablespoon chopped fresh oregano (or 1/2 tablespoon dried)
 1 tablespoon chopped fresh basil ( 1/2 tablespoon)
 1 teaspoon chopped fresh thyme (or 1/2 teaspoon dried)
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 3/4 cup all-purpose flour for dredging
 2 eggplants, about 1 pound each, sliced1/4 inch thick on a slight bias
 8 ounces whole milk mozzarella, thinly sliced.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees, and lightly grease a baking dish or gratin dish (14-by-9 1/2 oblong or 10-by-6 rectangular).
2. If using fresh plum tomatoes, plunge them into a pot of boiling water for 10 seconds, lift out with a slotted spoon and remove the skins. Core and cube them to yield 4 cups.
3. Heat 1 tablespoon of the olive oil in a saucepan, and saute the onion and garlic. Cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Add the plum tomatoes (or canned tomatoes), then the tomato paste. Add the oregano, basil and thyme.
4. Stir well, and bring the sauce to a simmer. Cook, covered, over low heat for 30 minutes, adding salt and freshly ground pepper if necessary.
5. Meanwhile, place the flour in a bowl. Dredge the eggplant slices in the flour. Use the rest of the olive oil, little by little, to saute the eggplant slices over medium heat -- about 2 minutes per side, or until lightly browned.
6. Pour a layer of tomato sauce over the bottom of the baking dish, and layer some cooked eggplant over that. Alternate the rest of the sauce and eggplant in layers. Arrange eggplant slices over the top. Cover with sliced mozzarella. Bake for 1 hour or until the surface is golden brown.
Yield: 8 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 360 calories, 25 grams fat, 20 milligrams cholesterol, 320 milligrams sodium (before salting), 10 grams protein, 30 grams carbohydrate.
 
Coleslaw
Total time: 10 minutes
 
 3/4 of a small head of cabbage, sliced as thinly as possible
 5 ounces olive oil (extra virgin preferred)
 4 ounces red wine vinegar
 Juice of one lemon
 Salt and freshly ground pepper to taste
 1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley.
1. Place the sliced cabbage in a large mixing bowl.
2. Combine the remaining ingredients, and blend thoroughly. Season to taste. Pour over cabbage, and toss well.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 185 calories, 20 grams fat, 0 milligrams cholesterol, 11 milligrams sodium (before salting), 1 gram protein, 4 grams carbohydrate.
 
Applesauce Cake
Total time: 1 hour 50 minutes
 Butter for greasing cake tin
 4 Rome apples, cored, peeled and sliced
 4 tablespoons water
 1/2 cup sugar
 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
 1/2 teaspoon chopped lemon peel
 Juice of half a lemon
 4 ounces softened butter
 1/2 cup light brown sugar
 1 teaspoon vanilla
 1 egg
 2 cups all-purpose flour
 2 teaspoons baking soda
 2teaspoons baking powder
 Pinch of salt
 2/3 cup chopped pecans
 1 cup raisins
 1/2 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg
 1/8 teaspoon cinnamon.
1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees, and lightly grease an 8-inch cake tin.
2. In a deep saucepan over medium heat, combine the apples, 4 tablespoons water, 1/2 cup sugar, 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon, chopped lemon peel and lemon juice. Barely cover with water, bring to a boil, reduce heat to a simmer and cook, stirring, until the mixture reduces and thickens -- about 20 minutes. Mash the mixture to a smooth consistency.
3. Meanwhile, in a mixing bowl, cream together the butter and brown sugar. Add the vanilla, and beat well; then the egg, and beat well.
4. Add butter mixture to the apple mixture. Into a separate bowl, sift together the flour, baking soda, baking powder and salt.
5. Add the pecans, raisins, nutmeg and cinnamon. Stir well.
6. Add the dry mixture to the apple mixture and stir to make a smooth batter. Transfer to the greased cake tin. Smooth the top with a spatula or knife, and bake for about 1 hour and 35 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted in the middle comes out clean.
Yield: 6 to 8 servings.
Approximate nutritional analysis per serving: 550 calories, 20 grams fat, 65 milligrams cholesterol, 635 milligrams sodium, 6 grams protein, 85 grams carbohydrate.

HEADLINE: Clinton Has Opportunity to Act Wisely on Cuba

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Clinton Administration officials insist that Fidel Castro is directing the flow of refugees fleeing Cuba. They, and much of the United States media, portray President Castro as the dictator in control of the floodgates, which he cynically opens and closes at will, forcing out thousands of unhappy Cubans. Such a distorted picture has plunged President Clinton into a policy quagmire. Mr. Castro cannot now stop the exodus; only a change in United States policy will stem the human tide. 
 In the last few years increasing numbers of Cuban refugees hijacked boats and planes to reach Florida. The hijackers were always given a hero's welcome in Miami, and their feats were broadcast to Cuba over the United States-financed Radio Marti. Whenever the Cuban Government successfully interdicted such illegal emigration, the United States accused it of committing human rights violations and classified those arrested as political prisoners.
Some Cubans trying to flee became emboldened by this express approval of their efforts in the United States. They increasingly used violence to overcome the Cuban police and those loyal to the Government who attempted to stop them.
Last year two Cuban police officers were bound and shot in cold blood by a group trying to steal a boat to set out on the Florida Straits. In two incidents in July, hijackers forced those not wishing to leave to jump overboard or take a dangerous journey against their will.
On July 13, an attempt to steal a tugboat ended in tragedy. Thirty people drowned when a botched effort to thwart the flight resulted in the sinking of the 19th-century vessel. The Clinton Administration branded the tragedy an example of Cuban brutality. Many Cubans, even high-level party members, felt the Government should not try to stop those fleeing.
Although increased military and police force might prevent some from leaving, it also increases the likelihood of violence and loss of life. Mr. Castro cannot risk the domestic consequences of attempting to solve unilaterally a problem the United States helped create. Administration inflexibility is counterproductive, and the insistence that Cuba's leadership commit political suicide is not viable.
The hand of Jorge Mas Canosa, the ultra-right-wing Miami expatriate, seems to dictate United States policy and can only strengthen the resolve of the Cubans in Cuba to tough it out. It is unrealistic to expect two generations of Cubans who have sacrificed for the revolution to surrender voluntarily to a man loathed by Cubans at home and by those who have suffered from his vengeance in Miami.
President Clinton, however, could chart a new course that would curtail the flight and avoid a crisis of still greater proportions. A modest shift in United States policy -- engaging in direct talks on a broad range of issues while lifting the embargo on food and medicine -- would provide the Cuban people some hope that things will improve. By easing the economic suffering even minimally, President Clinton would demonstrate that he, not Mr. Mas Canosa, is in charge and that the long-term interests of the United States and the Cuban people come before the ambitions of a narrow segment of expatriates.
Cubans would have reason to stay and work out the inevitable transition. Such reasonable measures would help open a broader debate in Cuba, leading to peaceful, democratic change.
 
DEBRA EVENSON
Chicago, Sept. 2, 1994
The writer, who has spent the last 11 months in Cuba on research financed by the John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation, is author of "Revolution in the Balance: Law and Society in Contemporary Cuba" (1994).

HEADLINE: Don't Call Unemployment a Jobs Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Secretary of Labor Robert B. Reich's boastful summary of the Clinton Administration's "work-force agenda" in "The Fracturing of the Middle Class" (Op-Ed, Aug. 31) is political disingenuousness. 
 It is not just "Wall Street" that "frets" that "unemployment is too low to contain inflation." Mr. Reich knows that the Administration, Congress and the Federal Reserve are determined to keep people out of work to depress wages and salaries.
The creation of 2.5 million jobs in the last year is not "progress," and Mr. Reich knows it. He has repeatedly acknowledged that most of the new jobs are part time, low paid or both.
The accepted policy to maintain at least 6 percent unemployment while labeling it "full employment" insures that the number of people out of work increases as the work force grows. Mr. Reich knows this, and knows that it is a formula for social disaster. When will he propose a real jobs policy?
 
FREDERICK C. THAYER
Pittsburgh, Sept. 1, 1994
The writer is a retired professor of public and international affairs at the University of Pittsburgh.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (79%);

HEADLINE: Don't Call Unemployment a Jobs Plan;
Meanwhile at the Fed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Jobs Versus Inflation at the Fed" (editorial, Aug. 30) states that I "called last week for the Fed to use monetary policy to bring down unemployment from temporary high levels." Not so. I even voted to raise the discount rate on Aug. 16. 
 You also suggest that my "declaration may have been designed to enhance the likelihood that the White House would elevate him to the Fed chairmanship when Mr. Greenspan's term expires." That is untrue; your very next sentence notes that I "preached the same doctrine as an academic and before Congress." Not all statements by high government officials are Machiavellian. Some are simply honest and lack an ulterior motive.
 
ALAN S. BLINDER
Vice Chairman, Board of Governors
Federal Reserve System
Washington, Sept. 2, 1994

HEADLINE: Missing Boat: Perils in a Life at Sea, and on Land

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GLOUCESTER, Mass., Sept. 6

 BODY:
The women of this fishing community have a covenant with their men. They don't tell their husbands how much they worry when the men are at sea, for days and sometimes weeks on end.
And the men don't tell their wives about the waves crashing over the deck in 50-mile-per-hour gales, or the ice on the masts in winter, or the freighters they can't see in the fog. And they never, never admit that sometimes they are afraid. 
 "I'll overhear my husband telling someone else about the boat hanging up, or a guy almost getting thrown overboard," said Jane Russo, 31, who met her husband, Vincenzo, when she was 15 and a waitress at Dulie's Coffee Shop, down by the docks. "But he never tells me."
 
Searching for Survivors
 This is how things are here even now, even as the men and women of this economically battered, close-knit town of Italian and Portuguese immigrant heritage grieves for the four fishermen whose boat went down in a storm 100 miles east of Cape Cod early on Monday. The missing men are not just names here; they are people most everyone knows.
The Coast Guard is still searching for the crewmen, all experienced hands who had weathered far worse storms than Monday's, but the people of Gloucester are beginning to lose hope. Only an automatic distress signal was received from the 78-foot trawler, the Italian Gold. A Canadian helicopter followed it to the overturned vessel, which sank 15 minutes later, but saw no sign of survivors.
"It doesn't look good," said Mrs. Russo, who has three small children and a husband on another boat.
Mrs. Russo and some of the other fishermen's wives were talking over coffee this evening in the basement of St. Ann's Church after a Mass for the the Italian Gold's crew. The missing men's wives, Donna Curcuru, Alise Carrapichosa, Joanne Govinco and Vera Curcuru (no relation to Donna Curcuru), were in seclusion, at home with their children.
Sinkings are rare, but the risk is constant, and it was only by God's grace, the women said, that they weren't the ones waiting by the telephone. "Who's to say your number's not going to be up?" Mrs. Russo said.
 
'Daddy's Gone Fishing'
 At 4 this morning, she said, her husband, the son and grandson of Sicilian fishermen, had left aboard the Miss Trish to cast nets for cod, haddock and flounder, just like the Italian Gold. "I tell my children, 'Daddy's gone fishing,' " she said. "When he leaves, you say something like, 'Make sure you call.' You don't tell him your fears, and he doesn't tell you his. You try to spare each other."
Grace Favazza, 66, lost her oldest brother, Vito, when another Gloucester boat, the Captain Cosmo, went down 16 years ago today with seven men aboard. "Sept. 6, 1978, the sea took him," said Mrs. Favazza, whose husband, Peter, 74, retired from fishing with a bad leg. "The whole boat and the crew -- no trace. Every day for a month my mother waited: 'Maybe today there'll be word, maybe tomorrow.' "
To be a fisherman's wife is to spend your life waiting, in a way -- waiting for your husband to come home, waiting for him to leave again.
Peter Favazza was at sea for the birth of his four children. It couldn't be helped, Mrs. Favazza said. Her husband had to earn a living the only way he knew how. "I called my sister each time," she said. "I said, 'I'm ready to have my baby. I'm packed.' "
Angela Sanfilippo, the head of the Gloucester Fishermen's Wives Association, was serving cookies at the church this evening. With the men gone, she said, the women have to manage life on land by themselves.
"Your kids get sick, you take care of them," said Mrs. Sanfilippo, who has raised three children, including a 23-year-old son who is a fisherman, like his father, grandfather and great-grandfather. "You buy a house, you plan a vacation."
Gerri Lovasco's husband, Peter, retired from fishing after 53 years of going to sea. She said the prolonged separations meant that the wives "had to make a lot of the decisions -- about school, confirmation, who the godfather was going to be." Their husbands, she said, "missed birthdays, anniversaries."
And weddings. "We," Mrs. Favazza said, indicating the women around her, "go to weddings with each other."
Still, Mrs. Lovasco said, it has been a good life. "We had beautiful houses, education for our children," she said. But Mrs. Russo, whose children are ages 4, 3 and 1, interjected with some bitterness, "Not anymore."
Mrs. Favazza's husband would be gone for 22 days at a time, fishing off Nova Scotia, then home for 3. Mr. Favazza, who now has trouble walking, rested at home while his wife was at the church today.
Later he said: "We went through a lot of storms, hurricanes. When the wind kicks up, you've got waves 20 and 30 feet; they splatter all over the boat. We had windows broken in the pilot house, the doors smashed in, the lifeboats washed away.
"Then in the wintertime, when the spray hits the mast, or any other part of the boat, it turns to ice. We stop the boat, we have to use wooden mallets to chop the ice off. Otherwise, it would tip over."
Once, about 15 years ago, Mr. Favazza said, his boat caught fire off Maine. "We got onto another boat, and watched her go down," he said. "Was I scared? Frightened to death."
 
Keeping Fear Private
 But no, he added, he never told his wife he was scared. Not then, not ever. "She had enough to worry about with the kids," he said. "She was working day and night, same as me."
Nowadays, the women may worry as much when the men are home.
After 375 years, fishing is disappearing as a way of life here. The oldest American fishing area, Georges Bank, is largely barren of the haddock, cod and flounder that sustained more than 10 generations of New Englanders.
With Government regulations intended to preserve what is left, fishermen can't work nearly as often as they want. For every two days they are out, they must stay home one. A 10-day trip means 5 days at home -- 5 days of not bringing in money.
Still, Mrs. Russo said, nothing will stop her husband from fishing, not this week's accident, not regulations, not the depleted fishing stock.
"You come to this country when you're 14," she said, speaking for her husband, and for many others. "You don't go to high school; you get on a boat. Now, you're 35 and you've got two mortgages, a house and a boat, and three children. It's not a good time for a career change."
Mrs. Russo squared her shoulders. "I'm damn proud of him," she said. "I have a brother-in-law who went to college. My husband says, 'He knows books, I know life.' "
The discussion quieted when Gay Viola, the sister of the missing skipper, Nicholas Curcuru, 48, entered, bringing only news of Mr. Curcuru's wife. "It's a way of life," Mrs. Viola said, whose father was a fisherman. "Even now, Donna's waiting for him to call and say he's coming home."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Cuban Talks Suspended As Envoy Returns to Havana

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Talks between the United States and Cuba on halting the exodus of Cuban boat people toward Florida were suspended today when the chief Cuban negotiator, Ricardo Alarcon, abruptly broke off discussions and flew back to Havana to consult his Government.
But the rest of the Cuban delegation remained in New York and the spokesman for the American delegation, David T. Johnson, said the negotiations could resume as early as Friday. 
 In Washington, Secretary of State Warren Christopher described the talks as "productive, useful, businesslike." And he emphasized that Mr. Alarcon's decision to return to Havana "is not by any means a breakdown in the talks but it's part of the useful talks that are taking place."
In Madrid, Cuba's Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, also expressed cautious optimism that an agreement might be possible, telling journalists, "I think we have not yet exhausted all the talks' possibilities."
"Such a dispute cannot be solved in a few days and I think we will arrive at a reconciliation," he added.
 
Position Called Moderate
 Members of a group of Latin American representatives to the United Nations who met privately with Mr. Alarcon here last night described his position as moderate and said he told them not to be surprised if, despite all the difficulties, there was an agreement within a few days.
However, American officials conceded that "substantial differences" remained between the two sides, suggesting that after six days of talks here Mr. Alarcon, a former Cuban Foreign Minister and United Nations representative, felt the need to consult with President Fidel Castro directly.
As usual neither side provided any information about the substance of the discussions, which today took place in the United States Mission to the United Nations after two days of meetings in the Cuban mission and lasted barely 45 minutes.
But while the United States has offered to expand legal immigration from Cuba in return for Havana's halting the deluge of boat people sailing for Florida, the Cuban Government wants any refugee accord linked to an easing of the 32-year American trade embargo against the island, arguing that the poverty this causes forces people to flee.
So far, the Clinton Administration has insisted that the negotiators confine themselves to immigration issues, although this leaves the United States team with relatively little bargaining leverage.
 
An Offer by the U.S.
 Initially, the Administration, which under a 1984 agreement can admit up to 27,000 Cuban immigrants annually but has been accepting only 2,000 or 3,000 in recent years, offered to raise this number to 20,000 if Havana clamped down on the boat people.
Cuba replied that since the United States ought by now to have issued over 100,000 more refugee visas than it has it should first agree to catch up with the target set in 1984.
The United States then said its earlier offer of 20,000 visas was "flexible" and could be raised to around 27,000 a year.
Cuba also suggested that the United States set a date for discussing the economic embargo and consider reversing the new restrictions President Clinton imposed this summer when he made it harder for American Cubans to send money to relatives on the island or to make visits there.
