HEADLINE: On a Harlem Block, Hope Is Swallowed by Decay

SERIES: Another America: Life on 129th Street -- First of three articles.

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
There are days that Robert LeShawn Garland, a lanky 18-year-old with a yen to fly airplanes, can look out his window and spy his father waiting in a snaking line to buy crack. Once their eyes met, and his father hung his head.
On the floor below, Donna Williams often starts her day with a beer, trying to beat the blues. She has five children, she just turned 40, and she has been on welfare for more than a decade. From her living room, she can see an empty lot and rows of boarded windows. 
 Two stoops away sit Mel and Dennis. Once they owned the block, these two brothers with high cheekbones and laughing eyes, counting their cash from drug dealing. Now 19-year-old Mel is in a wheelchair, paralyzed after taking seven bullets from a 9-millimeter pistol.
This is 129th Street between Malcolm X Boulevard and Fifth Avenue in Harlem. It is a block in the other America, the America of the black underclass. It is a place -- and it could be in Chicago, Miami or Los Angeles -- with its own values, rules and economy. While the experts debate welfare reform, education and job training, generations live and die on this block, a world apart.
The world of 129th Street is increasingly violent and dispirited. The scrappers on this block -- the ones who call the police on drug dealers and who badger landlords for repairs -- say the old civil-rights remedies like affirmative action do little to improve lives hobbled by a multitude of ills. While the black middle class has expanded greatly in the last 30 years, a growing number of black people have also been trapped in seemingly intractable poverty.
It is a measure of the block's isolation that when a girl from 129th Street dressed for an interview for an office job recently, she chose a black evening sheath and wobbly high heels. Few on this block have steady jobs, creating a feeling of perpetual waiting. The hours are whiled away on stoops, basketball courts or in front of the TV.
Strivers like Robert Garland, who traveled four hours each day to attend a good city high school and is now in college, are seen by many as outsiders and face ridicule. His half-sister Nadine Allen, who became an unmarried mother at 19 and is unemployed, is the one who saunters down the street greeting friends. Ms. Allen, a former drug merchant, has her pick of suitors, but Mr. Garland was dateless on prom night. Even the sweetness of romance is brief on 129th Street, and marriages are rare. Up and down the block are women who say they have been "dogged" by men, a term for being treated badly. They talk about being raped, beaten and abandoned. Mothers complain of men who walk by their own children as if they were invisible. The men claim the women want them only for the material possessions they can provide.
Many people talk of getting high school equivalency diplomas and jobs and moving away, but the reality is that almost no one ever does. Some, like Mel and Dennis, have tasted financial success from drug dealing. These are usually short-lived episodes of lavish spending on clothes and recreation that end in violence or an arrest.
One constant is death, taking the young and old alike. Almost everyone on this block is related to someone who has been shot, is addicted to drugs or dying of AIDS. In the last five months, four young men from the block were shot; three of them died. Here, children talk about the kind of funerals they want in the way that young people in other neighborhoods plan proms.
Few on the block believe that the American dream exists for them. The lives that flicker across their television screens remind them of what they lack and what they desire.
In quiet moments, anger and disappointment can be heard.
"They say that 129th Street is a black hole," said Vikki, who is 26 and lives here with her younger cousins. Like many others interviewed she insisted on not using her last name. "If you are born here, you die here."
 
The Mother
A Fruitless Wait
For Skills or a Job
 On a recent day, Donna Williams sat with a 40-ounce bottle of malt liquor that made her hands look especially small. She came to 129th Street four years ago, but she knows only two of her neighbors. The others scare her. She stays home, knitting and watching bootleg horror films as family members stop by.
At 40, Ms. Williams is tiny enough to wear her clothes from junior high school, but her eyes are ancient.
Ms. Williams's problems are multilayered. She never attended high school and has no marketable skills. She drinks every day but denies she is an alcoholic. Welfare caseworkers tell her otherwise. She has medication for depression, but tried to kill herself last year. She sees no connection between the children she started having at 15 and the life she has.
She believes life on 129th Street is every bit as horrifying as the movies she watches day after day about murderous ghosts and homicidal teen-agers.
"You see those kids on TV from Bosnia," Ms. Williams said, beginning to slur her words. "That's stupid. They eat better than our kids." Indeed, the block looks like a city after a war, with its vacant lots, abandoned buildings and four-to-seven-story dowager buildings of ornate ironwork, tiled hallways and marble stairways, long in decline.
 
A Job Goal Stymied
 Ms. Williams said she wants to get her high school equivalency diploma, get off welfare, and leave the city. But she said her goal of becoming a home-care attendant was derailed recently when her 17-year-old daughter had a baby after becoming pregnant on a camping trip for inner-city children.
Instead of increasing her welfare check -- because both her daughter and grandchild are her dependents -- she said the city mistakenly cut her payments and dropped her from a home-care training program. Her caseworker told her that a woman with a small child could not participate.
"They don't want me off assistance," Ms. Williams said, sounding bitter. "They want to keep you in a rut, keep you depressed."
Of her five children, ranging in age from 16 to 24, the three youngest live with her in the tidy apartment. The other day, her daughter Decima, 17, was back home with her 10-month-old son, Brennan.
They watched a film about giant man-eating ticks. Decima undid her long braids and argued with her mother about giving the baby medication for his teething. The temperature was in the 90's, but his grandmother warned Brennan away from the window.
"You know about these windows," she said, meaning the threat of stray bullets. Some children on the block have been wounded that way.
Born in Reading, Pa., to a mother who was a homemaker and a father who eventually left them, Ms. Williams left eighth grade to marry after she became pregnant. She eventually divorced her husband, a heroin addict who beat her. She found solace through liquor and making babies with other men.
"I look at my children and I know I gave something to the world," she said.
 
Talisman Against Despair
 Ms. Williams came to New York to live with her boyfriend, Bobby, and his mother. Bobby beat her, too, she said. When she obtained an order of protection against him, his mother evicted Ms. Williams and her children. When the city gave her the option of going to the projects or moving to a city-subsidized apartment on 129th Street, she ended up here.
Like talismans to ward off despair, almost every inch of her living room wall is covered with certificates and awards received by her or her children: perfect attendance by a sixth grader; the G.E.D. certificates of her son and daughter.
When Ms. Williams ran out of awards, she began plastering the walls with anything colorful, from a Met Life advertisement featuring Snoopy to one for Crayola washable crayons.
"I'm motivated," Ms. Williams insisted, as she watched a video whose opening scene was of a young black man killing two Korean store merchants. "But lately, motivated for what? I look out that window, and motivated for what? What went wrong?"
 
The Dealer
Teen-Ager Bears An Adult's Burden
 He sold drugs near Majester's Fish and Chips on the southeast corner of 129th Street. It is near a smoke shop where the old-timers congregate on folding steel chairs. Across the street are the beams of a church abandoned before completion and a boarded-up building where West Indian and African-American drug dealers worked different sides by mutual agreement.
At 13, this representative of the new generation of dealers has a face too immature to shave. He chews bubble gum and shows off his new roller skates.
"If you not white and your mom's got no money, what you going to do?" he said. "We got to eat now. Who would hire me? I was in the slow class at school, anyway."
His mother is a former crack addict who now drinks heavily. One day, she wandered by her son's corner. He cringed in embarrassment because she was wearing house slippers and a diaphanous dress that hung off her shoulders.
The young dealer cares for three younger brothers and sisters, getting them off to school in the morning, buying groceries and preparing meals. One morning, they shared a bag of Ruffles potato chips, washed down with Pepsi. He said he had never known anyone with a real job or anyone who went to college. When asked whether he might be able to go to college and better himself, he shook his head vigorously.
 
'You Have to Sell Your Soul'
 "I think everything is against the black man," he said, sounding like an imitation of the older men on the block. "You have to sell your soul to live with white people."
One day, as the dealer and some friends leaned against a car and puffed on a marijuana cigarette, someone shouted "Five-O," the code for the police. It comes from the television show "Hawaii Five-O." Someone flung the cigarette into a lot.
Three white officers jumped out of the car and patted down the group. They made them open the car trunk. They searched the ground and found a spent shell casing. It was a silent, hurried affair, ending with the officers speeding off.
"If you hadn't been here they would have beat us, called us niggers," one boy said to a visitor from outside the neighborhood.
The young dealer leaned against the car, shaking.
Sometime in the summer, he disappeared from the corner. There were rumors that he and his crew had lost their jobs after a shooting near their spot.
 
The Girlfriend
A Troubled Quest For Intimacy
 Sherri, 19, was pouting, and Mel-Mel, her 3-year-old son, was sobbing as they made their way across 129th Street. A woman Sherri knew had snubbed them, even though Mel-Mel kept waving and saying, "Hi." Sherri smacked him and jerked his arm.
"Have some pride," she said. "Don't be talking to nobody who don't talk to you."
Sherri is the former girlfriend of Mel, now in a wheelchair but once a successful drug dealer, and she is the mother of one of his two children. He treats her shabbily sometimes, she said, even though she has been supportive during his ordeals.
Children are valued here for the usual reasons, but also because they create an instant life for many women. With babies come a welfare check, a subsidized apartment, something to do with your time or a way to keep a man. Increasingly, though, the girls say their babies are accidental footnotes in a quest for intimacy.
Many men see their offspring as emblems of masculinity. Beyond the baby-making, things fall apart.
For a time, Sherri and Mel lived together as family. Sherri's mother was ill with complications from diabetes and 15-year-old Sherri was pregnant. After her mother died, Mel, on the run from the police, went back to selling drugs to pay for the burial.
Mel promised Sherri's mother before she died that he would take care of Sherri and their son. His own father was often in jail and used the family's food stamps for drugs. Sherri's father was absent. By all accounts, Mel has done better than either father, spending time and money to care for Mel-Mel.
But things quickly deteriorated for Sherri and Mel, too. The two 16-year-olds were overwhelmed by the responsibilities of adulthood. He chased girls. They came to blows and she called the police.
 
The Absence of Fathers
 The block is haunted by the ghosts of many a relationship. Men and women often seem to be at war. Many people grew up without fathers, most lack the money to support a family, and there is no pressure to marry.
Vikki, the legal guardian of her troubled younger cousins, had a boyfriend, George, who kept his address a secret. Vikki became pregnant by him but had an abortion. On one bad Monday in July, she was close to tears after learning that George had two other pregnant girlfriends.
Ms. Allen, one of Vikki's friends, said the father of her baby passes them on the street without speaking. Her goal is to marry a man "with a legal job."
Frances Weldon, the mother of Ms. Allen and Mr. Garland, said she was not surprised that many young people on the block believed in neither romance nor tenderness.
"If you grow up without it, how can you believe in it?" she said.
 
Brother and Sister
Siblings Share Dream of Escape
 Nadine Allen sat in her mother's bedroom and slowly dragged on a cigarette. The TV droned on, her son Dayvon lay kicking on the unmade bed, and ketchup spotted the linoleum floor. Ms. Allen was depressed and gaining weight. A high school dropout who had spent time in the drug trade, she was unemployed again and had no financial support from the father of her 1-year-old.
Ms. Allen, 20, is watching her friends die or sink into the muck of welfare and baby-making. Several weeks ago, she went to the wake for Liviro Bunch, a 22-year-old neighbor shot in a dispute that the police are still investigating. Memorial flowers decorated the block, looking incongruous among the garbage.
Mr. Bunch's murder increased Ms. Allen's desperation to escape 129th Street, but she has no clear idea of what to do.
The other day, Ms. Allen stood outside another funeral home and tears slid down her face. The service was for a 21-year-old childhood friend, Donald Bonaparte, shot in the head. As a tribute, some friends had written and planned to perform a rap called "Kill or Be Killed" but were talked out of it by one of the mothers.
"Things haven't really changed," Ms. Allen said of her prospects as a black woman. "If there was no racism there would be no 129th Street."
 
Planning to Be a Pilot
 Her brother, however, is on the cusp of escape. Robert Garland graduated from high school in June and went off to Alabama Aviation and Technical College on Labor Day. He plans to be an airline pilot, a dream he has clutched for years.
Mr. Garland traveled to August Martin High School in Queens each day for a special aviation program. When he was a sixth grader, his class was "adopted" by Marble Collegiate Church as part of the I Have A Dream Foundation program. The program, with its guidance and financial support, guaranteed a college education to any sixth grader who made it through high school.
By Mr. Garland's accounting, about 35 of the 84 "dreamers" made it. He knows that two died.
Mr. Garland has written off most of his peers on 129th Street. They say things to him like, "You read so much you got words coming out of your ears," he said.
"I'm different because I act different," Mr. Garland said. "Most of them, they want things now. They see the drug dealers with fancy clothes and cars."
Mr. Garland's mother left his father years ago because of his crack addiction. She never married Ms. Allen's father, her high-school sweetheart.
"What happened to my father taught me that you have to have a goal," Mr. Garland said. "You have to be determined, you have to want something different, something better."
In June, as Mr. Garland prepared for graduation, his sister quit her job at McDonald's. "It was too stressful," Ms. Allen said. "At the end of the week my paycheck was only $60. It wasn't worth it."
 
Easy Status Symbols
 Ms. Allen says she spent time in the drug trade to be "down," meaning to fit in. Like many children of 129th Street, she believed that her life would be transformed by things like sneakers, stereo equipment and gold jewelry. They are easy status symbols for those who know no other way to gain status.
"I needed money then," she said. "All the guys I associate with, what I see from them, if I stand on this corner I can make more money in a week than other people make in a month.
"I didn't have options like Shawn," Ms. Allen said. "It seemed the best opportunity for me."
She said many girls she knew got out of the house by having a baby and getting welfare and public housing.
"Everybody's having kids," she said. "They think that's the in thing to do. It's really to keep their boyfriends but it really pushes them farther away.
"The girls aren't looking for anything better," she continued. "They see themselves on 129th Street for the rest of their lives. A lot of these guys feel they're not going to live too long, so they want to leave something behind."
In some ways, Ms. Allen's is a soul corroded by what she sees. Mr. Garland stands apart and looks away. The mother urges on her son, but her voice is strained and wistful when calculating her daughter's chances.
Lately, Ms. Allen has considered going to Georgia to live with her maternal grandparents, reversing the trip her mother's family made decades ago when New York beckoned with promise.
"I have to leave," Ms. Allen said. "I have to leave or I'll die. There's nothing for me here."

HEADLINE: Treasury Had Doubts About Health Plan, Papers Show

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
From the first weeks of the Clinton Administration, Treasury officials expressed profound doubts about major parts of the President's plan to overhaul the nation's health care system, White House records made public today show.
Today, the Administration released 234 boxes of working papers of Hillary Rodham Clinton's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, after fighting for 18 months to keep the boxes, each containing about 2,500 pages, secret. 
 In the documents, economists warn that the President's plan had "fatal flaws" that could cause "real-world havoc" and "potential disasters" for the nation's health care system.
The papers were made public at a time of soul searching within the Administration about what went wrong with the President's campaign for universal health insurance. After rejecting several plans with that goal, Congress returns next week to take up more modest proposals.
The records of the task force show that Treasury officials anticipated almost all the criticism later aimed at Mr. Clinton's health plan, but that the White House brushed aside the concerns as relatively insignificant.
 
Concerns About Cost
 Harold M. Ickes, deputy chief of staff at the White House, said today that the records showed that Mr. Clinton's policy-making process was open to many points of view.
In the first half of 1993, Treasury officials often contended that Ira C. Magaziner, the coordinator of the task force, was making decisions without consulting Cabinet officers like Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen. The officials expressed concern that Mr. Magaziner had neglected the explosive question of how to pay for universal health insurance.
On Feb. 17, 1993, James R. Ukockis, a senior economist at the Treasury Department, wrote that the work of the task force "has gone from frenetic to frantic" as the White House devised schemes to control health costs and health insurance premiums. On Feb. 23, Mr. Ukockis wrote that Mr. Magaziner "was not interested in a balanced evaluation" of price controls, but wanted "someone to make the best possible case for a specific price control program."
Then on March 23, Mr. Ukockis wrote, "Every option has fatal flaws, which, although passed off as problems 'still under examination,' are actually major roadblocks to successful implementation." He expressed concern that Secretary Bentsen would be "confronted by a fait accompli when he is finally brought into the health policy process" by Mr. Magaziner.
President Clinton did propose Federal regulation of health insurance premiums as a way to slow the growth of health spending. The proposal was denounced by doctors, hospitals, insurance companies and members of Congress from both parties, just as the Treasury had predicted.
 
Ridicule and 'Guesstimates'
 Another official, David M. Cutler from the staff of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, upset White House officials when he challenged major premises of the Clinton plan. He argued in August 1993 that the growth of health spending had not done significant damage to the growth of the nation's total economic output. Moreover, he wrote, "Total compensation as a share of gross domestic product has remained remarkably constant since 1947, even as health care spending has increased as a share of G.D.P."
President Clinton eventually proposed that employers pay most of the cost of health insurance for their employees. Mr. Cutler said in August 1993 that this proposal "will mandate an increase in employer spending much greater than ever previously legislated," and he declared that this "mandate is essentially a tax," contrary to the official position taken by the White House.
Paul Starr, a Princeton professor who was in charge of a panel drafting proposals for short-term cost controls, complained a few days later that Mr. Cutler's analysis seemed to "downplay the importance of the problems we are trying to address."
In April 1993, Treasury officials ridiculed the reliability of estimates of savings to be achieved from the Clinton plan.
In response to a request from the Council of Economic Advisers, Administration officials "sat around the table making guesstimates of the savings to be realized" from various cost-control proposals, according to one Treasury memorandum. It concluded, "It was an appropriate exercise for April Fool's Day."
 
A Strategy Backfires
 Experts from the Treasury's Office of Tax Analysis protested Mr. Magaziner's decision to bring in experts from private industry to audit their revenue estimates.
"This outside review process is without precedent," wrote Janet Holtzblatt of the Treasury. "The audit group does not contain individuals with the experience to evaluate the work of the Office of Tax Analysis. It consists of eight members, seven actuaries and one health economist. All eight are employed by private industries with an interest in health reform and tax policy."
Just two weeks after Mr. Clinton took office, Professor Starr suggested that the President ask Congress for "standby authority to control health care prices." But in a memorandum to Mr. Magaziner, Mr. Starr wrote, "It is better for the exact method and span of controls to be left ambiguous, as this allows interest groups to imagine the worst."
This strategy backfired, White House House officials say. Drug companies, insurers and others in the health care industry were so alarmed at the talk of price controls that they organized a campaign to attack the Clinton plan before its details were set.
Mr. Ukockis wrote that Mr. Magaziner's insistence on price controls "may be a brilliant strategy, but it may also be reckless." He told the White House that "Treasury personnel are not to take part in formulating or advocating a price control proposal until Secretary Bentsen specifically approves of such activity."

HEADLINE: U.S., Despite Critics, Is to Expand Taiwan Ties

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Completing a policy review of how to treat one of Asia's emerging economic powers, the Clinton Administration announced today that it would expand official ties with Taiwan, while continuing not to recognize it as a country separate from China.
Republican and Democratic lawmakers quickly attacked this split-the-difference policy adjustment as not treating Taiwan with due respect, and the Government of this island of 20 million said the new policy fell short of what was needed. 
 The new policy is intended to accord more respect to Taiwan, in light of its important economic ties with the United States -- all without offending China, which insists that the United States not treat Taiwan as a full-fledged nation.
"Our fundamental one-China policy will be continued," said a State Department official who chose not to be identified. "The United States is committed to maintaining unofficial commercial, cultural and other contacts with the people of Taiwan."
Taiwan welcomed the revised policy today, but said it had not "sufficiently addressed the needs arising from the close relationship" of the United States and Taiwan.
Under the results of the policy review, the United States will not support Taiwan's entry into the United Nations or any other institution in which membership is open only to independent countries.
But the United States will support Taiwan's entry into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world trade organization.
According to the new policy, American officials, including some senior officials, will be able to have contacts with Taiwanese officials and visit Taiwan -- something that Administrations have shied away from.
The senior official who outlined the new policy said the top leadership of the United States would not visit Taiwan, and Washington would not permit visits by Taiwan's top leaders.
Last May, President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan was not permitted to leave his airplane during a refueling stop in Hawaii on his way to Central America. That move angered many members of Congress, who later invited Mr. Lee to visit their districts. The official said President Lee would now be able to leave his airplane.
President Lee was also barred from attending alumni reunions at Cornell University. A senior official said that under the revised policy, it would still be inappropriate for Mr. Lee to attend such reunions.
Paul Simon, an Illinois Democrat on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, belittled the policy adjustments as "small steps."
"We continue to give Taiwan the cold shoulder," he said. "Taiwan has a multiparty system, free elections and a free press -- the things we profess to champion -- while we continue to cuddle up to the mainland government, whose dictatorship permits none of these."
Under the revised policy, Washington will continue to provide military material and training to help Taiwan defend itself.
Under the new policy the name of Taiwan's official office in the United States will be changed to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States. At present, the office's name -- the Coordination Council for North American Affairs -- does not even identify it as an organ of Taiwan.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

WHERE HOPE IS SWALLOWED BY DECAY
In Harlem, 129th Street between Malcolm X Boulevard and Fifth Avenue is a block in the America of the black underclass -- a block that could be in Chicago, Miami or Los Angeles. It has its own values, rules and economy. Even as the nation engages in a spirited dialogue on issues like welfare reform, education and job training, places like 129th Street exist as a world apart. The scrappers on the block -- the ones who call the police on drug dealers and badger landlords for repairs -- say the old civil-rights remedies like affirmative action do little to improve lives hobbled by a multitude of ills. A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
CROWN HTS. DEFENSE TO SEEK NEW JUDGE
Lawyers for Lemrick Nelson Jr., who is charged with violating the civil rights of a Hasidic scholar stabbed to death during the 1991 violence in Crown Heights, said that they would ask the Federal judge assigned to the case to step down from it. They asserted that the judge, David G. Trager of United States District Court in Brooklyn, had a conflict of interest. B3. 

OUTSIDE STADIUM, SPIRIT OF BASEBALL LIVES
Across 161st Street from Yankee Stadium is Babe Ruth Field in Macombs Dam Park, with two chewed-up diamonds that are meager fields of fantasy for everyone from lazy-afternoon fly-shaggers to serious leagues of teen-age hardball players and aging softball addicts. With the big-league strike, the crack of the balls being hit by professionals' bats has been replaced by the "tink" of amateurs' metal bats. B3.
 
UNION DEFENDS OFFICER IN SHOOTING
Saying he wanted to "set the record straight" for an off-duty city police officer who mistakenly opened fire on a plainclothes transit police officer last month, the president of the police union said that the off-duty officer was completely focused on the other man's gun and shot in "response to a life-threatening gesture." B3.
 
DECLINE IN SUBWAY CRIME IS REPORTED
The transit police said reports of subway crime in the first six months of 1994 dropped faster than at any time since the start of 1990. B3.
 
REGION
 
A PLEDGE TO END AN INCOME TAX
The leading Republican candidate for governor, John G. Rowland, pledged that he would eliminate Connecticut's personal income tax over the next five years and reduce the state's business and inheritance taxes without raising other taxes to take their place. B6.
 
JERSEY CITY SCHOOLS TAKEOVER EXTENDED
The Jersey City public schools will remain under state control for at least another year, the State Board of Education decided. B6.
 
OFFICER, DENIED LEAVE, IS DISMISSED
A Ridgefield, Conn., police officer who was denied family leave after the birth of her daughter has been dismissed. B5.
 
TEACHER CHARGED IN SLAYING OF HUSBAND
Marilyn Kennelly should have been in class, guiding her students through Spanish and Latin lessons, but instead the 61-year-old teacher surrendered to police in Wilton, Conn., charged with murder in the beating death of her husband. B2.
 
ABORTION-PROTEST ZONE STRUCK DOWN
A Federal appeals court struck down as unconstitutional a court-approved buffer zone to prevent anti-abortion demonstrators from encroaching on an abortion clinic in Buffalo. B5.
 
Ralph J. Marino, New York's Republican Senate majority leader, plans to endorse Senator George E. Pataki for governor. B6.

HEADLINE: Peace in a Northern Ireland Factory

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 6

 BODY:
Patrick R. Dougan's office at the Mackie International factory sits astride the peace line, the wall -- imaginary in some spots, quite real in others -- that divides the Protestant and Roman Catholic neighborhoods of West Belfast.
"If you look over there to the left, you can see houses flying tricolors," Mr. Dougan said as he pointed out the window, referring to the Irish flag, a symbol of the Catholic minority's demands for a British withdrawal from the province. "Over there to the right, you can see Union Jacks." 
 At Mackie, no flags fly at all. They would not, said Mr. Dougan, the company's chairman and owner, be a good idea at the plant, once a bastion of Protestant employment and now the site of one of the more ambitious efforts to desegregate Northern Ireland's economy.
Of the 400 workers at the plant, which makes machinery for the textile industry, 29 percent are Catholic, up from 11 percent in 1991, when Mr. Dougan took over. Catholics make up about 42 percent of Northern Ireland's population of 1.6 million.
For Mr. Dougan, a wealthy Catholic entrepreneur, who was viewed with deep suspicion by Mackie's work force when he was recruited by the Government three years ago to revive the ailing company after the previous American owners filed for bankruptcy, the opportunity to hire more Catholics has been a byproduct of his success in stabilizing and then expanding Mackie International.
Relations on the shop floor have generally been harmonious, workers said, and Mackie is profitable again.
But even now, as the peace process in Northern Ireland gains momentum, Protestants arrive to work each morning through a gate adjacent to their neighborhood and the Catholics at a separate gate near their homes.
"I frankly don't see that wall coming down anytime soon," Mr. Dougan said. "But we have a gospel to preach, that it is possible to be successful right here on the battlefield, the erstwhile battlefield I hope, when people want to work together and get on with their lives."
Workplace integration in Northern Ireland is a huge task, given the province's deep-rooted patterns of segregation and employment discrimination, primarily against Catholics, and the enduring enmity between the two communities. Even putting history aside, male unemployment in the neighborhoods visible from Mr. Dougan's window runs as high as 60 percent, spawning levels of poverty, disillusionment and resentment that have made the area the primary recruiting ground for the terrorist forces on both sides.
Such integration is also a subject watched with great interest among American supporters of Northern Ireland's Catholics. New York City's municipal pension fund and other public pension funds are among the investors that subscribe to guidelines known as the MacBride Principles. The principles, which were named after an Irish politician, Sean MacBride, include a call for selling the stock of American companies operating in Northern Ireland that are shown to discriminate against Catholics. American companies account for about 10,000 jobs in Northern Ireland, or less than 2 percent of the total.
With Northern Ireland enjoying its best chance for peace in 25 years, Government officials and business leaders said they saw great opportunities to breathe new life into the economy, create jobs and redress the imbalances of the past while providing hope to both sides.
By some indicators, Northern Ireland has a long way to go. Catholic males, with a jobless rate estimated at 28 percent, are more than twice as likely to be jobless as Protestant males, who have an unemployment rate around 13 percent. With the economy still feeling the effects of recession, few industries are hiring new workers, making it hard to provide opportunities to Catholics.
At many of the biggest industrial employers, a combination of prejudice, fear and economic difficulty has left Catholics badly underrepresented. Of the 2,000 employees at Harland & Wolff, the shipyard that is Belfast's largest employer, only 5 percent last year were Catholic. With the company struggling to avoid further job cuts, the prospects for hiring more Catholics there are dim.
By the same token, there are employers with predominantly Catholic work forces who are having as much trouble hiring Protestants. Despite efforts to step up recruitment, the Sean Quinn Group, a cement manufacturer near Fermanagh, had only six Protestants among its 280 employees last year.
Although there is a growing Catholic middle class, in inner-city ghettos many Catholic families are enduring their second or even third generation of male unemployment. Skill and educational levels are low among those Catholics. Even when jobs in Protestant companies are available to Catholics, they are often passed up out of fear of violence. Catholic workers are a primary target of Protestant paramilitary forces.
Still, there has been measurable progress over the last few years in reversing discrimination. Catholics held 36.6 percent of all jobs last year, up from 34.9 percent in 1990, according to the Fair Employment Commission, the British agency that enforces a tough antidiscrimination law enacted in 1989.
"We're heading in the right direction, and the pace of change could accelerate very substantially if we were to have peace," said Robert G. Cooper, the panel's chairman. "You'd hope to see an expansion of the economy. And you would not have the enormous chill factor, the reluctance and fear on the part of many workers to go to jobs in particular areas."
The textile industry has a long history in Northern Ireland, and Mackie, which was founded in the mid-19th century and makes machines that prepare and spin fibers for textile companies, has suffered badly along with the rest of the industry over the last several decades. Employment at the company dwindled from the thousands down to 270 in 1991.
Mackie had been acquired in the mid-1980's by an American company, Lummus Industries of Georgia, but after Lummus went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in 1992, threatening Mackie's already precarious chances of survival, Mr. Dougan agreed to buy the company, with the price being the assumption of its $21 million in debt.
Mr. Dougan, who has turned around other companies, expanded Mackie's sales force, pushing into Asian markets, for example. He diversified into environmental services. And with some help from the gradual world economic recovery, Mackie's sales this year will be about $30 million, up from $9 million in 1991. The company should record a $3 million profit this year after a long period of losses, Mr. Dougan said.
Later this month, Mr. Dougan will take Mackie public through a $16.5 million share offering on the London Stock Exchange. The proceeds will go to debt repayment and modernizing machinery.
As he has added more than 100 new jobs over the last few years, Mr. Dougan said, he has recruited actively among Catholics, but never hired workers just because they were Catholic. He praised his Protestant work force for what he called its strong work ethic and reliability.
The biggest problem, he said, is finding skilled Catholic workers, who are in short supply. Many of the Catholics he has hired have been recently trained in jobs like welding, rather than in more highly skilled fields like machine-tool operations.
Catholics from nearby neighborhoods used to throw rocks at Protestant workers as they went in and out of the plant. But now, as the Catholic proportion in Mackie's work force grows, workers on both sides said they get along well, and that at least within the walls of the factory no one focuses on religion.
"You can't change the balance overnight, because you've got to hire the people who can do the kind of work we do," said Paddy Auld, a plant supervisor, who is Catholic. "If we don't get the proper people in, then the company can't survive, and one thing that people in all sections of the community are finding out is that if you lose your job, it doesn't matter what religion you are."

HEADLINE: VATICAN HOLDS UP ABORTION DEBATE AT TALKS IN CAIRO

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 7

 BODY:
In an unexpected maneuver today that angered many participants in the United Nations population conference, the Vatican was able to to put off for two more days any debate over how to deal with abortion in a plan to stabilize world population in the coming decades.
The Vatican move, apparently supported by several small countries that did not enter the debate until today, in effect reopened a discussion on the language of one paragraph of a 113-page document and sent it back to a committee until Friday. The action brought sharp condemnation from Egypt, the conference host, and sent delegates from a number of nations into private meetings to try to find a way to force the issue back onto the conference floor over the Vatican's objections. 
 At issue is paragraph 8.25 -- a number that is taking on symbolic importance here -- an already much-diluted section that deals with abortion. The Vatican insists that all references to abortion and other language that might imply that it is acceptable as a method of family planning be removed from the plan of action. Because the United Nations conference operates by consensus, a minority objection to the disputed passage was enough of an obstacle to send the issue back to a committee.
Most delegations, including the one representing the United States, expect the Vatican will refuse to sign the agreement, the same position it took at the population conferences in 1974 and 1984. Many delegates here believe that in the end the Vatican's team will have to step back and allow a consensus to carry the document, with reservations appended by the Holy See.
"Does the Vatican rule the world?" asked Egypt's Population Minister, Maher Mahran, speaking at a news conference shortly after this morning's discussion was derailed by new objections from a group of small nations, most of them Latin American. "We respect the Vatican. We respect the Pope. But if they are not going to negotiate, why did they come?"
Several reasons have been suggested for the Vatican's action: Some believe it is still possible to force some changes in the language, while others say the Vatican merely wants to prolong the debate to draw attention to its objections and possibly generate more support. But this did not seem to be happening today.
The Vatican's willingness to delay an international forum in order to make a point on abortion has isolated it from several large Islamic nations where it might have expected to find some support, including Indonesia, Iran and Pakistan as well as Egypt. That left only a few independent conservative voices, including Afghanistan, in opposition on the margins of the Conference on Population and Development, which is scheduled to end on Tuesday.
 
Anti-Abortion Groups Active
 At the same time, anti-abortion groups and Islamic militants have stepped up psychological pressure on those attending the conference by displaying graphic illustrations of fetuses or monopolizing microphones at news conferences and seminars, participants reported.
On its side, the Vatican today reiterated its concerns about the direction the conference was taking in an address by Archbishop Renato R. Martino, the delegate of the Holy See to the United Nations. Archbishop Martino not only condemned abortion and contraception but also sought to ally the Vatican with third world demands for more equitable sharing of global wealth and technology.
He drew a connection between "permissiveness" and the abuse of women, and suggested that many family planning programs were coercive and harmful.
After the abortion paragraph was sent back to a committee, the conference went on today to approve other chapters of the action plan, including two on internal and international migrations and their relation to the population question.
The Vatican's actions provoked questions that extended beyond the current conference to forthcoming United Nations meetings on social and economic topics, including a gathering on the role of women, which is scheduled for next September in Beijing. The questions came from a range of nongovernmental groups who say they are closer to the populations of Roman Catholic countries than the Vatican is.
 
Dissenting Catholic View
 "How come this is the only religion with a permanent observer seat at the U.N.?" Frances Kissling, president of Catholics for a Free Choice, asked today at a news conference. "How come we don't finally stand up and say we're not talking about abortion? We're not talking about family planning. We're talking about the role of women in church and state."
Timothy E. Wirth, Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs and leader of the United States Delegation, told reporters tonight that this was "a time of respectful disagreement."
He acknowledged that the Americans believed on Tuesday night that the conference was close to an accord on a paragraph that dealt with the dangers of unsafe abortions as a public health matter. Agreement on that paragraph is holding up consideration of other sections of the Conference on Population and Development's action plan still in dispute.
 
A Dozen Nations Object
 Rachel Kyte, political analyst for the International Women's Health Coalition, a New York-based organization that assists women's health groups and clinics worldwide, said that when the conference resumed its meeting on the text this morning, expecting to cement the consensus achieved last night, more than a dozen countries that had not spoken on Tuesday raised objections. Among them were Argentina, Ecuador, Honduras, Guatemala and Malta, as well as Guam, a United States territory, according to people close to official delegations. Reporters are barred from the debates.
The issue had to be referred to a special committee charged with reporting back by Friday morning.
"These Latin American nations are trying to make the Vatican happy," said Miguel Trias, head of Colombia's largest, government-backed family planning organization, Profamilia. "But in 2,000 years the Vatican has never been happy."
Alexander C. Sanger, president of Planned Parenthood of New York City, said in an interview that the divergent views of the Vatican and nongovernmental groups from Catholic nations, some of which have seats on official delegations, demonstrated a split between the Vatican hierarchy and millions of lay Catholics.
"There are two churches," he said, "one where the hierarchy talks to the presidents of countries, and then there's the church of the people. The people are picking and choosing what parts of Catholicism they want to carry over to their personal lives."
Britain's Minister for Overseas Development, Lady Chalker, told reporters today that if the Vatican negotiators did not want to wreck the conference, "they should enter their reservations now." For Norway, Sweden and Germany, delegates said, the conference had already gone too far in diluting language in order to lure the Vatican into a consensus.

 In no case should abortion be promoted as a method of family planning. All governmental and nongovernmental organizations are urged to strengthen their commitment to women's health, unsafe abortion as a major public health concern and to reduce the recourse to abortion through expanded and improved family planning services. Post-abortion family planning services should be offered promptly, which will also help to avoid repeat abortions.

HEADLINE: Affluent Europe's Plight: Graying

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Sept. 7

 BODY:
For most of those attending the population conference here, the question is simple to put, if baffling to answer: What do you do when your land has too many people, especially young people?
But what do you if your land has too few young people, a riddle that confronts the low-birth-rate countries of Western Europe, Italy in particular, where the population has actually begun to shrink and where ever-smaller family sizes and the aging of society mean that, in a few years' time, there will only be one person of working age for every two retirees demanding a pension. 
 The question might seem idiosyncratic in light of the cataclysmic issues of overpopulation and underdevelopment that have torn the social and economic fabrics of many third world countries and that provide the most obvious challenge at the United Nations Conference on Population and Development here.
But, in parts of the rich, developed world, the decline in birth rates also ties in with other, potentially explosive issues, notably migration from the poor south, that is coming increasingly to preoccupy Western Europe -- and even the United States as it faces waves of Cuban and Haitian fugitives in addition to the flow of job seekers from Mexico and elsewhere.
 
More Old Than Young
 "Migration is a global phenomenon that can no longer be left to the spontaneity of market demands or to the convenience of individual nations," Family Minister Antonio Guidi of Italy told the conference, at which his country occupies a peculiar position.
"In 1994," Mr. Guidi said in his address today, "Italy became the first country in the world with more people over the age of 65 than young people under the age of 15."
Not only that, according to statistics released earlier this year by the authoritative Istat research organization, the number of Italians -- currently 57 million -- actually shrank by 5,265 in 1993.
With the average Italian birth rate a statistical 1.21 -- the lowest figure of its kind in the world -- the nation's fertility is "much less than what is required for replacement" of the dead, said Joseph Grindlat, of the United Nations Population Division here.
 
The Perils of Affluence
 The story of how that happened and what it will mean is one that ties the fortunes of wealthy Italy to its poorer neighbors across the Mediterranean to the south -- a tale of the perils of affluence.
After the World War II, as elsewhere in Europe and America, a baby boom swelled populations, but, in Italy in particular, postwar industrialization and rapid economic growth brought other worries. People moved to the cities and housing became more scarce and more expensive. More and more women took jobs to meet the mounting costs, and wealth nurtured a consumer society.
"What attracts a couple less is to give life," said Msgr. Ersilio Tonini, a priest in the Italian city of Ravenna. An economist, Alessandra Nannei, said: "Over the past 15 years, maternity and homemaking have been stripped of value. Bringing up children is a tough job, but it no longer has society's full recognition."
 
Couples Live With Parents
 The creation of a wealthy, urbanized society, moreover, brought its own problems. Housing is so expensive and scarce that many young Italian couples do not have the money to rent a family-sized apartment and live with their parents for years until they can afford a place of their own.
Recent statistics have shown that a baby in Italy adds at least $200 to monthly family expenditures in clothes and food between the ages of 1 and 6; keeping teen-agers home works out at $600 a month.
Such considerations have evidently persuaded many Italians against having large families. The country's abortion laws are the most liberal in western Europe, permitting abortion on demand in the first three months of pregnancy. According to official statistics, the number of legal abortions per year in Italy fell from 234,800 to 155,200 between 1982 and 1992.
 
'Have to Have Immigrants'
 But the demographic changes have produced other strains. As people live longer, they need to draw on Italy's generous pension and social benefits, even as the number of people paying the taxes to finance such programs diminishes.
And as young people receive more widespread education, they start work later in life and choose the jobs they want to do more carefully.
"These days you have Egyptian cooks and Filipino maids," said a Government official who spoke on condition of anonymity. "There are certain jobs Italians won't do anymore. That means that, as Italians get fewer, we have to have immigrants."
The problem is common to many Western European countries. Germany, its Interior Minister Manfred Kanther said at the conference the other day, is home to 7 million foreigners among its 81 million people -- a population that, United Nations and other demographers say, will begin to shrink after the year 2000.
At the same time, population growth rates in North Africa and elsewhere in the third world, coupled with faltering economic growth, mean that developing countries will produce an ever larger number of people who cannot find jobs in their own countries and who look to migration to Western Europe to save them.
In Italy, home to over one million foreigners, the pressure for migration plays into a tense political landscape. Neo-Fascists in the coalition Government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi argue for tighter immigration controls, ostensibly to avert a wave of racism among Italians fearing that jobs could be taken away by foreigners. In France, Interior Minister Charles Pasqua has made political capital out of harsher immigration controls. Germany has been increasingly troubled by a wave of neo-Nazi xenophobia preying on Turkish migrants and other foreigners.
All that combines as a hazardous mix, as the United Nations conference here has acknowledged.
"International migration entails the loss of human resources for many countries of origin," says the conference's draft program of action, "and may give rise to political, economic or social tensions in countries of destination."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises as Official Says Germany Could Cut Rates

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against other leading currencies yesterday after a Bundesbank official said the central bank had room to cut interest rates.
Many traders bought dollars for marks after a Bundesbank council member, Hans-Jurgen Krupp, said he could "see room for rate reductions despite good economic progress." His comments appeared in an interview with The European newspaper, which was released to news services before its publication tomorrow. Lower German rates could help the dollar gain against the mark by making deposits in Germany less attractive. 
 "Krupp's comments gave the dollar a pop," said Matt Porio, a trader at Chase Manhattan Bank. "He caught the market off guard because many people think European rates are bottoming."
The dollar rose as high as 1.5543 marks yesterday after Mr. Krupp's comments were reported. It settled at 1.5507 marks in late New York trading, up from 1.5425 marks on Tuesday.
 
Rise Was Expected
 After Sweden and Italy raised interest rates in August, many traders and analysts concluded that European rates were poised to rise, ending a two-year decline. That view became more widespread after France's biggest commercial banks raised lending rates later in the month.
The Bundesbank left its own rates unchanged at a meeting on monetary policy last Thursday. The German discount rate on loans to banks is 4.5 percent, compared with 4 percent in the United States.
The dollar rose against the yen as traders waited to see if negotiators would make progress this week in talks aimed at shrinking Japan's trade surplus. The dollar rose to 99.45 yen yesterday from 98.66 yen on Tuesday.
The dollar held onto most of the day's gains after the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said he expected no breakthrough in this week's talks. Mr. Kantor also said a Sept. 30 deadline for making progress was a "long way away as we sit here on the seventh."
"I thought Kantor's comments showed cautious optimism about the negotiations," said Bob Lynch, currency analyst at MMS International, a market-analysis firm. Mr. Lynch and other analysts expect the dollar to trade in a narrow range against the yen until the Sept. 30 deadline, rising and falling with prospects for progress in the talks.
In other currency trading in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 5.3120 French francs, up from 5.2922 francs on Tuesday; at 1.2963 Swiss francs, up from 1.2940 Swiss francs, and at 1,577 Italian lire, up from 1,573.50 lire. The British pound fell to $1.5448 from $1.5524.

HEADLINE: Rowland Pledges an End To the State's Income Tax

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 7

 BODY:
The leading Republican candidate for governor, John G. Rowland, pledged today that he would eliminate Connecticut's personal income tax over the next five years and reduce the state's business and inheritance taxes without raising other taxes to take their place.
"We're not going to be increasing any of the other taxes," Mr. Rowland said during a television debate here with his opponent in next Tuesday's Republican primary, Secretary of the State Pauline R. Kezer. "We can cut enough spending." 
 But the key to his plan, he said, is his expectation that the state's economy will improve, generating more revenue from the remaining taxes, once state spending is slashed to make Connecticut more attractive to businesses.
"Is it credible to say that the income tax can disappear?" Mrs. Kezer said. She challenged Mr. Rowland to say how he would cut the state's $9.45 billion budget to make up for $2.8 billion in income-tax revenue. "I know a lot of people like to hear that, John, but I don't think it's believable to say that you can do that.
"To say that you can cut almost $3 billion out of this budget without showing us where those cuts are is just incredible."
 
Emulating Others
 Both candidates, however, agree that cutting taxes is essential, and both say they are emulating tax-cutting Republican governors in other states, especially Christine Todd Whitman in New Jersey.
The income tax, state spending and their effect on Connecticut's struggling economy took up much of the hourlong debate, which will be broadcast by WVIT-TV, Channel 30, on Sunday at 11 A.M. Later today, a crusader against the income tax, former State Senator Tom Scott, announced that he would be an independent candidate in the general election and pledged to eliminate the tax.
In 1990, Mr. Rowland, a Congressman from Waterbury, pledged not to raise taxes during a race he narrowly lost to Lowell P. Weicker Jr. Mr. Weicker pushed an income tax through the General Assembly to close a billion-dollar budget gap.
Mr. Rowland now says he has a five-year plan to eliminate the tax, but has not released details. Today, he said only that he would rely on attrition in the state work force, the consolidation of agencies, changes to welfare programs and cost-saving measures he has proposed for prisons, including the transfer of inmates to prisons out of state.
 
Of Pain and Suffering
 "There'll be pain, there's no question," Mr. Rowland said of budget cuts. "It will probably be across the board. But speaking of pain, it's been the people of the state who have suffered over the last three to four years. People who have lost jobs, people who lost income, people who have left the state."
"It's a question of how much they want from state government," he said. "That's the key philosophical debate in this campaign. Many of the Democrats have said we need more programs, we need more spending, we need to do more things for more people. I think we need to do just the opposite. We need to take care of basic necessities."
Mrs. Kezer has proposed cutting the state budget by 10 percent, or more than $900 million, in her first two years, and using the savings to cut the income tax.
Asked where she would find $900 million in budget cuts, Mrs. Kezer said it would "come out of government excess." As much as $100 million a year, she said, would result from not filling the 2,000 state jobs that become vacant each year. State offices have too many managers and too many job classifications, she said, and she would work with employee unions to reorganize departments.
 
Support for a Casino
 The state's bonded debt can also be reduced, she said, and she, too, would change welfare programs, limiting recipients to two years of benefits.
Both Mrs. Kezer and Mr. Rowland said they would favor another gambling casino in Connecticut, which already has one casino operated by the Mashantucket Pequots and a second to be operated by the Mohegan Indians, if it was approved in a referendum of residents where the casino would be situated.
Mrs. Kezer said any new casino would also have to make up for revenue the state would lose from existing compacts with the Mashantucket Pequots and Mohegans. Under those compacts, the tribes will pay the state $160 million a year only if there are no non-Indian casinos approved.
She said she opposes using Bridgeport's harbor, the site of competing proposals from several casino operators, because it would serve the state better to develop the port and increase exports.
Mr. Rowland said he would insist that a Bridgeport casino provide jobs to Bridgeport residents. And for the first time, he said that he does not favor Donald Trump's proposal for an amusement park on the harbor.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasuries Fall On New Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities closed above their lows of the session yesterday but still fell modestly as traders reacted to higher commodity prices and a Government report that labor costs rose in the second quarter.
Both reports fanned investors' fears about inflation, but the concern was partly offset by a steady dollar in the currency markets. 
 The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodity futures, considered a leading indicator of inflation, climbed more than a point to 234.23, propelled by rises in energy and precious metals.
The 30-year bond fell 11/32 , to a price of 999/32 for a yield of 7.56 percent, up from 7.54 percent on Tuesday.
 
Dollar Is Steady
 The steady dollar offered bonds some fragile support, keeping prices from sinking deeper as investors and dealers awaited news of trade negotiations with Japan. Traders noted that the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor cautioned not to expect any breakthrough at the meeting in Los Angeles this weekend.
Wholesale inventories rose a stronger-than-expected eight-tenths of a percent in July. Sales unexpectedly fell four-tenths of a percent, but traders said that report was less important than the Labor Department's report that labor costs rose a revised 3.4 percent in the second quarter, and that productivity fell by the largest amount in five years, 2.5 percent. Lower productivity makes goods more expensive to produce, and is thus a harbinger of inflation.
Yesterday a monthly tally of layoff annnouncements compiled by Challenger, Gray & Christmas showed a total of 46,000 in August, up from 19,000 in July, and the highest since 49,000 in March. The monthly average through the first eight months of 1994 stood at 46,000, little different from the 50,000 monthly average during the similar period a year ago.
The layoffs showed a continuing pattern of company cutbacks, despite the pickup in new hiring this year. Through August, the communications sector, notably the Baby Bells, and the aerospace industry have announced the most layoffs, the report noted.
 
Rate Cut Not Seen
 Michael R. Englund, chief economist for MMS International, a market and research analysis firm, said the market was not expecting any change in Federal Reserve Board policy at this month's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on Sept. 27. In fact, he sees little likelihood of any change before the November meeting.
"I think the market's main themes here are that the P.P.I. and C.P.I. numbers may be worse than anticipated, with energy expected to boost both to four-tenths of a percent over all and three-tenths of a percent at the core," Mr. Englund said, referring to the Producer Price Index and the Consumer Price Index. Still, he predicted that Treasuries would stay in line for the rest of the month because the market did not expect the central bank to move on short-term interest rates this month.
Analysts noted that the strong auto sales reported on Tuesday could add a little punch to approaching inflation reports, suggesting that the perception of a slowing economy might be overdone. "One theme we're seeing is that the inventory data for July have been quite strong, and August should be another big number because of vehicle assemblies being strong," Mr. Englund said. "This is also a positive for the econony, suggesting that second-quarter inventory buildup can be sustained."
Among government agency issues priced yesterday was a $700 million offering by the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae.
The 10-year debentures, being sold through various securities dealers, have a 7.85 percent coupon and are priced at 99.859 to yield 7.87 percent. According to Fannie Mae, the debentures are callable on or after Sept. 10, 1999, and are priced to yield about 59.6 basis points over Treasury securities with a comparable maturity.
In the municipal bond market, in the week's largest scheduled deal, the Industrial Development Authority of Lehigh County, Pa., sold $115.5 million of revenue bonds due 2029 for the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company through CS First Boston.
Rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's because of insurance coverage, the issue was priced to yield 6.4 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
A study says global warming may help U.S. agriculture.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
REMEMBER global warming? For the policy wonks, that was yesterday's worry; they have moved on to nuclear proliferation, ethnic slaughter and the reliability of DNA tests in identifying O. J. Simpson's blood.
But the near-consensus that civilization is playing high-stakes games with Mother Nature has not changed since the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. Nor has Washington's belated commitment to reduce the emissions of so-called greenhouse gases, mostly carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels, to 1990 levels by the year 2000. 
 Yet the results of the newest and, probably, the most careful analysis of the effects of climatic warming suggest that the fear of greenhouse gases decimating American agriculture may no longer be well founded. The study concludes that on balance, global warming will likely benefit American agriculture. And, if that is the case, finding the political support for paying to combat global warming may not be easy.
Greenhouse gases -- gases that trap solar heat -- lead to higher average temperatures and, on average, more rain because of increased evaporation from the oceans. And while the infant science of climate change will no doubt come up with some surprises, it does look as if the planet is heading for hotter times with radically altered patterns of rainfall.
Some places, including good chunks of Canada and Russia where growing seasons are perilously short, would undoubtedly find the change refreshing. But the handful of detailed economic studies done in the last several years suggested that American farmers would come out as big losers.
Some studies suggested that a doubling of atmospheric carbon would generate enough temperature change and rain at the wrong time to cause American crop losses on the order of $20 billion annually. "The specter of global warming calls up the vistas of corn blistering on the stalk," write the authors of the new contrarian analysis -- Robert Mendelsohn and William Nordhaus of Yale University and Daigee Shaw of the Institute of Economics in Taipei, Taiwan.
The trio's new assessment, to be published this month in The American Economic Review, is based on heavy-duty number-crunching of climate and soil data from 3,000 counties across the United States. But the underlying economics that drives their revisionist analysis is straightforward.
Earlier studies, they note, were all based on "dumb farmer" assumptions, in which the hewers and tillers, despite climate changes, kept doing whatever they had been doing. But that is not how farmers with access to technology and capital behave when production costs change. They adjust by changing seeds, fertilizers, growing techniques and even crops.
It may not be possible to simulate these adjustments directly, but the three economists offer a clever alternative. They have used their data on rain, temperature, soils and the crops that grow best under differing conditions to isolate the statistical impact of weather on agricultural productivity. This has enabled them to determine not only the impact of temperature and rainfall on crop yields but also the impact of changing from one crop to another under pressure from climatic change.
A uniform increase of 5 degrees Fahrenheit and a rise of 8 percent in precipitation -- the ballpark impact from a doubling of atmospheric carbon -- generate surprisingly modest changes in agricultural productivity, they found. Indeed, if the county data are weighted by the value of crops rather than just total acreage, global warming produces more winners in the United States than losers.
The key to understanding what is going on here, the three economists suggest, is the fact that climate-sensitive corn and wheat crops from the Plains states rarely account for more than a fifth of the value of America's farm output. And, more importantly, global warming appears to be good for fruits, vegetables, cotton and rice, which generally do better in warmer weather and are grown so densely that irrigation can economically offset variations in rainfall.
"These results do not amount to a declaration of war against tree huggers," noted Robert Hahn, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute. Uncontrolled climate change, he said, could still make a mess of lots of places and people. It might also increase the risk of catastrophe to levels that wake everybody up: Imagine a world with once-a-century floods or hurricanes happening once or twice a year. And even where it does not reduce economic output, global warming could radically change the pace and direction of plant and wildlife evolution.
But the study should serve as a warning not to assume popular support for this cause. For unlike dirty water and air that cause disease, or unrestricted hunting that decimates species that are good to eat or nice to cuddle, global warming will not automatically cause problems that unite people to fight it.
"It may take some fancy political footwork," Mr. Hahn predicted, "to sustain a consensus once the costs really begin to bite."

HEADLINE: ADVANCE IN TRADE MADE WITH JAPAN

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
American and Japanese trade officials said today that they were making progress toward agreements to open Japan's controlled markets in insurance and government purchasing.
But they said that talks on getting Japan to buy more American cars and auto parts were still deadlocked and that no accord was likely anytime soon. 
 Both American and Japanese officials emphasize that they still have much work to do to close the deals on insurance and Japanese Government procurement -- particularly procurement of telecommunications equipment by Japan's state-owned phone monopoly.
But if Washington and Tokyo are able to close those deals in the next few weeks, it appears increasingly likely that they will declare victory in those two areas and break them off from the auto negotiations, which would continue on a separate track for as long as it might take to reach an accord, if ever.
While any market-opening agreements with Japan would be good news for the Clinton Administration, the fact is that two-thirds of Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States comes from its vastly superior sales of autos and auto parts in this country, as compared with American sales in Japan.
If no agreements can be struck on insurance and procurements, or if only partial agreements are struck, then President Clinton could find himself faced with an unpleasant choice between his political credibility and the dollar's credibility.
The reason is that the Administration has set Sept. 30 as the deadline for Japan to make satisfactory progress in these trade negotiations; otherwise, Washington would initiate trade sanctions.
If President Clinton does not move to impose at least some sanctions on Sept. 30, he will appear to be backing down on his Administration's oft-repeated trade threat. With midterm elections looming in November, that could be politically damaging -- particularly since the Administration's private polls show its get-tough approach with Japan to be among its most popular foreign policy initiatives.
If the President does move to impose sanctions, it could set off another plunge of the dollar, as traders once again assume that the Administration's only tool for dealing with the trade imbalance between Japan and the United States is devaluing the American currency against the Japanese yen.
A weaker dollar might cut the trade deficit by making Japanese imports more expensive in the United States and American exports cheaper in Japan.
The Clinton Administration has already drawn up a list of imports from Japan on which it would impose punitive tariffs, under both the Super 301 and Title VII trade laws, should no deals emerge by the end of this month.
Japanese officials have told American reporters in recent days that they would either break off all negotiations with the United States if it imposes sanctions or take the United States before a tribunal of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
At the same time, the Japanese officials warned that other Asian countries with trade surpluses with the United States would not look kindly on Washington's resorting to sanctions, especially before the Jakarta meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which President Clinton will be attending in mid-November.
It is precisely to avoid these stark choices -- after 15 months of fruitless negotiations between the Clinton Administration and four different Japanese governments -- that the American and Japanese sides have begun what are likely to be a marathon set of talks to try to reach an accord before Sept. 30.
 
No Details Disclosed
 The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, and Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown met this afternoon with the Japanese Trade Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto. After his negotiations with Secretary Brown, Mr. Hashimoto quipped that "there was no fatal attack" on him from the American side, but he refused to disclose any details of how the discussions went.
Mr. Kantor and his top negotiator, Charlene Barshefsky, are scheduled to hold talks on Thursday and Friday in Los Angeles with the Japanese Foreign Minister, Yohei Kono, who will be in town for a four-way meeting of Japanese, American, Canadian and European Union trade ministers. Then all sides are expected to return to Washington for still more negotiating sessions.
In a briefing with reporters today, Mr. Kantor played down hopes for an immediate breakthrough, but he also played down the threatened trade sanctions as well.
"That appears to be a long, long way away as we sit here today," said Mr. Kantor, who clearly was trying to avoid saying anything that could set off another fall in the dollar.
"This is a time for listening, exchanging ideas, trying to determine whether on the framework, these sectors will be satisfied, and I think it would be unfortunate if I began to address the issue of Sept. 30," Mr. Kantor said. "How much progress and where we are successful are another question, and we will just wait and see over the next three weeks."
Progress on opening Japan's markets in insurance and government procurement has been more forthcoming because neither area involves large layoffs of Japanese workers or goes to the core of the Japanese economy.
But the automobile issue does. The car is the symbol of the Japanese export economy. The Japanese auto makers and affiliates carry enormous political weight in Japan. And, most important, because of all the past arguments and negotiations on auto issues between the two countries, there is great mistrust between them.
Therefore, the American side is demanding measurable criteria, some sort of fixed yardsticks, to determine whether Japan is really opening its automobile markets.
The Big Three auto makers say that as they try to import cars and light trucks to the Japanese market, they still face numerous nontariff barriers. For example, they particularly object to a process called "type notification," whereby a salesman must, as he completes a sale, take an imported vehicle to a Government office to have it certified. The vehicle must be certified for everything from emissions to quality standards, a process that can take up to six hours -- by which time, the Big Three argue, any self-respecting consumer would have given up.
