HEADLINE: An Innkeeper's Life, Leaky Roof and All

BYLINE: By HELEN PIKE 

 BODY:
ON a day last spring that was bright with sunshine, Luba and Bill Robinson finally realized that running a bed and breakfast was going to require more than just sipping port and trading witticisms with guests.
It was the afternoon they discovered water slowly sheeting down the parlor wall at the Whistling Swan Inn, a Queen Anne mansion in Stanhope, N.J., that had been lovingly restored. The owners were on vacation, and the Robinsons were inn-sitting, so to speak. So far that week, melting snow had already seeped into the basement, winding a course toward the washers and dryers. On another day, one of the housekeepers hadn't shown up, leaving Mrs. Robinson to wash the linen for the 10-bedroom inn by herself while her husband juggled reservations and dining-room duty. 
 On this warm afternoon, ice on the porch roof had started to melt, seeping behind the roof flashing that had separated from the house. "So there we were," Mrs. Robinson recalled. "Bill was on the porch roof and I was handing him an ice chipper when guests drove by looking for the driveway."
She improvised her inn etiquette. "I simply shouted out the directions," she said. "I mean, at that point, what else could I do?"
What the Robinsons, who work full-time for the AT&T Corporation, and other couples are doing is pulling aside the lace curtains on the romance of bed and breakfast inns. Many of them are assessing the merits of running their own establishments before taking the plunge.
This is a new approach taken by "refugees from Corporate America," as Pat Hardy calls them. Ms. Hardy is a founder and co-executive director of the 1,800-member Professional Association of Innkeepers International, which has trained about 1,500 wannabe innkeepers since 1980.
"They come with buyout money in hand and are looking for a major life-style change," she said. After taking the association's course, 90 percent change their minds.
These aspiring hosts are signing up for workshops or apprenticing as innkeepers. They are also attending seminars that cover everything from advertising to creative menu planning using grocery store coupons.
All of this knowledge may help set the sun on what Ms. Hardy calls "the green velvet skirt syndrome."
"That's what guests think it's all about: donning a smoking jacket or velvet finery, sipping sherry and talking about foreign affairs," said Ms. Hardy, who ran a bed and breakfast in Santa Barbara, Calif., for nine years and also helped write "So You Want to Be an Innkeeper" (Chronicle Books, 1990).
After a seminar and a weekend trial run, she recalled, "one couple, husband and wife dentists from the Midwest, decided their own lives didn't look so bad."
Others quickly learn they don't have the capital required to own an inn -- "a minimum of $200,000 and a lot of credit cards," Ms. Hardy said.
Some people, influenced no doubt by the sitcom adventures of Bob Newhart playing a befuddled Vermont innkeeper, decide to buy an existing inn where costly renovations have already been done and there is an established clientele. Others choose to manage an inn but not own one.
"You really learn the meaning of cash flow," said Paula Williams, who left AT&T and, with help from her husband, Joe Mulay, renovated the Whistling Swan Inn nine years ago from a multiple dwelling.
The couple were so besieged by questions from guests that they began conducting weekend workshops at the inn, which is 25 miles east of the Delaware Water Gap. (The $300 fee is refunded if a participating couple volunteers to fill in at the Whistling Swan for a week.) Eventually, Mr. Mulay followed his wife's footsteps with a buyout from AT&T and went to work with her full time.
Their workshops begin and end at the oak dining-room table that used to grace the Oklahoma farmhouse of Ms. Williams's grandmother.
A seminar last March drew seven participants, including one of the inn's three housekeepers, Barbara Depew. The couples were Margaret and Ronald Lunzman of Stockholm, N.J., who are looking for a bed and breakfast in the Poconos; Robert and Amy Geller of Monsey, N.Y., who spent their honeymoon at the Whistling Swan and hope to buy an inn in the future, and Ron and Jeanne Aquino Salvo of Mountainside, N.J., who want to go into the innkeeping business despite a few reservations.
"I'm the doubting Thomas," admitted Mr. Salvo, who works as a software consultant for Dun & Bradstreet. "This weekend is a big feasibility study."
About 3 percent of all inns fail each year, Ms. Hardy said. Some innkeepers choose a location too far off the beaten path, while others move to areas they are not familiar with. Still others decide to cut down on the number of rooms, making it difficult to pay for their investment. A few return the property to residential use after suffering from financial or emotional burnout or, as Ms. Hardy put it, "the disillusionment factor."
She estimates that the number of bed and breakfasts and country inns -- where dinner is served in addition to breakfast -- has stabilized between 12,000 and 15,000. In 1980, the number was a mere 1,000.
Ms. Hardy says she has seen the bed-and-breakfast industry crest in regional waves. From 1980 to 1985, there was growth on the East and West coasts, while in 1985, the Midwest and South surged ahead. Since 1990, there has been a swell of new inns in Montana, Wyoming and Colorado.
According to research compiled by the innkeepers' association, operating expenses can run between $8,000 and $15,000 a room. Ms. Hardy said a one- to four-bedroom inn would probably not break even; a five to eight-bedroom inn running at full occupancy year-round may earn $34,628 -- not including mortgage payments (and in 1992 the average occupancy rate was only 50 percent). A nine to twelve-room inn may earn only $79,000, again, minus mortgage payments.
Additional research shows that it takes about three years before innkeepers "start to see a light," Ms. Hardy continued. "In four years, they can put some money in their pocket, and in five years, they can buy a new car and go on a vacation."
Most entry-level innkeepers divide the responsibility of running an inn; one partner does most of the daily work, from making breakfasts to fixing toilets, while the other continues with his or her day job. "That way there's a second income to supplement operating expenses," Ms. Hardy explained.
Wendy Denn and her husband, Jon, publish the "Professional Inn Guide," a compilation of 395 members, whose inns meet certain standards set by organizations like the American Automobile Association and the American Bed and Breakfast Association. She, too, says prospective innkeepers should watch their expenses.
A simple bedroom makeover can cost $10,000 but can climb to $40,000 for a period room, said Ms. Denn, who also manages the Trinity Inn and Conference Center in West Cornwall, Conn.
After eight years of conducting workshops, Mr. Mulay and Ms. Williams have distilled their knowledge into a few key points.
"Figure out who you are so you can run an inn that works for you," Ms. Williams said. "Are you bidets and heated towel racks? Candles and Jacuzzis? Feather beds and remotes for the gas fireplace? Do you like to serve buffet style?"
Both suggest putting money back into the bathroom, the most frequently used room in an inn. "More businessmen are asking for tubs to soak in after a long day," Mr. Mulay added.
Have a private apartment, Ms. Williams advised, and take time out for a nap each day.
"Never buy a house without a clause that says the sale is contingent on receiving zoning approval," said Mr. Mulay, referring to property that will be converted from private to public use.
"Be prepared for a wide variety of diets, from vegetarians to diabetics to those guests with food allergies," said Ms. Williams, who collects recipes for food that can be prepared in bulk in advance and frozen. She favors a breakfast buffet and a single dining-room table where guests can eat family style.
"For heaven's sake, if you have a Victorian, don't name it after Victoria or Anne or any British princes," she continued. "Don't name it after fruits, either. Apple is the most over-used name after a queen or a prince."
"Workshops are useful not for convincing individuals to go into the business, but for helping them to decide it's not for them," said Ms. Williams, who also started the state's bed-and-breakfast industry association.
Of the 150 people who have attended weekend seminars at the Whistling Swan, 12 have gone on to open their own inns. Only one has failed, said Ms. Williams, adding that the host may have been doomed from the start by opening an inn in the already crowded New England market at the beginning of the recession.
As for the Robinsons, who were back in their Belle Meade town house Sunday night and at their respective jobs for AT&T Monday morning, they said they would do it all again.
"We still sipped sherry with the guests," Mr. Robinson said. "That was the reward for all the hard labor."
 
Advice For the Asking
 Paula Williams and Joe Mulay are planning a weekend workshop on Nov. 12 and 13 at the Whistling Swan Inn in Stanhope, N.J. The cost is $300 a couple. For information: (201) 347-6369.
Other seminars this fall with innkeepers in New Jersey, Vermont and Pennsylvania can be found through the Professional Association of Innkeepers International, P.O. Box 90710, Santa Barbara, Calif. 93190; (805) 569-1853.
 The Professional Inn Guide is $12.95, plus $2 for shipping and handling, from Colburn Press, Box 356, Montvale, N.J. 07645; (201) 652-1484.

HEADLINE: Three Congressional Endorsements

 BODY:
In three metropolitan area Congressional districts, victory in the Democratic primary on Sept. 13 will be tantamount to election because of the overwhelmingly Democratic registration. Here are our recommendations in these races.
Manhattan-Bronx, 15th District: Charles Rangel, the dean of New York's Congressional delegation, faces two challengers in only his second primary contest during 24 years in office. One of the challengers is Adam Clayton Powell 4th, son of the famous Harlem politician unseated by Mr. Rangel in 1970. 
 That infuses this race with history and a certain drama. When Mr. Rangel made his insurgent run for Congress, his opponent was clearly in the twilight of a once-powerful political career. Now Mr. Rangel is approaching the pinnacle of his own Congressional career. Mr. Powell 4th has depicted him as over the hill and out of touch.
Though too lax on Congressional reform, Mr. Rangel is a long way from being a spent volcano. He ranks fourth on the Ways and Means Committee, which is the source of all taxing power. Mr. Rangel's position is a clear benefit for his district and all of New York.
He has been active in trying to secure an empowerment zone for Harlem, which could be an important springboard for economic development. And he has been effective in forcing Washington to pay attention to urban concerns.
For his part, Mr. Powell has not been a particularly productive legislator, though he has developed a reputation for independence on the City Council. The brutal truth is that he is running more on his name than his record. Al Davis, an engineer, offers little of the background needed for effective service. So we firmly recommend Mr. Rangel.
Manhattan-Brooklyn, Eighth District: Jerrold Nadler has made an impressive debut in his first term in Congress. He has used his knowledge of transportation to address some of the city's infrastructure problems, from rebuilding the West Side Highway to proposing rail freight facilities to spur development.
Mr. Nadler faces two opponents in this race -- Deborah Green, a soft-spoken professional lobbyist on human rights issues, and Thomas Duane, a City Council member for nearly three years. By his own admission, Mr. Duane agrees with Mr. Nadler on most issues. A key distinction is that Mr. Duane is openly gay and promises to be especially sensitive to all forms of bigotry.
But Mr. Nadler already has a good record on civil rights issues, and his generally progressive stands on other issues ranging from health care to legislative reform merit our support.
Bronx-Westchester, 17th District: Voters in this scattered district -- covering parts of the Bronx, Yonkers, Mount Vernon, Pelham and New Rochelle -- confront an unusual if ultimately uninspiring choice.
Eliot Engel, seeking his fourth term, has not emerged as a forceful leader in New York's not particularly dazzling Congressional delegation. Many residents question his commitment to the district, and although he works hard, Mr. Engel has not left big footprints.
His challenger, the well-known salsa musician Willie Colon, has been involved in various social causes over the years, and we could not argue with voters who decide that a newcomer with strong ties to the large black and Latino population is more exciting than the incumbent. But, disappointingly, Mr. Colon has not mastered the issues that need to be addressed in Congress, and it is unclear where he differs on substance with Mr. Engel. Without great enthusiasm, we narrowly endorse Mr. Engel on the basis of his firmer grasp of the issues.

HEADLINE: The Trashing of CUNY

BYLINE: By Blanche Wiesen Cook and Sandi E. Cooper; Blanche Wiesen Cook, professor of history at John Jay College, is author of "Eleanor Roosevelt." Sandi E. Cooper is professor of history at the College of Staten Island and head of CUNY's Faculty Senate.

 BODY:
The decline or demise of the City University of New York has been forecast at least as far back as 1969, when enrollment was opened to anyone with a high school diploma. But this summer, the critics have been especially busy, and mean-spirited, too.
First, a long, contemptuous article by Heather Mac Donald appeared in the summer issue of City Journal, the quarterly of the Manhattan Institute, a conservative group that aspires to serve as the Giuliani administration's think tank. That attack found a much wider audience when John Leo cited it approvingly in U.S. News & World Report; Mr. Leo's column was then reprinted in newspapers around the country, and readers as far away as Seattle learned that "CUNY is at the cutting edge of a nationwide movement to do away with the very distinction between academic proficiency and deficiency and replace it with the concept of competence in one's own culture." 
These latest attacks reflect the national hand-wringing about the collapse of educational standards and local hostility to spending money for public education. They also reflect a social vision, disguised in the language of fiscal accountability, that follows these lines:
Not all students are educable; governments and universities are not equipped to repair the legacy of familial and societal decay; well-intended public efforts to eliminate inequality and abolish racism are expensive failures. Competition is the only way that the fittest and finest emerge as leaders. Higher education can benefit only a talented minority; it cannot address racial injustice or repair past discrimination; and, finally, what's good for the goose is good for the gander (that disposes of feminist or multicultural arguments). In short, social Darwinism is the anthem for the late 20th century.
To us, both graduates of city colleges in an era when tuition was free, these attacks are disgraceful. At a time when complex skills are needed for entry-level jobs, we see no wisdom in calls to curtail opportunity.
Those who lament the loss of 1950's standards, 1950's students and 1950's culture, the loss of some imagined Harvard on the Hudson, ignore the failures of the past, the achievements of the present and the realities of New York City.
There are in fact many similarities between the graduates of the old days and the graduates of today. CUNY's critics, however, tend to compare the top of the old with the bottom of the new. They ignore that the university has grown from 4 colleges to 20, including 10 senior colleges, 7 community colleges, a graduate center, a law school and an affiliated medical school. It serves more than 210,000 students, representing every segment of New York City.
These students include people from every ethnic group, from homeless families and families on welfare, and the newly arrived from every continent. At a time when less than 4 percent of students from the bottom quarter of the economic ladder now finish college, according to a recent report in Business Week, CUNY remains an exceptional avenue of opportunity. The first Rhodes Scholar from Brooklyn College is a Puerto Rican woman. CUNY graduates more African-American and Latino engineers, science majors and master's candidates than any other university in the United States.
But CUNY's critics invoke only those statistics designed to demonstrate that students burn money, fail excessively and earn worthless degrees. Ms. Mac Donald cites a 1989 survey finding that only 22 percent of the 1980 freshmen had graduated within five years. But studies by CUNY statisticians suggest that 40 percent graduate within eight years, and there is a good reason it might take so long: a typical CUNY student is a working adult, often with family responsibilities and often attending part time.
Open enrollment, the favored target of conservative critics, does not really exist anymore at the four-year colleges -- City, Hunter, Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island, New York City Technical, York, Baruch, Lehman and Medgar Evers. It was basically undone as a result of New York City's fiscal crisis in 1974-75. That year, classes and graduations were suspended, faculty and staff members lost salary, tenure was broken and tuition was imposed. Eventually the four-year colleges reinstated admission requirements close to the national norms.
Meanwhile, the system has been starved of the resources it needs to do its job. The full-time faculty has been reduced by a third since 1975. Class size has doubled, and classes are increasingly taught by young adjuncts or graduate students. Last year there was a furor over Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds's reorganization plan, which appeared to restrict liberal-arts education and redirect resources to practical, career-oriented training. Though this plan has been formally abandoned, faculty members remain suspicious that its objectives may yet be achieved by the back door, through budget allocations.
These difficult circumstances don't upset CUNY's critics, including a few professors who continue to accept salaries for work they now seem to detest. They represent a tiny minority of the faculty who have declared war not on the shrinking of the public purse but on the students.
The critics are correct to this extent: the allocated budgets cannot support CUNY's needs. But the critics' prescriptions for triage of the weak -- curtailing admissions, remedial services, counseling support and the SEEK program for disadvantaged students -- are wrong.
We must relearn some lessons and treat this generation as generously as we did the veterans of World War II. The public funds that they got helped create the biggest boom in American history. Only a handful of far-right cranks, in those days, complained about the G.I. Bill, or housing loans or pensions for the disabled. Is that because the beneficiaries were largely white males? Amid the difficulties of the present, the past always has a rosy glow that wasn't there when we lived in it.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Imagine A G.O.P. Senate

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"Seven More in '94" was the wild-and-woolly slogan perpetrated in this space almost a year ago, in a report of a long-shot Republican chance to capture the Senate.
Back then, the switch of seven seats to give the G.O.P. a 51-to-49 majority was seen as a partisan's pipe dream. Now, as the '94 campaign begins in earnest, you hear George Mitchell, the retiring Democratic leader, predicting a loss of three or four seats (not including his own) while Bob Dole (busily creating delegate i.o.u.'s in the Northwest this week) predicts Republican gains of six or seven. 
 Hyper-sophisticated political deconstructionists will interpret this to mean that the Democrats are winning the Expectation Game. By persuading the public that an upheaval is in the works, anything short of upheaval in November -- a five-vote loss in the Senate, say, along with a 20-vote loss in the House -- Democrats could characterize as a kind of midterm victory. The headline would begin: "Republicans Fail . . ."
Let me fall right into that expectation trap by posing the question too overconfident for prudent pols: What if the Republicans actually won control of the Senate -- or, in a dead heat of 50-50, were able to persuade Richard Shelby of Alabama to swing over? What then? With the lady in the old George Price cartoon, contemplating a zookeeper inside a monkey cage trying to get his hat back from the gleeful monkeys, we can ask: "Who's in charge here?"
Bob Dole would be majority leader, somewhat less beholden to the most conservative members than he is now. He would soon be forced to choose between leader and Presidential candidate; my guess is that he would take the bird in hand, though Alan Simpson, now the whip, would be pushing him hard for the Presidency.
The nonagenarian Strom Thurmond, the only American official able to call Deng Xiaoping "sonny," would be chairman of Armed Services, replacing Sam Nunn, who might then find being ranking minority member too much of a comedown and accept Defense or State in the lame-duck Cabinet. John Warner would be de facto Armed Services chairman until ol' Strom retires in 1997.
The Foreign Relations Committee (Quick: who's chairman now?) would go by seniority to Jesse Helms, unless he again affirmed his loyalty to his constituents' favorite, Agriculture; in that case, Richard Lugar would return to lead Foreign Relations, now in dire need of reinvigoration. (Quiz answer: Claiborne Pell.)
Banking would go to Alfonse D'Amato (and just watch those Whitewater subpoenas fly). Orrin Hatch would head Judiciary, Larry Pressler Commerce, Mark Hatfield Appropriations and Frank Murkowski Energy. Arlen Specter would become chairman of the Select Committee on Intelligence.
The innermost members of the Inner Club in a Dole Republican Senate, barring a major war, would be Bob Packwood heading the Finance Committee and Pete Domenici as chairman of Budget. With Simpson, they would decide what legislation moves.
What sort of legislation would move? Provided there was a shift of 30 votes in the House, a full-fathom-five sea change would take place in the wake of a majority change.
A balanced budget amendment would pass. So would a line-item veto. And a term-limits amendment would pass, be vetoed by a gutsy President Clinton, and have a chance of passage over his veto. Free trade would get a boost.
Health reform? The pre-existing Dole-Packwood plan -- permanent, portable insurance, with subsidies to the poor, deductions to individuals and no hidden taxes -- would sail through. And welfare reform, sidetracked since "Nixon's Good Deed" was done in by Democrats in 1970, would have its day in the sun.
Clinton's forgotten promise of tax relief to the middle class would be remembered. Taxes would not only go down, but policy would be directed away from consumption and toward investment. With a lower cap on mortgage deductions, prospects would be bright for tax-free savings accounts and a reduction of double taxation of dividends. The economic emphasis would be on growth, not redistribution of wealth.
What would "seven more in '94" do to the Clinton Presidency? The more relevant question is: Would the agile Clinton listen to the voice of the people, or spend his final two years furiously trying to sweep back the wave of the future?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Exxon Oil Spill Devastated a Way of Life

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Five years after the Exxon Valdez oil spill, all is not well in Alaska's Prince William Sound. I live here and know firsthand the environmental degradation, economic devastation and social upheaval it caused. Exxon ruined far more than the sound's fishing. Exxon ruined a way of life. 
 The commercial harvest of pink salmon in Prince William Sound, unlike other areas, has been coming up short since the spill, because of low prices, low volumes or both. The harvest improved in 1994, but was still low in oiled areas. Herring fisheries crashed in 1993 and 1994.
Government scientists have verified in laboratory studies that genetic damage and reproductive impairment occurred in pink salmon and herring exposed to the 1989 spill. Long-term effects occur predominantly in these and other species, like
harlequin ducks, oyster catchers and juvenile sea otters, which feed or breed in the intertidal zone.
More than 50 intertidal mussel beds in the oiled sections of the sound remain heavily contaminated with Exxon Valdez oil and may be a continuing source of chronic oil damage. This summer, five years after the spill, government scientists initiated tests to determine if the oil could be removed from these mussel beds.
Exxon scientists have not found any chronic effects from oil because they did not want to. I compared 32 government and Exxon studies, and found that Exxon's studies demonstrated a bias intentionally directed at "proving" there was no effect from the spill.
For example, Exxon scientists averaged the oil concentrations in sea-water samples taken from different depths and areas, including areas not yet oiled at the time of initial sampling. This averaging effectively diluted any high oil levels, and the resulting low "average" oil levels were used to justify Exxon's claims for absence of biological effects.
Social scientists have documented what we found out the hard way. Cordova, Alaska, is particularly vulnerable to technological disasters. Injury to natural resources disrupts the pattern of sharing that forms a web of behaviors and social interactions, giving a sense of worth to individuals, strength to families and structure to society. In 1993, subsistence harvests in Prince William Sound still had not fully recovered.
 
RIKI OTT
Cordova, Alaska, Sept. 1, 1994
 
The writer, a commercial fisher, is author of "Sound Truth," on the spill.

HEADLINE: SERBIAN PRESIDENT IS SAID TO ACCEPT TRADE MONITORING

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Western diplomats said today that President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia had accepted a compromise plan for monitoring the trade embargo he has imposed on the Bosnian Serbs. In return, they said, the Security Council will move to ease sanctions on Serbia as early as next week.
The United States, Britain, France, Germany and Russia, members of the so-called contact group trying to make peace in Bosnia, announced in Berlin on Wednesday that if the Serbs agreed to allow observers along the border with Bosnia, the economic embargo against Serbia would be relaxed in stages. 
 Mr. Milosevic imposed the embargo on his former proteges last month, after the Bosnian Serbs rejected the contact group's peace plan. The five nations had made the Bosnian Serbs' acceptance a condition for lifting international trade sanctions on Yugoslavia, which comprises Serbia and Montenegro.
The Bosnian Serbs have relied on Serbia for much of their war materiel. Without such shipments, especially of fuel, the Bosnian Serbs' ability to fight will be severely impaired, tipping the balance of power toward the Muslim-dominated Government.
Under such circumstances, pressure on the Bosnian Serbs to seek peace would be vastly increased.
First official word of the agreement came when the French Foreign Ministry announced in Paris that Belgrade had agreed to accept "an international humanitarian mission" along its border with Bosnia to verify Mr. Milosevic's pledge to end military assistance to the Serbs.
The new plan, American and other diplomats here said, foresees stationing up to 200 civilian monitors along this frontier, which largely follows the Drina River. The monitors would have the double task of certifying that Yugoslavia is continuing to supply the Bosnian Serbs with food and other relief goods, while insuring that it does not send in fuel and weapons.
As a reward for accepting the monitors, the five nations will recommend that the Security Council temporarily reopen Yugoslav airports to international flights and end the ban on Yugoslav participation in international sporting and cultural events, allowing it take part in the coming European soccer championships.
The contract group's United Nations representatives held a first meeting here today to start work on a sanctions-loosening resolution, as well as on another resolution tightening restrictions on Bosnia's Serbs.
If Mr. Milosevic sticks to the plan, many diplomats here say, President Clinton will have little chance of persuading the Security Council to lift its arms embargo on the Bosnian Government, as he has said he would try to do if the Bosnian Serbs did not make peace by Oct. 15.
The arms embargo, imposed on all sides in the Balkan conflict, has effectively perpetuated the weapons advantage held by the Serbs at the beginning of the war in 1992.
While the United States and the Council's five nonaligned members -- Pakistan, Djibouti, Rwanda, Nigeria and Oman -- favor lifting the arms embargo, the other nine -- Russia, Britain, France, China, New Zealand, Spain, the Czech Republic, Brazil and Argentina -- are opposed. In any event Russia, a traditional ally of the Serbs, has indicated that it would use its veto if needed to maintain the embargo.
 
Effect on Other Embargoes
 The United States cannot violate the arms embargo unilaterally without encouraging other countries to break embargoes that Washington favors, including those against Iraq, Libya and Haiti.
The new monitoring plan was worked out over several weeks between the official mediators in the former Yugoslavia, Lord Owen of Britain and Thorvald Stoltenberg of Norway, and Mr. Milosevic.
Brig. Gen. Bo Pellnas of Sweden, a former United Nations military observer in the Balkans who will become a civilian to lead the monitors, is to meet with representatives of the contact group in Geneva early next week to discuss the plan. The monitors are to be drawn from the mainly European members of the London Conference on the Former Yugoslavia, which has been trying for three years to end the fighting.
After Bosnia's Serbs rejected the peace plan drawn up by the contact group this summer, President Milosevic, who accepts the plan, closed Serbia's border with Bosnia, cutting off all supplies except food and medicine in an attempt to make the Bosnian Serbs change their minds.
The intermediary countries say Mr. Milosevic's embargo seems to be working, but they want to place monitors along the frontier to make sure.
But Mr. Milosevic refused to accept United Nations military monitors but finally agreed to civilians.
To avoid the appearance of infringing on Yugoslav sovereignty, the monitors will mainly observe the local border police as they check trucks crossing into Bosnia. The monitors will make recommendations to the border police and report back to the Security Council on whether Yugoslavia is cooperating.
 
Rebutting Domestic Critics
 To protect himself against domestic critics, diplomats say, Mr. Milosevic plans to present the operation as one intended to verify that he is keeping Serbia's Bosnian brothers and sisters fully supplied with food and medicine, and so refute rumors put out by his enemies that he is trying to starve them into surrender.
While the monitors will indeed perform this function, their prime role is to insure that Mr. Milosevic continues to deny the Bosnian Serbs military supplies.
If the monitoring plan works well, then the Security Council is expected to adopt two resolutions: One would end the ban on international air traffic and permit Yugoslavia to take part in international cultural and sporting events. But to keep up the pressure, this relaxation would lapse after a month or so unless the Council extended it. The other step would tighten sanctions against the Bosnian Serbs and make it harder for them to get money from abroad.

Serbs Attack Enclave
 SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sept. 8 (Reuters) -- Serbs from Croatia and Bosnia opened a major assault today against the Muslim enclave of Bihac, in northwestern Bosnia, officials said. More than 1,000 ethnic Serbian troops backed by tanks and artillery poured into Bihac from Croatia.
Serbs also fired a surface-to-air missile at two NATO combat aircraft, United Nations and NATO officials said. The planes, Harrier jump-jets of the British Navy, were not hit.
The United Nations peacekeeping force said the pincer offensive into Bihac was alarming because it involved Serbs from neighboring Croatia as well as Bosnian Serbs.
"We're talking of upward of 1,000 troops, tanks and artillery -- the works," said a United Nations spokesman, Maj. Dacre Holloway.
The NATO Southern Command in Naples said the two Harriers returned safely to the aircraft carrier Invincible in the Adriatic.

HEADLINE: Cuba, in Shift, Says Deal Can Be Reached With the U.S.

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAVANA, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Just days after the Government described its talks with the United States over immigration issues as being stalled, Cuban officials now say they believe a deal can be struck.
Returning home for consultations with President Fidel Castro and other officials, Cuba's chief negotiator, Ricardo Alarcon, said Wednesday night that despite major differences he was "confident that an acceptable agreement can be reached." 
 The change in tone came as the flood of refugees leaving the island on rafts and small boats appeared to be leveling off, easing pressure on the Clinton Administration to negotiate an accord under which the Cuban Government would renew efforts to stop the exodus.
It also coincided with meetings in Madrid between the Cuban Foreign Minister, Roberto Robaina, and three of the most prominent Cuban exiles ever to meet with members of the Castro Government.
 
Meetings Called Positive
 Though all three are considered moderates within the Cuban community in Miami, where they live, one of them, Ramon Cernuda, is a formal representative in the United States for one of the best-known dissident groups on the island. Another, Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, is a former leader of Mr. Castro's insurgency who turned against the revolution and spent years as a political prisoner.
Cuban officials provided no details on what was discussed in the meetings, which were arranged by Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain. The dissidents said only that the meetings represented a positive and conciliatory first step by the Government.
Under the circumstances, however, the symbolism may have been far more important than the substance.
"This is the first time that the Cuban Government has recognized the existence of the opposition and has agreed to speak with it," Mr. Cernuda told reporters in Madrid. Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo added, "The Cuban Government has taken a step that it had not taken in 35 years."
Since Cuba began its negotiations with the United States in New York more than a week ago, the Government here has sought to emphasize its willingness to engage Washington in whatever dialogue it can.
 
Negotiator Sees Gains
 At the same time, it has taken advantage of attention drawn to the refugees, a total of about 30,000 in the past month, to repeat its argument that only by ending the long embargo against Cuba can the United States ease the deprivation that Havana says is the essential cause of the exodus.
In an interview with Cuban television on Wednesday night, Mr. Alarcon suggested that Cuba was making headway in the political battle.
Citing recent criticism of the embargo by some United States senators and newspaper editorialists, he said, "Every day the view becomes more widespread in the United States that the only way to resolve the problems between the two countries is by putting an end to the blockade and sitting down to talk about all the problems in a broad and respectful way."
Cuban officials offered no details of the proposals that Mr. Alarcon presented to officials here before flying back to New York this afternoon.
But two diplomats familiar with the Cuban position said that for the first time since the refugee crisis began little more than a month ago, Cuban officials had begun talking about the possibility of taking back some of the Cubans now interned at camps in Panama and the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. American officials said that the United States was asking Cuba to accept only the 225 or so Cubans who have asked to return.
 
'A Handful of Issues'
 Some American officials have said that the mere threat of a forced repatriation of Cubans who risked their lives to leave the island could lead to riots at the camps and angry protests from Cuban-Americans. At the same time, the Clinton Administration has shown no sign of having come up with any other solution.
Some Cuban officials have indicated that an increase in visas for Cubans wanting to join relatives in the United States -- even to annual levels of more than 20,000 migrants -- would not be a sufficient American concession in the talks. One diplomat said that, in part, the Cubans were seeking assurances that sooner or later the United States would agree to talks focused on the embargo.
The chief State Department spokesman, Mike McCurry, said today that the negotiations on migration were down to "a handful of issues," which he would not specify. But the Clinton Administration has insisted that it will lift economic sanctions against Cuba only when the Communist Government takes concrete steps to democratize its political system.
Although diplomats said today that Mr. Robaina's meetings with the Miami exiles were the sort of first steps that Cuba might take toward an eventual political opening, Cuban officials generally played down their importance.
"This is part of a process," the Foreign Ministry official in charge of the Government's contacts with Cuban exiles, Jose R. Cabanas, said in an interview this afternoon. "What this shows above all is our willingness to talk with all sorts of people who have a respectful position and are not hostile toward our country."
Despite founding the paramilitary group Alpha 66 and spending 22 years in Mr. Castro's jails after being captured in 1964, Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo, 59, has supported discussions with the Government in order to bring about democracy. Mr. Cernuda, the director of a Cuban art museum in Miami, represents the Cuban Committee for Human Rights, a group led by one of the island's most prominent dissidents, Elizardo Sanchez. Like Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo and Alfredo Duran, a lawyer associated with Democratic Party politics in Florida who also met with Mr. Robaina, Mr. Cernuda has battled frequently with hard-line exile leaders in southern Florida.
 
'Gestures of Generosity'
 After meeting with Mr. Robaina himself today, the Spanish Prime Minister, who helped obtain Mr. Gutierrez Menoyo's freedom in 1986, said Cuba must "begin a process of rapid and profound transformations" that would include "gestures of generosity toward dissident groups."
Mr. Gonzalez's comments appeared to represent a ratcheting up of pressure on Mr. Castro by the Spanish Government, which has long sought to promote peaceful change in Cuba but has appeared increasingly frustrated with the results.
Meanwhile, the pressure of Cuban events on the Clinton Administration may be in remission. According to a spokesman for the United States Coast Guard district office in Miami, rescue vessels picked up 689 Cuban refugees on Tuesday and 1,029 on Wednesday, continuing a pattern in which the numbers had hovered around 1,000 a day since last Saturday.
By midnight , 610 more had been plucked from the sea.

 BODY:

The Economy
 Seeking to halt talk of a split at the top of the Federal Reserve, Alan S. Blinder, the Fed's vice chairman, took the unusual step of defending remarks, saying he does not differ with Alan Greenspan over monetary policy. [Page D1.] 
 Consumer credit grew for the 16th consecutive month in July, but at a slower pace than in previous months. In a separate report, a survey of companies showed they planned to increase spending on new plants and equipment at the highest rate in five years. [D2.]
The wrongdoing of unscrupulous brokers is difficult to uncover, according to a General Accounting Office report that said existing detection and reporting systems were inadequate. [D2.]
 
Companies
 Ford Motor indicated that William Clay Ford Jr. would lead the next generation of the company, the nation's most powerful industrial dynasty. Mr. Ford, a great-grandson of the founder, Henry Ford, will become chairman of the board committee that oversees all important financial and strategic decisions. The move makes him one of the most powerful executives at Ford. [D1.]
Bell Atlantic and AT&T have been squabbling in an $11 billion effort to build an advanced video network. While the companies are optimistic they can work out their differences, the dispute is another example of how the vision of a data superhighway is giving way to the reality of building a piece of it. [D1.]
The Ziffs may have picked the right time to sell their computer-publishing empire. And documents being reviewed by prospective bidders indicate that Ziff Communications had taken a number of steps during the last few years to improve profitability -- just the sort of touch-up that would make it more attractive to buyers. Treasury prices were little changed in quiet trading as investors awaited today's report on producer prices. [D11.]
Prices for lumber fell sharply after fears of a strike of wood workers in British Columbia faded. [D14.]
The dollar strengthened against the mark after German and American officials said the dollar was undervalued. [D14.]

 Warner-Lambert is a favorite subject of takeover talk. HEADLINE: Quayle, Defending '92 Speech, Returns to Family Values Theme

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8

 BODY:
With an eye on both his political past and future, former Vice President Dan Quayle returned today to the place where two years ago he made Murphy Brown's out-of-wedlock television baby a "family values" issue in the 1992 Presidential campaign.
Speaking again to members of the Commonwealth Club of California, he said the baby was still a values issue in American life, an unfortunate prime-time symbol of the country's "poverty of values." 
 "The ideal situation for our children is to be born and raised in an intact family, and I unapologetically assert that again," he said, asserting that liberals and news organizations had mocked and distorted his 1992 effort to focus attention on the dissolution of American families.
The critics and carpers were 180 degrees off, Mr. Quayle said, proffering a new analysis of his original speech.
"They turned it into an attack on single moms and working women," he said. "What I was talking about then, and what I am reiterating today, is the importance of fathers. Raising children is not just a mother's responsibility."
 
A Campaign in '96?
 What Mr. Quayle did not say today, and what he would not say even when pressed hard by his audience, was whether he had plans for making Baby Brown and the larger symbolism he sees an issue in the Presidential campaign of 1996.
Instead, he strung his audience along, throwing out phrases like "if I run," and here and there tweaking President Clinton, mainly for his handling of foreign affairs.
"This time around, if I choose to run, I will not run for the No. 2 spot," he said. "It will be my campaign, my ideas, and it will be done my way."
Could he persuade the electorate in 1996 to take him more seriously? Would the jokes and mockery stop?
"It's already much different," he insisted.
 
Testing the Waters
 This has been Mr. Quayle's stock approach to questions about 1996 for the past several months as he has toured the country, testing his standing within the Republican Party as measured against other possible contenders in 1996, among them Senator Bob Dole of Kansas and former Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp.
Once the 1994 elections for Congress and governors are over, he said, he will announce his decision.
Meanwhile, he is not only testing the waters but is also building up political good will by attending fund-raising events and rallies for 1994 Republican candidates from coast to coast. On Tuesday, for example, he was the featured guest at a fund-raising event in Pasadena for Gov. Pete Wilson, who faces a strong re-election challenge from State Treasurer Kathleen Brown.
And, like most national politicians with national ambition, Mr. Quayle has written the obligatory memoir, "Standing Firm," which is always on sale after each speech, with no extra charge for the autograph. Its recent publication, along with his increased presence on the hustings, has also resulted in an increasing number of invitations to appear on television news and interview shows. This morning, for example, he appeared on the NBC News program "Today."
In the speech here, Mr. Quayle was careful to press most of the hot buttons of Republican conservatism, everything from welfare reform to lower taxes. He drew frequent applause from his audience, seemingly made up mainly of Republican members of the Commonwealth Club, a public affairs forum that is a must stop on the political trail for serious national campaigners.
There was laughter when he charged that Mr. Clinton had no fixed foreign policy and sooner or later would discover that "there's more to it than the economy, stupid," a biting paraphrase of a Clinton campaign maxim. There were murmurs of approval when he proposed an oil embargo on Cuba to force President Fidel Castro's hand.
But for the most part, Mr. Quayle kept the focus on family values and his reprise of what he called "The Poverty of Values, Part 2."
He argued that although his first speech had drawn laughter and ridicule, the passage of time had proved him right. In fact, he noted, Mr. Clinton now speaks often about "community values."
 
Stirred National Debate
 In his 1992 speech, Mr. Quayle stirred a national debate about family values when he declared that "failing to support children one has fathered is wrong," then added: "It doesn't help matters when prime-time TV has Murphy Brown -- a character who supposedly epitomizes today's intelligent, highly paid, professional woman -- mocking the importance of fathers by bearing a child alone and calling it just another lifestyle choice."
Mr. Quayle said today that he did not intend to dwell on the television show and, in fact, he mentioned it only in passing. But there was never any doubt about what he was talking about.
"Illegitimacy seems to be a pathology that feeds upon itself, entrenching and expanding with each generation," he said. "If children grow up never knowing their father, they assume that fathers are irrelevant and that males are not accountable.
"The implicit message to young girls is that it is acceptable to have children without marriage. The message to boys is that they need not be responsible in their behavior. This is tragic and wrong. Little wonder that so many young people live amid ethical chaos."

HEADLINE: Regulator Fears That Economics Could Lead A-Plants to Scrimp

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that looming deregulation was creating unprecedented economic pressure for utilities and providing an "incentive to cut corners" at nuclear reactors.
The chairman, Ivan Selin, said the pressure would prompt his regulators to examine a new area when evaluating a plant that is operating badly: whether financial strain on the parent utility had left it starved for resources. 
 The pressure Mr. Selin was referring to results from a movement led by California regulators toward "retail wheeling." Under that system, electricity users can buy from the local utility, as they do now, or from distant generators, which can be either utilities or independent power producers. The local utility would be obliged to deliver the power. Such a system would end the monopoly power of utilities; anticipating that retail wheeling will be widely implemented, utilities around the country have moved to cut costs.
"Even financially sound utilities are under great pressure to reduce their rates, to be competitive," Mr. Selin said in an hourlong session with reporters on nuclear topics. "They may be tempted to put off capital investment that we consider necessary to maintain equipment in top shape. We have to be that much more alert about the safety implications."
 
Concerns About Indian Point
 Mr. Selin said his agency would pay close attention to spending by utilities at reactors but only where plants were in difficulty.
He cited only one example of a plant that bore watching, the New York Power Authority's Indian Point 3 plant, in Buchanan, about 35 miles up the Hudson River from Manhattan. A spokesman for the authority said that budget reductions were planned at Indian Point as part of an effort to cut the overall budget by 15 percent but that they were small and would have "absolutely no effect on safety" at the reactor.
Whether cost-cutting will lead the plants to jeopardize safety is a matter of debate among industry experts.
"What he says makes sense intuitively," Barry M. Abramson, a utility analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities, said of Mr. Selin's remarks. "Competitive pressures are going to force companies to cut costs."
Utilities have been cutting workers for a few years, Mr. Abramson said, and while they at first exempted their nuclear plants, they no longer do. And if corners were cut, it would be hard to discern, he said, adding, "No utility would tell you that they prefer to be the low-cost producer but unsafe."
Still, Mr. Abramson said, for most companies the nuclear plant is the biggest single asset, and they would not intentionally endanger it. He said, though, that competition might encourage some utilities to retire their high-cost reactors early.
Mark D. Luftig, an analyst at Salomon Brothers, said most companies would find it cheaper to invest in maintenance and keep the plant running more, because the key to profitability was keeping the plant on line.
At the San Francisco office of the Environmental Defense Fund, David Roe, an expert on electricity production and use, said Mr. Selin's warning was "a classic case of regulators' tunnel vision."
"The same thing was said about the airline industry" when deregulation was initiated there, he said.
Mr. Selin singled out Indian Point 3, which has been shut for safety reasons since Feb. 27, 1993, and which the Power Authority now believes could be ready to re-open early next year. With a combination of a weak economy in the Northeast and high-efficiency lamps, motors and heating systems, New York has an electricity surplus, which has helped cut electricity prices.
"The objective situation seems to indicate that they have more incentive to cut corners," Mr. Selin said, but he added that in recent months, "the Power Authority has been pouring resources into Indian Point."

HEADLINE: Blacks Far More Likely Than Whites to Have AIDS, Agency Says

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Black women are nearly 15 times more likely than white women to have AIDS, while black men are five times more likely than white men to have the disease, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said today.
AIDS is already the leading cause of death of black and Hispanic men age 25 to 44. Preliminary data indicate that AIDS has become the second-leading cause of death among black women age 25 to 44, the centers said. 
 In its weekly report on health issues, the agency said that of the 106,949 AIDS cases reported in the United States last year, 58,538, or 55 percent, occurred among racial and ethnic minorities. Of these, 38,544 involved blacks, 18,888 involved Hispanic Americans, 767 Asian-Americans and Pacific islanders, and 339 American Indians and Alaska natives.
There were 73 AIDS cases among every 100,000 black women, while the rate for white women was 5 per 100,000.
 
Many Cases of Drug Use
 Forty-seven percent of AIDS cases among minority women were caused by intravenous drug use, while 37 percent were due to the transmission of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, through heterosexual intercourse.
"We're still not getting the message across to women that you can become infected with H.I.V. through sex with a man and that you cannot tell that the person is H.I.V.-infected by just looking at them," said Dr. Teresa Diaz, an epidemiologist in the the agency's surveillance branch.
Among Hispanic and black men, homosexual contact was cited as the mode of infection in 39 percent of cases, while intravenous drug use was the cause in 38 percent.
Dr. Diaz said intravenous drug use was a continuing problem. "It is still the primary mode of exposure for black women," she said.
Racial and ethnic minorities accounted for three-fourths of AIDS cases among adult and teen-age women, and 84 percent of the cases involving children aged 12 and under, the agency said.
The data showed that complex social, economic and cultural factors complicated efforts to prevent AIDS, Dr. Diaz said.
"If you're poor and live in a high-crime area, you have other priorities, like violence or crime and other diseases, and may not have such a high priority for H.I.V. and AIDS," she said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Treasury Bond Prices Barely Budge

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed yesterday as investors limited their trading, awaiting today's release of the Producer Price Index. Some analysts expect the report to show that inflation is accelerating and to speed up the timetable of another interest-rate increase by the Federal Reserve.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond was unchanged at a price of 999/32 to yield 7.56 percent. The yields on some shorter maturities, like the three-year note, fell slightly. 
 It was the kind of session when even a stronger dollar in the currency markets, a smaller than expected decline in weekly jobless claims, or comments by the vice chairman of the Fed, could not turn the market's interest away from inflation.
Treasury prices rose in the morning and than slowly settled in the afternoon as market expectations grew that the Producer Price Index could be worse than expected. That notion may have been exacerbated by comments of Fed officials yesterday, said Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "They indicated that the central bank is still biased toward tightening further, but not necessarily in the immediate future," she said.
 
Conditional Explanations
 Ms. Schaja forecasts that overall producer prices increased four-tenths of 1 percent in August while the so-called core rate, which excludes food and energy prices, rose two-tenths of 1 percent. "If the core number is stronger it may be because of the stronger auto sales," she said.
Even if today's producer price increase turns out to be lower than expected, investors and traders are likely to wait until they see the August Consumer Price Index before they relax. That report will be released Tuesday.
Yesterday's initial weekly unemployment report released by the Labor Department showed claims for the week ending Sept. 3 down 3,000, to 330,000, from a revised 333,000 the previous week.
Economists said that with the release of this week's statistic, August's average for initial unemployment claims shows an improvement in the labor market compared with July. The August payroll employment report, however, showed an increase of only 179,000 in nonfarm payroll, compared with a 251,000 increase for July.
Another indicator of economic growth came in the Commerce Department's survey of capital spending, which showed a rise despite the upward trend in interest rates.
According to the survey, American industry is increasing its spending this year on new factories and equipment at the fastest rate in five years. The projected increase is 8.8 percent over last year's total and the highest since an 11.4 percent increase in 1989. But analysts cautioned that this spending could be nearing its peak.
 
Fed Members' Remarks
 Some cause for bond selling in the afternoon came from remarks attributed to a Fed governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, who said that the economy was in a solid growth pattern, leaving some to infer that the Fed would continue raising rates this year to keep growth under control and inflation at bay.
Traders said those comments eclipsed those made earlier by the Fed's new vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, to a group of mortgage bankers in Washington. He said that long-term interest rates would fall if inflation was under control.
In a surprise development, the Treasury announced that it would auction $4 billion of cash management bills today in what a Government official described as a precaution against a faster pace of spending than expected.
Elsewhere, prices of corporate bonds were little changed. J. P. Morgan & Company sold $500 million of 7 5/8 percent noncallable notes due in 2004 at a price of 99.504, to yield 7.697 percent.
And the Tennessee Valley Authority sold $500 million of 40-year power bonds with an 8 1/4 percent coupon at a price of 95.746, to yield 8.63 percent. Callable in five years, the issue was priced through CS First Boston.

HEADLINE: Republican Candidates Run Hard and Cheaply

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Sept. 8

 BODY:
It seems like a throwback to old-fashioned politics, two candidates traveling across Connecticut, speaking at luncheons, shaking hands at fairs, marching in parades, telling people face to face why they want to be elected to the United States Senate.
But for Dr. Gerald Labriola, a retired pediatrician, and Dr. Joseph Bentivegna, a young ophthalmologist, their shoe-leather campaigns in a primary for the Republican Party's Senate nomination are all they can afford. While the Democratic incumbent, Joseph I. Lieberman, has raised more than $4 million and already is spending heavily on television ads, the two Republicans together have raised less than $120,000. Television is something they can only watch.
 
Incumbent's Advantage
 As a result, changing the campaign-finance laws to limit the advantages of incumbency is one of the few issues on which the two doctors agree. Dr. Labriola, a former state senator and candidate for governor and lieutenant governor, notes that Senator Lieberman established a re-election fund a month after taking office in 1989. 
 "It's fundamentally unfair to allow incumbents to raise money for six years," Dr. Labriola said. "Five years ago, he was raising money while I was examining babies."
Dr. Bentivegna, who has never run for office before, and who often seems to rely on conversations with his patients for his information on issues, said Mr. Lieberman's millions intimidated better qualified Republicans.
"Why is a guy like me on the verge of winning this primary?" he said "It's because the more established politicians looked at that war chest and said 'Forget it.' "
Dr. Labriola, who was recruited for the race by national party officials and who won the party's endorsement in July, is running mainly against Mr. Lieberman, mentioning Dr. Bentivegna only when asked about him.
"Joe Bentivegna is a nice fellow, an eye surgeon from Rocky Hill," Dr. Labriola said blandly, when the question came up at a Rotary Club lunch in Meriden.
 
'Clintonesque' Opponent
 He describes Senator Lieberman, on the other hand, as part of the "Clintonesque group" in Washington, a Beltway insider who raises much of his campaign money outside Connecticut and has voted against the state's interests.
While Mr. Lieberman has gained a reputation for standing apart from his party on important votes, Dr. Labriola said he "fakes right and votes left," in the end siding with President Clinton nearly every time, even on tax increases that hit Connecticut's high-income families especially hard.
The Senator said he is a moderate, Dr. Labriola told the Rotarians. "But is Clinton a moderate?" he asked. "He's a tax-and-spend liberal."
"What do I offer?" he says to audiences. "A belief that the role of government is helping people only when they can't help themselves. Being tough on crime and knowing who's the victim and who's the criminal. Empowering people, not governments. Traditional values for the family, church, patriotism."
 
Health-Care Proposal
 As a doctor, he has a health-care proposal whose starting point is, he said, "First, do no ill." The health-care system needs only repairs, he said. Costs can be cut by reducing paperwork, limiting malpractice awards and lawyers' fees, and encouraging hospitals to find economies and doctors to order fewer tests.
He would finance the cost of making health care more accessible by reducing farm subsidies and foreign aid and by eliminating unemployment benefits for illegal aliens.
Most of all, he said, Congress should move slowly. "Health care is the most important piece of legislation since Social Security or Medicare, and it should not be trivialized," he said.
In a primary in which neither Republican has money for advertising, Dr. Labriola has the advantage of being on the top line of the ballot. It might also seem to be an advantage that he can accuse his opponent, Dr. Bentivegna, of favoring the legalization of drugs, opposing the death penalty and supporting socialized medicine.
Dr. Bentivegna, however, has made a virtue of speaking his mind regardless of the risks, pausing in interviews only to ask every few minutes, "Am I making sense?" The sensation of a political candidate's taking chances was appealing anough to win the endorsement of the state's largest newspaper, The Hartford Courant.
Dr. Bentivegna said he opposes capital punishment not only because it is wrong to take human life -- he opposes abortion for the same reason -- but also because it doesn't work.
"If I were a smart politician," he said, "maybe I'd be saying the same things as my opponent and Senator Lieberman, we need to build more prisons, we need more police, we need more executions, the same things that haven't worked for the last 25 years."
 
The Problem: Illegal Drugs
 At the heart of the crime problem, he said, is illegal drug use. He proposes to wean criminals off their drug habits by giving them increasingly diluted doses.
He, too, has a health-care proposal, but his would require an increase in the Medicare payroll tax. Dr. Labriola, he said, "says he's going to do it without tax increases, and I say that's fiction."
Dr. Bentivegna's plan is relatively simple. The Government, through the Medicare tax, would provide catastrophic health-care coverage for everyone, paying a person's medical expenses once they exceeded $15,000. Everyone could then afford his own health insurance for the first $15,000.
Dr. Labriola describes the plan as socialized medicine. But Dr. Bentivegna said no one should have to lose his life savings to a health problem. "Those of us who are fortunate enough to have good health have to pay more into the system to protect those who have poor health," he said. "That has to be explained to the voters."
 
Fate of the Middle Class
 Dr. Bentivegna is most passionate over the fate of middle-income people in recent years. In a self-published book, "An Agenda for Connecticut," he rails against the nation's economic and political elite for making the middle class pay for the bank scandals, real-estate speculation and leveraged buyouts of the 1980's.
"The middle class is being massacred," he said. "It used to be possible for a man or a woman to get a job and support a family on one income. Now you can barely do it on two."
Woven from newspaper clippings and stories of economic distress told to him by his patients, "An Agenda for Connecticut" has the feverish logic of a dinner-party argument. But Dr. Bentivegna is a suburban eye surgeon, not a revolutionary. What becomes clear is that he himself is well off, and that what is wrong, in his view, is that more people can't afford to live as he does.
"Anyone who makes a living wage in Connecticut should be able to have what I have," he said, "to live in a good neighborhood, afford health care and send their children to good schools."

HEADLINE: Beijing, Despite Taiwan Issue, Looks to Better Ties With U.S.

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Sept. 8

 BODY:
China said today that the Clinton Administration's decision to expand its official ties with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a renegade province, will adversely affect United States-China relations. But at the same time, it took another step to signal that it wants to improve its relations with Washington and repeated an invitation to President Clinton to visit China.
The modest change in Taiwan policy was announced in Washington on Wednesday. It reaffirmed the longstanding American position that there is only "one China," but in a nod to Taiwan's growing economic power in Asia it loosened some of the strictures that have prevented American officials from carrying out direct talks with Taiwan officials on trade and economic issues. 
 For the first time since 1979, the most senior American official in Taiwan visited President Lee Teng-hui in his office to brief the island's President on the policy change.
Taiwan is the home of the Chinese Nationalist Government that fled the mainland in 1949 before Mao Zedong's victorious Communist army. Taiwan's Nationalists have given up their longstanding claim to represent all 1.2 billion Chinese on the mainland. President Lee has been seeking to accommodate the strong pro-independence movement on the island while remaining true to the goal the nationalists and Communists still share: eventual reunification under one government.
In a formal statement on Wednesday, Taiwan also reacted stiffly to the change in Washington, saying it did not go far enough. But today, its leaders seemed pleased with the policy adjustment.
The Chinese Government's reaction appeared similarly ambivalent. Speaking at a weekly Foreign Ministry briefing, Shen Guofang, a Government spokesman, said the series of measures announced in Washington on Wednesday "have seriously violated the three joint communiques signed between China and the United States."
"This act of the United States brazenly interferes with the internal affairs of China and is something we are firmly opposed to," Mr. Shen said. "This will seriously, adversely affect the further development of bilateral relations."
But Mr. Shen repeated that China would like President Clinton to come to Beijing for a summit meeting.
Such a meeting appears now out of the question because of China's deteroriating human rights conditions.
Mr. Clinton decided in May to break the linkage under which Washington demanded improvements in human rights in return for the annual renewal of China's low-tariff trade access to the American market. But Mr. Clinton had hoped his action would lead to reciprocal steps by Beijing to begin accounting for and releasing thousands of political prisoners. So far, it has not.
President Jiang Zemin, leaving for Moscow last week, made a point at his departure news conference of saying he had invited Mr. Clinton to come to Beijing.
Today, Mr. Shen added, "Meeting and exchanging views between leaders of China and the United States is of great significance for enhancing understanding and improving bilateral relations.
"We welcome President Clinton to visit China at his convenience," Mr. Shen continued. "President Clinton has already accepted the invitation and hopes to visit China at his convenience."
[In Washington, White House officials said Mr. Clinton had received no formal invitation and had no plans to visit China.]
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang met for the first time last November at the summit meeting of Asian Pacific leaders. They are expected to meet again this November at a similiar summit in Indonesia. Mr. Clinton has never visited China.
Western diplomats here say there would have to be significant progress in these disputes before a summit meeting could occur.

HEADLINE: A Democrat Who Thrives Opposing the President

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: OZARK, Ala., Sept. 7

 BODY:
From almost the day President Clinton entered the White House, Senator Richard C. Shelby has been at his heels, a nettlesome and outspoken critic. Never mind that Mr. Clinton is from Arkansas and Mr. Shelby is from Alabama, or that both are Democrats.
Although the positions that Mr. Shelby has taken reflect the native conservatism of Alabama, what has made him stand out from other conservative Southern Democrats is the flourish and relish with which the two-term junior Senator has consistently opposed the President. 
 Just weeks ago, for instance, Senator Shelby sided with Republicans in an 11th-hour bid to scuttle the crime bill, at a time when its passage was crucial for Mr. Clinton. And as the Administration was pressing its health care measure, Mr. Shelby was holding news conferences with Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who is a leading critic of the legislation. Mr. Shelby also co-sponsored an alternative health care plan backed by conservative Republicans.
Last year at this time, Mr. Shelby was trumpeting his being one of the first of six Democrats to oppose the President's budget as a tax-and-spend prescription, forcing Vice President Al Gore to cast a tie-breaking vote in the Senate.
As the 60-year-old Democrat travels his state from Muscle Shoals to Mobile, there is some grumbling about his chumminess with the likes of Senator Gramm.
"Some of us are somewhat distressed, not so much because he exercised his independence, but because of the zeal with which he did it," said Greg Hawley, the Democratic chairman of Jefferson County, which includes Birmingham. "We don't expect him to be in lock step with the Democratic leadership, but we also don't expect him to be in lock step with the Republican leadership, as he has been lately."
 
Best of Both Worlds
 While some in the state that proudly calls itself the heart of Dixie speculate that Mr. Shelby may be ripe to switch parties, as Senator Gramm did 11 years ago, many political observers dismiss such speculation. They note that Mr. Shelby has the best of both worlds as a Democrat, and is shrewd enough to know it.
While Alabama is still largely Democratic, all the Republican Presidential candidates have carried it since Ronald Reagan first ran in 1980. But the Democratic Party label still means a great deal. By remaining a registered Democrat, while talking Republican, Mr. Shelby avoids being outflanked from either end of the ideological spectrum.
The Senator himself dismisses the speculation that he may change parties, even while aiming another barb at the President.
"I have no intention of switching parties," he said in an interview. "I can be more effective inside the Democratic Party by moving them to the right. President Clinton ran as a new Democrat, and we thought we were getting a centrist. But he has not been that. In order for the President to survive, he has to move back toward the center. He's a smart politician and very resilient, and I think he'll do that."
So far it appears that Mr. Shelby has not been hurt at home by his outspoken criticism of the President and his brazen flirtation with Republican positions.
 
Plenty of Applause
 Indeed, the luncheon audience on Tuesday at the noncommissioned officers club at Fort Rucker applauded enthusiastically as the Senator criticized the crime bill as "watered down" and described the Administration's health care proposal as "unwise, unwanted and unworkable."
Natalie Davis, a pollster and political science professor at Birmingham Southern College, said polls showed Mr. Shelby with a 67 percent approval rating, as against a 48 percent approval rating for the state's senior Senator, Howell Heflin, another Democrat.
Mr. Heflin probably votes as conservatively as Mr. Shelby, and against the President just as often, but with less fanfare.
"Bashing Clinton is becoming a political plus for Shelby," Ms. Davis said. "He's politically astute, and I suspect there is a good deal of calculation in what he does."
As Mr. Shelby threaded his way through the luncheon gathering here, Mayor Johnny Henderson of Enterprise said the Senator was "a patriot and a fine American" for eschewing partisan politics and the party line.
Mayor Henderson said it did not matter whether Mr. Shelby switched parties because "no matter what side of the aisle he is on, he is going to vote his convictions."
 
Criticism From Blacks
 But the Senator's anti-Administration posture has worn thin with some blacks, who represent nearly 30 percent of Alabama voters and more than 40 percent of the dependable Democratic primary vote in the state.
James Jarmon, a school principal and City Councilman in Ozark, said that lately he and many other black voters were disappointed with Mr. Shelby for his opposition to changes in the health care system that would put the cost of increased coverage on employers, and for the Senator's opposition to the crime bill.
Mr. Jarmon also said he was disappointed with Mr. Shelby's constant criticism of Mr. Clinton and with the Senator's attacks on the municipal government in the District of Columbia, which is predominantly black.
"I hear rumors that he might go to the Republican Party," Mr. Jarmon said, "and the fact is for me, it wouldn't matter that much if he did. Initially, he had strong black and white support, but lately he seems to want to pick a fight and be combative with the Administration."
But Jack Drake, a lawyer from Tuscaloosa and a member of the state Democratic Committee, said Mr. Shelby's opposition to the Administration had been exaggerated, perhaps for its effect back home on conservative voters.
Mr. Drake, who describes himself as a liberal and friend of Mr. Shelby, said Mr. Shelby had supported the Administration more often than not.
Mr. Shelby noted that he had for the most part been solidly behind the President on foreign policy. He also pointed out that he had deferred to the President on most Cabinet and sub-Cabinet appointments, although he thought many were "not the strongest."
But, still, when it comes to "core values," like taxes and "the economic well-being of America," Mr. Shelby said, he would not hesitate to criticize.
"I could look the other way on these issues," he said, "but it would be intellectually dishonest. I see myself as a Harry Truman Democrat, someone who is outspoken, who knows who he is and who knows where he comes from."

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Agrees to Pact for Venture

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
A computer-chip company from California and I.B.M. announced yesterday that they had reached agreement on a joint manufacturing venture that could bring as many as 700 jobs over the next three years to the mid-Hudson Valley, where I.B.M. has laid off thousands of employees in the last two years.
Supported by $40 million in low-interest loans from New York State, the computer-chip company, the Cirrus Logic Corporation of Fremont, Calif., plans to invest $100 million in the new operation. Cirrus Logic and International Business Machines, based in Armonk, N.Y., have agreed to convert an existing I.B.M. plant in East Fishkill in Dutchess County to supply each company with semiconductors used in computers and other electronic equipment. 
 "Born and bred by I.B.M. over many years, the Hudson Valley talent pool is very attractive," said Tom Rigoli, a spokesman for Cirrus Logic. "We think it is without peer as a location for world-class chip-manufacturing talent."
 
Direct Involvement
 Until now, Cirrus Logic has relied on 14 independent computer-chip manufacturing plants around the world to produce its advanced integrated circuit designs. This is the first time that the company, which had revenues of about $350 million last year, has decided to become more directly involved in making its own semiconductors.
The joint venture, to be called MICRUS and run by Stanley J. Grubel, a former I.B.M. executive, will also provide I.B.M. with the microelectronic devices it now makes on its own.
The project, which was first disclosed in January, is expected to be operating by early next year, Mr. Rigoli said. Specific terms of the agreement were not revealed because some details remain to be worked out.
