HEADLINE: Tenacious Lawyer Turns Exxon Spill Into Pollution Case for the Ages

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
In the annals of the environmental bar there has never been a trial like the one against the Exxon Corporation that began last May and is about to end in Federal District Court in Anchorage.
Like Alaska itself, everything about the Exxon Valdez disaster and its legal aftermath was oversized. The 1989 oil spill, 11 million gallons, was the largest ever by a tanker in North American waters. About 15,000 fishermen and other Alaskan plaintiffs sued Exxon, asserting that the spill had destroyed their livelihoods. 
 Exxon, the tanker's owner, is the world's richest energy company. Its senior executives, who by the time the trial began had already spent $3.4 billion restoring Prince William Sound and compensating victims, believed they had adequately proved their contrition. Vowing not to settle, they unleashed the company's vast coffers to hire a defense army that included scores of lawyers, scientists and economists.
 
Plaintiffs' Leader Emerges
 But what really transformed an already sensational pollution case into a transcendent political event was the emergence of Brian O'Neill, a rumpled, stubborn, mouthy 47-year-old Minneapolis lawyer, as the leader of the plaintiff's trial team.
Educated at West Point, Mr. O'Neill learned long ago how to define tactics and manage conflict. In court, he attacked relentlessly, repeatedly accusing Exxon's witnesses of lying. Outside court, he dominated the public debate, laying so many verbal mines in Exxon's path that the company's lawyers unsuccessfully sought in June to have him muzzled by the judge, H. Russel Holland.
Typical of his attacks was Mr. O'Neill's assertion in May that Exxon was "too big to give a damn about its people."
"And it's too big to give a damn about the public," he added.
The aim of such attacks, he said in a recent interview, was to transform the case against Exxon into a binding referendum in which 11 jurors were afforded a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to send a message to the big boys.
"Multinational corporations have a franchise that you don't have and that I don't have," Mr. O'Neill said, echoing the thrust of his closing arguments. "They get a franchise to take our oil out of the ground. They get a franchise to be rich and wealthy and respected beyond most people's dreams. And with that franchise comes responsibility to behave. This case will teach those people who have those franchises that they are responsible."
Maybe. So far, the first two of the trial's three stages have been a draw. In phase one, which ended on June 13, the jury decided in Mr. O'Neill's favor and determined that the disaster had been caused by reckless behavior by the tanker's captain, Joseph J. Hazelwood, and Exxon's senior executives.
In phase two, which ended in August, the jury seemed to side with Exxon when it awarded Mr. O'Neill's clients $286.8 million, only a third of the compensatory damages they had requested. The verdict forms that jurors sent to Judge Holland clearly indicated their rejection of large chunks of Mr. O'Neill's case.
Now both sides await a decision in phase three, in which the jury will decide whether Mr. O'Neill's clients deserve a punitive damage award and, if so, how much.
Mr. O'Neill's aggressive courtroom tactics and his public taunts made him the trial's dominating personality.
James Neal, the 65-year-old former Watergate prosecutor from Nashville who heads Exxon's trial team, regularly mocked his adversary in court, often beginning his cross-examinations by sarcastically quoting him. As the trial wore on, the personal animosity became palpable. One afternoon in late July, Mr. Neal and Mr. O'Neill left a hearing jaw to jaw, voices pitched, each accusing the other of low-ball tactics.
Exxon executives and lawyers repeatedly declined to discuss Mr. O'Neill's work. But in an interview in June, Patrick Lynch, an Exxon lawyer, said that the amount of money Mr. O'Neill and his team was seeking indicated they were driven by greed.
"This is a group of plaintiffs' lawyers whose basic interest is the profit motive," said Mr. Lynch, a partner at O'Melveny & Myers in Los Angeles.
Mr. O'Neill has fomented almost as much antipathy on his own team. The job of organizing and disciplining a group that included some of the nation's most talented environmental lawyers meant months of shouting, arguing and often brutally trampling egos. During much of the trial, members of his team said, the plaintiff's legal office at the corner of Ninth and K Streets in Anchorage was a cauldron of backbiting and second-guessing.
"Before we started the trial, Brian was a 100-pound gorilla," Lynn Sarko, a member of the team from the Keller Rohrback firm in Seattle, said in July. "Now he's an 800-pound gorilla."
Mr. Sarko added, "Dealing with Brian in this trial you needed a really thick skin."
Brian Boru O'Neill was born on June 7, 1947, in Hancock, Mich., but spent no time there. His father, an Army engineer, kept the family on the move. Brian was the oldest of six children, and he excelled in school. As a senior at West Point, he was a leader of the class of 1969, being named one of the 76 cadet captains.
After two years in Europe with a gunnery division, Mr. O'Neill returned to the United States and took a three-year leave of absence from the Army to attend the University of Michigan Law School, graduating in the top five of his class in 1974. He rejoined the Army and after a short tour with the Army General Counsel's office in Washington, he resigned his commission in 1977 and joined Faegre & Benson, Minneapolis's second-oldest and second-largest corporate law firm.
He had already developed an interest in environmental law, but in the late 1970's the practice paid little. So by day Mr. O'Neill represented inventors in patent infringement lawsuits and took other business cases that eventually made him one of Faegre & Benson's top earners, said John French, the firm's managing partner. By night and on the weekends, he built a separate practice, suing the Government and others over environmental issues.
 
Environmental Successes
 In his 17 years at Faegre & Benson, Mr. O'Neill has won lawsuits that curtailed grizzly bear hunting in Montana, protected wolves in northern Minnesota and compelled the Federal Government to withdraw strychnine as a pesticide. He also won a $10 million judgment against Union Oil in an industrial pollution case in Minnesota.
By 1992, when he took a case involving the Endangered Species Act all the way to the Supreme Court, where he lost, Mr. O'Neill had established himself as one of the nation's leading environmental lawyer-advocates, an image he relished.
Until recently, he wore his hair to his shoulders and favored shorts, T-shirts and sandals at the office, even in winter. Some colleagues at Faegre & Benson grimaced at his name, hated his clients and loathed his style.
"It's fair to say that Brian is on the radical edge -- or considered that by the firm because of the magnitude of the cases and the notoriety," said Steve Shroer, a Faegre & Benson partner who has worked with Mr. O'Neill in Alaska and elsewhere for years. "And, frankly, Brian doesn't help himself much. He's a very vocal guy."
Mr. O'Neill was nearing his 42d birthday when he read the first accounts of the Exxon Valdez spill. The early facts impressed him: thousands of dead birds and otters; a $1 billion fishing industry threatened; a captain whose blood alcohol level violated Federal rules for commanding a supertanker.
But his path to the top of the plaintiff's legal team was far from direct. The first stop was Soldotna, a fishing village on the Kenai Peninsula south of Anchorage, where two Alaska lawyers, Pete Earhardt and Chuck Robinson, were suing British Petroleum and the owners of the tanker Glacier Bay over an oil spill in July 1987 in the Upper Cook Inlet.
Estimates of that spill ranged from 40,000 to 150,000 gallons, and Alaska had closed the upper inlet to salmon fishing, temporarily stripping more than 800 fishermen of their livelihood.
Mr. O'Neill saw the case as his entree to the Exxon Valdez suit because the two lawsuits shared the same clients. He persuaded the Soldotna lawyers to let him try the Glacier Bay case, and by the middle of that summer, Mr. O'Neill and a young partner, Gerry Nolting, had assembled a team of Faegre & Benson lawyers.
 
$51 Million Dress Rehearsal
 The case turned into a dress rehearsal for the Exxon Valdez trial; in addition to clients, it shared similar economic theories as well as the judge, Mr. Holland, who had been appointed to the Federal bench by President Ronald Reagan.
On Sept. 5, 1991, the jury in the Glacier Bay case returned a decisive verdict, and British Petroleum, the tanker's owners and their insurers, eventually agreed to pay $51.3 million in damages, at the time the largest award ever in an oil spill.
Immediately after the Glacier Bay trial, Mr. O'Neill began attending the regular meetings in Seattle of plaintiffs' lawyers in the Exxon Valdez case. By that time, most of the work on the case was progressing well. The exception was the assessment of financial losses, the heart of the case, which was in disarray, said David Oesting, who coordinated the plaintiff's trial preparations.
Mr. O'Neill, having just proved he could build a successful case by accumulating the same sort of evidence, saw his opening, and in 1992 he took charge of assembling the damage assessment. By July 1993, he had completed a comprehensive study that solidified his standing as a manager and tactician.
When it came time to name the leader of the Federal trial, "he really had no competition," said Mr. Oesting, manager of the Anchorage office of Davis, Wright & Tremaine of Seattle.
"He had proven himself in the Glacier Bay case," Mr. Oesting said. "He had a good relationship with Judge Holland. His firm was obviously committed. And he had shown himself to be one smart, tough lawyer. And with this crew of lawyers on our side and the other crew opposing us, you had to be that."
The stakes are enormous for both sides. If Exxon loses, the cost could be billions of dollars and further damage to the company's image. If Mr. O'Neill loses, his clients will recover only a fraction of what they say they have lost, and the plaintiffs' law firms will recoup less than the $100 million they say the case has cost them -- $20 million in direct expenses and $80 million in lawyers' time.
But Mr. O'Neill argues that the highest cost could well be to the environment. If Exxon wins, he said, law firms will be discouraged for years from tackling such cases.
"If we fail, then this whole tactic that companies are using -- that we are big enough and wealthy enough to grind anybody into the ground in court -- will have been proven to work in the biggest environmental case yet."

HEADLINE: Fed Deputy Denies Rift With Chief

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Seeking to calm a controversy over whether he is soft on inflation, Alan S. Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, took the unusual step today of defending remarks he made at a recent conference and saying he does not differ with his colleagues over monetary policy.
Mr. Blinder said that stories about an intellectual split at the top of the Fed were "alleged news." And he added that he and Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had similar monetary policy beliefs but used different rhetoric to explain them. "There is no rift between the chairman of the Federal Reserve and myself," he said in a speech this morning to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. 
 Speaking broadly of his 18 colleagues on the Federal Reserve's interest-rate policy committee, Mr. Blinder said, "I don't believe there are any current operational differences of any significance."
Nevertheless, Mr. Blinder today reiterated many of the same positions that he advanced in the speech in Wyoming on Aug. 27 that started the controversy. In that speech he said that when unemployment was high, lowering it should be a legitimate short-term goal of the central bank and that the Fed should use interest rates to do that, as well as to keep inflation in check.
 
Meaning Not Clear
 And his statement that there are no operational differences was left undefined. It could mean that that Mr. Blinder has no problems with Fed policy now because the central bank is pushing interest rates higher while unemployment is low. But Mr. Blinder explicitly left open the possibility of future disagreements with his colleagues on whether creating new jobs should sometimes take precedence over fighting inflation.
Because unemployment now is lower than it has been in years, the practical significance of Mr. Blinder's remarks is slight for the interest rates that Americans pay on everything from car loans to home mortgages.
Mr. Blinder, who has been at the Fed only since June, was clearly worried today about the storm in monetary policy circles that his remarks in Wyoming provoked and which could endanger his prospects of becoming chairman when Mr. Greenspan's term expires in early 1996. Mr. Blinder said today that he had originally intended to give another speech to the mortgage bankers but changed his plans after the stir over his Wyoming speech.
After today's speech, Mr. Blinder also took the highly unusual step of holding an unscheduled news conference to respond to further questions on the issue. It was the first news conference by a chairman or vice chairman of the Federal Reserve in several years.
While Mr. Blinder said he would continue to explain Fed policy publicly, he added that one possible moral of the controversy "is that if you are on a central bank board, you ought to keep your mouth shut because anything you say is likely to be exaggerated -- and I must admit I'm considering that moral more than I did before."
Mr. Blinder suggested today that his Wyoming comments, expressed in the highly technical terms of an economist addressing other economists, might have been exaggerated. He said he had emphasized the potential role of central banks in reducing short-term unemployment because he was speaking there at a conference on unemployment. "Had I been speaking at a conference on price stability, I certainly would have emphasized that there is no long-run trade-off," he said today.
 
Referred to Colleagues
 But he declined to answer whether there were any philosophical splits, referring reporters instead to his colleagues. Some of these colleagues, who have insisted on anonymity, have expressed discomfort in the last two weeks with Mr. Blinder's ideas.
Mr. Greenspan, who attended the conference in Wyoming and listened to Mr. Blinder's speech, has said nothing publicly to extricate his vice chairman from the current dispute, and declined to comment today.
In the arcane world of interest-rate policy, even subtle differences in rhetoric can take on tremendous importance in financial markets as possible guides to future Fed policy. Federal Reserve officials and Wall Street economists said that the views that Mr. Blinder expressed in Wyoming could signal future policy clashes over interest rates if unemployment and inflation rose.
High unemployment confronts central bankers with a choice between reducing short-term unemployment with low interest rates or controlling inflation with high interest rates. Mr. Blinder's comments today and in Wyoming strongly suggested that he would be more reluctant than his colleagues to raise interest rates when unemployment is high.
 
Views in Wyoming
 Mr. Blinder said in Wyoming that he thought the Federal Reserve should try to reduce unemployment and inflation in the short run, but should focus only on controlling inflation in the long run.
The experience of the 1970's soured most Federal Reserve officials on trying to do anything more than controlling inflation. Yet enthusiasm for a broader Federal Reserve mandate remains strong in the academic circles in which Mr. Blinder, a former chairman of Princeton University's economics department, has spent most of his life.
Mr. Blinder said in Wyoming that he thought the mistakes of the 1970's could be avoided by raising interest rates quickly in response to outside shocks to the economy, like the sudden rise in oil prices in 1974.
He said that he agreed with Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that interest-rate policy could be used only in the long run to hold down inflation, and could not be used to suppress unemployment over the long term. Allowing higher inflation through low interest rates can only hold down unemployment in the short term, he said.
Mr. Greenspan has said that "ephemeral" reductions in unemployment could be achieved by allowing inflation to rise, but has never defined what this meant. Mr. Blinder said in an interview on Aug. 28 in Wyoming that the reductions were not ephemeral but that they did not last more than a year or two.
But some of Mr. Blinder's remarks today seemed likely to keep alive the perception in monetary policy circles of an intellectual division at the Fed.
 
Laws Termed Inadequate
 Mr. Blinder repeated today his view, strongly expressed in Wyoming, that current laws were adequate in calling for the Federal Reserve to pursue both maximum employment and low inflation. Mr. Greenspan has testified before Congress in favor of amending the Federal Reserve Act to require that the central bank set interest rates only with an eye to holding down inflation.
Many economists nonetheless believe that in practice, Mr. Greenspan has for a long time run monetary policy with at least some attention to holding down unemployment, and would continue to do so even if the law was changed.
Financial economists said that the interest-rate policy positions implied by Mr. Blinder's often theoretical speech today were different from Mr. Greenspan's positions, but only in subtle ways that had no relevance to current interest rates. Mr. Blinder "just does believe much more in the appropriateness of using monetary policy in aiming at more targets than just inflation," said Richard B. Berner, a senior vice president and chief economist at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.

HEADLINE: Harlem Family Battles Burden of the Past

SERIES: Another America: Life on 129th Street -- Second of three articles.

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
It was an exquisitely bad day in a time of long, bad days. The washing machine broke and the food stamps ran out. Despite scores of phone calls, the welfare caseworker could not promise Vikki the bigger apartment she needed to care for the three cousins she was raising and the baby she was expecting.
In a gloomy apartment in Harlem, Vikki, 26, has been waging a lonely campaign to keep it all together. Once a key figure in a local drug operation, she is unemployed, diabetic and overweight. She is the legal guardian of the cousins, whose drug-addicted and abusive parents abandoned them long ago to foster care. 
 Three years ago, when she optimistically became their guardian, she was sure she could do better for the boys, Shawn and David, who are brothers, and Lenny, their cousin. Today they always need more: more money, more food, more love.
"I didn't consider how much it would take to raise these kids," Vikki said. "I just thought we'd all be together and nobody would beat us and we'd get regular meals."
Because the family's life had been so desperate, Vikki decided to have an abortion this summer. She learned that her boyfriend had two other pregnant girlfriends, she said, and she did not want to raise another child on welfare.
On 129th Street, between Malcolm X Boulevard and Fifth Avenue, the traditional family is harder to find than ever. The replacement families vary.
In some apartments, teen-age mothers on welfare double up to get by. In others, the exhausted female companions of grandfathers comfort the children of imprisoned mothers. Other households are headed by children in their teens because their parents are gone, for whatever reason.
The families on 129th street are no different than others in American cities with a growing and increasingly desperate black underclass. In these poor communities people shift through the debris of failed dreams to salvage what they can.
In Vikki's home, a single overhead bulb illuminates the narrow living room, situated in the middle of three small bedrooms. The lineoleum floor is dirty and missing some tiles. Three steel folding chairs sit along the baseboard. The only window overlooks an enclosure filled with junk.
The family members insisted that their full names not be used.
The apartment is the only stable home Shawn, 13, and David, 20, have known, and Vikki is the only real parent they've ever had. She said their mother died of cirrhosis of the liver last October; their father died of AIDS in April.
The bottom bunk bed in Shawn's room belonged to 17-year-old Lenny, who once slept on a park bench to avoid abusive relatives. He is now locked up on Rikers Island for selling drugs. Vikki said he wanted the money to buy school clothes.
Despite such setbacks, Vikki tries to sweeten life in little ways. On Sundays, she often puts together a huge Sunday dinner of "the kids' " favorite foods, like greens and corn bread, baked macaroni, chicken and lasagna. She makes sure that Shawn does his homework, in between his trips to the Y.M.C.A. to play basketball and study karate. She does the laundry and housekeeping and travels to the Bronx every other week to buy cheaper and fresher groceries than she can find in Harlem.
 
Food, Affection, Advice
 Other young people on the block regularly gather at the apartment looking for a meal, affection or advice from Vikki.
Recently, she has been looking for "some kind of role model" for Shawn, a listless child who is animated only when he talks about karate. He has refused the help of at least two psychotherapists.
Vikki doesn't always know what support to offer David. His friends are being picked off by drugs, violence and jail. He is frustrated by his inability to get anywhere without a high school diploma.
The mood in the first-floor apartment is often somber, as Shawn, David and Vikki try to take life one day at a time.
 
The Boys
Quiet Sorrows, Lasting Pain
 Shawn, short and wiry, with slanted almond eyes, flashed a crooked smile whenever someone commented on his wounded expression. It was last March, and Shawn, who never really knew his mother, had just re-established a relationship with his father, who used to beat him so badly that the neighbors would hear him sobbing for hours. For years he lived in foster homes and with other relatves.
Every day in the weeks before his father died, the boy with arms like matchsticks slowly pushed a heavy mop around the apartment, but a bad smell lingered. Perhaps it came from the black cat, Lucky, or the garbage in the hallway. After school, Shawn often went to his room and sat on the lower bunk bed, twisting his hands and staring into space.
These days Shawn insists that he is O.K., although as his father lay dying in a Veterans Administration hospital he skipped school and gambled away his sneakers in a basketball game. In July, he ran away from home for four days and returned without comment, missing Vikki's 26th-birthday party. He calls Vikki "Ma" but does not like her to touch or comfort him.
As a mother, he said his cousin "is not strict like she's supposed to be."
"It's not too good around here," Shawn said of the neighborhood. "When I grow up, if nothing happens to me, I want to leave."
Shawn's favorite subject in school is reading and he wants to be a karate instructor. He does not like to talk about his feelings. On the streets, he has the jaunty, exaggerated bounce of a homeboy.
 
A Palpable Sadness
 David has his own sorrows. A thin young man who often wears his hair in braids, he is a high-school dropout who works as a day-care center assistant. He is a quiet loner with a palpable sadness. Occasionally he shares in the family's social life, as he did the other day when one of the young men on the block came by with a tape of one of his rap songs.
"I just recently started thinking about about all that stuff, my grandmother's house, the foster homes," David said. "That stayed with us so long we were cold toward each other," he said, speaking of his relationship with Shawn.
"It took us a long time to open up to each other. Shawn never talks. Never."
David said he thinks of Vikki like a mother but family life is not for him. He hates the idea of having his own wife and children. His immediate future includes getting a high school equivalency degree or entering the Job Corps.
"I'd rather be alone, secluded from society," he said.
 
Worrisome Talk
 Vikki worries when she hears talk like that. She also worries that she set a bad example for Lenny. To make ends meet on $700 a month in welfare and disability payments, she rented space to drug dealers in their first-floor apartment in the six-story tenement.
A stereo system is all that remains of the drug money. Vikki and her friends spent the rest on nightclubs, clothes, taxicabs hired for two- and three-hour stretches and restaurants like Red Lobster and the International House of Pancakes.
The "crew" of drug dealers broke all Vikki's furniture during long nights of rough-housing. She no longer has a telephone because the dealers made so many expensive calls.
 
The Past
 Scars That Show, Scars That Don't

When Vikki was young, her family consisted of her mother, herself and her older sister, nicknamed Pookie. Their mother, a communications specialist in the Air Force, and their father, a supermarket manager, divorced when Vikki was 2. Her mother remarried, but Vikki doesn't remember her stepfather ever having a steady job.
One morning 12 years ago, after a night of fighting, her stepfather flung acid on the two girls. During the fight Pookie had accused him of molesting her. Both suffered burns on their faces and upper bodies. Vikki said that the last thing she remembers is a schoolteacher who lived down the hall sprinkling her with cold water and praying.
Vikki said she is bitter that her mother, who lives upstairs in Vikki's building, separated from her stepfather but never divorced him. She said that he was never punished for his crime. He is now dying of AIDS, and Vikki -- who is usually unfailingly kind -- said she is glad that he will soon be dead.
The attack left Vikki with dark scars on her face and arms. She tries to hide the way it made her feel.
 
Acting Out in School
 In her youth it was harder to hide the pain; she acted out in school by fighting and cutting class. Her mother shipped her off to live with various relatives, and at one point, she was among eight children and three adults who lived in a two-bedroom apartment in a Bronx housing project. The children's parents had problems: they were addicts or abusive or in jail.
"I used to fight and argue with my cousins all the time," Vikki said. "They smoked crack. I couldn't stand it. My mind was not into school. My mind was into getting enough money to get out of my grandmother's house."
She felt increasingly distraught and restless as she watched her family deteriorate, Vikki said. She took a succession of jobs to help out, from flipping hamburgers to working as a hospital orderly. She helped supervise her boyfriend's drug operation but managed to take a few classes at the Borough of Manhattan Community College.
Pookie went to live with other relatives and eventually became a licensed practical nurse. Although their lives are different, Vikki describes her relationship with her sister as close. Pookie lives in New Jersey now and offers support and advice on rearing "the kids."
 
The Future
Nurturing Hope In a Bleak Time
 The buzzer kept sounding, bringing bad news. Mel, another drug dealer for whom Vikki once worked, was in the hospital because of complications from the shooting last April that left him paralyzed. There were problems with his catheter and an infected bedsore.
Another friend had just found out she was pregnant and wanted to know if she could hold in her stomach to hide it.
Then there were the girls with babies, girls so young that it seemed the babies should have been dolls instead of flesh and blood. They showed off their children and talked about baby clothes, baby weight, problems with food stamps, housing and teen-age fathers.
 
Why So Young?
 "I sit down and ask some young girls why they have babies so young," Vikki said. "They say they want someone to love, someone to call their own. A lot of them have lost their parent. They weren't raised with a father or a mother. You get a boyfriend and try to keep him."
"A lot of guys are on a baby kick, have their baby," she said. "I guess they think it makes them a man."
One of the girls, who did not want her name used, had run away from home. She was 15, her baby was 5 months old, and she and her mother were fighting. Her mother, still at home with two young boys, was pregnant again.
"Do you have anything to eat?" she asked.
The only thing in the house that evening was a bag of Pepperidge Farm Lemon Nut Crunch cookies, so that was what they ate.
"I'm planning to get my own apartment with another girl," the young woman said. "Somewhere nice, not around here."
"I want a good job, so I can take care of my baby," she said. "I don't want to be on welfare, like my mother."
 
Dreams Are Hard to Hold
 Vikki has her dreams, as well, but they are getting harder to hold.
"There are days when I just sit here," she said in the month before her abortion, as the days become longer and her abdomen expanded. "I don't know. I never had bills before. To take care of a whole household and pay bills.
"I want the all-time American dream: husband, kids, a house with a picket fence, two incomes, my kids in colleges, vacations with my kids wherever I want," Vikki said. "What's going to happen to me? My goal is to go into nursing and somewhere down the line be a doctor."
Vikki admits that becoming a doctor is unlikely because of the time and the expense involved. She has a plan, but her voice drops with mingled embarrassment and resignation as she talks about it.
"I be thinking if I can make enough money once dealing drugs, $5,000 or $10,000, I can invest," she said.
 
Another America
 
YESTERDAY -- The violent and dispirited world of 129th Street.
 
TODAY -- A woman struggles to hold together a nontraditional family.
 
TOMORROW -- The drug trade, where the dealer is outlaw and entrepreneur.

HEADLINE: Wall St. Rally Spurred By High-Tech Stocks

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks posted solid gains yesterday as fresh buying in high-technology stocks touched off a rally in the broader market.
The Dow Jones industrial average broke back through the 3,900 level, rising 22.21 points to close at 3,908.46. 
 In the broader market, advancing issues led declining ones, 1,319 to 837, on New York Stock Exchange volume of 296 million shares, up slightly from 292.1 million on Wednesday.
A second day of gains in technology stocks led the way for other stocks to rise, despite a flat bond market, analysts said.
"Sustainable leadership has been hard to find," said Gerry Simmons, manager of equity trading at Interstate/Johnson Lane. "Probably the closest thing we have had to it recently has been technology."
The Nasdaq composite index, often a barometer for technology stocks, rose 5.02 points, or 0.66 percent, to 769.30, after a 4.80-point rise Wednesday.
Some traders said the Nasdaq market was benefiting from buying by portfolio managers who missed Wall Street's August rally and were now searching for laggards.
"They're focusing on the Nasdaq because Nasdaq has lagged the broader market," said Leon Brand, global market strategist at NatWest Securities.
Among technology stocks riding the buying wave were the Compaq Computer Corporation, up 1 1/8, to 36 5/8; Hewlett-Packard, up 2 1/4, to 90, and the Microsoft Corporation, up 11/16 , to 5715/16 .
The stock market's strength in the face of a steady bond market raised some eyebrows, especially ahead of today's potentially volatile report on August producer prices.
"You don't see the kind of the optimism in bonds that you do in stocks," said Walter Revis, market analyst at Principal Financial Securities. "I think we're seeing a little bit of a buying frenzy right here. That's one reason I think stocks look more dangerous than bonds in here."
Although bond traders were nervous about the producer prices report, the 30-year Treasury bond was steady and its yield was unchanged at 7.56 percent.
 
Rise in July Producer Prices
 But the stock market seemed to be anticipating a benign report on wholesale inflation. In July, producer prices rose five-tenths of 1 percent.
A negative surprise on inflation could send Wall Street into a quick retreat, analysts said. "This market doesn't forgive any surprises," Mr. Brand said.
Among individual issues, Kmart's stock rose 1/2, to 18, after the retailer said it would close 110 stores in the United States and cut about 6,000 jobs in a restructuring of its core discount store business.
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing climbed 1 3/4, to 56 3/8. It said it expects its earnings per share to increase by 10 percent a year on average over the next three years.
I.B.M.rose 3/8, to 67 7/8, and Cirrus Logic gained 1 7/8, to 31, after they announced a joint venture to make semiconductor wafers.
Citicorp gained 1 1/8, to 44 7/8. Prudential Securities named it "single best idea" and raised its earnings forecasts.
Shares in Contel Cellular soared 5 3/4, to 23 1/2, on news that GTE had offered $22.50 a share for the 10 percent stake in Contel held by the public. GTE, which owns the other 90 percent, finished up 1/8, to 30 7/8.
Informix fell 1 3/4, to 23 1/4. Merrill Lynch downgraded its opinion of the stock.
Shares of 20th Century Industries fell 3 1/8, to 9 1/2, after it said its earthquake expenses were expected to rise to $815 million from the previously estimated $685 million.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 2.15, to 473.14. The American Stock Exchange index gained 0.19, to 455.51.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.04, to 260.82.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Rose During July

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Consumers increased their borrowing in July for the 16th consecutive month, though less briskly than in previous months, the Federal Reserve said today.
Total consumer installment credit outstanding grew by $5.57 billion, at a 7.9 percent annual rate, down from a revised $11.16 billion increase in June when credit was rising at a 16 percent annual rate. Previously, the Fed had said June credit rose $10.89 billion. 
 In separate reports today, the Commerce Department said a survey of companies showed they planned to increase spending on new plants and equipment at the highest rate in five years, and the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week. The number of jobless claims fell to a seasonally adjusted 330,000 for the week that ended on Sept. 3, down 3,000 from the previous week.
 
 
Borrowing Costs
 The increase in consumer credit came as consumers' borrowing costs continued to rise. In an effort to head off inflationary pressures, the Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates five times this year, lifting rates on consumer loans.
The Fed's report showed that automobile loans increased $4.14 billion, at a 16.5 percent annual rate, in July, down from $4.97 billion, at a 20 percent rate, in June.
Similarly, growth in revolving, or credit-card, credit eased in July to $3.66 billion, or an annual rate of 14 percent. This credit increased in June by $4 billion, at a rate of 15.6 percent a year.
 
 
'Other Credit'
 The big change came in a category called "other credit," which includes loans for buying mobile homes, boats, trailers and vacations. This credit contracted $2.23 billion in July, at an 11.3 percent annual rate, after growing in June by $2.19 billion, at an 11.2 percent annual rate.
The Commerce Department's survey of 5,000 companies in July and August found that they intended to increase spending in 1994 by 8.8 percent, to $638.4 billion -- the biggest rise since 1989, when investment jumped 11.4 percent.
The investment survey showed growing optimism, notably among manufacturers, that prospects were good for improving business. The new survey updated one done in April and May in which companies said they would raise 1994 spending by a smaller, 8.3 percent. The investment plans for 1994 are up from increases of 7.3 percent in 1993 and 3.4 percent in 1992.
 
 
'Not Surprising'
 "Given the kind of economic growth we've seen, it's not surprising that corporations want to improve their capacity," said Sung Won Sohn, an economist with the Norwest Corporation of Minneapolis.
The latest investment survey showed manufacturers, who traditionally offer better-paying jobs, intend to increase spending this year by a sturdy 7.3 percent, up from an earlier estimate of 6.9 percent. That is more than double the 1993 investment rise of only 3.1 percent.
All figures are in current dollars, not adjusted for inflation.
Nonmanufacturing businesses like airlines and utilities said they planned to increase spending by 9.5 percent this year from 1993. They raised capital spending in 1993 by 9.3 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Gains on Comments By German and U.S. Aides

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar gained some strength yesterday after German officials and senior Clinton Administration aides said the American currency was undervalued.
Traders said the dollar also received support from speculation that high-level trade talks between the United States and Japan were making some progress. But they said there was no basic underlying economic reason for a greater dollar demand. 
 "It was one of these days of concerted jawboning," said David de Rosa, a director at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York. "A lot of people said they wanted the dollar to go higher."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 99.60 Japanese yen, up from 99.45 yen on Wednesday. It also rose to 1.5568 German marks from 1.5507 marks.
Currency traders said the dollar received an early lift from remarks by Hans-Jurgen Krupp, a member of the German Bundesbank's council, who said the strength in the American economy did not justify the dollar's weak level. A day earlier, Mr. Krupp also helped strengthen the dollar by asserting that interest rates in Germany should come down.
Later in the United States, top American officials talked up the dollar further.
"It's verbal support, I would call it," said Earl I. Johnson, a vice president at the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
Bowman Cutter, deputy assistant to the President for economic affairs, said the Administration had "made clear that we'd like to see a stronger dollar."
Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said he was "cautiously optimistic" about trade talks with Japan.
The United States has imposed a Sept. 30 deadline for progress on reducing Japan's $60 billion trade surplus with the United States and opening up that country's market wider to American imports.
"I think we're going to go right down to the wire," Mr. Johnson said of the high-level talks.
Many currency traders believe that if negotiations fail, the Clinton Administration would encourage a lower dollar. That would make Japanese goods more expensive in the United States, hurting Japan's exporters.
The dollar also picked up support against the mark amid continued speculation that the Bundesbank would cut German interest rates to improve that country's economy. Lower rates tend to weaken a currency's attractiveness.
Meanwhile, the British pound slipped to $1.5445 in New York, from $1.5448 on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Kyocera Told It Has to Pay

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Kyocera Corporation, a Japanese disk drive manufacturer, said today that an arbitration court ordered it to pay $257 million to the Lapine Technology Corporation and the Prudential-Bache Trade Corporation for breach of contract.
Kyocera's American depository receipts fell $4, to $143.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. 
 The decision was made by the arbitration court of the Paris-based International Chamber of Commerce, a Kyocera official said.
Kyocera will seek to have the order reversed at a United States district court in California, he said. "This judgment is erroneous and illegitimate in terms of fact and legal judgement," Kyocera said in a statement.
In 1984, Kyocera contracted with Lapine and Prudential to produce 3.5-inch hard disk drives used as memory devices for computers. The disk drives were developed and marketed by Lapine. Lapine was financed and managed by Prudential, Kyocera said.
Lapine is owned by the LaPine Holding Company, in which Prudential has a two-thirds stake and Kyocera has the rest.

HEADLINE: Inside Art

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Historical Society to Sell
G. Oliver Koppell, the New York State Attorney General, has finally permitted the New-York Historical Society to sell about $20 million worth of art and objects from its collection. The proceeds are to go toward the museum's endowment, which covers some of its operating costs as well as the care of the society's art collection and library. But the sale, expected to take place at Sotheby's in New York early next year, will proceed in a highly unusual fashion.
In an attempt to raise the most money for the financially troubled institution while giving other New York State institutions a break, Sotheby's, the attorney general and the society have come up with what they are calling a "pre-emption plan," whereby New York State museums, libraries and archives will have a right of first refusal to buy items at a discount, but only after the auction. Buyers will be informed before the sale that in fact, they may not be buying at all. If an institution decides it wants a work of art or an object that has been auctioned, that can in effect void the sale of that item to the private bidder. 
 "This seems like the best way of balancing all the interests involved," said Miner H. Warner, the chairman of the historical society.
Mr. Koppell said he had long been negotiating with the society. "They've convinced us that this is necessary," he said. "We realize people have an emotional response to deaccessioning, but we think we have safeguarded the public's interests as well as the interests in the city and the state who have a financial investment in this institution."
New York institutions will be able to buy items after the sale at a graduated discount: 10 percent of the bid price for works costing $25,000 or less, 5 percent for items selling for $25,000 to $100,000, and 3 percent for items selling for more than $100,000, providing that the item sells for more than its high estimate. For works that don't find buyers at auction, the Attorney General's office will have to approve sales item by item.
Mr. Warner said the society was prepared to provide financing for up to five years at commercial interest rates. In addition, institutions may not sell their purchases for 10 years.
While the society will not confirm exactly what it is selling, Mr. Warner said none of its core collection would be auctioned. Eighty percent of the value of what is thought by art experts to be up for sale comes from a group of European paintings, 10 of which have been on loan to the Metropolitan Museum of Art since 1978. In addition, the experts say the society is planning to sell much of its European paperweight collection, furniture that is not of museum quality, and redundancies in its silver collection, as well as a group of smaller collectibles.
 
Rescuing 'Three Graces'
 In Britain, Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, the Dutch-born industrialist and art collector, has become something of a white knight. Last week, the Victoria and Albert Museum in London announced that the baron had pledged the remaining $1.2 million needed to prevent Canova's "Three Graces" from leaving England. But to the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., his philanthropic gesture is yet another slap in the face for the museum's five-year struggle to export the 19th-century marble statue of Venus's handmaidens.
"We have been treated very shabbily by a country that taught us fair play," said John Walsh, the director of the Getty.
When the museum learned of the baron's contribution, and heard that it was made on the condition that the statue be exhibited in Spain, it issued a statement saying: "It now seems to us that anything that will frustrate the 'Three Graces' being put on permanent display at the Getty Museum is acceptable to Britain, even if it means endangering the statue itself. Sculpture experts who know that statue well agree that it should not be moved any more than is absolutely necessary."
The Getty was willing to pay nearly $12 million to the current seller, an unidentified Cayman Islands corporation; completion of the sale depended upon obtaining an export license from the British Government. But on Aug. 9, Britain's National Heritage Secretary, Stephen Dorrell, imposed a second three-month delay on exporting the sculpture to give British museums a chance to match the Getty's price and keep the artwork in Britain.
The Victoria and Albert joined forces with the National Gallery of Scotland to raise $8.94 million. (The museums say they plan to share the work.) In addition, $1.5 million came in mid-August from John Paul Getty 2d, the son of the oil baron who founded the Getty Museum; he lives in London and has been a major donor to other British fine-arts projects. Now Baron Thyssen has come up with the rest of the money.
A spokeswoman at the Victoria and Albert said that under the terms of Baron Thyssen's pledge, before the sculpture went on view in Britain it would spend six months or a year at the Villahermosa Palace, next to the Prado in Madrid, where the Baron's art collection is on public view. The baron's secretary said he was traveling and was not available for comment.
Timothy Clifford, the director of the National Gallery of Scotland, said the baron had asked only to borrow the sculpture for an exhibition planned for two years from now. "We're thrilled that it looks as though the 'Three Graces' will stay in England," Mr. Clifford said. "The Baron has plenty of connections with England. He's had two British wives, his son lives here and he keeps an apartment in London."
The Getty is going to court in London today to seek a judicial review of Secretary Dorrell's delay of the export license. "We're hoping the judge will agree that the Secretary of National Heritage acted improperly," Mr. Walsh said.
 
A Contemporary Feast
 Gerald S. Elliott's extraordinary collection of contemporary art has become a bonanza for both the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago and for Christie's in New York.
Mr. Elliott, a prominent Chicago lawyer who died in March, amassed significant holdings by such important American and European artists as Bruce Nauman, Donald Judd, Richard Serra, Susan Rothenberg, Anselm Kiefer and Georg Baselitz. At his death, he left the Museum of Contemporary Art in Chicago 105 works: 65 paintings and sculptures, and 40 photographs. It is the museum's single largest gift.
To pay estate expenses, however, a separate group of 48 works, valued at $4 million, will go on sale at Christie's in Manhattan on Nov. 2. Included is Ms. Rothenberg's "Kelpie," a 1978 painting of two horses that the auction house estimates could sell for $350,000 to $450,000.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A detail of Susan Rothenberg's "Kelpie," to be auctioned from the Gerald S. Elliott estate. (Christie's New York)

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Did Football Send Owners To the Table?

BYLINE: By GEORGE VECSEY 

 BODY:
IF our wonderful baseball owners can get over their gripping obsession with the salary cap, baseball fans may have to give thanks to a strange new ally: football.
My theory is that king football -- and particularly a new American sporting hero named Jeffrey Lurie -- had a great deal to do with the wonderful owners scurrying to New York yesterday. 
 We know the wonderful owners don't like to spend their own money, but there they were, splurging on full-fare, spur-of-the-moment airline tickets, to deal with this ruinous strike, now nearly a month old. About time, wouldn't you say?
It is quite likely that football pushed the owners in two different ways: First, a few diehard loonies like me may have missed baseball over the Labor Day weekend, but from what I gather, millions of others were quite occupied with football. This may have sent a shiver of mortality into the baseball owners, not otherwise known for their perceptiveness.

 The owners could see an entire September and October of North Americans settling into their dens and bars and watching brutes whacking into brutes. They are already spooked by football. They've got players trying to see a fastball in late-afternoon angled sunlight, and post-season games starting at children's bedtimes, and they won't play baseball at all on Monday nights in October because of football.
Then there is the specter of the O. J. Simpson trial, coming soon to a television set near you. This ugly melodrama is not a sports story or a football story, but it is surely a television extravaganza that could keep people from clicking the dial. The baseball owners saw the need to get back to work before their sport was totally irrelevant.
But football may have contributed to the potential end of the baseball strike in another powerful way. Football exposed the salary cap as the last refuge of weasels. Up to now, the salary cap has gotten pretty good press because it helped the National Basketball Association get its house in order. But the N.B.A. of a decade ago is not the National Football League of today.
In this brave new world, the proud owner of the New York Giants, Wellington Mara, was not able to make a large and loyal offer to his old quarterback, Phil Simms, because the Giants were backed right up against that demon of a salary cap. Mara was sad and Simms was enraged at the new order. (That George Young, who made the decision not to pay Simms, may have been right in his football judgment is a different story; Mara would have paid Simms handsomely to be a tutor in uniform.)
But the worst-case scenario of the salary cap happened in Philadelphia. A football fanatic named Jeffrey Lurie recently called in some family money to purchase the Eagles for a reported sum of $185 million, the highest ever paid for a professional sports franchise. The fee was even higher than the $173 million paid last August for the Baltimore Orioles, a team currently not operating because of the ghastly economics of baseball, if you can follow that reasoning.
This Lurie began having pangs about all the money he had shelled out or maybe he just can't help himself from putting the squeeze on people. He began circulating among his new players, forcing at least three Eagles to take salary cuts or else risk being dropped from the team. Lurie's reason? That wicked old salary cap. The Eagles promptly went out and lost their first game. Maybe they'll lose all 16. It would serve Lurie right.
The sight of an owner personally trying to knock back salaries in the week before the season opened is a new low among the moneyed set. Sure, Charles O. Finley tried to fire an Oakland second baseman during the World Series, and sure, George Steinbrenner lambasted a Yankee third-base coach and various pitchers during post-season games, but the salary cap has introduced a new ownership excuse: "The devil made me do it," as Flip Wilson used to say.
A few of the brighter baseball owners just might have observed this Lurie in action, ruining his team's morale, destroying his image, in the name of the great idol of a salary cap. I am also guessing that the baseball players watched Lurie perform, and that was enough to stiffen their resistance to the salary cap. Why give the baseball owners a chance to be like that guy?
None of this guarantees that the owners and the players will be able to save the season. Both sides were bumbling around yesterday, doing homework they could have done a year ago, if you ask me. But if they manage to hold onto the World Series this year, they should thank football for scaring them into action. Football won't ask much in return. Just stay out of its way. That's enough.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For the New York State Legislature

 BODY:
The New York State Legislature's poor record this year on budgetary and social issues leaves no doubt that Albany could use some shaking up. But who will do the shaking? The paucity of quality challengers taking on incumbents in next Tuesday's primary voting for safely Democratic Senate and Assembly seats is a disappointment. Some of the least worthy incumbents face no challenge.
Here are our endorsements in several of the livelier contests in New York City districts where a primary victory virtually guarantees election. 
 SENATE -- 27th District, Manhattan: The retirement of Manfred Ohrenstein, the Senate minority leader, has produced a three-way race. The most promising candidate is Catherine Abate, a respected Commissioner of Correction during the Dinkins administration. Ms. Abate has knowledge of criminal justice issues, and the resourcefulness to get things done.
Her opponents, Charles Dworkis, a former district assistant for Mr. Ohrenstein, and Anne Compoccia, president of Community Board 1, know the district and generally share Ms. Abate's progressive views. But they cannot match her experience.
ASSEMBLY -- 33d District, Queens: Barbara Clark, an eight-year Assembly veteran, has been most active on education and child care issues. Though she sometimes needlessly alienates her would-be allies, she has generally been an effective advocate for her constituents. Neither of her opponents, Harvey Elwood, a school counselor, or Stephen Jackson, a promising political newcomer, has made the case for unseating her.
37th District, Queens-Brooklyn: In her decade in the Assembly, Catherine Nolan has emphasized family and transportation issues, fighting for increased subsidies for mass transit. Her challenger, Pamela Fisher, the director of a senior citizens' center, seems capable, but she has not made a compelling case for dumping a reasonably effective incumbent.
47th District, Brooklyn: The challenger, Joseph Cardieri, a former District Attorney now in private legal practice, insists that the 22-year incumbent, Frank Barbaro, is out of step with the times and the district. But Mr. Barbaro has used his seniority to push issues of concern to his constituents. He deserves re-election.
51st District, Brooklyn: The incumbent, Javier Nieves, became vice chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus in his first term. But he can point to few other achievements and has alienated community leaders with his unpredictability. The challenger, Felix Ortiz, a former budget analyst for the city, has a firmer grasp of the issues and promises to be a more effective consensus builder. We favor Mr. Ortiz.
54th District, Brooklyn: Darryl Towns, another first-term incumbent, is off to a good start, actively promoting much-needed economic development efforts in his district. His opponents, F. Louis Caraballo, an attorney, and Anibal Ortiz, a former police officer, do not make a case for denying Mr. Towns a second term. We support Mr. Towns.
55th District, Brooklyn: In this race a lackluster 12-year incumbent, William Boyland, faces two challengers. Reginald Bowman, a community activist and school board member, is smart but can be divisive. Beatrice Jones, another community activist who runs a day-care center, is sincere but might not be effective in the rough-and-tumble world of Albany. Mr. Boyland gets our lukewarm endorsement.
68th District, Manhattan: After nearly 20 years in the Legislature, Angelo Del Toro's record should be more impressive. Although chairman of the Education Committee for four years, Mr. Del Toro only recently became energetic in pushing reforms on school custodians and teacher discipline. His opponent, Nelson Antonio Denis, is an attorney who speaks articulately about economic development and the need for expanding youth programs. While Mr. Denis is untested in office, he offers the possibility of much-needed change. We endorse him with hope.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: For a Baseball Case History, Look at Cleveland

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In the writings about the baseball strike and its economics, I've seen little about the huge benefits team owners and players get from the investment that cities make in ballparks, arenas, infrastructure such as streets and highways and continual service demands, including the police. The owners receive sweetheart deals to "rent" the stadiums, making huge profits from concessions and advertising, though the cities own and must maintain the facilities. 
 Cleveland has been called one of the unluckiest cities in the major leagues because of its expensive new stadium and a winning team that was an underdog choice and sentimental favorite to win the American League pennant and even the World Series this baseball year.
Sportswriters and commentators have glorified the new stadium, but tell little about the cost to fans and nonfans of Cuyahoga County, who are paying for the stadium-arena complex, known as Gateway. County taxpayers are picking up, by way of "sin" taxes, $275 million of the cost directly and are on the hook for millions more.
The complex's real cost, when interest and infrastructure are added, is some $750 million. County taxpayers are guarantors of $305 million over the $275 million in "sin" taxes.
Cleveland has lost 26,000 jobs since the vote that approved the stadium, when voters were promised 28,000 more jobs. And despite promises of $4.3 million in property tax revenue when the vote for the "sin" tax was promoted, the complex had its property taxes capped in perpetuity by law at what the property was worth when the area was dilapidated.
Taxpayer money has purchased a 900-seat restaurant in the stadium for the Cleveland Indians owner, where ordinary fans are not allowed on game day; and a second, $2.3 million luxury restaurant for the Cleveland Cavaliers owners. Gateway promoters even threw in a separate, $7 million, 57,500-square-foot office building, including $900,000 in furnishings, for the Indians' administrative of
fices, although the lease called for team offices within the stadium.
Ohio chipped in some $45 million in gifts and grants, while other governmental agencies have expended more than $15 million in addition for infrastructure needs. When I asked Gateway's executive director, Tom Chema, if he had reported these as gifts to the Internal Revenue Service, he said, "Absolutely not."
Isn't it time that gifts bestowed by cities fearful of losing sports teams are treated as gifts to owners so that the Internal Revenue Service and taxpayers can get at least a share?
 
ROLDO BARTIMOLE
Cleveland, Sept. 2, 1994
The writer publishes a newsletter on Cleveland politics.
